DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf
Ozal Tells Bush Iraqi Strength Exaggerated
DOC.TEXT: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey said Tuesday neighboring Iraq's military strength has been exaggerated and he doesn't expect Iraq to invade either Saudi Arabia or Turkey. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``lost that chance'' to attack his neighbors with the arrival of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, Ozal told a National Press Club luncheon. Recalling that it took Iraq's army eight years to gain the upper hand in its war against Iran, despite backing from the Soviet Union, France and most of the West, Ozal asked, ``how can you call that (Iraq) a strong army?'' James Dobbins, deputy undersecretary of state for European and Canadian affairs, said Ozal gave President Bush a similar unflattering assessment of Iraqi military prowess. Dobbins said Ozal stated that public perception of Saddam's army being one of the strongest in the world was ``simply an exaggerated concern, that you're not dealing with the kinds of crises the Western world has dealt with in the past ... I don't think he was saying it'll be a runover.'' At the National Press Club, Ozal said neither he nor Bush knew how long it would take for the economic embargo and other sanctions to force Saddam to retreat. His own view was ``maybe four-five months, maybe later, we'll see.'' Asked if he took seriously Saddam's threats to attack oilfields in Saudi Arabia, Turkey and other neighboring countries resisting Iraq, Ozal replied, ``I never thought he was going to attack because I thought he was going to take Kuwait and stop there.'' If Saddam had met no resistance he would stay in Kuwait, controlling the oil of both Iraq and Kuwait and ``probably have a tremendous effect on the rest of the Gulf. Ozal said. ``Why should he attack Saudi Arabia, why Turkey?'' he asked. Ozal dismissed as ``speculative'' a reporter's suggestion that Turkey wants to repossess oil-rich Mosul province from Iraq after the Gulf crisis. Although the Ottoman Empire considered it part of Turkey, the League of Nations gave Mosul to British-ruled Iraq after World War I ``and I think it's all over,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigate Revenge Motive For Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pee Taylor cq in 11th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl slain outside a housing project - the 16th child shot in New York City in two months - may have been killed in revenge rather than at random, police said Tuesday. Laykama Taylor, whose nickname was ``Sugar,'' spent her last days in fear of retaliation for a street fight, neighbors told police. ``They're going to shoot me. They're going to get me,'' Laykama had told a friend who was interviewed by detectives, said a police source told the Associated Press, speaking on condition of anonymity. The young girl was fatally shot in the back Sunday afternoon as she sat on a bench braiding a friend's hair outside a housing project in the city borough of Brooklyn. Another young girl was shot at the same project on Monday. In all, 16 children have been shot in New York City since July 22, police said. Laykama was the sixth to die. Police initially described Laykama's shooting as accidental, but the Daily News on Tuesday quoted police saying revenge was the motive. Detective Lt. Robert Ceccarini disputed that report Tuesday. Laykama had argued with another 12-year-old girl on Thursday, and older boys from both of the girls' families became involved in the fight, police said. ``We do know there was prior disputes involving her and a girlfriend, and they made up, and brothers got involved, pushing and shoving,'' Ceccarini said. ``But as far as that being a motive, we haven't uncovered that.'' The young men involved in the fight were questioned by police and remain suspects in the shooting, Ceccarini said. Laykama was shot from an upper floor or the roof of the project as she sat in a courtyard filled with playing children. Detectives were awaiting ballistics tests, but said they believed the killer used a 9mm handgun. ``That wasn't a stray, that bullet was meant for her,'' said the girl's aunt, Pee Taylor. As police investigated Laykama's shooting, a 13-year-old girl was shot in the head Monday night while sitting on a bench in the same housing project. She was hospitalized in stable condition. Earlier Sunday, a 15-year-old girl was shot in the leg as she stood with a group of friends in Brooklyn. A 12-year-old girl was shot Friday while playing in a Harlem playground.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-Six People Murdered At Ranch
DOC.TEXT: Men firing submachine guns massacred 26 laborers at a ranch in western Colombia on Tuesday, an official in a nearby town said. Twenty-four workers were rounded up, taken to a soccer field and shot as they huddled together, an official in the town of Candelaria said in a live broadcast interview with the radio chain RCN. The town government spokesman, Jorge Ramirez, said in the interview with the radio chain RCN that two peasants on a road near the ranch were shot to death by the killers as they fled in three vehicles. Witnesses said the killers wore uniforms like those of Colombia's anti-narcotics police, RCN said. Both leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads often disguise themselves in police uniforms. A war between two drug cartels in Colombia also has claimed more than 150 lives in the last two years. There have been more than a dozen such massacres in the last three years in Colombia. Investigations have shown that all were the work of right-wing death squads. The federal attorney general's office has said that the death squads are run by drug traffickers who own immense ranches. Leftist guerrillas frequently try to extort money from ranchers. The death squads kill people they suspect of being guerrillas or rebel sympathizers. The reported massacre was at a ranch just outside Candelaria, about 225 miles west of the capital of Bogota. The town is in the state of Valle. Policemen answering the telephone at the national police headquarters in Bogota on Tuesday night referred all questions about the reported massacre to the department's public affairs office. The office as closed Tuesday night when the Associated Press attempted to verify the report.

DOC.HEAD: Lab Tests Don't Link Suspects to Five Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Crime laboratory results given to police investigating five student slayings failed to link any of several suspects to the killings, a newspaper reported. It's uncertain whether the test results received last week actually cleared any suspects, or if they just failed to support existing suspicions, The Gainesville Sun said in its Wednesday editions. Police last week increased night patrols in the area where the college students were slain. The newspaper quoted unidentified law enforcement sources as saying the beefed-up patrols were ordered after an investigative task force received the results of tests, and after the apparent failure of intense searches of woods frequented by the Edward Lewis Humphrey. Humphrey, an 18-year-old University of Florida freshman, has been mentioned most often as a suspect, though police say they have eight suspects in the case. The tests didn't link any of the eight to the crimes, the newspaper said. Investigators have taken pubic hair and blood samples from Humphrey and Stephen Michael Bates, 30, the only other suspect whose name has been made public. Both are jailed on unrelated charges and neither has been charged in the Gainesville murders. Tests were under way on semen, blood and a single pubic hair found at one or more of the murder scenes and on a knife found in a milk jug at Humphrey's home in Indialantic. Humphrey's public defender, J.R. Russo, told the Sun he didn't know about any test results. Task force members refused to comment on lab tests or on what the findings might mean about Humphrey's viability as a suspect, the newspaper said. Associated Press attempts to reach task force members for comment on the report weren't immediately successful. The nude, mutilated bodies of Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26 in their apartment near the University of Florida campus. The next day, the decapitated body of 18-year-old Christa Hoyt was found in her apartment nearby. On Aug. 28, the bodies of Manuel Taboada and Tracy Paules, both 23, were found in an apartment they shared. All were students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College. Humphrey is being held on $1 million bond in the Brevard County Jail in Sharpes. He has been charged with the Aug. 30 beating of his 79-year-old grandmother. Police have searched the woods near his Gainesville apartment and have executed search warrants on his residences and car. Bates, 30, who is being held in Polk County, is charged with a burglary in which he woke a woman and her daughter and threatened them with a knife.

DOC.HEAD: Pillsbury Doughboy Celebrates 25 Years of Belly-Pokes, Giggles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
Eds: JoBe in 9th graf cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP1 sent Sept. 25.
DOC.TEXT: At age 25, the Pillsbury Doughboy is on a roll. A new series of television ads show the pudgy figure playing ``air'' guitar, wailing on a harmonica, rapping and zipping around on a skateboard. ``This is a guy having fun doing what he's doing,'' said Craig Evanich, vice president of marketing in Minneapolis-based Pillsbury Inc.'s prepared-dough division. But other than updating his song repertoire, the Doughboy, also known as Poppin' Fresh, hasn't changed much since he first popped out of a can of ready-to-bake dough in 1965. To celebrate the Doughboy's 25th birthday, the downtown Pillsbury Center atrium will be transformed Thursday into ``Doughland.'' Entertainer Steve Allen will toast the Doughboy's birthday. The Doughboy was created when an advertising executive fantasized about what would pop out of a tube of refrigerated dough. Ads show the white Doughboy as a kitchen helper. ``He's not an authority. He doesn't come in the kitchen and tell people what to do,'' Evanich said. For the last 16 years, the Doughboy's voice has been provided by JoBe Cerny, a Chicago-area actor. Cerny said he tries to infuse some of his own personality into Poppin' Fresh. ``He's warm, cute and just a likable guy. My job is to try and help keep him that way,'' Cerny said. Poppin' Fresh has become a part of pop culture. In 1972, Playthings magazine named him ``Toy of the Year'' after Pillsbury introduced a doll Doughboy, and in 1987, Advertising Age declared him America's most-loved character. The Doughboy's elfish personality is like that of the magical helpers of ancient myths, said Ellen Havre Weis, founder and executive director of the Museum of Modern Mythology in San Francisco. ``It's very symbolic of the home and hearth,'' Weis said. ``He's dough brought to life.'

DOC.HEAD: List of Average Teacher Salaries
With PM-School Statistics
Guatemalan Refugees Struggle To Preserve Dream of Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: From their shabby camp on this arid hillside, Guatemalan refugees can see the green hills of their homeland. For eight years their dream of returning has been nurtured like an ember. The dream has helped them survive the precarious life of the camps and memories of the terror that drove them here. But, year after year, the political violence of their homeland has eroded the dream. They've been here so long that the Mexican government has offered them permanent settlements. That puts the refugees in a painful dilemma - whether to choose relative security in a foreign land or the uncertainty and violence of their home. ``Everyone says they are going home someday,'' said Pablo Farias, a psychiatrist who works with refugees. ``But after a while, you realize it is sort of a speech. When you get past that, you start getting to the real sadness.'' The people of Las Cieneguitas are among the tens of thousands who fled in the early 1980s during Guatemala's ``scorched-earth'' campaign to wipe out a leftist insurgency and depopulate remote northern war zones. ``We didn't want to leave our homes,'' said 55-year-old Ramiro Velazquez de Arturo. ``But we didn't want to die.'' About 46,000 refugees ended up in U.N.-supervised camps near the border in Chiapas, Mexico's southernmost state. In 1984, they were offered permanent villages in two other states - Campeche and Quintana Roo. More than half refused, despite the prospect of jobs or land, of better housing and education. They chose to stay in miserable camps such as Las Cieneguitas, a collection of rickety shacks without water or electricity, where diseases such as typhoid are epidemic. ``Those who stayed in the camps are the ones who want to go home. They have been keeping alive the hope,'' said Sister Lucia Jimenez, a nun who has worked with the refugees for a decade. ``The whole meaning of who they are, of what has happened to them, is linked to being a refugee,'' Farias said. The 23,000 exiles in Chiapas - most ff them Indians - are now dispersed in 123 camps, some with only a handful of families. Las Cieneguitas, with 1,600 people, is one of the largest. The refugees survive on international aid and what little day labor they find. It isn't much. Chiapas is a poor state where Mexicans fight Mexicans for land. ``There is intense competition for the natural resources. We are piling up problems between the Mexican and refugee communities,'' warned Jorge Santistevan, regional representative of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. Mexican officials recently proposed creating a handful of villages with farmland and projects aimed at self-sufficiency within a few years. Permanent residence and citizenship for children born in Mexico would be part of the deal. ``It's a recognition that things aren't going to get better in Guatemala and that these people won't be going home,'' said Victor Osorio, spokesman for an umbrella group of 16 private refugee assistance groups in Mexico City. Although they resisted resettlement in 1984, the refugees in Chiapas are considering the proposal. ``It is interesting,'' said Ricardo Kurtz, a 26-year-old Kanjobal Indian who serves on a refugee negotiating commission. ``It would mean better health services and education.'' The commission on which Kurtz serves was elected in 1987 to hold repatriation talks with Guatemala's government. It is a symbol of the unity and political awareness the refugees found in exile. ``They are not the same people who left Guatemala,'' said Santistevan, the U.N. representative. ``They are far more sophisticated.'' The commission has drawn up a brief list of conditions for returning to Guatemala, including guarantees of safety and restoration of land. ``For a campesino, the land is like your mother,'' Velazquez de Arturo told a recent visitor here. The exiles, many of whom cannot read or write, keep close track of events back home. Most camps have at least one shortwave radio and broadcasts from Guatemala and the BBC are carefully monitored. The news is bad. There has been an upsurge in the kidnapping, torture and murder of peasant, student, labor and human rights activists. The army still occupies isolated areas, although the ``scorched-earth'' campaign has ended. Guatemala's weak civilian government has not been able to meet the refugees' demands or gain their trust. The exiles are also shocked by the campaign now under way to chose a successor to President Vinicio Cerezo, who took office in 1986 after decades of military rule. Efrain Rios Montt, a brigadier general who took power after a 1982 coup, is doing well in the polls despite a legal ruling that, as a former dictator, he cannot serve as president. ``It's incredible that he would run,'' said Velazquez de Arturo. ``It was in his times that most of the massacres took place.'' Velazquez de Arturo knows. His village suffered three army massacres before the inhabitants fled en masse in 1982. He says he cannot forget burying the mutilated bodies of friends and neighbors, the burned-out ruins of their homes. Almost everyone in the camps lives with such memories. ``We have peace here, if nothing else,'' he said. Over the years, only a few thousand refugees have gone back to Guatemala. Farias recalls one who committed suicide the night before he was to return. ``Whatever way it goes for these people - deciding to go back or deciding to assimilate - I think there is going to be a lot more suffering,'' he said. ``The balance they have struck is very fragile.''

DOC.HEAD: Isakson Facing Uphill Struggle in Quest for Governorship
DOC.TEXT: Johnny Isakson is attacking Georgia's ``old boy'' network in a bid to become the state's first Republican governor since Reconstruction, but he faces an uphill fight against Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. Isakson, the state House minority leader, has accused Miller and others of squandering tax dollars to build individual offices for state legislators while leaving some schoolchildren to attend class in trailers. Miller and his Democratic gubernatorial campaign branded Isakson's ad ``an exercise in rank hypocrisy.'' Isakson has two state offices and even voted for the budget that financed the legislative office construction, Miller's statement said. Miller has been lieutenant governor for 16 years, but Isakson isn't a newcomer to state government either. The prosperous Atlanta real estate executive has been a state legislator since 1976. Miller is a former Marine rifle range instructor who talks tough on drugs while promising a sales tax exemption for food. Isakson has a reputation as a solid, no-nonsense legislator, and his contacts in the business community are counted as a plus. But Isakson must overcome the momentum Miller built during his drive for the Democratic nomination and state voters' preference for Democrats in top state offices. ``Without question, it's still Zell's to lose,'' said Atlanta pollster Claibourne Darden. Isakson's media consultant, Robert Goodman, disagrees, saying the Democrat is vulnerable. Miller has been running as ``a media candidate trying to pose as the champion of change,'' said Goodman. ``But Zell Miller is part of the old boy network, as you will see as the campaign evolves.'' Miller has political ties to highway builders and other interests and until this year used a lakeside lot leased from a utility. Miller outnumbers Isakson 2-1 in staff and money. Political consultant James Carville heads the Democrat's campaign, stressing opposition research. ``It is hard for somebody to hit you when you have your fist in their face,'' Carville has been quoted as saying. President Bush plans to host a $1,500-per-couple fundraiser for Isakson, who had raised $2 million through July compared with $4.4 million for Miller. Miller swept away five Democratic primary challengers - including Atlanta's former mayor, Andrew Young - by promising to legalize state lotteries. Miller said his campaign emerged from the primary in good shape and ``is as strong as garlic in a milkshake.'' Isakson had little trouble dispatching three rivals to win the GOP nomination, then took a back seat while Miller and Young fought a runoff battle. Miller usually has allowed his aides to answer Isakson and has been adept at focusing attention on his favorite issues, especially his proposal for a state lottery. When the candidates appeared together at a forum before educators, Miller stole the headlines by proposing that parents be allowed to choose which public schools their children should attend. State spending is a key issue for Isakson, who for years as House Republican leader criticized Georgia's spending process as lacking discipline and priorities. Often, the dissent fell on deaf ears because the Republican minority had little legislative impact on state government, and because of Isakson's penchant of attacking with a barrage of statistics. This year, Democrats have served the issue to him on a platter. Just a year after passing the biggest tax increase in state history - a one-cent sales tax increase to finance prisons, schools and health needs - the state must cut spending by $332 million because of an economic slowdown. Isakson still employs some of his old techniques of responding to the issue with detail, recently releasing a 13-page budget policy statement. But he also has gotten media savvy in the age of the 30-second sound bite. ``It's up to Johnny to use the old George Patton technique - attack, attack, attack,'' said Darden. ``If Johnny doesn't, he's gone ... He has to attack and show Zell is not the one to vote for and - by default - Johnny is.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush dipped into Sidney Sheldon and Scott Turow over the summer, took a fancy to television's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' but was baffled by Bart Simpson and his acid-tongued cartoon family. ``It was the dumbest thing I have ever seen, but it's a family thing, and I guess it's clean,'' she said in an interview in the Sept. 23 issue of People magazine. During her summer vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine, the first lady said she found time to work out daily and catch up on her reading, which included Sheldon's ``Memories of Midnight'' and Turow's ``Burden of Proof.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Viveca Lindfors, who won an Emmy last week for her portrayal of an aging dance teacher on the ABC series ``Life Goes On,' says good roles for older women are rare because most movies are made by men. Male directors and producers don't want to cast older actresses, said the 69-year-old Miss Lindfors. ``Why is it there are so many interesting parts for men, 60, 65, 70?'' she said in an interview Monday. ``Male actors keep working, and they get better and better and more and more interesting. And why don't they allow women the same thing? We get better, too, and we get more interesting.'' Despite her complaints, Miss Lindfors has kept busy over the years. In the film ``Misplaced,'' which opened Friday, she plays a Polish immigrant. Other recent credits include ``The Exorcist III'' and ``Luba.'' --- INDIANAPOLIS (AP) - Arnold Schwarzenegger went to the aid of an injured motorcycle patrolman who was struck by a car. The brawny actor was in town to stress the importance of physical fitness in his role as chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. Officer Ronald G. Knight, 36, was preparing to direct traffic for Schwarzenegger when his motorcycle collided Monday with a car driven by an elderly woman, police said. ``He comforted the officer and ensured that the proper medical assistance reached him,'' said sheriff's Capt. Steven A. Davis. The officer suffered cuts and bruises, authorities said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Fashion model Lesly Brown, the wife of ``Wheel of Fortune'' host Pat Sajak, has given birth to a boy. Patrick Michael James Sajak weighed 7 pounds at birth Saturday at an undisclosed Los Angeles-area hospital, Sajak spokesman Bob Burton said Monday. It was the couple's first child. Sajak, 43, and Miss Brown, 25, were married in January. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Gilbert Cates, who produced the 1990 Oscar telecast and directed such films as ``I Never Sang for My Father,'' has been named dean of the theater, film and TV school at the University of California at Los Angeles. The UCLA school has about 100 faculty members and more than 900 students. The two-time president of the Directors Guild of America has also produced or directed ``One Summer Love,'' ``The Promise,'' ``The Last Married Couple in America,'' ``Oh, God! Book II'' and ``Summer Wishes, Winter Dreams.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Luther Campbell of the rap group 2 Live Crew has agreed to stop using the name Luke Skyywalker and pay a undisclosed amount to settle a $300 million lawsuit filed by George Lucas' film company. The lawsuit, filed in March, said Campbell's use of the name violated the copyright on the ``Star Wars'' movie character Luke Skywalker. Campbell has already changed his record company's name from Skyywalker Records to Luke Records. Lucasfilm attorney Charles Shephard announced the agreement Monday. The ``Star Wars'' character is a clean-cut space warrior; the rap group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' has been declared obscene by a Florida judge, and members of the group have been arrested on obscenity charges. Campbell attorney Howard Frumes said the agreement was made in order to focus on the Florida case, ``where the issues are more important.''

DOC.HEAD: Trinidad Still Feeling Aftershocks of Six-Day Hostage Siege
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) - ``Sorry for inconvenience caused by the criminal acts of frenzied looters,'' reads the sign in the window of the closed Hometown Pharmacy. ``We'll be back as soon as possible.'' The suburban drug store was among scores of businesses plundered after Moslem militants stormed Parliament and the government-run TV station on July 27 and took the prime minister and more than 50 others hostage. Nearly two months later, Trinidadians are still feeling aftershocks of the six-day siege and accompanying looting that left 24 people dead and 500 wounded on this tiny nation of 1.2 million inhabitants off the coast of Venezuela. The fighting delvered a shock to the ailing Trinidadian economy, causing an estimated $60 million damage to the devastated main shopping district of Port-of-Spain. Tourism, not surprisingly, was also hurt. But there is a touch of irony in the fact that only hours after rebel Yasin Abu Bakr and his followers surrendered Aug. 1, Iraq invaded Kuwait, sending oil prices skyrocketing. Trinidad produces just under 1 percent of the world's oil. The worst long-term damage may be to the nation's sense of itself as a land of British-style democracy, multiracial harmony, oil wealth, cricket and calypso. For Harmony Pharmacy owner Jeffrey Marchack, who lost his entire inventory of $100,000 worth of drugs and merchandise, the episode has meant a decision to install an iron grille in the front window and a cashier's cage. Such security measures didn't seem necessary before, he said nostalgically, because ``we were always known to be happy-go-lucky, peace-loving people.'' ``The myth of exceptionalism has been blown apart,'' said Selwyn Ryan, a sociologist and political pollster at the University of the West Indies. ``The myth that we're a nonviolent society is just that - a myth.'' Industry Minister Bhoe Tewarie said Bakr and his Jamaat al-Muslimeen (Society of Moslems) were a ``group of extremists'' with no popular support. ``And I think Trinidad and Tobago proved to the world that it is a very stable democracy that was threatened but never shaken by the events of July 27.'' But fearing that supporters of Bakr and 113 other jailed rebels might be plotting another attack, the government has extended a state of emergency until mid-November. The proclamation gives security forces unrestricted rights of search and arrest. By day, the capital of Port-of-Spain once again teems with shoppers, street vendors and clogged traffic. Residents are growing tired of being restricted to their homes at night under a 9 p.m.-to-5 a.m. curfew. ``We cannot expect that their sense of humor, which as been bearing up quite nicely until now, can be maintained for undefined periods,'' the Trinidad Guardian said in an editorial urging an end to the curfew. Police, usually armed only with billy clubs in this former British colony, now patrol with automatic rifles. Soldiers wearing berets and camouflage jungle fatigues guard the bullet-scarred Parliament building and television station. The capital's major hotels are open, but with mostly empty rooms. Bulldozers and dump trucks remove tons of rubble from the main shopping district, where fires destroyed almost every building in a two-square-block area. The government is offering business loans and planning to redesign the district, which had become badly rundown. But rebuilding could take months, if not years. Industry Minister Tewarie insists the coup attempt would not have any lasting affect the economy. Tourism was hurt in the short term, he said, but the industry accounts for a tiny proportion of the nation's wealth. Despite the boom in oil prices, Tewarie said, the government has no plans to significantly increase production because it is wary of increasing its dependence on oil income. Trinidad has been gripped by recession since oil prices collapsed in 1983. Bakr, 48, a former policeman who converted to Islam and drew followers mainly among poor urban blacks, blamed Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson for the widespread poverty that resulted. Robinson, 64, was shot in the left leg after the takeover of Parliament. He has returned to work and now walks with a cane. The prime minister, who had introduced wage freezes, spending cuts and layoffs to revitalize the economy, had become highly unpopular before the coup attempt. He remains in danger of losing the next election, due next year. Bakr and his men face a string of charges, including murder and treason, which carry the death penalty. A preliminary hearing was to begin today in a converted gym. The FBI has charged an American Moslem, Louis Haneef of Pompano Beach, Fla., with supplying assault rifles, ammunition and other equipment to the coup leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists See Signs That Predicted Jolt May Occur Within Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic sent Sept. 24.
DOC.TEXT: Five years and $15 million ago, the federal government issued its only official earthquake prediction: The central California town of Parkfield would be severely shaken by 1993. Recent rumblings suggest the forecast soon may come true. ``They definitely elevate my belief that the earthquake is likely to happen in the next few months,'' said Evelyn Roeloffs, scientist in charge of the U.S. Geological Survey's Parkfield earthquake prediction experiment. After a three-year lull, seismic activity increased during the summer and particularly this month near tiny Parkfield. The town is halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco in grassy, oak-dotted ranchland of the Cholame Valley, which straddles the mighty San Andreas Fault. It was in the valley that actor James Dean died in a 1955 car crash. Moderate to strong quakes measuring 5.5 to 6.3 on the Richter scale have ruptured a 20-mile-long section of the fault near Parkfield roughly every 22 years since 1857. The most recent was in 1966. The quakes caused little damage in the valley, where about 200 people now live. The temblors' regularity prompted a 1985 Geological Survey prediction that another magnitude-6 quake was 95 percent likely during a 10-year period centered around January 1988, which meant by no later than January 1993. The Parkfield prediction is the only one ever issued by the federal government and ndorsed by California and federal scientific panels. The Geological Survey has spent $15 million installing scores of seismometers and other sensors and instruments near Parkfield, making it ``the most heavily instrumented piece of fault in the world,'' survey spokeswoman Pat Jorgenson said. Researchers hope the sensors will help them recognize changes in the Earth in the months, days, hours and minutes before the predicted magnitude-6 jolt, allowing them to issue a short-term public warning. ``I'm not hoping to rain death and destruction on Parkfield, but I'm hoping we can have the event we set up all this instrumentation to catch,'' Roeloffs said by phone from Menlo Park. The predicted quake is not expected to cause significant damage, said Richard Andrews, chief deputy director of California's Office of Emergency Services. He said it could shake things off shelves and damage chimneys in Parkfield and surrounding towns such as Paso Robles, Avenal, Coalinga and Atascadero. The streams of scientists visiting Parkfield spurred rancher Jack Varian's family to open the town's only cafe and start building a four-room motel. A sign outside the restaurant says: ``Parkfield Cafe, Parkfield, Calif. Earthquake Capital of the World. Be Here When it Happens.'' Varian's 27-year-old son, John, is excited about the impending quake, but ``I just want it to wait until March until the motel's open.'' ``I'll be darned if I'm going to hope for an earthquake,'' said Parkfield School teacher Duane Hamann, who works part-time making measurements for scientists. ``Things are going to fly all over the place.'' To help people protect themselves, the Geological Survey and state officials established a warning system in which alerts are triggered by various combinations of small quakes and other signs. The highest alert, known as ``level-A,'' will spur officials to issue a public warning that the predicted quake is at least 37 percent likely within three days. Since 1986, there have been no level-A or B alerts, 22 level-C alerts and 53 level-D alerts, Roeloffs said. The latest level-C alert - a warning that the quake is between 3 and 11 percent likely within three days - was issued Sept. 9. Roeloffs said the alert was triggered by a magnitude-3.3 quake north of Parkfield on Sept. 9 and an unusual rise in well water levels. Another 3.3 quake rattled the area Sept. 10. The small quakes were followed by numerous aftershocks, and by magnitude-2.2 quakes Sept. 14 and 15. There also was a steady increase in magnitude-3 quakes all summer farther northwest of Parkfield - a pattern Roeloffs called ``similar to the seismicity in the six months before the 1966 earthquake.'' Geological Survey scientists have said there is a 2 percent to 10 percent chance the Parkfield quake could grow into or trigger a major, magnitude-7 jolt. If that happened, Parkfield and surrounding towns might experience considerable damage, especially to unreinforced brick buildings, according state officials. Slight damage might occur as far away as San Luis Obispo, Hollister, Bakersfield and Fresno. In 1857, a moderate Parkfield quake was followed within hours by an earthquake exceeding magnitude 8 that ruptured a 200-mile stretch of the San Andreas from south of Parkfield to the Los Angeles area. Recent studies, however, show that is extremely unlikely to happen after the next Parkfield quake. Other studies raise doubts about the Parkfield prediction. Previous Parkfield quakes around magnitude-6 happened in 1857, 1881, 1901, 1922, but then the pattern was broken with one in 1934, 10 years early. However, the next magnitude-6 quake waited until 1966, seeming to restore the original pattern. Geological Survey geophysicist Jim Savage argues that uncertainty created by the timing of the 1934 quake means the likelihood the Parkfield quake will happen by 1993 is only 60 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Met Opera Opens, Mrs. Bush Attends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY50 sent Sept. 24.
DOC.TEXT: The Metropolitan Opera opened its season with Puccini's much-loved, melodic ``La Boheme,'' starring Mirella Freni and Placido Domingo. Both were magnificent in the leading roles. With Mrs. George Bush, Prince Rainier and his son Prince Albert in the State Box, the evening began with the audience standing for an orchestral piece unfamiliar to most of them, the national anthem of Monaco, where Rainier is head of state. That was followed by ``The Star Spangled Banner.'' Usually Met artistic director James Levine conducts on opening night, but Monday night Christian Badea held the baton. He took the important duets and arias of the fourth act slower than usual. That made them especially gentle and poignant. The slower tempo began with Rodolfo (Domingo) ad Marcello (Brian Schnexnayder) lamenting the loss of their girlfriends. It continued with Colline (Julien Robbins) saying goodbye to the overcoat he's about to sell, and the final duet of Rodolfo and Mimi (Miss Freni). Miss Freni, who made her Met debut as Mimi in the first week of the 1965-66 season, is amazing. She sounded incredibly young at the beginning of the opera and, with her small waist, looked young. Unlike some singers who only sound good singing loud, her voice is even more lovely when she's singing quietly and sweetly, as she did all through Act 4, on Mimi's deathbed. Domingo was fine, though a couple of times he slipped from his best voice. He was charming, blowing out his candle so that he and Mimi are together in the dark, then shrugging, as seen in the follow spotlight. He and Miss Freni conveyed that there was a chemistry between them. Near the end of Act 1, when they're supposed to kiss, a big smack was heard. Baritone Richard Cowan, a native of Euclid, Ohio, graduate of Indiana University and winner of several vocal prizes, made a sterling Met debut as Schaunard, the fourth bohemian roommate in a Paris garret. Cowan sang Schaunard in a recent ``La Boheme'' film and will sing the title role of ``Don Giovanni'' at the Met in October. All the bohemians sounded young and strong. Schnexnayder was especially impressive. Barbara Daniels sang Musetta well but performed the part as though doing a Zsa Zsa Gabor imitation. Franco Zeffirelli's production, from 1981, has held up well. The attic room is shown to be tiny by having the roof of the building it's above much bigger and sloping toward the audience. It looks as though the Met still has 218 people walking around Paris' Latin Quarter at the beginning of Act 2. Mrs. Bush's gown was red, with long sleeves and a bodice shot with gold threads. With it, she wore a triple strand of pearls. The formally dressed audience chose, in general, to be attractively and conservatively dressed this year. A champagne supper on the Grand Tier of the Met followed for 650 guests who paid $1,250 each. Performance tickets ranged from $35 to $500.

DOC.HEAD: White House Threatens Veto of Gramm-Rudman Cut Delay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for grafs 5-6 pvs, Administration officials, with meeting over for evening, Sununu comment; SUBS 1 graf for 9th graf pvs, Darman said, to restore first reference to Darman; should stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will veto any attempt by Congress to postpone the $85 billion in Gramm-Rudman spending cuts that loom next week unless a budget deal is reached, White House officials said Monday. The compromise remained elusive because of a dispute over whether to slash the capital gains tax rate. The Bush administration insisted it would not agree to higher income tax rates on the wealthy, a demand Democrats were making in exchange for the capital gains tax reduction. As the standoff continued, the specter of massive cuts in federal spending grew nearer and the administration promised to let them take effect without a budget deal. ``We're T-minus seven,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, referring to the number of days before the slashes occur. ``We're sticking with it and still talking.'' Administration officials and congressional leaders held an evening meeting that lasted until nearly 12:30 a.m. Tuesday, trying to work out a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction package. With the new fiscal year beginning next Monday, the two sides remain locked in a budget stalemate that has persisted all year. ``We're making progress in cutting spending, but we're not there yet,'' White House chief of staff John Sununu said after the session. Negotiators continued to reveal little about the details of their closed-door discussions. The principal hangup remained a dispute over a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, which Bush wants and Democrats oppose. Currently, capital gains - gains from the sale of assets, such as corporate stock or houses - are taxed just like ordinary income. White House budget chief Richard Darman said the administration would continue to oppose higher income tax rates on the wealthy. ``We're not shifting our position on anything,'' he said. ``Why should we?'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., had said Sunday that Republicans were looking for a tax boost on the wealthy that Democrats would accept in exchange for a capital gains tax reduction. It was unclear whether he meant to include higher tax rates on the rich, a position GOP bargainers have fought all year. Frustration with the stalled budget talks caused debate on every bill brought to the House floor Monday to deteriorate into an argument over which party was to blame for the budget impasse. A day intended for action on 37 non-controversial bills became one of parliamentary delays by Republicans, angry because a vote on the budget had not been scheduled on this week's calendar. Democrats said a vote couldn't be scheduled on a bill that didn't exist. ``This place is in total disarray,'' said Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y. Oct. 1 is the day the Gramm-Rudman law will automatically impose $85 billion in cuts in the $1.2 trillion federal budget, an amount that would hobble many federal programs. It's also the day the government will run out of money because the budget gridlock has blocked all spending bills. Democratic congressional leaders planned to begin moving legislation through the House on Tuesday, temporarily providing financing to the government. House Speaker Thmas S. Foley, D-Wash., said if a budget compromise is reached, the legislation would also delay the Gramm-Rudman spending reductions. The postponement is expected to last through Oct. 20 to give lawmakers a chance to enact the budget into law. But Foley cautioned that without a budget pact, the House might not try to delay the Gramm-Rudman slashes. ``If there is no agreement, we will have a different condition,'' Foley told reporters. ``We don't have any policy at the moment that isn't directed toward an agreement.'' Even if the House measure failed to delay the Gramm-Rudman cuts, the Senate could add the provision later in the week. By sending Bush a measure temporarily rolling back the automatic cuts, Democrats would put the president in the position of having to decide whether to hold off on the cuts slashes - and perhaps taking the blame for them. White House officials reasoned that by refusing to put off the Gramm-Rudman reductions, they could pressure negotiators to work out a deal. ``If you get into the business of suspending and suspending and suspending ... we'll be at it for 114 years,'' said Darman, one of the bargainers.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Reports Good News in the Beanfields
DOC.TEXT: Overall, it's been a pretty good year for dry, edible beans, says the Agriculture Department. Department bean counters always refer to them as dry and edible to distinguish the pintos, navies and small reds from green beans, which aren't dry, and castor beans, which aren't edible. As of Sept. 1, total dry, edible bean production is expected to be 31.4 million hundredweight, the most since the record 1981 harvest of 32.8 million hundredweight. Heat and drought conditions took a toll during the summer in the northern Great Plains, or 1990 output would probably have exceeded the old peak. Even so, prospects for this year's bean harvest are much improved from 1989's harvest of 24.3 million hundredweight and the drought-riddled 1988 production of 19.3 million. Catherine R. Greene of the department's Economic Research Service said recent industry reports show ``excellent growth conditions'' for much of the 1990 bean crop. Exceptions, she said, include drought areas of the northern plains and California. Greene said Monday in a telephone interview that the aggregate prices of dry beans in the 1990-91 marketing year are expected to decline because of the larger harvest and a buildup in bean inventories. In 1989-90, the season average price at the farm was about $28 per hundredweight, or 28 cents per pound. During the summer, farm prices rose to record levels, averaging nearly $33 per hundredweight. Greene did not make any new price predictions but noted that her agency's most recent projection showed that bean prices might tumble to less than $20 per hundredweight over the 1990-91 season. ``Dry beans have been up for a long time,'' she said. According to USDA analysts, the harvested acreage jumped 26 percent from last year to about 2.1 million acres, with North Dakota accounting for about half of the increase. North Dakota production, which is mostly pinto and navy beans, was indicated in September at 5.4 million hundredweight, compared with 2.46 million in 1989 and 2.7 million in 1988. Another big dry bean producer is Michigan, with production estimated at 5.25 million hundredweight, compared with 4.5 million last year and 2.14 million in 1988. Nebraska, ranked third, is expected to produce nearly 4.66 million hundredweight, up from less than 3.5 million in 1989 and 3.76 million in 1988. Other commercial dry bean producers include California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Minnesota, Montana, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Texas, Utah, Washington and Wyoming. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An experimental oral vaccine to control coccidiosis, a parasitic disease of chickens, is being tested by the Agriculture Department. So far, says microbiologist Mark C. Jenkins of the department Agricultural Research Service, the vaccine appears ``virtually 100 percent effective'' in protecting young chickens against the disease. Jenkins, who heads the research team at the agency's protozoan diseases laboratory in Beltsville, Md., said none of the 200 chickens orally vaccinated became ill when exposed to the coccidial parasite. The vaccine consists mainly of a preparation made from an ineffective stage of the parasite that has been bombarded with x-rays, making the organism sterile so it can't reproduce. But it is still alive and can penetrate a chicken's intestines. ``Our theory is that when the chickens are fed the sterilized coccidial parasite, they react by producing antibodies and immune cells,'' Jenkins said in a report released Monday. ``This protects them from infection when exposed to disease-causing parasites.'' Coccidiosis costs U.S. poultry farmers more than $300 million a year in lost weight gain and medication, he said. Most infected birds usually look healthy, but the parasite prevents them from absorbing nutrients from the gut, causing ``a sort of slow starvation.'' Scientists said the vaccine, although promising, is still a few years from practical use. It will require at least another year of laboratory testing and then extensive field studies to make sure it is effective in large commercial flocks. Most poultry farmers now control coccidiosis by medicating the feed. But the parasites often develop resistance to the drugs, and new medications have to be developed. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - U.S. farm exports are expected to drop next year as foreign production competes with sales of grain and other products, the Agriculture Department reports. The department's Economic Research Service said Monday that a drop in corn exports in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 will help lead the overall decline. ``U.S. corn exports are expected to fall 7 million tons (more than 275 million bushels) as overseas customers replace U.S. corn with competitors' feed wheat,'' the report said. ``Wheat prices are expected to average lower in 1990-91 due to larger crops. But higher soybean prices will help offset some of this decline.'' Overall farm exports in the current year are estimated at about 148.5 million metric tons worth about $40 billion, both up slightly from 1988-89. The report did not include any figures to show U.S. export values and volume in 1990-91. The department's first official export estimates for next year will be issued in late November.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanians Ask Why Kingdom Singled Out For Condemnation
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Jordan is wounded and its leaders are confused and unable to understand what they see as an acrimonious campaign against a tiny kingdom struggling to survive in peace. ``We feel that since the Americans and the Europeans and the allies of the United States for that matter cannot punish Iraq, what they are trying to do is punish Jordan. We don't know the reason behind it,'' said Deputy Foreign Minister Mutasem Bilbeisi. Western diplomats contend privately that Jordan has not done enough to condemn Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But they agree the punishment does not fit the crime. Jordan's already faltering economy has been driven to its knees by the Persian Gulf crisis. Perhaps Jordan was slow to adhere to the embargo, but the world has been slower still with the aid Jordan needs to survive, the country's leaders say. ``You cannot deny the fact that we could have made billions if we wanted to out of this crisis,'' Bilbeisi said in an interview. Jordan would only have to violate the sanctions and continue to deal with Iraq, a country that accounted for about 40 percent of Jordan's trade, he said. ``I don't like to insinuate anything but there were monies thatwwere easy to obtain under the table. Jordan could have done it, we could have solved all our economic problems if we had taken a position contrary to our position.'' ``But at what expense?'' Bilbeisi asked. ``I don't think the government is going to defy the whole world and break the sanctions.'' Bilbeisi and other Jordanian officials, speaking on condition they not be identified, try to portray Jordan as a voice of reason in a world gone mad. Like the United States, Jordan has called for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and for a restoration of the emir. But it also has tried to prevent the deployment of foreign troops in a region with bitter memories of colonalism and foreign domination. King Hussein has tried to slow the steady march toward war by seeking to negotiate an Arab solution to the crisis. But Western diplomats contend his efforts are unrealistic, that none of the proposals meet even the minimum requirements of the U.N. Security Council resolutions seeking to force Iraq to relinquish Kuwait. ``The main principles inherent in any of these (peace) proposals would be the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and the return of a legitimate government to Kuwait,'' said Bilbeisi. ``But whether this meets with the resolutions of the Security Council or not is beside the point because we think some of the resolutions of the Security Council are detrimental to any peace effort because they are so tight,'' said Bilbeisi. He said the word ``unconditional'' in U.N. resolutions makes peace efforts more difficult. Iraq and Kuwait had a border dispute even before the invasion. Jordan is recommending that an Iraqi withdrawal to the line of dispute, rather than the pre-attack border, would be a good starting point for negotiations. ``Let's be pragmatic. He (Saddam Hussein) went to war to protect his interests in those oil fields,'' said Bilbeisi. ``If we convince the man to withdraw to that point of dispute and then if we can manage or can arrange negotiations between Kuwaitis and Iraqis and if the Kuwaitis agree to a new boundary between them then I don't think any country will object to this,'' he said. But diplomats, echoing the comments of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, argue that King Hussein ``failed the first test of principles'' by not publicly condemning Iraq. The king has said only that he opposes the acquisition of territory by force. ``Our position is that we cannot condemn and mediate at the same time,'' said Bilbeisi. Popular support for Iraq is overwhelming in Jordan. Bilbeisi and others argue that the king could not possibly take a harder stance or send troops to join a multinational force in Saudi Arabia. Jordanian officials argue it is easy for a Pacific Ocean state or one in middle Europe to comply fully with the U.N. sanctions on trade with Iraq. But they say it is something else for Jordan, which has no firm guarantees of foreign aid and stands to lose $2 billion this year alone because of the crisis. No one objected to Jordan's relations with Iraq when its neighbor was fighting Iran and seen as a deterrent to the spread of Islamic fundamentalism in the region, the officials say. Bilbeisi also claimed that some in other countries were doing more to help Iraq but not being subjected to the same condemnation. He said: ``Most of the smuggling in the world now is taking place between Turkey and Iraq, between Iran and Iraq and you'll be surprised that the best business of smuggling now going on is between Syria and Iraq,'' the Arab world's bitterest rivals.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes 70,000-Person Cut in Military Personnel
DOC.TEXT: A House panel approved a cut of 77,000 people from the armed forces, conceding that a more significant reduction would be unwise while President Bush continues to send troops to the Persian Gulf. Meeting behind closed doors Monday, the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense adopted the troop cut as part of its defense spending plan for fiscal 1991, said a panel member who requested anonymity. The lawmaker did not specify how many people each service would lose. Nearly 2.1 million people are on active duty. The subcommittee is expected to finish work this week on its $296 billion version of the military appropriations bill for the fiscal year beginning next Monday. The panel's action came as the United States continues to send forces to the gulf region to stop Iraqi aggression against its neighbors. President Bush has called more than 21,000 reservists to active duty in the crisis. The subcommittee's troop reduction is far less than the 129,500 cut set by the House last week when it approved a $283 billion defense authorization bill. The authorization bill sets spending ceilings; actual funds must be provided in separate appropriations bills. The lawmaker said a higher troop cut was considered inappropriate in light of the circumstances in the gulf region. The reduction of 129,500 in the authorization bill includes 68,500 from the Army, 36,500 from the Air Force, 20,000 from the Navy and 4,500 from the Marine Corps. During debate on the authorization bill, a Republican effort to cap the troop cut at about 100,000 while eliminating additional funds for the F-A-18 aircraft failed. President Bush, in proposing a $307 billion defense authorization budget and $303 billion in defense appropriations for the coming fiscal year, sought a troop cut of 38,000. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he would recommend that Bush veto the authorization bill because of the hefty reduction in troops and the major cuts in strategic weapons, including the B-2 stealth bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative. The Senate, which approved a $289 billion defense appropriations bill last month, adopted a 100,000 cut in U.S. troop strength in fiscal 1991, including 50,000 in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Losses Seen Leveling Off at S&Ls, But Another Slide Feared
DOC.TEXT: Losses seem to have leveled out at the nation's privately run savings institutions, but analysts say the spread of weak real estate markets could produce another slide. The 2,437 S&Ls outside government control lost $196 million in the April-June period, the Office of Thrift Supervision said Monday. That was a modest improvement over the $219 million loss in the first three months of the year. It also was a dramatic gain over the $720 million loss in the last three months of 1989 but a substantial deterioration from the $308 million profit earned by the same institutions a year earlier. ``It's very difficult to predict that the trend of reduced losses in the industry will continue or that the industry as a whole will become profitable this year,'' thrift office Director Timothy Ryan said. He noted a ``real disparity'' in thrift performance geographically. Thrifts in the Pacific Northwest and in the upper Midwest continue to be profitable, largely because these areas have so far escaped the real estate downturn experienced in the Southwest and, more recently, the Northeast. Private analysts, however, offered an unreservedly bleak assessment of the industry's prospects. ``It's fairly clear the real estate correction process is becoming national,'' said Richard C. Aspinwell, vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank and a member of a private academic group, the Shadow Financial Regulatory Committee. ``There's not a lot on the horizon to suggest we have turned the corner,'' said University of North Carolina professor Robert A. Eisenbeis, another member of the group. The second-quarter results did not include losses at the 247 failed but still-operating institutions under the control of the federal Resolution Trust Corp. They are to be reported separately later this week. They also did not include 15 institutions that had been rescued close to the end of the quarter by the RTC, which was created last year to manage the government's bailout. Also, the losses are being held down by government subsidy payments to 61 thrifts bailed out in 1988 by the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Excluding results from those institutions, private-sector S&Ls lost $315 million in the April-June period. While avoiding forecasting future industry performance, Ryan said the recent decline in losses shows that the program of seizing failed institutions is helping solvent thrifts by reining in competitors. ``The one thing we have seen is ... moving these institutions into the RTC tends to provide opportunities for the rest of the industry,'' he said. An analysis by the thrift office, which divides S&Ls among four groups based on their financial health, shows that 1,169 healthy institutions have earned consistent profits over the last 18 months: $646 million in the second quarter of 1990, $641 million in the first quarter and $582 million in the second quarter of 1989. However, in a worrisome sign, the performance of the next group - 674 weak institutions that were nevertheless expected to survive - deteriorated. Those institutions earned $31 million in the April-June period, compared with $195 million in the previous quarter and $296 million a year earlier. An additional 350 thrifts in danger of failing lost $153 million last quarter, compared with a $332 million loss in the first quarter and a $217 million loss a year earlier. And 244 S&Ls considered all but certain to fail lost $720 million last quarter, compared with $723 million in the first quarter and $353 million a year ago. Included among the 244 were 13 S&Ls that had been bailed out by the thrift office's predecessor, the bank board.

DOC.HEAD: Notes from the Undercount: Census Coordinators Compare Woes
DOC.TEXT: The city of Chicago thinks the Census Bureau has overlooked more than 300,000 of its denizens. Charleston, S.C., contends the bureau miscounted the number of housing units on almost 40 percent of its blocks. Houston says its housing vacancy rate is about 10 percent - not the 14.5 percent claimed by the agency. These and other complaints were voiced Monday by a group of city census coordinators who met to map a strategy to force the federal government to correct what they say is a drastic undercount. Ed Kobilarcik, a Census Bureau spokesman, said more than 8,300 governments have responded to the preliminary census results so far. Of those, he said about 80 percent have challenged the government's count. ``The census people, as honestly as I can put it - they blew it,'' said Tom Kelly, coordinator from Highland Park, Mich. Kelly said that at first the Census Bureau thought Highland Park was a Detroit neighborhood, not an independent city. ``I knew we were in trouble when all the Highland Park census forms said Detroit,'' he added. ``We had to negotiate just to get on the map.'' Eleanor Tevnan, coordinator for Elizabeth, N.J., said the bureau's preliminary count showed a 2.3 percent population increase since 1980, making it the only major city in the Garden State to post a gain. ``We still believe we have an undercount, despite that,'' she said. The officials came from cities as small as Meridian, Miss., and as large as Los Angeles. But all 21 cities represented have filed challenges to the Census Bureau's preliminary population estimates. They are driven by the fact that the greater their population, the more federal aid they will receive. Population also determines how many representatives they will have in Congress. Kobilarcik defended his agency's work, saying, ``We don't feel that it's been a disaster. We think we've had a very successful census.'' The bureau plans to respond to the governments in November, he said. Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant has already told Congress there will be big changes in the initial numbers. ``The census count will increase in practically every jurisdiction throughout the country because of ongoing coverage improvement programs,'' she said. At Monday's meeting, each coordinator had a collection of complaints about census procedures in his or her city. Barbara Kaplan of Philadelphia told how the Census Bureau missed about 500 housing units in the four-block neighborhood of Rittenhouse Square, for example. Hulbert James, New York City's census coordinator, said the bureau cited a 54,000-pupil decrease in school enrollment as evidence of the city's shrinking population. That decrease was primarily due to students dropping out of high school, not people moving away, he said. James called on the group to form a national coalition for census correction to show a united front to the federal government. And Lance Simmens, who directed the meeting for the National Conference of Mayors, said mayors would be invited to join an ``attack team'' charged with publicizing these problems. The team will be led by New York Mayor David N. Dinkins and Meridian, Miss., Mayor Jimmy Kemp. Simmens also outlined three tracks cities will take to force the federal government to correct its figures. Cities will try to influence the administration directly, he said, noting that Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher has agreed to a meeting next week with the conference. The conference is also pursuing legislation and a federal lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Angolans May Get Food Aid
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials hope an international food relief effort can get under way in Angola within the next 30 to 60 days to prevent widespread starvation. ``The crisis is upon us and we must act now,'' said Andrew Natsios, head of the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. Angolan officials have committed themselves to a U.N. plan that would permit emergency food deliveries from third countries. The leftist government had been worried that the United States might use food deliveries to send weapons to the anti-communist UNITA rebels. Natsios was snubbed by Angolan officials two weeks ago during a visit to Luanda, the capital. They had a change of heart last week and agreed in a communique to allow ``the prompt and efficient delivery'' of food supplies to tens of thousands of Angolans who face starvation because of drought. On Monday, Natsios made public the joint Angola-U.S. communique he worked out with Gen. Antonio Dos Santos Ndalu. The talks were secret and Natsios declined to say where they were held. Angola agreed to allow food deliveries to the hungry in both government-and rebel-held territory. Angolan officials have said that up to 2 million people live in the drought-affected area. UNITA spokesmen have said the number of hungry Angolans could be as high as 750,000. The U.S. estimate is that as many as 250,000 Angolans are at ``immediate risk of starvation.'' Natsios told reporters Monday he saw the effects of the drought during a visit to Angola that began about two weeks ago. At one location, he saw children who had eaten only two or three meals in a week. At another, there were children who had only mice to eat in the preceding days, he said. ``The U.N. plan must be implemented immediately,'' Natsios said. He added that he is hopeful the international community will respond generously to Angola's plight. A U.S. official, insisting on anonymity, said the Angolan government may be showing flexibility on the aid issue in order to influence pending congressional deliberations about future aid to UNITA. The Angolan government strongly opposes such aid, which the United States has been providing to UNITA since 1986. The civil war has raged since 1975. The Namibian government agreed last week to allow food shipments to be sent to Angola through its territory. Another possibility is Zimbabwe, where there is a food surplus, Natsios said.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Says He Didn't File Returns
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic candidate for office in the nation's capital says he deliberately failed to file federal or local income taxes for several years, according to a published report today. Charles J. Moreland, who is seeking to become the District of Columbia's ``shadow'' representative in the House, told The Washington Post he hasn't filed federal income tax returns for at least five years and city returns for the past three years. The ``shadow'' House seat Moreland hopes to fill is actually an unpaid advocate to lobby Congress for statehood for the city, and Moreland says his non-filing was meant to draw attention to the statehood issue. Moreland, who is the second candidate for citywide office to acknowledge failure to file taxes, was quoted as saying he believes his actions ``put me in a better position to achieve the goal of statehood. We have to confront the system.'' Eleanor Holmes Norton, who became the Democratic nominee for the city's delegate to Congress, was plagued in the last week of her primary campaign by disclosures that she and her husband had not filed city income tax returns for seven years from 1982-1989. The couple subsequently paid the city more than $88,000 in back taxes, interest and penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Judiciary Committee's Swing Votes Announce Support for Souter
DOC.TEXT: All three swing votes on the Senate Judiciary Committee say they favor Judge David Souter's nomination to the Supreme Court. Sens. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., and Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., announced Monday they would vote for the 51-year-old New Hampshire jurist when the committee meets Thursday. Three years ago, Heflin and DeConcini, the committee's most conservative Democrats, and the committee's most moderate Republican, Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., all came out against President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert Bork, who went on to defeat. Now all three are supporting Souter. Specter announced his support last week. In voicing his approval on Monday, Heflin said he saw in Souter an ``endearing quality of being willing to listen, to be fair and impartial.'' He made clear Souter left a far different impression than that made by Bork, who was seen by many as too dogmatically conservative. ``Judge Souter will not bring a scorched-earth philosophy to the court, but he will bring a sense of historic perspective and a clearheaded approach to the analysis of legal issues,'' said Heflin, a chief justice in Alabama before joining the Senate. ``He has not chosen to turn back the clock on the great constitutional principles of our day,'' said DeConcini, turning around some of the rhetoric used against Bork. So far, seven of the committee's 14 members have endorsed Souter. Six of the eight Democrats and one of the six Republicans have not yet stated their positions. No committee member has announced opposition to Souter, and only one member of the entire Senate, Alan Cranston, D-Calif., has said he would vote against confirmation. Cranston explained in a speech to the Senate on Monday that he could not abide Souter's refusal to say whether he would vote to overturn Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. ``I cannot support a nominee who refuses to acknowledge that a woman's right to choose to terminate a pregnancy is a fundamental right,'' Cranston said Monday. ``To me, the right of privacy in matters relating to family life and procreation goes to the very essence of the liberty and freedom from government control that Americans deeply cherish,'' Cranston said. The large number of undecided Senate liberals appeared to be a reflection of divisions within the national liberal community. Over the weekend, the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, an influential coalition of rights groups, called for the Senate to reject Souter. ``We do not believe that David Souter has demonstrated that he has a commitment to constitutional guarantees of individual rights and liberties,'' the group said. It cited as ``astonishing'' Souter's statement during the committee's hearings that his home state of New Hampshire does not have racial problems. But in its statement, the group listed members of its coalition that specifically declined to be included in opposing Souter. Those included the American Civil Liberties Union, several Jewish groups, the League of Women Voters, People for the American Way and the U.S. Catholic Conference.

DOC.HEAD: Black Activists Protest Bush's Meeting with de Klerk
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Should stand; meeting scheduled in afternoon
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-South Africa
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk's official visit to Washington is stirring protests from anti-apartheid activists, but some black members of Congress are joining colleagues to meet with him today. ``Our view is that (de Klerk) has not earned a trip to the Oval Office,'' Randall Robinson, head of the TransAfrica group that has led U.S. protests against apartheid, said Monday. ``President Bush has made a large mistake and has offended freedom-loving people around the world and in the United States by becoming the first president since apartheid was codified in 1948 to invite into the Oval Office the head of a country that practices repression in an unprecedented way,'' Robinson said. Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, said the 24-member group canceled its plans to meet with de Klerk out of concern the session would be misinterpreted and could lend symbolic support to the apartheid regime. Dellums joined Robinson and other activists outside the White House gates to protest Bush's meeting with de Klerk on Monday. But Dellums said he would join congressional foreign affairs committee members in a large session with de Klerk today. And House Majority Whip Bill Gray, D-Pa., the highest-ranking black in Congress, planned to join House Speaker Thomas Foley and other congressional leaders in a smaller session with the South African leader. ``Many of us will raise questions that need to be raised in that forum,'' Dellums said. ``We decided we would do it within the context of the Congress as an institution,'' he said. ``To meet with the Congressional Black Caucus separate and apart bestows a level of credibility that at this point we weren't prepared to deal with.'' De Klerk had sought the meeting with Dellums' caucus, but the lawmaker canceled it over the weekend after Robinson attacked Bush's plan to meet with the South African president. The change of mind reflects the black community's difficulty in dealing with de Klerk's visit, said Milton Morris, director of research for the Joint Center on Political Studies, a black think tank. While de Klerk is a symbol of the racist apartheid system, Morris said, he has brought change and black leaders may be able to influence further change by meeting with him. He noted de Klerk released African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela from prison. ``I think it would have been a good opportunity to indicate some satisfction at the general direction of change in South Africa,'' Morris said. ``Change has obviously been dramatic, and has been in the right direction. ... One needs to take note of that. ``It is ironic that Mr. Mandela, whom we respect a great deal, is in almost daily negotiation with Mr. de Klerk, who has been more forthcoming than any other white South African, and here we are boycotting Mr. de Klerk,'' Morris said. ``...There are strong pressures for a united front on this. The fact they got off on separate directions simply underscores the difficulty of the situation.'' NAACP Executive Director Dr. Benjamin L. Hooks said he supported TransAfrica's protest of de Klerk's visit to the White House. He said that while de Klerk has taken positive steps toward establishment of a democratic society, the basic foundation of apartheid remains in place. ``Until this is dismantled, we believe a visit to the White House by South Africa's chief executive is totally inappropriate,'' Hooks said.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 11 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Pentagon Reports Drop in Soviet Military Spending, Arms Production
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military spending and arms production fell last year, and the Kremlin leadership is developing a military strategy with more emphasis on defending the homeland and less on ``external adventurism,'' the Pentagon said today. The Defense Department's annual report on the Soviet military, entitled ``Soviet Military Power 1990,'' described the Soviet Union as a nation so entangled in internal unrest that its military capabilities are hard to assess. ``Much that was once certain about the Soviet military is now open to debate,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney wrote in the publication's introductory essay. ``It is not clear how that debate will be resolved.'' Cheney said U.S. intelligence analysts believe Soviet military spending fell 4 percent to 5 percent last year compared with 1989, and that it cut back on some aput. The most pronounced cuts in arms production were in ground forces materiel, the report said. Tank production, for example, was cut in half, to about 1,700 tanks in 1989. Smaller but significant cuts occurred in artillery and multiple rocket launcher output. The Soviets produced strategic, or long-range, offensive missile systems in 1989 at about the same pace as the year before, the report said. Production of bombers, fighters and fighter-bombers declined by an unspecified amount, while production of surface warships and submarines rose to 21 from 18 the year before. Cheney, in his essay, cautioned that despite some signs of a less threatening Soviet military stance, the nation still has its nuclear missiles aimed at the United States. ``All evidence indicates that this fact will not change,'' Cheney wrote. ``Furthermore, the threat is no longer clear cut; the implications of change within the Soviet Union are not completely known.'' While the Pentagon report stressed that the Soviets still possess a formidable arsenal of nuclear weapons capable of destroying the United States, the publication was filled with passages expressing hope for lasting change. Included were pictures of Soviet intermediate-range nuclear missiles being destroyed in accordance with the 1987 INF treaty, and of Soviet M-4 Bison long-range bombers with their tail sections severed, making them unusable. The report said the Soviet economic crisis and a host of internal political problems ``are bringing the Soviet Union to the brink of economic breakdown and potential internal chaos.'' ``As a result, the Soviets are developing a policy and strategy that is oriented toward defense of the USSR and away from external adventurism,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Many Americans Are Dumb Consumers, Survey Shows
With PM-Consumer Ignorance-Test
DOC.TEXT: This is a quiz to see how you stack up against 1,139 other people who were surveyed about their survival skills as consumers. Question: Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien sign a one-year lease for an apartment at $400 a month but change their minds and never move in. Legally, they owe the landlord: $400, $800, $1,200 or $4,800? If you said $4,800, you are among the 52 percent who answered the question correctly. The discouraging thing about this, according to the Consumer Federation of America, is the 48 percent who didn't have the right answer. Question: Which of the following drugs can cause drowsiness and therefore should not be taken before driving: Aspirin, antihistamines, antacids or laxatives? Right, it's antihistamines. You are among the 79 percent who got that right. Question: When a check bounces, who, if anyone, is usually charged a fee? The multiple choices are: a. the check writer only; b. the person to whom the check is written only; c. Both the check writer and the person to whom the check is written; and d. neither the check writer nor the person to whom the check is written. Only 29 percent got the answer, which was `c.' The Consumer Federation of America said Monday that it put these and 246 other questions to 1,139 people in shopping centers in seven states and found only 54 percent of its questions were answered correctly. Five tests were given, each with 50 questions. ``Many consumers are not equipped to function competently in the marketplace,'' said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the federation. The questions asked about definitions, the most efficient way to buy goods and services, the use of household products and drugs and solving problems related to products. The test results send ``a clear and acutely troubling message,'' said Michael Van Buskirk of TRW Foundation, which paid for the study conducted by the Educational Testing Service. ``The test shows that those in the lower rungs of the economic ladder are further disadvantaged in their attempts to climb up because of their consumer skills,'' he said. ``The public and private sectors have expended extraordinary resources in the name of consumer protection and education but those tests give those efforts a failing grade.'' Scores were low on housing purchases, checking and savings programs, food purchases and life insurance. Consumers were more knowledgeable about drugs and housing rental. For instance, 87 percent knew the significance of co-signing a loan; 78 percent knew the relation of salt consumption to high blood pressure; 79 percent the relationship between use of antihistamines and drowsiness; and 76 percent knew the meaning of a full warranty. Brobeck said the less educated, the poor, the young and minorities all scored less than 50 percent on the test, even though a person could answer about 25 percent correctly just by guessing. Consumers were found to be knowledgeable in some areas, automobiles for instance. Two in three of those questioned knew that comprehensive insurance - rather than collision, liability or uninsured motorist coverage - would pay for a replacement of a stolen car. Brobeck said the consumer federation, which represents 240 nonprofit groups with 50 million members, would meet with the White House consumer office, top federal officials, educators and business leaders to discuss the implications of the findings. There will be an effort, too, to beef up high school instructions in consumer affairs. So that more than 38 percent can correctly answer questions like this: ``Which deposit account usually plays the most interest? Certificate of deposit, money market account, NOW account or passbook savings account.'' The answer, of course, is the CD.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Takes His Case to Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Meetings on Capitol Hill begin 9:30 a.m. EDT; lead planned
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: South African President F. W. de Klerk is seeking to convince congressional leaders that he is serious about his commitment to establish a non-racial system in his country. De Klerk planned meetings this morning with Senate leaders and, after an appearance at the National Press Club, a visit with House members. Part of de Klerk's mission is to persuade Americans that his goal of dismantling apartheid is irreversible. But some black activists said they are not yet convinced. The 24-member Congressional Black Caucus canceled a meeting it had scheduled with de Klerk because it feared the session could be misinterpreted.
