After de Klerk's meeting Monday with President Bush, Randall Robinson, head of the TransAfrica anti-apartheid group, said the two leaders' meeting sent a ``false and dangerous message'' that South Africa is on its way to change. De Klerk, meanwhile, assured Bush that the process of democratic reform cannot be reversed. ``We will not turn back,'' he said, promising a new system in which all South Africans will have a ``vote of equal value.'' Bush, in turn, hailed the ``dramatic progress'' away from apartheid rule in South Africa. ``Clearly, the time has come to encourage and assist the emerging new South Africa,'' Bush said after his 2{ hour session with de Klerk. Behind the leaders, a black Marine held the flag of South Africa and a white Marine held the American flag. It was just a year ago that de Klerk assumed the South African presidency, a time when U.S.-South African relations were still frosty because of the negligible progress toward ending white rule. Bush remarked on how far South Africa has come under de Klerk's tutelage. ``Who among us, only a year ago, would have anticipated these remarkable developments,'' Bush said. De Klerk has overseen the lifting of bans on democratic political parties and the release of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, among other prisoners. Still, South Africa has not met the requirements for lifting U.S. economic sanctions, which were imposed by Congress four years ago over President Reagan's veto. U.S. officials said South Africa still must lift emergency rule in Natal Province and release the remaining political prisoners before the sanctions may be suspended. Later, Foreign Minister Pik Botha said Bush's characterization of the dismantling of apartheid as irreversible should help persuade European governments to lift sanctions. He said he understood the difficulty in changing U.S. sanctions written into law by Congress. ``We are aware of the sensitivities constraining the U.S. administration and we are not here to ask the U.S. to do anything about it at this stage,'' Botha said. The Congressional Black Caucus remains skeptical about de Klerk's promises. Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., caucus chairman, explained the decision not to meet with de Klerk, saying, ``To meet with the caucus separate and apart bestows a level of credibility that at this point we are not prepared to deal with.'' But Dellums and other black members of the House were to be among the lawmakers meeting with de Klerk this afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Crunch? Not Judging By Administration's Idling Limos
With PM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: While budget negotiators burned the midnight oil, idling Bush administration limousines burned gasoline - despite the president's pleas to the country to conserve energy. The limousines waiting to take White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and budget chief Richard Darman from the Capitol after the nearly four-hour session broke up past midnight this morning were parked - their engines running for at least a large part of the meeting. Darman had arrived on Capitol Hill at about 8:30 p.m., while Sununu appeared about a half-hour later. The two men departed shortly before 12:30 a.m., Darman in a Lincoln Towncar and Sununu in a Chrysler New Yorker. Spot checks at about 11 p.m. and again at 12:15 a.m. revealed that both vehicles, parked on Capitol grounds, were idling. Drivers lounged in each car, apparently with heaters running to break the chill of the fall night. A third automobile, a Lincoln Towncar used by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, was not running. Bush has made occasional calls for energy conservation in light of the Persian Gulf crisis. He was criticized for repeatedly using a gasoline-guzzling motorboat during his August vacation in Kennebunkport, Me.

DOC.HEAD: `GoodFellas' Debuts in No. 1 Spot
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Director Martin Scorsese's Mafia portrait ``GoodFellas'' opened at No. 1 at the weekend box office with $6.4 million in ticket sales. Another mobster movie, ``State of Grace,'' on the other hand, made $464,969 in its second weekend of limited release and finished 19th, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. The graphic ``GoodFellas'' stars Robert De Niro as a veteran hit man and Ray Liotta as his shooting partner. The Meryl Streep-Shirley MacLaine comedy ``Postcards From the Edge,'' adapted from Carrie Fisher's novel, finished second with ticket sales of $6.3 million. In third, and soon to pass the $150 million mark, was ``Ghost,'' with $5.1 million. Fourth was ``Narrow Margin,'' the new thriller pairing Anne Archer as a witness on the run and Gene Hackman as her guardian. It made $3.6 million. ``Funny About Love,'' a new comedy from Gene Wilder, opened poorly in fifth with a gate of $3 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``GoodFellas,'' Warner Bros., $6.4 million, 1,070 screens, $5,952 per screen, $6.4 million, one week. 2. ``Postcards From the Edge,'' Columbia, $6.3 million, 1,322 screens, $4,784 per screen, $17.2 million, two weeks. 3. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $5.1 million, 1,766 screens, $2,888 per screen, $148.4 million, 11 weeks. 4. ``Narrow Margin,'' Tri-Star, $3.6 million, 1,132 screens, $3,205 per screen, $3.6 million, one week. 5. ``Funny About Love,'' Paramount, $3 million, 1,213 screens, $2,503 per screen, $3 million, one week. 6. ``Death Warrant,'' MGM-UA, $2.8 million, 1,090 screens, $2,570 per screen, $9.2 million, two weeks. 7. ``Flatliners,'' Columbia, $2.2 million, 1,469 screens, $1,490 per screen, $51.3 million, seven weeks. 8. ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. $2 million, 1,285 screens, $1,561 per screen, $78.6 million, nine weeks. 9. ``Darkman,'' Universal, $1.5 million, 1,236 screens, $1,180 per screen, $30.4 million, five weeks. 10. ``Hardware,'' Millimeter, $1.3 million, 692 screens, $1,887 per screen, $4.3 million, two weeks.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Consumer Ignorance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a sampling of the 249 questions asked in multiple-choice tests of consumers in shopping centers. 1. Which of the following institutions usually charges the highest rate of interest on an unsecured consumer loan? a. An insurance company; b. a local bank; c. a finance company; d. a credit union. Answer: C. 2. A real estate agent's commission is generally what percent of the sales price on a house? a. 2%; b. 4%; c. 6%; d. 10%. Answer: C. 3. The presence of radon gas in homes can be detected by a. unusual odors; b. stains on walls; c. readings on Geiger counter; d. results of a special test. Answer: D. 4. To find the best buy among similar products, a consumer should check the: a. universal product code; b. size of the package; c. item price; d. unit price. Answer: D. 5. If a person files a complaint in a small claims court against a television repair shop, which of the following statements is true? a. The case will be heard by a jury; b. the person will need an attorney; c. the person can represent himself or herself; d. the person can win an award of up to $5,000. Answer: C.

DOC.HEAD: Hayden Wins Endorsement on Abortion Issue
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mike Hayden of Kansas has won the endorsement of the president of the National Organization for Women, who said she is abandoning the group's historical alliance with women and Democrats. NOW president Molly Yard said at a news conference that Hayden's support of abortion rights makes him more deserving of support than Joan Finney, the Democratic nominee who opposes abortion rights. ``I do not know how anybody who is pro-choice can support Joan Finney - no matter how Democrat you are. Nobody is more Democrat than me,'' Ms. Yard said Sunday. Yard's endorsement was a personal one and did not represent an endorsement by the women's group. Hayden was endorsed by abortion opponents in 1986, but his wife said in a weekend interview in The Kansas City Star that he had never sought the endorsement. Patti Hayden said in the interview that she had an influence on Hayden, who calls himself an abortion rights advocate.
DOC.HEAD: Engler: Blanchard Administration Demands Contributions for State Business
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial hopeful John Engler is accusing Gov. James Blanchard's administration of awarding contracts in exchange for campaign contributions. Engler on Monday asked Attorney General Frank Kelley to appoint a non-partisan assistant attorney general to investigate any linkage between individuals who have been awarded state contracts and political donations. ``I believe in instances there have been'' contracts awarded in exchange for political campaign contributions, Engler said at a news conference. Blanchard administration officials called Engler's charges ridiculous. ``Absolutely not,'' there is no linkage between contracts and contributions, said Shelby Solomon, director of the state Office of Management and Budget. The basis of Engler's charge was a series of stories in The Detroit News. The newspaper said it found contracts totaling $183.5 million over the last three years have gone to people who gave $114,000 to the governor's campaign and officeholder expense accounts.
DOC.HEAD: Durenberger To Raise Money In Advance of Possible 1994 Race
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger says he plans to get an early start on fundraising for the 1994 election even though he hasn't decided to seek another term. The decision will be based on ``whether I can make a difference,'' the Minnesota Republican said in an interview published in this week's issue of National Journal. Democrats called for Durenberger to resign after he was denounced by the Senate this summer for financial misconduct, which included the laundering of speaking fees and improper payments for his Minneapolis condominium. Steve Moore, a spokesman for Durenberger, confirmed the accuracy of the magazine interview. He said the senator was not available for another interview. Durenberger's campaign treasury went into the red this year after he dipped into it to help pay nearly $500,000 in legal fees.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Focuses on Hispanic Education
DOC.TEXT: Hispanic leaders are overjoyed with President Bush's pledge to improve federal efforts to promote quality education for Hispanic Americans. Bush, flanked by Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, used a ceremony Monday marking National Hispanic Heritage Month, Sept. 15-Oct. 15, to issue an executive order on educational excellence for one of the fastest growing minorities in America. Stressing ``too many Hispanic Americans are not getting the first-rate education they need and deserve,'' Bush said the executive order sets up an advisory committee to keep the education secretary abreast of ways to improve federal educational efforts. The order, an outgrowth of an Hispanic task force report, also directs Cabinet agencies to work along with individuals and educational, business and community groups serving Hispanic Americans to increase participation rates of Hispanics in federal education programs. Cavazos called the order ``a demonstration of (Bush's) thorough commitment to bringing Hispanics into the mainstream of American life through education.'' ``The president's intent in this policy is to improve education for all children who face obstacles in the education system,'' he said. Lisa Navarre, spokeswoman for the National Council of La Raza, said officials are encouraged by the order because the research and advocacy group, along with the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities, had been working for nearly two years to win a commitment from the administration. ``On a political and general level, this is a very significant and symbolic act,'' said Navarrete. ``It shows an interest in the federal government to do something about the crisis in Hispanic education.'' Antonio Rigual, president of the higher education group, said, ``We think that over the next six to 12 months, we will see how the executive order translate itself into programs that begin to address the needs of Hispanics. ``Our opinion has always been that our federal government has really turned its back on Hispanic students. But (the order) begins now to really position Hispanic education institutions and Hispanics in general to make special gains,'' he said. The nation's Hispanic population reached 20.1 million in March 1989, a 39 percent increase over 1980. The president noted that in five years, Hispanics will make up more than half the high school population in some major cities, such as Los Angeles. Within 10 years, he said, 12 percent of all school children will be Hispanic. The National Council of La Raza said Hispanics continue to have the highest school dropout rates of any major group. About 43 percent of Hispanics age 19 or over have no high school diploma and are not enrolled in school. ``We must find new strategies to boost graduation and literacy rates - strategies that really do get the job done, strategies that really work,'' said Bush. ``We must figure out how to help these young people, how to equip them with the tool to enter a nation in a world where technology advances so rapidly that literacy and analytical and technical skills are not luxuries but essentials.'' In other federal initiatives, the president said: -Cavazos will work with governors from key states, enrolling large number of students in migrant education programs to develop criteria for a high school diploma for migrant students. -Federal education programs will intensify efforts to increase language development among preschool children. Head Start will provide general guidance, he said. -The Education Department will increase emphasis on early education programs under the Bilingual Education Act to achieve English proficiency for preschool children lacking those skills. The order acts upon recommendations from a special Hispanic task force formed within the president's Domestic Policy Council. With Cavazos as the chairman, the task force held public hearings on Hispanic education in San Antonio, Boston, Miami, Chicago and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: New Tracing Center Tracks Victims of Holocaust
DOC.TEXT: Using newly released Soviet documents on 400,000 of Hitler's victims, a new Red Cross clearinghouse is offering to help people track the fates of loved ones sent to labor or death camps by the Nazis. The center opened here Monday to process a flood of expected requests for access to the records in West Germany that the Soviets began releasing last year. Soviet soldiers recovered the documents when the camps were liberated at the close of World War II. Emmy Hubert Mogilensky, the daughter of Holocaust victims, said at the opening of the Holocaust and War Victims Tracing and Information Center that she sympathizes with relatives who still don't know the fate of loved ones. The 67-year-old woman said she grieved with her brother when the Red Cross sent them a message in 1946 saying their parents died in a Nazi concentration camp.As time passed, she said the letter became a ``comfort, a closure.'' ``For us, the questions were finally answered and we could go on with our lives,'' said Mogilensky, who was invited to speak at the opening. Millions of people, mostly Jews, were sent to labor and death camps under Hitler. An estimated 6 million Jews were killed. The Soviet papers include nearly 70,000 death certificates from the Auschwitz concentration camp in Poland. Also included are the names of 130,000 prisoners used for forced labor and 200,000 victims in other camps, including Dachau, Sachsenhausen, Gross Rosen and Buchenwald. ``The pain of not knowing where they were. If they were murdered in the camp. Did they die in the cattle cars on the way to the camp? It haunts you. It does not let you rest,'' Mogilensky said. ``Can you imagine after 45 years still wondering, still not knowing?'' Copies of the Soviet documents are housed at the International Tracing Service in Arolsen, West Germany, a branch of the Central Tracing Agency of the International Committee of the Red Cross. To use the Baltimore center, people can contact local American Red Cross chapters to obtain inquiry forms. Caseworkers send the completed forms to Baltimore, where they are translated into German and forwarded to Arolsen. Center volunteers will provide progress reports so people don't think their requests have been forgotten. Diane Paul, program director of the Central Maryland Red Cross, said certifying a Holocaust victim's fate can take months. The research is complex, involving cross-referencing with other lists, she said. It is further complicated by the various spellings of names and possible inaccuracies in the records. ``For example, the name Schwartz can be spelled 156 different ways, and there are 400,000 persons filed under this name alone,'' Paul said. Western allies released concentration camp documents soon after World War II. But Soviet authorities had kept the records sealed despite repeated requests. There are 46 million documents already on file in Arolsen covering 13 million people. Over 44 years, the center has responded to 1.8 million people searching for information about missing relatives. ``These people, their children, their brothers, their sisters, their cousins, aunts and uncles were no longer able to give voice to say, `Here I am,''' said Alfred Himmelrick Jr., a Baltimore businessman who went to see the records in Germany on a liaison mission for the new tracing center. ``It was then that the 13 million people on file became real, not abstract.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill Protecting Older Workers' Benefits
DOC.TEXT:
The Senate has approved legislation bringing older workers' job benefits under the protective umbrella of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. The bill, sent to the House Monday on a 94-1 vote, is aimed at reversing the effects of a Supreme Court decision which held that employee benefits were not covered by the 1967 civil rights law. Only Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, voted against the measure. ``This one Supreme Court ruling opened the door wide for potential discrimination in older workers' health, disability, life insurance and severance benefits,'' said Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa. ``It did so by threatening or permitting the use of deferred compensation in the form of pension benefits to be converted to an unintended and counterproductive use,'' Heinz said. ``The Supreme Court decision sanctions discrimination in benefits solely on the basis of a worker's age, without regard to who the worker is or what he contributes to the work force.'' The bill puts the Senate on record as saying it intended the 1967 law to prohibit arbitrary discrimination against older employees in the administration of benefit programs - unless separate treatment of workers on the basis of age could be justified.
---
DOC.HEAD: Government Files Reverse Discrimination Suit Against Maryland
DOC.TEXT: Lottery

The Justice Department is accusing the Maryland lottery of bias against white men because it set aside several top positions for women and minorities in 1983. The civil rights suit filed Monday alleged that Maryland and its lottery agency violated Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act by refusing to hire qualified white males for the four positions set aside for minorities in 1983. The lawsuit was denounced by a state official as an unwarranted attack on a one-time effort by Maryland to recruit more minorities into the lottery agency. Two black men, a black woman and a white women were recruited ``in response to a Maryland Human Relations Commission investigation and determination that the lottery agency was not doing enough to meet affirmative action requirements,'' said Dennis Sweeney, deputy state attorney general.
---
DOC.HEAD: EPA Releases Cancer Estimates
DOC.TEXT:
People who regularly eat fish taken from streams near pulp and paper mills that discharge dioxin run a increased risk of developing cancer, says the Environmental Protection Agency. The EPA made public Monday the results of a study showing that dioxin concentrations in fish downstream from 19 such mills ``may be high enough to pose an increased cancer risk greater than one in 10,000'' to average consumers of fish caught there. ``The estimated cancer risk is potentially higher for avid sports fishermen and subsistence level fishermen because their consumption of fish is generally higher than that of average consumers,'' the EPA said. The EPA said its risk estimates are based on the consumption of fish - such as catfish, bass, suckers and squaw fish - that spend their entire lives near a paper mill and accumulate greater concentrations of dioxin in their tissues. The risk estimates do not apply to migratory fish, such as salmon, that spend only a short portion of their lives in the contaminated waters. The one-in-10,000 estimate is an upper bound. Any actual risk, if present, could be lower. The agency generally tries to act against risks this large, and treats smaller risks with less concern. The average risk in the United States of dying of cancer from any source is about one in five.
---
DOC.HEAD: Health Officials, Doctors Team Up To Trace Progress of Virus
DOC.TEXT: Causing AIDS

Federal health officials are collaborating with several hundred physicians in the United States and Canada to gather more information about the progression of the infection that leads to AIDS. The study will give medical researchers a better picture of which symptoms and diseases are most common in different groups of patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, officials said in announcing the study Monday. It also will provide information on what treatments patients are using and will help researchers identify medical changes that occur as HIV infection progresses towards acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The study will allow researchers to compile a data base on a broad spectrum of HIV patients and will help physicians identify patients who can participate in clinical trials of experimental drugs, officials said. More than 30 community-based clinics and programs in the United States and Canada will participate in the study. They include 18 sponsored by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and 15 sponsored by the American Foundation for AIDS Research. Several hundred physicians will be able to enroll patients they see at these clinics and programs, as well as patients they see in their private practices. These physicians care for more than 60,000 HIV-infected patients, according to the research foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Union Vote Shows Overwhelming Support for GM Pact
DOC.TEXT: Early returns from a United Auto Workers vote this week on a national contract with General Motors Corp. show the agreement is headed for overwhelming approval. The union's 300,000 workers in 29 states were expected to ratify the tentative agreement reached a week ago that guarantees full income for laid-off workers. The voting ends Sunday. The union plans to use the three-year contract as a pattern for agreements with Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. At GM's Arlington, Texas, assembly plant, with about 3,000 workers, Local 276 President David Perdue said Monday that production workers voted 98 percent and skilled trades workers voted 94 percent to accept the contract. ``There really weren't that many concerns,'' he said. ``Everybody for the most part is pretty happy.'' Locals in Bedford, Ind., with about 1,200 workers, and Baltimore, with about 3,100 workers, also voted overwhelmingly to ratify the pact. Meanwhile, Ford of Canada workers went back to work Monday after ratifying a new contract following a week-long strike. The shutdown halted work in all nine factories operated by the Ford subsidiary. Company officials said the walkout did not disrupt U.S. Ford factories or sales as feared. The GM contract includes a $4 billion commitment to guarantee the income of workers who are laid off more than nine months. It also maintains a program to hire one new worker for every two who quit, retire or die. In addition, the contract provides for a 3 percent raise in the first year and lump sum payments in the second and third years of 3 percent. Cost of living adjustments were retained.

DOC.HEAD: Children Pour Into Desert Refugee Camps
DOC.TEXT: For the first time, large numbers of children are joining the seven-week-old exodus from Iraq and Kuwait. About one-third of the estimated 15,000 refugees who've arrived daily at Jordan's desert transit camps since Saturday are children, relief workers say. Some are just weeks old and many are suffering from heat exhaustion after their long journeys through the desert and from the lack of milk at the camps. ``We've no experience of this. More and more and more families have begun arriving over the last few days, replacing the bachelors we had before,'' said Red Cross relief coordinator Stefane Spang. ``It's a whole new problem.'' About eight small children sat with 20 adults Monday inside a sweltering green military tent, coated with yellow dust swirling in clouds off the desert. They sweated and swatted flies. The adults fanned the children. ``My father said we can go after some days, but I'd like to go now,'' said Shayam Lal, a 6-year-old Indian whose sober gaze made him seem far older. ``We've reached too far away from Kuwait to go back, but this place is too far from India,'' he said. About 30,000 people are in the transit camps of Azraq I and II. Workers with the International Committee of the Red Cross said there was not enough milk or disposable diapers. Spang, in Amman, said 1,100 gallons of milk would be delivered to the camp today. But he did not know how long it would last because it was unclear how many children are languishing in the camps. Shayam Lal's father Agith Lal, a former bank clerk in Kuwait, said his family came on a bus two days ago with 33 adults and 15 children, including four infants. Shayam sat beside his father and brother and read a dog-eared comic book. He said it was too hot to go outside and play. ``I'd rather be in school,'' he said. ``I miss my friends.'' But Shayam probably won't see his classmates in Kuwait again, and his father fears that if the trip home takes too long, his son may get home too late to enroll in school. ``Education is critical,'' Lal said. ``When the Iraqis took our things, I didn't mind too much. But taking a year of school from my son makes makes me very, very angry.'' The refugee families, mostly Indian, said they remained in Kuwait despite the Iraqi invasion after seeing reports on Kuwaiti television of the appalling conditions in the first makeshift transit camps at the Iraq-Jordan border. The newcomers said they decided to leave occupied Kuwait, where life is getting increasingly difficult, after seeing Iraqi TV footage of the new camps. In the Azraq I transit camp, trucks drive between the tents distributing rice, tomatoes, apples, cucumbers and sometimes canned fish. A Red Cross official said that with the huge increase in the number of children, relief workers hope to increase protein in the daily ration. The refugees stay in the transit camps for an average of four days before leaving Jordan for India aboard specially chartered aircraft. The evacuation has been running fairly smoothly for the last two weeks. But there are still more people entering Jordan than leaving it, and the population at the Azraq camps has been gradually rising.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Plans Air Bags in All 1994 Cars
DOC.TEXT: Honda will install air bags in all its 1994 cars, joining a growing list of automakers that plan to offer the safety devices as standard equipment. Nobuhiko Kawamoto, president and chief executive officer of Honda Motor Co., said Monday that air bags for drivers and front-seat passengers will replace automatic seat belts. Chrysler Corp. equips all its U.S.-made cars with driver-side air bags, but cars it receives from other companies, notably Mitsubishi Motors Corp., lack the devices. General Motors Corp. said it will expand use of driver and passenger side air bags to all of its domestically designed cars for the 1996 model year. Ford Motor Co. said by the mid-1990s it will equip all of its cars with driver- and passenger-side air bags. Under federal law, all cars made in the United States after Sept. 1 must have either an air bag or automatic seat belt for drivers and front-seat passengers. Kawamoto, on his first U.S. tour as head of Honda, would not predict how many Honda and Acura cars the company will sell in the United States by the time air bags became standard equipment. Through the first eight months of this year, Honda sold 593,508 cars, up 11.2 percent from the same time last year.

DOC.HEAD: Some Equipment for U.S. Military Comes from East German Army
DOC.TEXT: About half the military aid pledged by West Germany for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf will be in the form of East Germany military hardware, the chief government spokesman says. The spokesman, Hans Klein, has also denied a news report that Washington was angry about the decision to include the East German equipment. He said officials would fulfill Chancellor Helmut Kohl's pledge of ``modern equipment.'' Pressed by Washington, Kohl last week promised about $2 billion in aid for the U.S. government and poor nations hurt by the suspension of trade with Iraq. The government set direct military aid at about $1 billion. Klein told reporters Monday that about $470 million worth of military equipment for the U.S. forces would be East German military hardware. Parts of the East Germany military will be integrated into the West German army when the two Germanys unite on Oct. 3. Other units are being disbanded. West German military officials are still debating what to do with Soviet-made East German military equipment they will inherit. Klein said U.S. officials were aware that some of the military equipment for the U.S. forces would come from East Germany. He said there were no complaints from the U.S. side. However, the West German newsmagazine Der Spiegel said in its latest issue that Washington was angry about the East German military equipment. Defense Ministry spokesman Max Reichert told reporters that Soviet-built MiG-29 combat aircraft owned by the East German air force are not part of the deliveries. Most of the equipment consists of tracked vehicles, water tankers, trucks, radio equipment and similar hardware. No weapons systems are involved. West Germany has already started delivering advanced Fuchs vehicles that can detect chemical weapons. The vehicle is manufactured in West Germany, and 60 of them are to be deployed in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall On Higher Oil Prices; Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: Buffeted by concern over higher oil costs, share prices closed sharply lower in Tokyo on Tuesday. The dollar also softened against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 418.51 points, or 1.76 percent, ending the day at 23,359.32, its lowest close since Jan. 27, 1988, when it ended trading at 23,335.91. The index shed 174.85 points on Friday. Trading was thin, with only 230 million shares changing hands in the first section. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 136.70 yen, down 0.63 yen from Friday's 137.33-yen finish. The currency opened at 136.75 yen and ranged between 136.40 yen and 137.00 yen. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 8.675 percent by 4:00 p.m. from Friday's 8.600-percent finish. The price fell to 80.79 from 81.09. On Monday, Tokyo financial markets were closed for a national holiday. Stock traders said the Nikkei's plunge was largely due a sudden surge in oil prices as well as a sharp decline in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York. Tomoya Kohda, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said the index quickly fell due to index-linked large-scale selling in reaction to the surge in oil prices. ``Although index-buying by a few foreign securities houses narrowed the Nikkei's losses, the rise in oil prices largely discouraged investors,'' he said. ``Fear of inflation is quickly growing in the market,'' Kohda said. Convinced that an extensive war with Iraq is inevitable and probably imminent, oil traders drove crude oil prices on several world spot markets to a peak of about $40 a barrel Monday. Tuesday morning in Tokyo, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for November delivery was sold at $38.71 a barrel, 46 cents higher than its counterpart on the New York Mercantile Exchange. North Sea Brent crude for November delivery was valued at about $38.80 per barrel. Oil prices were more than $3 higher than last week's closing figures. In currency dealings, trading lagged after the opening as investors retreated to the sidelines to avoid risks before the end of the first half of Japan's fiscal year, dealers said. The first half of fiscal 1990 for most Japanese companies ends Friday. Beginning Thursday, foreign exchange transactions will be settled in the second half of the fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Jesuit Priest and China Watcher Dies
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Lazlo Ladany, a Hungarian-born Jesuit who ran the world's oldest journal of China-watching from a student hostel at the University of Hong Kong, has died of lung cancer. He was 76. Ladany, a trained violinist and lawyer, died Sunday at Canossa Hospital, where he had been undergoing treatment for the last month. He was born in Budapest on Jan. 14, 1914 and entered the Jesuit order in Hungary when he was 22. Three years later, he was sent to China to preach. For the next nine years, Ladany lived in Shanghai and Beijing, studying Chinese. The revolution of 1949 forced Ladany and other Jesuits to flee China. The victorious Communist Party cracked down hard on Roman Catholics, executing thousands and forcing Chinese priests to break all ties with the Vatican. Ladany arrived in the British colony of Hong Kong and began publishing China News Analysis in 1953. It became his life work and made him famous on university campuses and in embassies on both sides of the Iron Curtain. Operating out of a small room in a student hostel at the University of Hong Kong, Ladany would monitor news broadcasts from almost every Chinese province. His gleanings from the broadcasts opened a window on China for many, which was off-limits to most Western journalists at the time. In addition to engaging in the highly speculative tea leaf reading of Chinese politics, Ladany's newsletters also gave a feel for life in China. One newsletter during the Cultural Revolution was devoted to a prissy Shanghai teen-ager who, like millions of others her age, was sent to a commune to labor with peasants. She and other city girls were appalled at the poverty of their peasant comrades and failed at gardening because they couldn't bring themselves to spread human feces, the only fertilizer available, near their house. Ultimately, she bribed the village headman with rubber shoes and other treats from Shanghai and escaped to Hong Kong, where Ladany interviewed her. The newsletter devoted a lot of coverage to hogs, China's main source of meat and an important fertilizer source. Under the heading Pigs, the issues were spiced with barnyard humor, such as Chairman Mao Tse-tung's statement that ``every pig is a small fertilizer factory,'' and that China should push for a ``one man-one pig'' agricultural policy. ``China could very well exist without missiles or bombs,'' Ladany once said. ``It could not exist without pigs.'' In another newsletter, Ladany was one of the first to report that prostitution had returned to China. He also came close to predicting the fall of China's Gang of Four, who along with the Mao, led China during the Cultural Revolution of 1966-76. At the end of 1982, Ladany turned China News Analysis over to a new editorial team which resumed publication on Jan. 1, 1984. He remained a close watcher of China and was a persistent skeptic of China's reformers, especially Deng Xiaoping.

DOC.HEAD: Council Refuses to Revive Tuition Tax
DOC.TEXT: The City Council failed to revive the nation's first tax on college tuition but voted to seek other ways of raising extra money from Northwestern University and three other colleges in this Chicago suburb. The council, in a 10-8 vote Monday, fell two votes short of overriding Mayor Joan Barr's veto of a tuition tax of up to $60 a year on students at Northwestern, Kendall College, Garrett Evangelical Theological Seminary and Seabury-Western Theological Seminary. ``The people who are opposed are always joined together on anything the city administration wants,'' said Alderman Jack Korshak, who proposed the tax. The tax would have generated an estimated $500,000 a year toward the city's budget, which totaled $77.3 million in 1990-91, officials said. The measure, adopted on Sept. 10, centered on Northwestern's unwillingness to pay the city for police and fire protection. The university has its own security force but occasionally asks for assistance from Evanston police. Evanston schools are exempt from property taxes, and the measure was intende to give tax relief to homeowners who saw higher bills in this community of 73,000 because of reassessment last year. The council also voted 15-3 Monday to establish a three-member committee to look for ways to increase the amount of money Northwestern gives the city. Northwestern is willing to hold talks with city officials on ``all matters of mutual interest to the city, not just a financial contribution,'' said spokesman Chuck Loebbaka. Opponents who labeled the tax ``anti-education'' and ``anti-business'' said it would destroy the relationship between the city and its educational institutions. Northwestern, which owns 242 of the 5,400 acres in the community, has said it is typical for such institutions to be exempt from property taxes. Most of the school's nearly 10,500 students are undergraduates who pay tuition of $13,725 a year.

DOC.HEAD: ABC, CBS Plan New Late-Night Newscasts
DOC.TEXT: The late-night news war is heating up with plans by CBS and ABC to take on the Cable News Network and other competitors. A half-hour show on CBS will premiere Monday opposite ``Nightline'' with Ted Koppel on ABC. ABC's overnight, to run from 1 a.m. to 6 a.m., will start Jan. 7 if plans are approved, ABC News Vice President Joanna Bistany said Monday. Charles Kuralt and Lesley Stahl will be co-anchors of the new CBS program to air at 11:30 p.m. Unlike ``Nightline,'' which usually tackles a single topic each night, the new CBS show will examine several topics each night through live interviews, extended news segments and essays, CBS said. It also will report the latest developments in the United States and the Middle East as long as the Persian Gulf crisis continues, CBS said. There was no guarantee the CBS show will continue after January, when the network plans to begin first-run entertainment programs in the 11:30 p.m. slot. ``My hope is that by then we have a program of the type of quality, the type of (affiliate) clearance and the ratings to continue,'' CBS News President Eric Ober said. Kuralt will be the anchor here and Stahl will be the anchor in Washington. Each will continue anchoring their other respective Sunday shows - Kuralt on ``Sunday Morning'' and Stahl on ``Face the Nation.'' The two network projects are part of efforts to seek new franchises for the news divisions and ward off inroads made by cable, including CNN. In January, NBC plans to start a 24-hour news operation, serving its affiliates with international, national and regional stories for use in local newscasts.

DOC.HEAD: Rains Leave at Least 45 Dead In Mexico
DOC.TEXT: As rescuers searched debris for victims, residents of this normally bone-dry northern city mourned relatives lost in flash floods that wiped out gully settlements, claiming at least 45 lives. Officials administered food and medical care to 2,000 flood victims at 25 public schools converted into shelters on Monday night, Red Cross spokesman Blanca Patricia Valles said. About 800 people were in shelters run by the army. About 5,000 were rendered homeless by flooding from downpours that began late Saturday, state spokesman Jorge Macias said. He described it as the worst storm to hit Chihuahua, the state capital, in a century. Forecasters said about 5 inches of rain fell on the city. Alfonso Sanchez Gallo, spokesman for the Chihuahua state governor's office, said nine people were missing from low-income areas set in gullies. ``It rains very little here. Many humble people with scant resources built their homes in the gulches. ... That's the only reason why so many people, homes and vehicles were carried away,'' he said. More than 300 homes collapsed and 350 vehicles were swept away, Sanchez Gallo said. Three coffins adorned with flowers lay in a back room of the Vallejo family home Monday in the city's Francisco Villa neighborhood, one of the hardest hit. Delvina Vallejo had tried to save her 4-year-old daughter from the torrent that picked her up as it rushed through their home. Both the mother, who was pregnant, and child perished as the husband watched clinging to a doorframe. ``She saw her daughter on the waves and grabbed her. That's when the water rushed at her and they drowned,'' said neighbor Margarita Avita. She said Mrs. Vallego was ``in her coffin with her hands crossed, in the same way she was when she was holding her little girl.'' Police patrolled the same neighborhood Monday afternoon, warning people that a dam was about to break. Residents panicked and cried as they rushed to higher ground, but the dam held. About 40 percent of the city of 600,000 was still without water service, state spokesman Macias said. Electricity, which went out during the storm, had been restored, but there wer still some problems with telephone service.

DOC.HEAD: Webster's Dictionary Among Books Challenged
With PM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A definition of sexual intercourse has landed Webster's Dictionary among such banned and challenged books in the United States as the Bible, ``The Grapes of Wrath'' and ``Hamlet,'' a library group says. As part of its ninth annual Banned Books Week, the American Library Association has released a list of censored books and their authors, ranging from Dr. Seuss to Stephen King. ``We need to bring to the attention of the American public the fact that our First Amendment rights are under attack,'' said Judith Krug, director of the association's Office for Intellectual Freedom. More than 1,000 attempts to challenge or ban books were reported to the 51,000-member American Library Association in the year up to May, Krug said. Webster's Dictionary was challenged in the Upper Pittsgrove Township, N.J., school district by parents who objected to its definition of sexual intercourse as ``the sexual joining of two individuals,'' said Paul Whitman, secretary of the school board. Webster's 1986 edition was removed from fourth- and fifth-grade classrooms last fall but is still used in upper levels, Whitman said. A year ago, ``The Lorax'' by Dr. Seuss was challenged in a Laytonville, Calif., school district. Parents working for a local logging company said the children's book offered a negative portrayal of the industry. The book remained on the second grade's required reading list until teachers decided to put it on an optional list in the spring, said Superintendent Brian Buckley. Stephen King's ``The Stand'' was restricted to ninth-grade students with parental consent at a Beaverton, Ore., school after parents raised objections to violence and sexual language. Another King novel, ``Christine,'' was removed from library shelves at a Connecticut district after a parent complained about offensive passages. Banned Books Week, which runs through Saturday, is ``a celebration of our freedom to read,'' Krug said. ``We've proven time and time again that censorship dies in the light of day,'' Krug said. Krug said she advises librarians and teachers to set specific policies on censorship, but professionals aren't the only ones who can get involved. Anyone who attends school board meetings or writes letters to newspapers can have an effect. ``As individual citizens we have to stand up and be counted,'' Krug said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Groups Clash in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem groups battled with howitzers and mortars in southern Lebanon during the night, and at least three people were killed and 12 wounded, police said. The clashes, which broke out Monday afternoon and tapered off early this morning, pitted the Syrian-backed Amal and the pro-Iranian fundamentalist Hezbollah on the northwestern edge of the Iqlim al-Tuffah region. The thuds of exploding shells echoed for miles. Amal, which is backed by guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization, accused Hezbollah fighters of shelling its positions in Kfar Hatta, five miles southeast of Sidon. A police spokesman said no change in the position of either militia was reported. A force of about 1,000 guerrillas, drawn mainly from PLO chief Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah faction, mans a narrow buffer separating Amal and Hezbollah positions in the disputed region. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on and off over three years for leadership of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. More than 1,000 people have died in the clashes and more than 4,000 have been wounded. The disputed area is next to a 440-square-mile border strip occupied by neighboring Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Red Tide Toxin Prompts Oyster Recall in 17 States
DOC.TEXT: About 4,500 gallons of Washington state oysters distributed in 17 states are being recalled because of red tide contamination. The state Health Department said Monday the oysters contaminated with the shellfish toxin were harvested at Liberty Bay, west of Seattle, by Coast Oyster Co. The shellfish were combined with uncontaminated oysters from a different harvest area, then packaged for distribution, the department said. The oysters recalled were valued at $100,000. The oysters were distributed under the brand name Hilton's Willapoint Fresh Oysters with Washington state certification number 006. They had ``sell by'' dates of Sept. 27 to Oct. 16. The oysters were shipped in Washington state and to Texas, Alabama, Florida, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Georgia, Nevada, Missouri, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Maryland, New York, New Mexico, North Carolina and Louisiana. As a precaution, the health agency closed Liberty Bay to shellfish harvesting until further notice. Red tide occurs in shellfish that have consumed large amounts of a microscopic organism. It can cause severe illness and in some cases can be fatal. Symptoms include numbness, tingling of the lips, tongue, hands and feet, and breathing difficulties. The toxin was discovered during a routine sampling of shellfish for contamination at a state laboratory.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Justice Minister Apologizes for Remarks on Blacks
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese Cabinet minister who compared black Americans to prostitutes apologized today after criticism from the State Department and American black leaders. Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, 64, told reporters his comments were ``completely inappropriate.'' ``So I retract the remarks and deeply apologize to those concerned,'' said the newly appointed minister, who previously served in two other Cabinet posts. The minister created the stir Friday while speaking at a news conference after the arrests of foreign women allegedly working as prostitutes in Tokyo. He said prostitutes ``ruin the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods and added: ``It's like in America when neighborhoods become mixed because blacks move in and whites are forced out.'' On Monday, the U.S. State Department issued a statement saying ``such remarks are offensive to the American people.'' Ralph Neas, executive director in Washington of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, had called the minister's comment ``reprehensible and racist.'' The justice minister's comments were the latest in a series of remarks by Japanese politicians that have provoked outrage among U.S. minorities. In 1986, then Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone caused a furor when he said: ``On the average, the United States is lower because of a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans.'' The prime minister said he was referring to literacy rate. He later pologized and said he realized his comment had ``offended many Americans.'' But he did no retract his remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Owned Limo Parked in Suburban Detroit Under Bush Freeze Order
DOC.TEXT: Like a father laying down the law to his teen-age son, the government says that as long as Iraq occupies Kuwait, Saddam Hussein can't use the car. The Iraqi president's black, bomb-proof $300,000 limousine is resting on its bulletproof tires at a repair shop in the suburb of Livonia, where the Cadillac was sent to have its engine rebuilt, the Customs Service said Monday. It will be held there under authority of President Bush's executive order freezing Iraqi assets in the United States, the agency said. ``We have reason to believe that this car might have been used by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein,'' said Donald Watson, Customs assistant regional commissioner of enforcement in Chicago. ``In any case, he's not going to get it back.'' The Customs Service titled its news release on the car ``Is Saddam Hussein Walking?'' The Cadillac was one of 12 bought by Iraq in 1988 from O'Gara-Hess & Eisenhardt Manufacturing Co., a maker of armored vehicles in Cincinnati, the Customs Service said. The car has bomb-proof armor and tear gas dispensers. Iraq returned the limousine to O'Gara-Hess & Eisenhardt in June for refurbishing, and the Ohio company then sent it to ECS-Roush in Livonia for engine work, Turner said. Bush froze Iraqi assets after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Money Tops List of Reform Goals From Urban Educators
DOC.TEXT: Taking issue with a set of school reform goals backed by President Bush and the nation's governors, a group of urban educators offered a reform agenda with money at the top of the list. The set of six goals for improving struggling city districts was released Monday at the annual meeting here of the Council of Urban Boards of Education, a unit of the National School Boards Association. The first goal is ``equitable and adequate funding of public education.'' In contrast, the national education goals conceived last February by the president and the governors skirted the issue of money. The other goals on the urban agenda included achieving ``racial, ethnic and socio-economic integration,'' promoting excellence, providing ``multicultural education,'' promoting community school boards as the primary governing bodies in urban districts, and educating the public to convey ``the advantages of education in urban settings and promote confidence in urban public education.'' ``Let's face it, urban schools have been under attack, fairly or unfairly. But you have to remember that we are the only country in the world that tries to educate all,'' said Arlene C. Penfield, president-elect of the National School Boards Association. The urban agenda had no timetable for achieving its goals. The governors targeted the year 2000. ``We definitely endorse the national goals,'' said Ulysses V. Spiva, chairman of the urban group and a school board member in Virginia Beach, Va. ``But we did not feel they addressed all the needs of urban school districts. We don't want the governors and the president to withdraw, and say, `Hey guys, here are our goals, we're done,' '' he said in an interview. The six national goals backed by Bush and the governors were: assuring children arrive at school healthy and ready to learn; cutting the dropout rate to less than 10 percent; having students achieve competence in key subjects; making U.S. students No. 1 worldwide in math and science achievement; wiping out adult illiteracy, and ridding schools of drugs and violence. The urban reform goals were developed by the board's 11-member steering committee, made up of school board members from their respective districts.

DOC.HEAD: 43 Arrested in Quayle Visit
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators tossed paint-filled balloons, bottles and firecrackers at police outside a hotel where Vice President Dan Quayle was addressing a fund-raiser, police said. Forty-three people were arrested. No injuries were reported in Monday's protest by about 200 people outside the Portland Hilton. The protesters represented a variety of causes. Some carried signs reading, ``No blood for oil'' - a protest against the buildup in the Persian Gulf - and ``No fascist state.'' Among the chants was ``Right wing go away, sexist, racist, anti-gay.'' Demonstrators set fire to newspapers and made obscene gestures at about 100 officers ringing the hotel, said police spokesman Dave Simpson. Officers on horseback moved into the crowd, using night sticks to drive the protesters back. Police seized American flags as protesters tried to ignite them. Those arrested were charged with misdemeanors including disorderly conduct, unlawful assembly and harassment. After Quayle left the hotel for the airport, the protesters moved to a track a block away and delayed a commuter train during the afternoon rush hour. Lanny Swerdlow of American Atheists said he came to the demonstration because Quayle supports a local ballot measure that would give tax credits of up to $2,500 to parents who send their children to private schools.

DOC.HEAD: Fifty-One Killed In Fiery Gas Truck Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6 grafs for last 3 grafs pvs to ADD quotes from survivor.
DOC.TEXT: At least 51 people were killed when a gas truck overturned and exploded at a busy Bangkok intersection, quickly covering cars, shops and a women's dormitory in flames, police said today. Another 92 people were injured, many seriously, said Bangkok police superintendent Col. Kongbej Chooseekongdej. The 6-wheel truck overturned near the railway crossing at New Petchburi Road on Monday night. The liquefied gas gushed out of its two huge tanks, and flames swept over 43 cars and 30 shops and other buildings on both sides of the street, said deputy commander of the Bangkok police, Col. Wanlop Watjanapooka. The truck crashed into cars waiting to get onto an expressway, said a witness who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``A huge ball of flames rose into the air. It may have been a kilometer (half-mile) high,'' he said. ``Then I saw the line of cars exploding in succession.'' Gas had leaked under the cars and ignited and the fire raged for two hours before 60 fire engines and hundreds of volunteers extinguished it. ``We were driving back to the hotel after dinner and we got caught in a traffic jam,'' said Peter Gillies, who was slightly burned. ``We could smell gas but were just sort of trapped. About 30 seconds later everything just exploded. ``Once we smelled the gas we thought something was going to happen, but we didn't get out quick enough,'' said Gillies, of Nanaimo, British Colombia. ``There seemed to be like two blasts, one when we were in the car and one when we got out. We had to run through the flame but my wife wasn't quick enough.'' Gillies' wife, Michelle, was seriously burned. There was no immediate information about where most of the fatalities occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge To 33-month Low; Dollar Drops
DOC.TEXT: Share prices plunged to a 33-month low in Tokyo today as surging oil prices discouraged investors, dealers said. The dollar weakened against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 136.70 yen, down 0.63 yen from last Friday's finish. The U.S. currency opened at 136.75 yen and ranged between 136.40 yen and 137.00 yen, with an estimated $8.15 billion trading hands in spot trading. On Monday, financial markets were closed in Tokyo because of a national holiday. The dollar opened lower after weakening in New York. Trading then lagged, with ``the dollar hardly moving in the afternoon'' as investors retreated to the sidelines to avoid risks before the end of the first half of Japan's fiscal year, said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. The first half of fiscal 1990 for most Japanese companies ends Friday. Foreign exchange transactions after Wednesday will be settled in the second half of the fiscal year. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 418.51 points, or 1.76 percent, ending the day at 23,359.32, its lowest closing level since Jan. 27, 1988, when it ended at 23,335.91. The Nikkei shed 174.85 points on Friday. Today's trading was thin, with only 230 million shares changing hands on the market's first section. ``The market was shocked when oil prices rose to $40 (a barrel), although investors have expected prices could reach that level at least temporarily,'' said Kenji Maeshiro, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. ``But what investors are really afraid of is not the price. For us, no matter how much oil rises, it is still okay as long as we have oil supplies,'' he said. ``But we can't deny the possibility of being able to get no oil as a result of the Gulf conflict.'' Japan depends on imports for 99 percent of its oil needs, and 70 percent comes from the Middle East. An overnight surge in oil prices of more than $3 a barrel was set off by a statement by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that he would rather go to war than let the U.N. trade embargo strangle his country. Higher crude oil prices create a threat of inflation and typically lead to increases in gasoline prices. Maeshiro predicted that oil prices of up to $25 to $30 a barrel could be absorbed by the effects of the stronger yen if it remains at about 135 yen per dollar. However, rising oil prices ``will definitely slow down the nation's economy,'' he said. ``So far, Japanese companies, especially manufacturers, don't seem to be affected by the higher oil prices, but the Bank of Japan will have to reverse its tight monetary policy sooner or later,'' he said. Maeshiro said overnight declines in the Dow Jones average in New York and a plunge in Japanese government bond prices contributed to the Nikkei's drop. ``There is no positive element to encourage investors' buying interest now,'' he said. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 80.77 points, down from 81.09 on Friday and their lowest level ever. Their yield rose to 8.680 percent from last Friday's 8.600 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against other foreign currencies in early European trading today. Gold prices were sharply higher, rising by more than $15 an ounce in Hong Kong. Dealers said the absence of any economic news this week and signs that finance ministers from the seven major industrialized countries aren't seeking changes in foreign exchange trends left the market focusing on oil and the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The direction for the dollar is certainly lower,'' said a chief trader at a Frankfurt money center bank, adding that concerns about the U.S. economy were pulling the dollar down. John Baker, senior dealer at Bank Julius Baer and Co., said he expects the Swiss franc, considered a safe haven currency, to benefit especially if the dollar continues to fall on oil price jitters. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.63 yen from Friday's Tokyo closing to a closing 136.70 yen. Japanese markets were closed Monday for the Autumnal Equinox national holiday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 136.50 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.5592 German marks, up from 1.5565 -1.2945 Swiss francs, down from 1.2965 -5.2245 French francs, up from 5.2145 -1.7527 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7665 -1,167.00 Italian lire, up from 1,165.50 -1.1485 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1483 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8895, compared with $1.8810 late Monday. Bullion dealers said the price of gold shot up late Monday in line with a strong rally in oil prices, which are inflationary. Investors buy gold as a hedge against inflation. Dealers said the strong up trend continued in Far East trading but profit-takers in London stopped the precious metal's climb. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $406.35 per ounce at midmorning, up from $396.55 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $407.00, up from $392.20 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $15.03 to close at a bid $404.45. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.93 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.89.

DOC.HEAD: Forecast: Nothing But Blue Skies
DOC.TEXT: Blue skies prevailed over much of the nation's interior today as warm air chased away the weekend's chilly blast. Today's forecast calls for scattered showers and thunderstorms in Oregon, Idaho, Nevada and Utah, and showers in Northern California and Florida's southern tip. A warming trend was predicted for the East, with temperatures rising into the 70s. The South was looking for a near-perfect day, with sunshine, low humidity and highs in the 80s. Nighttime lows in the 50s were expected. Temperatures were expected to soar into the 90s in parts of the Plains and the Southwest. Highs were expected to be in the 80s for the Rockies and in the 70s for the Pacific Northwest. Skies were mostly clear early today, with some clouds in the Northeast and Florida. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 100 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Government Orders More Grain Planted
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: , BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) - Iraq has ordered farmers to plant 80 percent of their land wihh wheat to offset food shortages caused by the international trade embargo, the ruling party's newspaper reported today. Any farmer who violates the order will be fined double the value of the production expected from him, the Agriculture Ministry said. Ministry Undersecretary Abdul Sattar Hussein was quoted by the Baath party newspaper, Al-Thawra, as saying committees have been formed in all provinces to supervise the program. Provincial governors are heading the committees. ``Because of the economic blockade, we all should shoulder our responsibilities in order to plant each inch of our land and increase the production of grains, especially wheat because this is the basic foodstuff for our people,'' the undersecretary was quoted as saying. The U.N. Security Council has imposed an embargo on trade with Iraq to punish it for its Aug. 2 invasion and seizure of neighboring Kuwiat. Iraq has 43 million acres of arable land but little more than 13 percent of it is in use. Almost 57 percent of that is planted with grains, mainly wheat, barley and rice. Iraq has been a major importer of foodstuffs, buying about 75 percent of its food abroad last year. Annual imports, especially grains, totaled $1 billion before the U.N.-ordered embargo. The United States had been the major exporter of foodstuffs to Iraq. Hussein said his ministry has provided cheaper seeds and fertilizer, and has increased wheat prices to encourage farmers to grow more, Al-Thawra reported. He also said special workshops are being set up to help maintain and repair machinery and help farmers overcome technical problems.

DOC.HEAD: Harold King, Reuters World War II Correspondent, Dies
DOC.TEXT: British journalist Harold King, who covered the battle of Stalingrad and forged close ties with French leader Charles de Gaulle, has died. He was 91. The Reuters news agency's Paris bureau, which King headed from 1944 to 1967, said he died Monday at a clinic at Nogent-Sur-Marne, near Paris. He died of heart failure following surgery for a bladder-related ailment, the British agency said. ``Harold was larger than life, commanding attention and respect among journalists, in political circles and among the best restaurants in Europe,'' Reuters managing director, Glen Renfrew, commented in London. King was born Harold Koenig in Berlin in 1898. The family moved to London and his father, a German psychiatrist, changed the family name to King when World War I broke out in 1914. King began his literary career in 1919 as secretary to writer Jerome K. Jerome, author of ``Three Men in a Boat.'' But he quickly shifted to journalism and moved to Paris in 1931, where he became correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and the Financial Times. King fled Paris for London in 1940 as Hitler's armies stormed across France. He then began his long career with Reuters, covering Gen. de Gaulle's exiled French forces. Reuters later sent King to the Soviet Union, where he wrote on the Red Army victory at Stalingrad and covered Stalin's breakup of the Communist International in 1943. King accompanied the Free French landings in southern France in 1944. He cultivated his contacts with de Gaulle during the general's postwar withdrawal from political life. France recalled him as president in 1958 during the height of the Algerian war. The two men enjoyed close relations, and King became one of de Gaulle's favorite media contacts. After King stepped down as head of the Paris bureau, the agency named him honorary assistant director for life. He later worked as a correspondent for the Toronto Telegram. France named King a commander of the Legion of Honor, one of the country's highest honors, in 1971. King had been in failing health for about a decade. His recent surgery followed a broken hip suffered in a fall a few weeks ago. His wife, the Romanian dancer Irene Codreanu, died in 1985. The couple had no children. Funeral arrangements were not immediately announced.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Want to Run Yosemite Park Concessions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The contract...', to include full name of company in first reference.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists who contend Yosemite National Park has become over-commercialized have banded together in an effort to take over the contract to run the park's hotels, restaurants and concession stands. The Yosemite Restoration Trust, a non-profit group formed with the backing of leaders of The Wilderness Society, the Sierra Club and the National Audubon Society, launched an effort Monday to win the contract that expires in 1993. The contract now is held by a company known as Yosemite Park and Curry Co., a division of entertainment giant MCA that has operated hotels in Yosemite for 91 years. If it won the new contract, the trust would have to negotiate to buy Curry's vast holdings. If the trust's bid succeeds, it will be the first time environmental advocates control tourist services in a national park. The group claims the 100-year-old park in the Sierra Nevada is being turned into a crowded resort replete with pizza and ice cream stands, video rentals, moonlight tram tours and ever more cars. ``On a busy Sunday afternoon the air in the Yosemite Valley is almost as bad as in Los Angeles,'' said Dr. Edgar Wayburn, a former Sierra Club president. The park has 3.4 million visitors a year. The group said it wouldn't knock down the park's hotels and motels but would try to change an atmosphere some consider overly commercial. George T. Frampton Jr., president of The Wilderness Society and a member of the new trust's board of directors, accused Curry Co. of exploiting the park while giving the government a tiny share of profits. ``We must put park protection ahead of private profits in our national parks,'' Frampton said. ``Yosemite, as it enters its second century, is far too precious a place to be run as a private profit center.'' Frampton and others claim Curry has failed to carry out a 1980 park managemetn plan that calls for reducing roads, traffic and buildings. Curry spokesman John Poimiroo, however, said warehouse and reservations operations, for example, have been moved out of the park to Fresno, and the number of buildings in the park have not increased in 20 years. Curry doesn't report its profits in Yosemite, but Poimiroo said a reported estimate of $17 million is grossly exaggerated. The company pays the government 0.75 percent of its gross revenue. In 1988, that amounted to $590,000 on revenue of $78 million. ``We admit that what we pay now we consider to be low,'' Poimiroo said. ``But in the 15 years since MCA took over this company it has invested over $100 million in the park.''

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Supervisors Say Embarcadero Freeway Should Be Demolished
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Many longtime...', to clarify that critics of freeway want it changed, not replaced in current form.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a year after the World Series earthquake, the city's supervisors have voted to tear down the quake-damaged Embarcadero Freeway and replace it with a ground-level or underground road. The resolution approved 6-5 Monday by the Board of Supervisors is strictly advisory because state and federal authorities have final say on what to do about the elevated freeway that has been shut since the Oct. 17 quake. The 1.5-mile stretch of freeway, also known as Interstate 480, extends from the Bay Bridge to Chinatown and the North Beach restaurant district. Many longtime residents, backed by Mayor Art Agnos, want the freeway replaced with a ground-level or underground road because the elevated freeway blocks a view of San Francisco Bay and covers prime real estate. Merchants in Chinatown have demanded speedy repairs instead, saying their businesses have been in a slump since the earthquake. The earthquake damaged the freeway's underpinnings so badly that the road was closed to all traffic. Agnos said a replacement roadway could cost about $135 million. ``What we're saying today is that we have a unified message that will go to Sacramento and Washington that says San Francisco has made a decision,'' said Agnos. ``We want to take down a structure we do not believe can be made safe and replace it with a structure that can be made safe.'' The freeway, he said, has been ``a terrible blight on the face of our city for the last 35 years.'' Most of the earthquake's 67 victims were killed in the collapse of a section of Interstate 880, an elevated freeway in Oakland.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It Will Put Bush on Trial Oct. 15
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it will put President Bush on trial Oct. 15 for ``crimes against the peoples of the world.'' Iraq first announced its plan to put Bush on trial on Sept. 12, shortly after Western officials suggested Iraqi President Saddam Hussein be tried for crimes against humanity for the use of chemical weapons in 1988 against Iraq's minority Kurdish population. Baghdad accuses Bush of planning a war against Iraq, attempting genocide by sponsoring U.N. sanctions on Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait, and committing aggression against Panama and Grenada, according to Hamid Al-Rawi, chairman of Iraq's bar association and head of a panel preparing for the trial. ``Bush has committed many crimes since he took office as president of the United States and also before that when he was vice president,'' the English language Baghdad Observer quoted Al-Rawi as saying in today's editions. He was quoted as saying the United States, which has sent more than 150,000 troops to the Persian Gulf to counter Iraq, had committed ``a crime against peace, punishable by international law.'' Al-Rawi said the trial would be an ``international process'' with witnesses from other countries and Arab and non-Arab jurists. It would be conducted on the same basis as the Nuremberg trials of Nazi war criminals following World War II, he said. Other accusations against Bush include the enforcement by the United States ``of an economic blockade against the people of Iraq with the aim of starving children, women and elderly to death, and also preventing food, medicine and baby milk from reaching the country in violation of the the U.N. charter.'' ``This is a crime punishable by international conventions which consider this an act of genocide,'' Al-Rawi was quoted as saying. AlRawi did not say what the punishment might be if Bush is convicted during the three-day trial.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Leaves After Failing To See Eye-To-Eye With Tehran
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad of Syria left Tehran today after a four-day visit, and sources said he failed to win an Iranian pledge not to send food and other essentials to Iraq. Sources close to the Syrian delegation said Tehran reiterated its pledge to uphold embargo rules imposed by the U.N. Security Council after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But Iran insisted it is not breaking the sanctions because the embargo allows ``humanitarian shipments'' of food. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Iranians had promised not to buy embargoed Iraqi oil, or to help Baghdad export its crude. An Iranian newspaper had said Assad carried an appeal from the United States against food shipments as well. Assad failed to see eye-to-eye with Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on many issues, but those differences were not great enough to drive a wedge between Iran and its main Arab ally, the sources said. The first indication that things were not going well for Assad came when he announced Sunday he was extending his stay, apparently for a last-ditch effort in trying to impress upon Rafsanjani the importance of witholding food shipments to Iraq. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, said Assad was seen off at Tehran's Mehrabad airport by Rafsanjani. Before departing, Assad said the results of his talks had been ``good and very effective.'' He said his meetings with Rafsanjani had been ``friendly, and I don't think anything relating to the region remained undiscussed.'' Rafsanjani said ``in our talks we did not reach any point of difference requiring a great deal of discussions.'' The English-language Tehran Times said some of Rafsanjani's discussions with Assad, conducted behind closed doors, had lasted several hours. The report did not provide any details of those meetings. Besides the embargo, the two are also believed to have discussed the fate of 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Say Beirut-Style Bombing `Won't Happen Again'
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Pentagon rules for coverage of operations in Saudi Arabia prohibit disclosure of exact locations of U.S. military installations. ---

Marines guarding a military supply port in northeast Saudi Arabia said today the greatest danger to them was a Beirut-style terrorist car bombing. But they said they were ready to quash any threat. ``I think he'd be a pretty foolish terrorist to take us on,'' said Chief Warrant Officer Charles Rowe, who was shipped out of Lebanon the day before the Oct. 23, 1983, car bombing that killed 241 American servicemen. ``This is a personal opinion, but I wouldn't mind evening the score,'' Rowe said in a dockside interview as fellow Marines marched and drove around the port perimeter. Of any potential terrorist attacker, he said: ``I know he's going to suffer. I'll promise you he'll suffer. We're going to hurt him.'' The Marines search for answers about the impact of the Beirut bombing on their units and psyches even as they insist there is no comparison to the peacekeeping deployment in Lebanon and the defensive mission in Saudi Arabia. In Lebanon, the Marines were grouped in a vulnerable barracks building and all but the last layer of their security was in the hands of the fractious Lebanese military. In Saudi Arabia, the Marines are spread across the port area and have an elaborate security system that includes decoy guard posts and targets. The Marines say they trust the Saudis who guard other sectors of the port, which receives supplies for the entire American military deployment. The commander of the security unit, Lt. Col. Tom Hayden, said alert levels were at their maximum level for several days about two weeks ago, after the military received intelligence about a possible terrorist attempt on the port. He refused to provide details concerning the intelligence and said security was back to routine alert status. The Persian Gulf port is far from the Iraqi troops to the north in Kuwait, and Iraq has no navy to speak of, leaving the air and ground as the only likely attack routes. Hayden said he is confident that Air Force, Marine and Navy air power would block any Iraqi attempt to send fighter jets into Saudi territory. And the Army has stationed several Patriot ground-to-air missile lauchers at the port to protect the Marines against incoming missiles. So as he discounts the comparisons with Lebanon, Hayden pointed to a port gate and says his principal worry is a car bombing, ``the favorite terrorist weapon in this part of the world.'' But, with bravado much like that of Rowe, Hayden predicted any attempt would fail. ``I think that terrorists would realize that would be a mistake,'' Hayden said. ``It won't happen again.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Plans `Private' Visit to United States
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki will make an unannounced trip to the United States this weekend and may meet with President Bush, a government source said today. Mazowiecki left this morning for a four-day visit to Spain, where he will meet with King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. He will travel on to the United States on Friday and may see Bush on Saturday, according to the Gazeta Wyborcza daily. There was no immediate comment on the report from the White House. A Polish government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mazowiecki would not be accompanied by an official delegation. However, several senior Polish officials are already in the United States, including Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, who is appearing before the International Monetary Fund, seeking forgiveness of part of Poland's $42 billion debt to the West. Also, Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski is attending the United Nations General Assembly session in New York. Relations between the United States and Poland have become close since Mazowiecki's Solidarity-led government took power just over a year ago. But Polish officials have expressed concern that the recent political split in the Solidarity camp, pitting Mazowiecki backers against loyalists of Lech Walesa, could erode U.S. sympathy for Poland. The visit would be Mazowiecki's second to the United States as prime minister. He traveled to Washington in March and met with Bush then. Walesa announced Sept. 17 that he is running for president. Elections are to be held by the end of December but the exact date has not been set. Political supporters of Mazowiecki met with the prime minister Saturday and said they expected he would announce his presidential bid shortly after lawmakers approve legislation setting up the election. Walesa, chairman of Solidarity, 13 months ago picked Mazowiecki to be prime minister. But he has criticized the government as too slow in ousting Communists from positions of influence and privatizing the economy. President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist leader who tried to crush Solidarity through martial law in 1981, agreed to end his term 4{ years early to allow popular presidential elections.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Party Chief Re-elected After Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with background on defeated reformer. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Lilov announced...' ^By ROLAND PRINZ
