DOC.TEXT: A day after offering his resignation, the chairman of the governing Socialists was re-elected today by delegates to a party congress whose majority appears reluctant to forge ahead with quick reform. Alexander Lilov, who was opposed by reforers in the party, was re-elected during an all-night session of the long-ruling party that shed its Communist appellation last spring, then won multiparty elections. He gained 833 of the more than 1,300 votes, officials said, defeating radical reformer Alexander Tomov. Tomov won election to the party's 151-member Supreme Council, formerly its Central Committee. Lilov announced Monday that he was stepping down to make way for a new, more ``pragmatic'' leader. But the announcement apparently was a tactical maneuver to elicit support, and his re-election appeared a victory for conservative forces. Lilov, 57, became party leader in February, four months after hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted. Since then, however, Bulgaria has made fewer changes in its Communist system than some of its Eastern European neighbors. Lilov had served as chief ideologist of the Communist Party until Zhivkov dropped him from the leadership in 1983. He rejoined the top ranks only after Zhivkov's ouster. Progressive and conservative factions of the renamed party are now vying for control. Throughout the congress, spokesmen for reform factions repeatedly called for Lilov's replacement. But the reformers were outnumbered, and their candidates stood no chance against Lilov. A Socialist Party official said Monday that reformers numbered about one-third of the delegates. In June, the Communists won Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. Since then, however, their popularity has waned as the economy sputtered. Basic foods like sugar and cooking oil are rationed, and electric power is cut regularly. The Socialists ended weeks of deadlock over Bulgaria's presidency by agreeing last month to elect Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the democratic opposition. He serves as the country's chief of state. Despite his election, government opposition has sometimes turned violent. An angry crowd of protesters attacked, burned and looted the Socialist Party headquarters on Aug. 26. That attack was reportedly provoked by the Socialists' refusal to remove a red star from its headquarters. On Monday, the party congress voted to remove all such symbols of the Communist era from party buildings and adopted a new emblem - a white rose on a red background. The congress decided Monday that its new chairman would be chosen by the whole congress - not just the party's Supreme Council of about 150 members. It has also elected a new party presidium and council.

DOC.HEAD: Protester Says KGB Threatened to Destroy Tent City
DOC.TEXT: A woman who spends her days in a tent city near the Kremlin said today the KGB had threatened to set fire to the protest encampment at night when there would be no witnesses. The KGB denied it. Valentina Philimonova, one of 50 people camped on the grass every day outside the Rossiya Hotel, said that a man she identified as a KGB agent had threatened to pour gasoline on the tents and set them alight if the people didn't end their protest against the failure of the government to provide adequate housing and jobs. ``He said they would come at night when no one would see what was happening,'' she said. An officer at the KGB's press center said not only would the agency ``never attempt such provocations now, but it would have been unthinkable even during the time of stagnation,'' a reference to the era of the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev. It was not the first case of people approaching the tent city, identifying themselves as KGB agents and trying to intimidate the protesters or provoking their anger, said the officer, who refused to give his name. ``No one at KGB would allow it,'' he said of the alleged threat. Ms. Philimonova lives in a wooden shack covered with slogans saying that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has failed to carry out his oath, pledging to serve the people. She is among dozens of people who inhabit and gather around the 31 tents, hoping someone will listen to their problems and punish those responsible for their plight. Some of the signs that adorn the tents and shacks denounce the Communist Party; others tell of losing homes and jobs because the protesters had dared to criticize their bosses. The protest began July 2 when the demonstrators arrived outside the enormous hotel near Red Square and put up the tents and shacks, made of wood and plastic, hoping to attract official attention and help against the local government. They arrive at 8 a.m. and leave at 9 p.m. So far, the government has not responded to their protest.

DOC.HEAD: Student Killed in Caste-Quota Protest; Burned Student Dies
DOC.TEXT: One student was killed and four were wounded by gunfire today as police battled to control a riot touched off by a government policy setting job quotas according to caste standing. A student who had set himself on fire at a crowded intersection in the capital on Monday died at a hospital today, officials said, and in surrounding neighborhoods, thousands of people pelted police with bricks and stones. The army was reported on alert in New Delhi, and has already been called out in at least seven other northern Indian cities. In Monday's incident, student Surinder Singh Chauhan, 22, doused himself with gasoline in a busy intersection and set himself alight. The student shot to death today was identified as 21-year-old Pawan Sahni. Four other protesters were being treated at hospitals for gunshot wounds, reporters at the hospitals said. In today's protests, housewives and middle-class Indians joined the students in the streets. The crowds attacked and set on fire police vehicles, school buses and public buses. The protests began after Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced Aug. 7 that 27 percent of government jobs will be reserved for people from lower castes, who have been downtrodden for centuries by India's rigid caste system. Another 22.5 percent of the coveted jobs already were kept aside for what the government described as the most backward castes and native tribes. Five to 10 percent of jobs are proposed to be reserved for the poor, irrespective of caste. The move triggered a wave of protests by upper-caste students who say it will deprive them of job opportunities. At least 25 people have died in battles with police, and a score have attempted suicide by setting themselves ablaze. On Monday, Singh gave a Cabinet minister and a senior party leader the authority to open talks with protesting students and explain the policy. But students have refused to negotiate until the government scraps the quotas, which Singh has said he will not do. Chandra Shekhar, a senior leader of Singh's Janata Dal party, urged the government today to review its stand. It was the first break in the leadership's refusal to respond to the students. ``History will never forgive us,'' said Shekhar. ``If they are led by frustration and despair to this extreme position, there is no hope for the future of the country,'' he was quoted as saying by Press Trust of India. Police cordoned off the hospital where the burned student died, but thousands of people gathered in streets nearby. Witnesses said police fired tear gas and rifle volleys. Students responded by pelting the police with stones and attacking police vehicles, ripping out car radios and smashing windshields. At least seven police vehicles were damaged and one was burned. Many state-owned buses also were set on fire. Hindus, who comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people, are divided into four castes and hundreds of sub-castes, which determine a person's social standing.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister: East Germans Fear For Their Futures in United Germany
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This is one of a series of stories on the German countdown to unity on Oct. 3.

Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said today that East Germans fear for their futures in a united Germany, and that social guarantees are needed to ease the move to a new society. In a wide-ranging conversation with The Associated Press board of directors, de Maiziere also said the lingering specter of the former secret police is ``one of the most difficult legacies we have'' from the Communist past. East Germany's first freely chosen leader, in an address and during a question-and-answer session, outlined his hopes for his 16 million people as they move closer to German unification on Oct. 3. He said East Germans had the misfortune of living for four decades under a government in which their futures were decided by the Communist hierarchy. A tremendous obstacle will be teaching them to take control of their destinies to live successful lives in the competitive, free-market society epitomized by West Germany, he said. ``The future in the past meant the future prescribed by the Politburo,'' he said. ``Now the people see their future is not a prescribed time, but a free time. This is something people did not learn, and they are afraid of that.'' He said the future government of a united Germany must have a ``strong social consciousness'' to help East Germans make the transition. He also said the files on 6 million people compiled by the notorious secret police known as the Stasi, and the tens of thousands of people who worked for them, are among the most difficult problems confronting the new society. He said German law enforcment officials should have access to those files to punish people who committed crimes for the Stasi, and to rehabilitate people whose lives were ruined by the dreaded security apparatus. But there should not be wide public access because the information contained in them could be damaging, de Maiziere said. About 5,000 Stasi workers were used exclusively to listen to telephone conversations, and the details in the files not only contain political views but information such as whether people were faithful to their spouses. De Maiziere will relinquish control of his country to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Oct. 3. He said he has viewed his role as prime minister as that of a lawyer representing a very large client during the hard bargaining on the terms of unification, and he would accept a similar role in a united Germany. However, he said he has made no decision on whether to become one of the four East German ministers who will be added to Kohl's Cabinet when the Germanys unite. Meanwhile, East Germany's interior minister said today that he believed extremists from both the left and right were planning to disrupt unification celebrations next week in Berlin. Peter-Michael Diestel spoke hours after about 500 leftist protesters rampaged in central East Berlin, smashing windows at a major department store. Diestel, speaking to reporters, called Monday night's incident a ``general rehearsal'' for disturbances he said were planned at the celebrations starting late next Tuesday. He did not say how he had learned of the plans.

DOC.HEAD: Waste Management Subsidiary Agrees to Pay Huge EPA Fine
DOC.TEXT: A company has been fined $3.75 million fine for violating licensing regulations for burning PCBs and other hazardous wastes, an Environmental Protection Agency official said. The fine was the agency's largest ever assessed against a single facility. The federal EPA cited CWM Chemical Services Inc., a subsidiary of Waste Management Inc., for several technical violations, including improper record-keeping and failing to monitor continuously for oxygen, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide emissions when burning PCBs. The violations at the plant, located on Chicago's South Side, did not endanger the environment, EPA spokesman John Connell said Monday. CWM disposes of hazardous waste for government and private industry clients. ``We wanted to take strong enforcement action to prevent any future violations that could cause environmental problems,'' Connell said. The violations occurred mostly in 1986 and 1987, and the company has corrected the violations since then, CWM spokesman Joe Pokorny said. Cancer-causing PCBs - polychlorinated biphenyls - once were commonly used in electrical transformers as a coolant. They since have been banned.

DOC.HEAD: Council Chooses Successor to Mayor of Nice, Who Faces Charges
DOC.TEXT: The city council of this Riviera resort city today chose Honore Bailet to succeed longtime mayor Jacques Medecin, who quit amid charges of mismanagement. Bailet, 70, was assistant mayor and a close confidant of Medecin during his 24-year rule. He will serve in the post until new municipal elections can be set. Medecin, 62, had been mayor of Nice since his father, Jean, died in 1966. The elder Medecin became mayor in 1928. Medecin, who resigned Sept. 16, faces charges that he overstepped his authority by acting as the city's accountant in renegotiating the municipal debt. He is now in Argentina but must appear in a Nice court Wednesday or be declared a fugitive. Medecin calls the charges a frame-up by his political enemies.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Calls Solzhenitsyn Article Disrespectful
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with quotes and details. No pickup. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today rejected exiled writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn's recent proposals for replacing the Soviet Union with an all-Slavic state as disrespectful to other ethnic groups. In his first public remarks on Solzhenitsyn's suggestions, the 59-year-old Soviet leader said they were unacceptable and sharply conflicted with his own views on how to restructure relations between the 15 Soviet republics. ``As a politician, his views on the future of our multinational state are unacceptable,'' Gorbachev told the Supreme Soviet legislature. ``They are far from reality. ... These views have a destructive character.'' Gorbachev's remarks put him into a competition with Solzhenitsyn, a Nobel laureate, for the hearts and minds of the Russian people and underscored the writer's increasing importance. In his article, which appeared Sept. 18 in the reformist newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda, Solzhenitsyn, 71, called for spirituality over materialism and a unified Slavic nation. He criticized Gorbachev's reforms. Solzhenitsyn suggested forming a ``Russian Union,'' which would include the republics of Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine. A large part of Kazakhstan would also be included. The other 12 Soviet republics, including the rest of Kazakhstan, have different cultures and should be allowed to secede, he said. It was the first piece he has written directly for the Russian people since he was exiled and stripped of his citizenship in 1974. Gorbachev said Solzhenitsyn's political views are ``all in the past, the past Russia, the czarist monarchy.'' ``For me,'' the president added, ``this is unacceptable.'' Gorbachev told lawmakers his goal in restructuring relations among the republics was a ``union of sovereign states where every people feels well and realizes its potential.'' He responded to Solzhenitsyn's article at the request of a legislator from Kazakhstan, who objected to the call for Russians to take control of some of his republic's territory. The lawmaker, Erkegali Rakhmadiev, said in an interview later that what Solzhenitsyn was proposing was a ``Hitlerite, fascist approach'' to ethnic relations. Some Ukrainians also bristled at Solzhenitsyn's proposed new union. The independent news agency Postfactum said Tuesday the regional governing council in Lvov, in the western Ukraine, approved a statement saying that in Solzhenitsyn's article, ``We are once again cast in the role of a small brother.'' Most of the Soviet Union's republics already have launched drives to wrest more power from Moscow or to secede, and the discussion of Solzhenitsyn's article came during debate on a new treaty to govern relations among the republics. The Soviet leader spoke from a lectern in the Supreme Soviet's white marble meeting hall in the Kremlin in a soft and calm voice, making a rare public reference to his own Russian heritage and to his roots in southern Russia. His deliberative tone contrasted sharply with his angry, loud pronouncements in recent days in legislative debates on economic reform. After reading the article twice, Gorbachev said he was ``possessed by very conflicting feelings.'' ``As a Russian, I fully grasped the pain and alarm for the fate of the Russian people, for the fate of Russia. But at the same time, as a Russian I resolutely cannot agree with Alexander Isayevich's position in relation to other peoples. In the most mild evaluation, this is a disrespectful position.'' Despite his criticism of Solzhenitsyn's proposals, Gorbachev praised him as a ``great person'' with interesting thoughts. Solzhenitsyn, who lives in Canvendish, Vt., described life in Soviet prison camps in such acclaimed works as ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich,'' and ``The Gulag Archipelago.'' He was deported after the latter book was published in the West. Gorbachev restored the writer's citizenship last month, although Solzhenitsyn has expressed reluctance about returning.

DOC.HEAD: Residents of Brooklyn Project Where Child Was Shot: `It's a Terror'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 9th graf, ``Fifteen children,'' with 4 grafs to update with another child shot. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Many Cypress..'. Myqueen in 19th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A resident of a Brooklyn housing project where a 12-year-old girl was killed says that if soldiers can be sent to the Middle East they also should be sent to New York's war zones. ``The tenants here want the National Guard brought in. They feel that if the National Guard can be sent to Iraq, then they ought to be brought to Brooklyn,'' said the resident of the Cypress Hills project, who identified herself only as Mildred. ``Just that nobody cares about us,'' she added. On Monday, children played near a patch of blood where Laykama Taylor - known as Sugar - was shot in the back while playing Sunday afternoon. The Daily News reported today that Laykama may have been killed because of a family squabble, rather than being the victim of a bullet intended for someone else. Her aunt, Pee Taylor, told the newspaper that Laykama had argued with another 12-year-old three days earlier and that older members of both girl's families had been dragged into the fight. ``That wasn't a stray. That bullet was meant for her,'' the aunt said. On Friday in Harlem, another 12-year-old girl was shot and wounded while playing in a playground. Yet another youngster, a 13-year-old girl, was shot in the head Monday night while sitting on a bench in the same Cypress Hills housing project. The girl, whose name was not released, was sitting on a bench with a friend, said police Officer Scott Block. They heard shots and started running when the teen-ager noticed she had been hit. She was in stable condition at Brookdale Hospital, Block said. He said she was either shot with birdshot or pellets from a BB gun. Sixteen children have been shot in New York City since July 22, police said. Laykama was the sixth to die. Many Cypress Hills residents say they are so overwhelmed by the drug-related violence they simply don't leave their apartments. Some tenants, like Mildred, want the National Guard called in. ``It's like a terror all the time here,'' said Trina Williams, 21, who was walking near the project Monday with her daughter, Tanara, 4. ``You have to look out for your life all the time here. I was homeless before I came here and you'll take anything when you're homeless, but I didn't know it would be this bad.'' Mayor David Dinkins called Taylor ``the latest victim of the epidemic of gunfire that is turning our cities into war zones.'' Dinkins called again for tighter gun controls. Another resident of the bleak complex in Brooklyn's East New York section said there are about three shootings per week at Cypress Hills. ``This is the OK Corral,'' said Latoya Williams, 16. ``I almost been shot a lot of times. You just bend over and you hear some bullet go whizzing by.'' On Monday, two teen-agers who knew Laykama Taylor came to the playground where she was killed. They said their mothers want to move but have nowhere to go. ``It's getting worse. Kids can't even come out and play anymore,'' said Myqueen Divers, 14. ``I'll be outside and I'll hear shots. I get really scared and I start panicking. I run to the closest place I can find.'' Kareem Pope, 13, said his mother wants him to stay inside their apartment when he's not in school. ``The place is terrible,'' he said. ``They should take the guns away from people. There's guns and more guns all the time.'' Also on Sunday in Brooklyn, 15-year-old Salima Brown was shot in the leg as she stood with a group of friends in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section. Brown said shooting at random at groups of youths is ``how they have fun'' in her neighborhood. ``Usually they just shoot to make you run and they start laughing,'' said Brown, who was treated at a hospital after a bullet passed through her thigh.

DOC.HEAD: Six Villagers Reported Killed, 20 Abducted by Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels shot and killed six Sinhalese villagers and abducted 20 Moslems in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, military officials and residents said today. The villagers were killed Monday night when a force of about 40 rebels raided the predominantly Sinhalese village of Gajabapura, 150 miles northeast of Colombo, the officials said. They said the rebels had planned a massacre but were beaten back by government-armed home guard units and villagers. The dead included a family of four and two elderly men, said the officials, speaking on condition of anonymity. At least 10 homes were burned by the rebels. The 20 Moslems, all males, were abducted early today from Ullikulam village, eight miles south of the town of Batticaloa, residents said. The residents, contacted by telephone, said they heard gunshots shortly after rebels raided homes and seized the Moslems, but the fate of the captives was not immediately clear. The village residents spoke on condition of anonymity. On Friday, Moslem home guards allegedly hacked to death at least 16 Tamil villagers at Podukudiyirru colony, seven miles east of Batticaloa. Tamil politicians Monday demanded the disbanding of Moslem home guards and accused the government of being indifferent to the killings. Elsewhere, the military said seven Tamil rebels were shot and killed Monday in skirmishes with government troops in the north and east. At least 14,000 people have died since Tamil militia began a campaign in 1983 against the Sinhalese-dominated government to carve out a separate Tamil homeland in the north and east of the island. The mainly Hindu Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people, have long accused the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population, of discrimination. In another development, the government said it would investigate allegations that Israel simultaneously trained Sri Lanka's security forces and the Tamil guerrillas they were fighting. A statement from President Ranasinghe Premadasa's office said the probe was ordered after the allegations appeared in a book by a former member of the Israeli intelligence agency, Mossad. The Israeli government has said the book, ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer,'' by Victor Ostrovsky, is full of lies.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Senate to Approve Treaty Ending Division of Germany
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today asked the Senate to swiftly approve an historic treaty ending the division of Germany and relinquishing all rights and responsibilities of the four victorious powers from World War II. Bush called the accord ``the culmination of more than four decades of Western resolve and determination, from the darkest hours of the Cold War to the bright new horizons that stretch before us.'' At a ceremony in the Rose Garden, Bush signed a letter formally transmitting the treaty to the Senate. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and West German Ambassador Juergen Ruhfus witnessed the signing. The treaty was signed in Moscow on Sept. 12 by the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France after six months of negotiations. The four powers will formally retain their rights over Germany until they all have ratified the treaty. However, the four countries agreed to ``suspend'' their rights Oct. 1, two days before Germany becomes unified through the merging of East and West Germany. ``It is wholly fitting that Germany formally and irrevocably achieve its unified status at the earliest possible moment, unfettered by four-power rights, shared by the Soviet Union, which are now outmoded and unnecessary,'' Bush's letter said. After the defeat of the Nazis in 1945, the four allies divided Germany and its capital into four occupation zones, which became East and West Germany and East and West Berlin. The treaty ends the division of the country and calls for the Soviet Union to complete the withdrawal of its estimated 370,000 troops from East Germany by 1994. U.S., British and French troops will remain stationed in Berlin during the interim. In his remarks, Bush said the treaty ``will end the artificial division of Germany and Berlin and it will restore to Germany sovereignty over all its territory and end all remaining four power rights and responsibilities. ``This agreement clears the way to achievement of the goal we Americans have long shared with the German people, a united, democratic and sovereign Germany,'' the president said. In his letter to the Senate, Bush said the treaty ``represents a major achievement for our German allies, who have not forgotten the past or the role Germany once played in the horrors of 1933-45, but who have demonstrated over four decades of steadfast support for democracy and the Western alliance what the world can expect from the united Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: Bus Crash Kills 1, Injures 13
DOC.TEXT: A tour bus carrying members of a senior center on a gambling junket hit a car and overturned down an embankment, killing one person and seriously injuring 13, authorities said. Heavy rain was falling when the car skidded on U.S. 395 and the bus ran into it, according to Nevada Highway Patrol Sgt. Marvin Davenport. The Majestic Tours bus was carrying senior citizens from Norwalk, Calif., to Bally's Resort-Hotel in Reno, about 10 miles north of the accident site. The driver of the car, Lynne Hammill, an off-duty highway patrol officer, was pronounced dead on arrival at Washoe Medical Cente shortly after the accident Monday afternoon. The bus driver, Greg Armenta, 27, said Hammill's southbound car appeared to spin out of control on the rain-slicked road. ``I tried to avoid hitting it, but I couldn't get out of the way,'' Armenta said. ``After that, I don't know what happened. I tried to control the bus, but I couldn't.'' The bus overturned down an embankment. One passenger was listed in serious condition today; 12 others were in fair or stable condition. Many of the remaining 45 bus passengers were treated for minor cuts, bruises and sprains and released, hospital officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Keating's Lawyers Appeal $5 Million Bail
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court will decide whether jailed savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating's $5 million bail is excessive in a criminal fraud case involving the collapse of his Lincoln Savings. Keating, 66, contends he is being made a scapegoat, is broke and cannot defend himself against the host of lawsuits against him if he is locked up. ``He is more than $5 million in debt. He has no assets that are not already pledged to creditors. At most, Keating could post a $500,000 bail, and then only through the help of his children,'' his lawyers said in papers filed with the state appeals court Monday. After a two-day hearing last week, Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner refused to lower the $5 million bail, saying the charges against him are so serious he might flee. That amount is far too high for Keating to meet and 50 times higher than the bail imposed in identical cases, his lawyers said. They said he has shown he is no flight risk by never dodging any proceeding against him, even though he's known for a year he was under criminal as well as civil investigation. It wasn't clear when the 2nd District Court of Appeal would issue a decision on the bail appeal. Three other defendants are free. They had their bails lowered from the original $1 million each to $100,000 or $200,000, which they posted. All four are due back in court Oct. 5 to enter a plea to charges of defrauding investors in Irvine-based Lincoln. Keating and three former top officers of his companies are charged with misleading investors about the safety of risky junk bonds sold at Lincoln branches. The bonds were issued by Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., which Keating headed. Keating and the others are charged with ordering employees to steer Lincoln depositors away from insured certificates of deposit and into the bonds. Many of the buyers were elderly and lost their life savings. All told, 17,458 investors lost more than $250 million, prosecutors said. The charges do not address the most central allegations in the Lincoln case: that he looted the thrift and made huge political donations to politicians who then pressured regulators to go easy on Lincoln. Private analysts have estimated Lincoln's failure may cost taxpayers $2 billion. That would make it the most costliest thrift failure yet, surpassing the $1.7 billion bailout of Miami's CenTrust Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes Rose 2.1 Percent in August
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes rose 2.1 percent in August, continuing a three-month rebound, a real estate trade group said today. It forecast a slowdown in the fourth quarter because of rising mortgage rates. The National Association of Realtors said house resales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.40 million units compared to July's revised 3.33 million rate. Sales rose 0.9 percent in June from the 1990 low of 3.30 million units in May. ``Despite rising rates, the resale market is stable and slightly better than July,'' said Norman D. Flynn, the Realtors president. ``The strength we see largely is due to people who are buying homes in less populous areas and recreational areas.'' However, Realtors chief economist John A. Tuccillo said mortgage rates will rise during most of the fourth quarter, having a negative impact on existing-home sales. Fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage rates rose from 9.84 percent to 10.24 percent in August, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. They averaged 10.16 percent at the end of last week. The Realtors also said the national median existing-home price was $97,000 in August, down 1.3 percent from July but up 1.3 percent from a year earlier. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Flynn said a decrease in the national median home price from July to August indicates sellers are bringing down prices in response to rising interest rates. ``This is a typical occurrence,'' he said. Sales climbed 6.9 percent to 1.40 million in the South, where the median price was $86,900. They rose 2.2 percent to 950,000 units in the Midwest. The median price there was $75,000. But sales fell 1.8 percent in the sluggish Northeast to 550,000 units. The median price in the Northeast was $144,900. They also dropped 3.8 percent to 530,000 units in the West, where the median price was $141,600.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Killed In Car Crash, Four U.S. Marines Injured
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A Saudi civilian was killed and six people, including four U.S. Marines, were injured in a two-vehicle collision on a Saudi expressway, U.S. military officials said today. They said the accident, involving a civilian taxi and a Marine vehicle, occurred Monday afternoon on the six-lane highway 18 miles north of Jubail, a major oil port on the Persian Gulf. A statement issued by U.S. officials said the Saudi victim was ``pronounced dead at the scene of the accident,'' and the six injured were taken to a military hospital. The unidentified civilian was the first Saudi citizen reported killed in an incident involving American military personnel since the buildup in Operation Desert Shield began in early August. Four Americans are known to have died; three in mishaps involving military vehicles and one aboard a U.S. navy ship. One of the two Saudis injured was listed in critical condition with multiple injuries and trauma. The other was reported in stable condition with skull fractures, the statement said. Three of the Marines were admitted for observation with injuries ranging from concussion to cuts. The fourth Marine was treated for minor injuries and released. The names of the injured Marines were withheld until their next of kin had been informed. The statement said the cause of the accident was being investigated. The type of Marine vehicle involved was not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Storage Tank at Port Terminal Explodes
DOC.TEXT: A storage tank at a petroleum products terminal exploded, killing one worker, officials said. The workman was sandblasting the terminal Monday afternoon when a tank holding 35,000 gallons of isopropyl alcohol exploded at GATX Corp., a jet fuel and petroleum products transporter, said Matt Ballaban, fire department spokesman. The victim was not identified. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known, said Holly Rea, a spokeswoman for Chicago-based GATX. The force of the explosion sent the tank's lid up to 100 yards into the air. No other tanks were involved, although a nearby building sustained some damage, Ms. Rea said.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Find in Favor of Plaintiff In Tobacco Trial But Give No Award
DOC.TEXT: Jurors agreed that smoking killed a man whose family pursued a $17 million wrongful death lawsuit against the American Tobacco Co. and a distributor, but they did not award any financial damages. ``We decided both parties were at fault,'' said David Roach, foreman for the 12 Lafayette County jurors. ``We came to a decision we could all live with when viewing the alternative of a hung jury.'' Roach said he and eight other jurors ``thought the American Tobacco Co. acted in an irresponsible way. It was a very close decision. We were fairly near a hung jury, frankly.'' The jury decided 9-3 Monday that 35 years of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day had caused the 1987 lung cancer death of 50-year-old Nathan Henry Horton. The jurors, half of them smokers, heard 11 days of testimony about smoking risks and whether Horton ran them by choice. Deliberations began Monday and took about 5{ hours. The suit, filed by Horton and continued by his family, named the American Tobacco Co. and Greenwood distributor New Deal Tobacco and Candy Co. A first trial ended in a mistrial last year when jurors could not reach a verdict. It was considered the most significant such case since a New Jersey jury awarded a widower $400,000 in 1988 after deciding a cigarette company was partly responsible for his wife's death from lung cancer. In that case, an appeals court this year overturned the award and ordered a new trial. After Monday's verdict, Horton family attorney Don Barrett of Lexington asked Circuit Judge Eugene Bogen to award some sort of damages. He also asked for a new trial on the issue of punitive damages. Bogen said he would rule later. Horton's widow, Ella Mae Horton of Lexington, refused to answer questions as she left the courtroom. Tobacco company lawyers said the verdict showed jurors were unwilling to decide whether Horton or cigarettes were more responsible for his death. One of them, Jim Upshaw, told jurors in closing arguments Monday that Horton was a ``risk-taker and he made a free choice to smoke.'' The family's attorneys contended Horton he was unaware of the magnitude of the risks. The Hortons wanted $2 million in actual damages and $15 million in punitive damages. Warning labels have been required on cigarette packages since 1966.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Matsushita In Buyout Talks with MCA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with MCA confirming talks under way, but not indentifying company; stock price jumps. A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Entertainment giant MCA Inc., parent of Universal Studios, confirmed today that it is in buyout talks after a newspaper identified the potential suitor as Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. of Japan. The news sent the company's stock price soaring 67 percent. The Wall Street Journal said people it did not identify who were familiar with the talks said the huge Japanese consumer electronics manufacturer was considering acquiring MCA for $80 to $90 a share, or a range of about $6.7 billion to $7.5 billion. In Japan today, a Matsushita official who spoke on condition of anonymity said MCA is one of the companies with which Matsushita is involved in talks, but that nothing has been decided. Later, MCA issued a statement in which it confirmed it is ``in discussions with a major international company regarding a possible negotiated acquisition of MCA.'' ``The discussions are continuing on a friendly basis. No agreement has been reached. There is no assurance that an agreement will be reached,'' the statement said. If the deal materialized, it would be the second major transaction in which a Japanese manufacturer of electronic hardware acquired a U.S. maker of entertainment programs. Last year, Sony Corp. acquired Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $5 billion. The deal stirred criticism about Japanese control of American assets. MCA, based in Universal City, Calif., is the parent of Universal Studios and produces films and TV shows in addition to having interests in publishing and theme parks. MCA stock has been trading well below the deal price, and its shares rocketed higher today on the New York Stock Exchange. MCA climbed $23 to $57.50 a share when trading opened. Matsushita's brands include Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. The company had revenue of about $44.4 billion in the year ended March 31. The Journal report said individuals with knowledge of the talks cautioned that it was far from certain that a deal would materialize. They said that regulatory barriers that did not figure in the Sony-Columbia deal remain. MCA, for instance, owns an independent television station, WWOR in Secaucus, N.J., which a foreign company would be prevented from owning. MCA earned $191.77 million on revenue of $3.38 billion last year, a 16 percent increase over earnings of $164.91 million and $$2.90 billion in revenue during 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LOS ANGELES
Marines Ground Four Harrier Jets
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs with Marine Corps confirming the groundings, picks up 6th graf pvs, ``We simply...
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps has grounded four Harrier jets, similar to those deployed in Saudi Arabia, because of faulty sensors that help stabilize the fighter-bombers, the service said today. Col. Stuart Wagner said the jets, which can take off vertically and hover like helicopters, were found to have defective ``rate sensor assemblies.'' The assemblies are equivalent to the power steering on a car. ``It's not critical to flying the aircraft safely, but it's something we want to fix,'' he said. Officials determined the rate sensor assemblies made by Northrop Corp. are wearing out faster than projected. Wagner said the grounded Harriers are based at Kaneohe Bay Marine Corps Air Station in Hawaii. The defects, he said, will have no effect on the Harriers sent to Saudi Arabia in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The spokesman did not know when the Harriers were grounded or how long they would be out of commission. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 fraud charges of improperly testing the sensors and a cruise missile guidance system for the Air Force. The Harrier groundings were first reported today by The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times. The Marines' fleet of nearly 200 AV-8B Harriers was expected to come up during a hearing today before the House Committee on Government Operations. ``We simply don't know whether the weapons will do their job,'' said Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., a committee member. ``We may find that some of what our soldiers depend upon will not perform up to specification. It may threaten the lives of many of our men and women in uniform.'' No spare sensor assemblies are available, forcing the Marines to park the $22 million planes as problems arise. No other company produces the assemblies. A fifth Harrier was to be grounded soon and the grounding of the rest of the fleet was scheduled at a rate of three planes every two months, the newspapers said. Last year, Northrop was suspended from receiving new contracts for the sensor, among other products. Northrop officials said Monday they had no knowledge of the groundings.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Saber-Rattling Makes $40 Oil Appear Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-5th grafs pvs, `The surge...', with 5 grafs to UPDATE with today's benchmark price up 5 cents in early trading. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `That would...'. A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil is within striking distance of $40 a barrel, which would be equal to the record set 10 years ago and twice the price before the Persian Gulf crisis. ``One piece of fresh news, and $40 is there,'' Dean Witter Reynold Inc. trader Ed Kevelson predicted Monday, after crude futures crossed the $39 threshold for the first time on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The price of light sweet crude, the benchmark grade, peaked for the day Monday at $39.20 before settling at $38.25 for November delivery, a record close on the exchange, which began trading crude futures in 1983. The oil markets slowed a bit this morning, with light sweet crude trading 5 cents higher at $38.30 a barrel in early trading. ``We've just seen people step back,'' Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said today. ``There really isn't fresh news from the Middle East.'' Monday's rise came just a week after oil futures had first hit $33 per barrel on the exchange, setting off a steady climb that has shattered records in days or even hours. The surge Monday was set off by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's statement that he would rather go to war than let the U.N. trade embargo strangle his country. ``Because of that radio broadcast on Sunday, people are anticipating much higher costs in the future,'' Hittle had said Monday. ``People in the market are talking about $40 a barrel as being the next target.'' That would be almost double the price before Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and right at the level of cash prices that were paid in 1980, after the Iranian revolution. Higher oil creates a threat of inflation and typically leads to increases in gasoline prices at the pump. An industry survey released Sunday said the average price at the pump hit an all-time high of more than $1.38 a gallon, up about 20 cents since the invasion. But $40 oil today would not be as expensive, in inflation-adjusted terms, as $40 oil was in 1980. Oil would have to hit about $57 per barrel in 1990 dollars to equal the real cost of oil from a decade earlier, said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. That is not far from the figure of $60 per barrel that some groups have used as an estimate for how high oil prices could rise during a shooting war in the Mideast. ``If there's a shooting war, the sky's the limit until governments step in and put in price controls and rationing and all that,'' Dodge said. Some experts have pointed out that gasoline has thus far not kept up with the rise in crude during the crisis. ``Forty dollars for crude oil is up about $20 from where it was before all this unpleasantness got started,'' Dodge said. ``That $20 increase is about 48 cents per gallon, and so far, the price of gasoline is only up about half of that. It eventually could go up another 25 cents.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Texas School Finance Law Unconstitutional
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to CORRECT in 4th graf that judge said access to funds was not equal, sted access to state aid; UPDATE with comment from governor. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `He held...'. SUBS 14th graf, `State Rep...', to delete now-redundant first reference to Clements; DELETES 17th graf, `Clements wasn't..', now outdated.
DOC.TEXT: The Texas system of financing schools remains unconstitutional despite this year's overhaul by the Legislature, a judge ruled today. State District Judge Scott McCown said the $14 billion-a-year system is still flawed. But he deferred making any immediate changes, giving the Legislature until Sept. 1, 1991, to act. ``Our need for education is too great and our wealth too modest for inequitable funding our schools to be tolerated,'' McCown wrote. The judge said the finance system doesn't give all schools ``substantially equal'' access to funds. The Texas Supreme Court ruled unanimously last October that there were ``glaring disparities'' between rich and poor school districts, violating a requirement in the state Constitution for an ``efficient system'' of public schools. Schools were funded with local property taxes, state aid and a small amount of federal funds. But because of disparities in property wealth, annual spending per student among districts ranged from $2,112 to $19,333, the court said. The new school finance plan was adopted in June by the Legislature after four special sessions. Lawmakers anted up an additional $528 million for public schools in 1990-91 and made numerous changes that backers said would improve education. But poor school districts challenged the new funding plan. They argued that it was no different from the old system. The state will appeal today's ruling, Gov. Bill Clements said. ``I don't agree with his judgment at all,'' Clements said. ``He's a young judge. Perhaps the Supreme Court in its review will reconsider that opinion.'' Kevin O'Hanlon, a lawyer for the Texas Education Agency, said the 52-page decision didn't give state officials enough direction on how fix the system. ``He held it unconstitutional because it wasn't good enough, but he didn't give us a heck of a lot of guidance on what would be good enough,'' said O'Hanlon, a former assistant attorney general. He said that unless the courts tell the state how to make a constitutional system, the litigation could last for years. Rick Gray, a lawyer for poor school districts that challenged the school funding system, applauded the ruling. He said McCown did ``a very exhaustive, thorough analysis. ... We think it's a great day for all schoolchildren and we hope the Legislature will set about the task of fixing the system in the future.'' State Rep. Paul Colbert, a member of the House Public Education Committee, blamed Clements for blocking an alternative finance plan that poor school districts would have accepted. Clements killed that proposal by vetoing the taxes needed to pay for it. ``It's entirely because of Gov. Clements' foot-dragging and the Republican legislators who upheld his veto that we're back in the court again, and we're literally about to turn over the keys of the schoolroom to the courts,'' Colbert said. Clements killed two school finance reform plans because they each relied on a half-cent increase in the state sales tax. He later agreed to a quarter-cent increase in the plan overturned by today's decision. McCown allowed the school finance system to remain in place this school year. But he retains jurisdiction over the case. The judge said that if the Legislature fails to devise a constitutional school finance plan by next September, he would consider stopping the spending of state and local tax money, or imposing a school spending plan.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Immigration Checks at London Airports
DOC.TEXT: U.S. immigration officers began checking passports Tuesday at London's Heathrow and Gatwick airports in an effort to reduce long delays clearing customs in the United States, the U.S. Embassy said. The 45 officers will check travel documents on this side of the Atlantic for four months as part of an expermental program. A record number of tourists to the United States has resulted in routine delays of two hours at busy U.S. airports and waits of up to five hours for some flights have been reported. Passengers from Britain represent a quarter of all international travelers entering the United States, immigration officials said. All passengers on selected flights on nine airlines to New York, Boston, Dallas, Los Angeles, Cincinnati, Charlotte, Newark and Miami will be checked before boarding in London. Officers will use a computer with access to U.S. immigration data. If the pilot program is successful, the British Home Office said it would consider a reciprocal permanent arrangement with immigration checks in major U.S. airports for travelers to Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed, 35 Injured in Bus Crash
LaserPhoto LON2
DOC.TEXT: A tour bus crashed over a cliff in the Mount Tamborine area Tuesday, killing seven people and injuring at least 35, some seriously, authorities said. The bus was carrying 54 senior citizens believed to be from New South Wales state, police said. It came to rest halfway down the mountain. The crash occurred in a mountainous region of Queensland state in an area known as the Gold Coast hinterland, about 35 miles south of here. The bus was returning from a day trip in nearby Coolangatta.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Kills 18 In Central Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: A typhoon that struck two Vietnamese provinces submerged or swept away more than 140,000 homes and left 18 people dead and 11 missing, the official Radio Hanoi said. The broadcast was an update on the destruction of Typhoon Ed, which hit the coastal provinces of Quang Nam-Danang and Quang Tri on Sept. 18. A transcript of the Saturday broadcast was seen in Bangkok on Tuesday. It said 39 people also were injured in the storm, which brought severe flooding. Many schools, hospitals and medical aid stations were damaged or torn down, and flooding also damaged wide areas of rice fields.

DOC.HEAD: Kew Garden Raises Money from Sale of Exotic Benches
DOC.TEXT: Nine garden benches carved from exotic trees uprooted from Kew Gardens by a devastating 1987 storm were sold at auction Tuesday for $21,000, Sotheby's auctioneers said. The money will go to the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew for conservation work at the gardens in west London. Two benches were made from each of five fallen trees: a 65-foot white ash, a 75-foot North American red oak, a tulip tree, a Roble beech from Chile and a Norway maple. One of the oak tree benches did not sell because it failed to reach the minimum bid amount set by the auctioneers, a Sotheby's spokeswoman said. She did not know what the minimum price was. The other oak bench was sold for $2,170 to an unnamed British buyer, said the spokeswoman at Sotheby's Billingshurst office, where the auction was held, 40 miles south of London. The tulip tree benches fetched the highest price, Sotheby's said. A Japanese buyer, bidding by telephone, paid $5,900 for the pair, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Facing Awesome Range of Problems in New Political Season
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Prime Minister Brian Mulroney heads into the new political season with an awesome array of worries ranging from rebellious Indians and unpopular taxes to threats of a breakup of the confederation. Mulroney is in big trouble with voters, scoring 14 percent or less in the polls. But the opposition Liberals have been unable to capitalize on Mulroney's growing unpopularity and were drubbed in two recent provincial elections. Many Canadians feel the country is leaderless and adrift. Both Mulroney and Liberal Party leader Jean Chretien slipped out of sight for most of the summer and both may ultimately suffer for that. Mulroney's government is the most unpopular since the Gallup organization began taking polls in the country 50 years ago. The polls say the Progressive Conservatives are favored by only 20 percent of the population. At the end of July, Gallup asked Canadians who would make the best prime minister - Mulroney, Chretien or socialist New Democratic Party chief Audrey McLaughlin. Of those questioned, 30 percent chose Chretien, 18 percent McLaughlin and 14 percent Mulroney. Thirty-eight percent rejected all three or said they didn't know which one they liked. ``There is a conjunction of events that has made the public rather cranky about politicians in general, more so than usual,'' said Ron Watts, a professor of political science at Queen's University and director of the Institute for Intergovernmental Relations. ``We are going through an unusually bad patch.'' The bad patch includes: -A country sliding into recession. -Failure of the Meech Lake agreement to get Quebec to sign the constitution. -A standoff between Mohawk Indians and the army over land rights. -A new 7 percent goods and services tax scheduled to go into effect in January on virtually everything. -The commitment of Canadian ships and fighters in the Persian Gulf crisis. -A series of patronage appointments to the Senate, including Conservative Nova Scotia Premier John Buchanan, currently under criminal investigation. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa has formed a commission to study what steps the French-speaking province should take next - independence, sovereignty in association with Canada, or some other form of relationship with the central government. A report is due next spring. To make matters worse, Mulroney's former Quebec lieutenant, Lucien Bouchard, betrayed him and formed a separatist Bloc Quebecois in the House of Commons dedicated to independence for Quebec. Mulroney dismisses the bad news in the polls. ``What matters is where you are on election night, not some two or 2{ years before,'' he said. But Mulroney's low profile for much of the summer has led many Canadians to feel he has been avoiding the tough questions. ``It seems to have been an eternity this summer, and through all this, Mr. Mulroney has pulled a disappearing act,'' said Liberal Jean-Robert Gauthier. Chretien, whose showing in the polls has slipped since he won the Liberal leadership in June, also is suffering. Bad news for the Conservatives usually means good news for the Liberals. But not lately. The fallout has become impossible to read. Both parties were thrashed in the Ontario provincial elections in August. The socialist New Democrats ousted the Liberals from the government of Canada's richest province. And in the Manitoba provincial elections a week later, the Conservatives won a majority, shoving the Liberals into third place behind the New Democrats - who are to the left of the Liberals. Ontario New Democratic Party leader Bob Rae profited from voter unhappiness with Liberal Premier David Peterson. That disgruntlement stemmed partly from new provincial taxes and a political party financing scandal. But voters appeared to be put off mainly because Peterson called an unnecessary election two years early, a move seen as purely self-serving. Fringe movements are growing. The rightist Reform Party, a child of western Canada, recently moved onto the national scene with 6 percent in the polls. Bouchard's Bloc Quebecois has 5 percent. ``Ultimately, if we end up with an array of regional parties, that will seriously weaken the federal system,'' Watts said. No matter what one's opinion of Mulroney, he can hardly be called a do-nothing prime minister, having worked hard for the free trade agreement with the United States, the goods and services tax and the Meech Lake agreement. ``The trouble is people are not happy with what he is doing,'' Watts said. ``The perception of weakness weakens the leader even if the leader is not really weak.'' It seems the Canadian people themselves are unsure of what they want. Said University of Calgary analyst David Bercuson: ``Because they don't really indicate any overall general direction to the leadership, the leadership doesn't know what to do.''

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Says War Could Come Soon in Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with speech delivered, Shevardnadze also calling for tribunal to deal with world terrorists. Pickup 11th, `Secretary..' Security Council session expected to begin about 4:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze today said that war could break out in the Persian Gulf at any moment, and called Iraq's invasion of Kuwait an ``act of terrorism.'' In a speech to the General Assembly, Shevardnadze referred to Aug. 2, the date of the invasion, as ``Black Thursday,'' and called the action ``irrational.'' ``Iraq flagrantly violated the United Nations Charter, the principles of international law, the universally recognized norms of morality and the standards of civilized behavior,'' the minister said. He spoke in Russian and his remarks were translated into the many languages of those attending. Shevardnadze spoke on the second day of the General Assembly sesssion. On Monday, leaders from France, Iran, Brazil, Argentina, Poland and Indonesia condemned Iraq for invading Kuwait and demanded an immediate pullout. The Soviet foreign minister hinted at the possibility of a United Nations military operation in the gulf region, noting that ``the United Nations has the power to suppress `acts of aggression.' '' ``There is ample evidence that this right can be exercised,'' he said. But such an step should come only after all peaceful, non-military forms of pressure have been applied, he said. Up until the invasion, the Soviet Union was Iraq's strongest ally. But the Soviets have firmly sided with the U.S.-led effort to isolate and pressure the Baghdad government. The Soviets have said they might be willing to participate in a U.N. military effort in the gulf provided that the Soviets share command. The Soviet foreign minister termed Iraq's actions a ``major affront to mankind'' and added: ``Unless we find a way to respond to it and cope with the situation, our civilization will be thrown back by half a century.'' ``A great war may break out on the gulf region any day, any moment. An act of terrorism has been perpetrated against the emerging new world order.'' Shevardnadze also called for the creation of an international tribunal to judge individuals who ``declare the threat ... for purposes of blackmail of using weapons of mass destruction, hostage-taking or mass terror.'' It was a clear reference to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who has threatened to destroy Israel if the Security Council's economic embargo causes his people to suffer, and has moved Western detainees to strategic sites in Iraq to serve as ``human shields'' against any attack. Such a tribunal could also judge those who resort to torture, terrorism, atrocities, or any other ``grave crimes against humanity,'' said Shevardnadze. Later today, the Soviet minister was to preside over a special meeting of the Security Council attended by up to 12 foreign ministers. The session is expected to end with passage of a resolution extending to air corridors the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected to fill the U.S. seat in the 15-member council. On Monday, after Shevardnadze and British Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd held a two-hour private meeting, reporters asked if the air embargo would be approved. ``I hope so,'' said Hurd. Shevardnadze nodded confidently. He said through a translator: ``We want action. There is no other way.'' ``It is a fairly balanced draft that takes care of the safety of air flights, but at the same time, continues the idea of sanctions until Iraq agrees to withdraw from Kuwait,'' said Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov, president of the Security Council. The air embargo would ask all nations to bar flights to and from Iraq, but it would not authorize shooting down airplanes. On Monday, the council adopted a brief resolution calling for aid to nations suffering economic hardship from loss of trade with Iraq. They include Jordan and about a dozen other nations. Every speaker who strode to the rostrum of the General Assembly on Monday denounced Iraq for its Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. In his address, French President Francois Mitterrand declared: ``Kuwait is a sovereign state, a member of the international community. In the name of what can one decide that this state has ceased to exist?'' The Iraqi U.N. Ambassador, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, listened impassively at his seat. Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, stayed away after U.S. officials barred him from coming on a special Iraqi flight. Iran's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, told the gathering that his government would obey all Security Council sanctions and embargoes targeting Iraq. However, a security and oil industry sources have said Iran has agreed to provide ``humanitarian'' food and medicine shipments across the common border with Iraq in return for 200,000 barrels of refined oil a day. Velayati also criticized the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf region - which intends to counter Iraqi - as destabilizing.

DOC.HEAD: Beirut Memories Linger Amid Promises `It Won't Happen Again'
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Pentagon rules on coverage of operations in Saudi Arabia prohibit disclosing the precise location of U.S. military installations. ---

Chief Warrant Officer Charles Rowe shipped out of Beirut a day before the 1983 truck-bombing that killed 241 U.S. serviceman. He had a private vow for any terrorist who tried it here. ``I'll promise you he'll suffer,'' he said. ``We're going to hurt him.'' Rowe and fellow Marines guarding a vital port in northeast Saudi Arabia said no comparisons should be drawn between Lebanon and the new mission in the Mideast, Operation Desert Shield. But they concede their security planning is shrouded by memories of the Beirut attack. ``I wouldn't mind evening the score,'' Rowe said. The memories are so strong that the commander of the Persian Gulf port's security unit that reporters visited on Tuesday said at times he had to urge superiors not to go overboard with the precautions. ``Any time you overdo it you bring attention to it,'' Lt. Col. Tom Hayden said. ``Any dumb terrorist can say, `Hey, that looks important.' I'd just as soon keep a low profile.'' The port is far from the Iraqi ground forces to the north in Kuwait and Iraq has no navy to speak of. So Hayden's main worries are air or terrorist-style ground attacks. He says he's confident American fighter jets could turn back any Iraqi fighters, and the Army is helping the Marines with a Patriot missile battery at the port designed to destroy any incoming missiles. That leaves a car or truck bombing as the main threat, Hayden said, adding such an attack could come from a group sponsored by Iraq's Saddam Hussein or any of the other groups ``who have been trying to blow up Americans for 10 years.'' His unit was on maximum alert for several days two weeks ago after ``we were told something was possible and I reacted to it.'' He said the heightened alert was based on ``one specific piece of information,'' but refused to discuss it. ``We have since lessened and we're at what I would call a routine posture right now,'' he said. Routine still means constant patrols along the Persian Gulf and the perimeter of the sprawling port, a camp for Marines as well as a major arrival point for equipment and supplies for the thousands of American troops here. Hayden, like the men below him, tries to steer visitors away from the Beirut analogy. In Lebanon, the Marines were part of a peacekeeping force, crowded together in a makeshift barracks in an airport administrative building, ordered not to assume defensive positions but instead to allow elements of the fractious Lebanese army to provide their security. ``If we could have done in Lebanon what we're doing here it wouldn't have happened,'' Hayden said. Hayden is deploying his security forces as he says it should have been done in Beirut, if only the Marines there had the authority to defend themselves. ``We'e constantly changing positions, changing patrols and changing routines,'' Hayden said. The Marines also are engaging in a fair share of deception, setting up mock guard posts and camoflauge tents over junk. ``There are some facilities that have guards that have no value at all,' Hayden said. He concedes Marines would make an attractive terrorist target. A successful attack would send shudders through an American public that remembers well the Beirut bombing of Oct. 23, 1983, when a suicide attacker crashed through the Marine barracks' gates in a bomb-laden truck. Fundamentalist Shiites claimed responsibility. Hayden said it would be foolish for terrorists to target the Marines again. ``I think it would be a mistake,'' he said. ``They would look for a softer spot. It won't happen again.'' Capt. Wayne Sparks was one of the replacements sent to Beirut after the bombing. Younger Marines sometimes ask him about his experience and whether they are as vulnerable. ``They ask what the terrorist threat is, what kinds of things could an enemy do to us,'' said Sparks, 35, of Portsmouth, Ohio. Sparks said he had no qualms about returning to the Middle East. ``I'm a Marine,'' he said. ``I do what I'm responsible to do and I don't question it.'' Rowe said he was satisfied with the security here, which he said relies on ``dispersion and great vigilance.'' He says he knew 50 to 60 of the men killed in Beirut just after he left, and was close friends with a half dozen of them. ``I think that every Marine is aware of it and those of us who were in Beirut are more aware of it,'' Rowe said. ``But you can't allow it to dominate your life. If you do, you give in to fear and the terrorist wins.''

DOC.HEAD: Carol Stuart's Family Condemns Movie on Her Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 graf after 3rd graf pvs, `The CBS...', to add no-comment from network, add background on consent. Picks up 4th graf, `Good Night...'.
DOC.TEXT: A TV film tonight about Charles Stuart, who allegedly shot his pregnant wife, summoned police over his car phone and later apparently killed himself, sacrifices privacy to profit, the woman's family says. ``While we agree that the First Amendment must provide protection to legitimate journalists, we decry its use as a shield by those who profit by producing `entertainment' without authorization,'' Carol Stuart's parents, Giusto and Evelyn DiMaiti, and her brother, Carl, said in a statement Monday. The CBS movie sets a ``dangerous precedent'' that could sacrifice the privacy of other grieving families for the sake of movie profits, they said. CBS publicist Ed Devlin said the network had no response to make to the family's criticism. Producer Arnold Shapiro did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment today. In general, docudramas can be made without the consent of those involved as long as they stick to public records. Individuals who sell the rights to their stories to producers essentially sell the rights to their private stories. ``Good Night Sweet Wife: A Murder in Boston'' stars Ken Olin of ``thirtysomething'' as Stuart. The movie was produced in association with Arnold Shapiro, who was taping a segment of the show ``Rescue 911'' in Boston when Mrs. Start was slain Oct. 30. The rescue of the Stuarts was shown on the TV program. Mrs. Stuart was fatally shot in the head during what her husband claimed was a robbery by a black man. The white couple's son, who was delivered prematurely by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Stuart was shot in the side but recovered. In January, Stuart apparently jumped to his death from a bridge after learning that his brother, Matthew, had implicated him in his wife's slaying. Public interest in the crime was heightened by a dramatic, tape-recorded telephone conversation between Stuart and an emergency dispatcher who tracked down the Stuarts' location to send an ambulance. The crime shocked Bostonians and heightened racial tensions. The crime's hold on the public imagination grew greater still when it became clear that the prime suspect was Stuart himself. Matthew Stuart's involvement in the slaying remains under investigation. His lawyer, Nancy Gerttner, said he was distressed by the movie. ``We deeply regret the television portrayal of these events at this time which are based only on the media accounts, which are distorted and which are obviously without the participation of any of the principals,'' Gertner said. The DiMaiti family called on anyone profiting from the movie, including advertisers, to donate money to the Carol DiMaiti Stuart Foundation. It provides scholarships to youths in Mission Hill, the poor neighborhood where she was shot.

DOC.HEAD: Economy at Virtual Standstill; Some Say Recession Has Arrived
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy nearly came to a standstill in the second quarter, edging up a feeble annual rate of 0.4 percent, the government said Tuesday. Many of the nation's top economists believe a recession is imminent - if not under way already. While White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said ``we don't believe we are in a recession right now,'' he acknowledged the latest Commerce Department report on the gross national product ``is certainly cause for concern. It's not good news.'' The department's revised report on the GNP - the nation's total output of goods and services - was the lowest since a 0.3 percent rate during the last quarter of 1989 and showed the economy weakening even before the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The economy was headed toward a recession before Iraq, and Iraq was just the nail in the coffin,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co. A recession ``seems inescapable,'' he said. Surveys following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait - and the subsequent oil-price spiral - showed many top economists forecasting an imminent recession. The National Association of Business Economists reported Tuesday that more than half of the 71 professional forecasters responding to its survey in late August and early September said a recession already has begun or will begin in the fourth quarter of 1990 or the first quarter of 1991. And half of the top economists surveyed each month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators now believe the economy will enter a recession this year. ``In a sharp revision of earlier views, 50 percent of the 50 panel members replying ... now think the long-delayed recession will start this year,'' wrote R.J. Eggert, the newsletter's editor. ``Of those expecting the recession to begin this year, three believe it actually began in the second quarter, six expect the downturn to begin in the current quarter and 16 have pegged the fourth quarter of this year as the starting date.'' Sinai pointed to negative economic data already available for July and August and said, ``It looks like the recession started in the third quarter.'' ``The economy ground to a halt in the second quarter and is in the process of contracting right now,'' added Richard W. Rahn, chief economist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. A price index tied to the GNP was unchanged at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the second quarter. But with the surge in oil prices, inflation as measured in the Consumer Price Index jumped 0.8 percent in August alone. The higher prices will be reflected in the third-quarter GNP report. The price of oil before the Iraqi invasion was less than $20 a barrel. It reached a record $38 a barrel at one point on Monday. Since oil is used in producing so many consumer goods as well as for heating and transportation, any price increase not only slashes available funds needed to feed economic growth but also feeds inflation. The department originally had estimated the economy grew at a 1.2 percent rate from April through June, after advances of 1.7 percent in the first quarter and 2.5 percent in 1989 and 4.5 percent in 1988. But it said Tuesday that more complete data showed weaker net exports and lower inventory accumulation than first thought. The new data showed net exports declining by $9.2 billion rather than $4.5 billion, and inventories totaling $19.8 billion rather than $22.4 billion. ``But there really were no areas of strength,'' Sinai said. Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, rose just 0.2 percent, down from 1.1 percent in the first quarter. Business investment fell 4.7 percent after a 5 percent gain from January through March. Housing construction plunged 11.2 percent after advancing 15.1 percent in the first quarter. Government spending rose 6.2 percent but most of that was by the federal government. State and local spending was down 0.6 percent. If the economy were in a recession - generally described as two consecutive quarters of negative growth - it would end the nearly eight years of expansion that began after the 1981-82 downturn. The Commerce Department also reported today that after-tax corporate profits fell a revised 0.6 percent, worse than the 0.2 percent drop first reported and their poorest showing since a 5.9 percent decline in the third quarter of 1989. They had risen 0.5 percent in the first quarter and 1.7 percent in the final quarter of 1989. The various changes left the GNP growing by $4.5 billion in the second quarter. After removing the effects of inflation, the GNP totaled an annual rate of $4.16 trillion.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Warns War Can Break Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with speech delivered. Security Council will begin meeting about 4:30 p.m. EDT. Pickup 10th, `On Monday...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said today that the Persian Gulf could be on the verge of war, and he hinted at the possibility of a U.N. military operation in the region. As Shevardnadze spoke on the second day of the 45th General Assembly, the U.N. Security Council prepared to vote on extending the naval embargo on Iraq to the air. The financial markets, meanwhile, reflected world pessimism over the possibilty of a settlement in the near future to the Persian Gulf crisis. Gold prices rose $15 an ounce in Hong Kong, helped the New York Stock Exchange hit a 14-month low and had oil prices flirting with $40 a barrel. The General Assembly has become a forum for world leaders to vent their rage at Baghdad. In his speech, Shevardnadze referred to Aug. 2, the date of the invasion, as ``Black Thursday.'' ``Iraq flagrantly violated the United Nations Charter, the principles of international law, the universally recognized norms of morality and the standards of civilized behavior,'' the minister said. He hinted at the possibility of a U.N. military operation, noting that ``the United Nations has the power to suppress `acts of aggression.' '' Up until the invasion, the Soviet Union was Iraq's strongest ally. But the Soviets have firmly sided with the U.S.-led effort to isolate and pressure the Baghdad government. ``War may break out on the gulf region any day, any moment,'' Shevardnadze said. On Monday, French President Francois Mitterrand issued a strong message to Iraq. ``There is no compromise as long as Iraq does not comply with resolutions of the Security Council and withdraw from Kuwait. The sovereignty of that country is not negotiable,'' he told the assembly. But he also held out the possibility of peace. ``If Iraq were to withdraw its troops and free the hostages, everything might be possible,'' Mitterrand said. Iraq is preventing several thousand Westerners from leaving Kuwait and Iraq. Mitterrand was suggesting that after an Iraqi pullout, other areas of discord in the Middle East could be discussed. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said he will not consider abandoning Kuwait unless Israel leaves the Arab territories it has held since 1967. Although every foreign leader who spoke Monday joined Mitterrand in assailing Iraq, Saddam did not appear to be backing down. The French Foreign Ministry said today that Iraqi soldiers have taken two new French nationals hostage in Kuwait and transported them to an unknown destination. There was little indication today of a breakthrough in Tehran, where Syrian President Hafez Assad, newly aligned with the West since the crisis broke out, has been tryingto get leaders to pledge full observance of the U.N. embargo. Assad left Tehran today after a four-day visit, but sources said he failed to get an Iranian pledge not to send food and other essentials to Iraq. Sources close to the Syrian delegation said Tehran reiterated its pledge to uphold embargo rules, but insisted that the embargo allows ``humanitarian shipments'' of food. On Sunday, Saddam declared he would rather go to war than let a U.N.-ordered trade embargo ``strangle'' his country. A day later he insisted that ``Kuwait belongs to Iraq and we will never give it up even if we have to fight over it for a thousand years.'' His comments have caused jitters in financial markets, because oil prices would shoot up if war broke out and more expensive oil would fuel inflation. The price of crude has already almost doubled since Iraq invaded oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting President Bush to send tens of thousands of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to lead a multinational force standing up to Saddam. In Tokyo, where the market was closed Monday, the Nikkei Stock Average today closed down 418.51 points, or 1.76 percent. The close - 23,359.32 - was the index's lowest in 33 months. Analysts said that like the skyrocketing oil prices and market declines elsewhere on Monday, the drop in the Nikkei reflected the belief among investors that an extensive U.S. conflict with Iraq is inevitable. Oil prices peaked at $39.20 before settling at $38.25 Monday on the futures market in New York. Some say the price will reach $60 if war breaks out. Gold, which shoots up in value in times of uncertaint, rose $15.03 today in Hong Kong to close at $404.45. In New York on Monday, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 59.41 points to 2,452.97, a 14-month low. As leaders from Brazil, Argentina, Poland and Indonesia condemned Baghdad Monday at the United Nations, Iraq's U.N. ambassador, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, listened impassively from his seat. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, scheduled to address the General Assembly next week, was not present. The United States has not given its permission for an Iraqi Airways flight to bring Aziz' delegation to New York and Iraq has so far refused to make arrangements through another carrier. In his speech to the assembly, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati criticized both Iraq and the United States, which he said was using the military buildup to back its imperial designs on the Persian Gulf region. Bush issued his own tough message Monday. After speaking to about 150 representatives of Arab-American groups in Washington, he was asked by a participant why he would not talk directly with Saddam. The president said Iraq would have to first pull out of Kuwait, restore the former Kuwaiti leadership and assure the safety of Americans. ``We're not going to yield one inch on those provisions,'' he said. In other developments: -The exiled emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, left today for New York for his first public appearance outside Saudi Arabia since Iraq invaded his country. Sheik Jaber is to address the U.N. General Assembly on Thursday and meet Bush on Friday. -A squadron of Italian fighter planes took off for the United Arab Emirates.
