The Italian government said the eight Tornado will provide air cover for the country's naval task force. -A Saudi civilian was killed and six people, including four U.S. Marines, were injured in a two-vehicle collision Monday on a Saudi expressway, U.S. military officials said today.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Amy Irving wasn't sure she wanted to return to the stage less than five months after giving birth, but the producers made her a deal she couldn't refuse. ``My initial instinct was to say, `No, I want to stay home with the baby,' '' said the actress during a rehearsal break from Wendy Wasserstein's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, ``The Heidi Chronicles.'' As she spoke, she cradled 4{-month-old Gabriel, her son with Brazilian director Bruno Barreto. Barreto directed Miss Irving's recent film ``Show of Force.'' The Ahmanson Theater, which is presenting ``The Heidi Chronicles,'' arranged for a nursery next to Miss Irving's dressing room and found rehearsal space near the home of her mother, actress Priscilla Pointer. In addition, they slated rehearsals around the kindergarten schedule of Miss Irving's 5-year-old son, Max, from her marriage to Steven Spielberg. The production will run Oct. 14-Dec. 23 at the UCLA James A. Doolittle Theater in Hollywood. Miss Irving plays the character Heidi Holland during the years 1965-1989. Heidi is an art historian and feminist who finds her beliefs challenged by the changing times. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Gene Nelson, who tap-danced his way to stardom in films such as ``Oklahoma'' and ``Lullaby of Broadway,'' says the popularity of rock 'n' roll nearly destroyed the art form that made him famous. Nelson on Monday became the 1,919th actor to be honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Nelson, 70, says the rise of rock 'n' roll and, later, country music, led to the demise of the extravagant musical films that showcased dancers. ``It's improving, thanks to Gregory Hines and others. These people have been very important in the preservation of tap dance as an art form,'' Nelson said before the ceremony on Hollywood Boulevard. ``It's a tough row to hoe because rock 'n' roll and country and western have taken over. They win all the music awards. There are no more musical movies, really.'' Nelson's other film credits include ``Tea for Two,'' ``West Point Story'' and ``Follies.'' --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country singer Patty Loveless is coming out in the open about her relationship with record producer Emory Gordy Jr.: They're married. Loveless, whose current hit is ``On Down The Line,'' married Gordy in Gatlinburg in February 1989. Loveless, 33, revealed her secret in interviews with People magazine and on The Nashville Network's ``Crook & Chase'' show, scheduled to air Wednesday night. Loveless said one reason she had kept her marriage secret is that she wanted to make it in Nashville on her own and not with the help of Gordy's connections. Besides producing records, Gordy has played bass and other instruments on the albums of Emmylou Harris and other country artists. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Corey Feldman, who recently underwent drug abuse treatment, was charged with heroin possession following his second narcotics-related arrest since March. Feldman, whose voice is heard in the ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' movie, was charged Monday. Arraignment was scheduled for Oct. 1 in Van Nuys Municipal Court. Feldman, who has appeared in such films as ``Stand by Me'' and ``Gremlins,'' had been scheduled to be in British Columbia on Oct. 1 to begin filming the movie ``Cafe Romeo,'' publicist Jeff Sullivan said. Los Angeles police detained the 19-year-old actor in North Hollywood on Thursday night after responding to a call of a possible auto theft, Sgt. Gil Rivera said. The actor was taken into custody after a check showed he was wanted for three outstanding traffic warrants, police said. During a prebooking search, police found two balloons containing one-third of a gram of heroin in Feldman's socks, Rivera said. The actor was freed on $5,000 bail. Feldman was arrested during a traffic stop in March after police officers found heroin and cocaine in his car, authorities said. He pleaded innocent to charges of possessing heroin and cocaine for sale and had finished a drug rehabilitation program following that arrest, said narcotics Detective Robert Holcomb.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leader Says his People are Daunted by Unification
LaserPhotos BER1, WX16
DOC.TEXT: The last leader of a sovereign East Germany said Tuesday his people are truly afraid as they prepare to join the competitive, free-thinking and robust society next door. Lothar de Maiziere, in a wide-ranging talk with The Associated Press board, said his nation's 16 million people will need help to thrive in a new world based on initiative and free enterprise. He said East Germans, forced to live in a Communist society for four decades, have grown accustomed to a life in which their futures - and their jobs - were largely preordained by the government. Although most East Germans desperately desire the German unification that takes place Oct. 3, de Maiziere said they realize they will be expected to take control of their individual destinies. ``The future in the past meant the future prescribed by the Politburo,'' he said. ``Now the people see their future is not a prescribed time, but a free time. This is something people did not learn, and they are afraid of that.'' He said the government of a united Germany must have a ``strong social consciousness'' to help East Germans make the transition and avoid becoming a second-class population. De Maiziere, a 50-year-old lawyer, will turn over to West Germany the leadership of his nation in just eight days. He was East Germany's first freely chosen leader and guided it through a rocky, six-month period of tough negotiations on the terms and timing of unification. He said he has made no decision on whether to accept one of the four new Cabinet posts that will be filled by East Germans in the newly expanded government of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. But de Maiziere said he has viewed his role as prime minister as that of a lawyer representing a very large client, and he would accept a similar role in a united Germany. He defended his people, who critics say will be bringing nothing to a united Germany but debts, social problems, a questionable work ethic and a crumbling economy. He said East Germans did not choose their system, which was imposed by the Soviets and remains a legacy of the war started by the Nazis. The nation, de Maiziere said, is part of German history and the cradle of the culture that gave the world Bach, Goethe and Handel. He said the former Communist secret police that entwined the nation for 40 years remains one of the old regime's ``most difficult legacies.'' Tens of thousands of people worked for the dreaded security apparatus, which compiled intimate dossiers on 6 million people. He said German law enforceent officials should have access to those files to punish people who committed crimes for the secret police, and to help others whose lives were ruined by it. But there should not be wide public access because the information contained in them could be damaging, divisive and distorted, de Maiziere said. About 5,000 secret police workers were used exclusively to listen to telephone conversations, he said, and the details in the files not only contain political views but reveal whether people were faithful to their spouses. Each file on a particular person also contains, on average, the names and activities of 40 to 50 other people who came in contact with that person. De Maiziere said he chose not to read his own file when questions arose about whether he cooperated with the secret police, but allowed respected leaders to do it for him. He was subsequently cleared. He also said he hoped for a political solution in the Persian Gulf crisis, and believes a united Germany will refute critics who say it is too preoccupied with itself to assume a role of global leadership. He credited President Bush, former President Reagan and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for creating the political climate that made German unity possible.

DOC.HEAD: Deputies Storm McDonald's, Free Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Girard, 32...', to UPDATE with bail set for suspect.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA3,LA4,LA5; LaserColor LA106
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff's deputies lobbed ``flash-bang'' grenades into a McDonald's to divert a gunman and stormed the restaurant early today, rescuing the last of 20 people held hostage up to seven hours, authorities said. None of the hostages was injured, authorities said. The suspect was taken into custody. The Los Angeles County sheriff's SWAT team, which never made contact with the gunman, got help from an 18-year-old assistant manager of the restaurant who hid in the kitchen. Ramiro Gironas spied on the gunman, reporting his movements by telephone throughout the standoff, authorities said. ``All I know was to take care of my people, my crew,'' Gironas said. ``I'm glad I'm safe and that all my people are safe. I'm not a hero. I just did what I had to.'' Some hostages, including a 3-year-old girl and an 85-year-old woman, had been forced to lie on the floor under tables at the after-school hangout, authorities said. Several children were among the hostages, La Verne police Lt. Jim Crawford said. The gunman had fled to the McDonald's from a holdup at a nearby clothing store and took the hostages about 5:30 p.m. Monday. A second participant in the earlier robbery was arrested outside the McDonald's as the standoff began, authorities said. Six hours later, SWAT officers rescued 12 hostages from the restaurant basement, authorities said. Shortly after midnight, they said, ``flash-bang'' grenades intended to disorient with a burst of light and noise were used to divert the gunman. Then, a deputy seized him and rescued the last eight hostages. ``They were able to get inside without being detected,'' sheriff's Deputy Bill Wehner said. ``A deputy leaped over the counter and took the suspect into custody.'' Some of the freed hostages and onlookers broke into applause as authorities took the suspect Douglas Girard, to a command post. The freed hostages were taken to nearby Lutheran High School, where Deputy Dick Dinsmoor said they would get a chance to talk to a psychologist. The children were given teddy bears, he said. The sheriff's department revised the number of hostages inside the restaurant several times before finally settling on 20, said sheriff's Deputy Roger Hom. Girard, 32, of San Jacinto and his alleged accomplice, Frank M. Teresi, 38, of Anaheim, were booked for investigation of armed robbery and false imprisonment, Hom said. Bail for Girard was set at $500,000; no bail was set for Teresi because he is on parole for robbery and being under the influence of a narcotic. Girard was treated at Pomona Valley Hospital for slight facial injuries he suffered while being arrested, Hom said. A .38-caliber revolver was recovered inside the restaurant, said police Sgt. John Ortega. It was earlier believed two gunmen were inside the restaurant, authorities said. Negotiators had struggled to reach the gunman by telephone but never made contact to learn whether he had any demands. The sheriff's 18-member Special Enforcement Team had been called in to negotiate for the hostages' reease. Dozens of police officers surrounded the restaurant. La Verne is about 25 miles northeast of Los Angeles. Gironas said he communicated with the 12 people in the basement with a headset used by workers at the drive-up window. McDonald's employee Anis Hussain, 25, was among 11 restaurant employees and one customer in the basement. He said the group remained calm. ``It was hot down there, but no one cried and no one got hysterical,'' Hussain said. Hussain recalled that when the man came into the restaurant, a gun in his back pocket, ``he bought a couple of Big Macs, some french fries and something to drink'' before taking the hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto, Opponents Launch Campaigns
LaserPhoto KAR2
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her political foes launched campaigns Tuesday for next month's elections, which are seen as a forum on whether her government was wrongly dismissed. Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government was forced out Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. She has been ordered to stand trial next week before a special one-judge court in the eastern city of Lahore on charges of corruption and misconduct. The army-backed caretaker government on Tuesday filed corruption charges against Ms. Bhutto's father-in-law and two more former Cabinet ministers. A special tribunal in Karachi is scheduled to decide later this week whether Ms. Bhutto must stand trial on two other corruption charges. If convicted by the tribunal, she could be disqualified from next month's poll and barred from politics for seven years. The elections set for Oct. 24, three years ahead of schedule, are seen as a referendum on President Ghulam Ishaq Khan's decision to dismiss Ms. Bhutto's government. He used constitutional powers to do so, but she called it a thinly veiled coup. The alliance opposing Ms. Bhutto, known as the Islami Jamhoori Ittehad, or Islamic Democratic Alliance, is scrambling to prop up a crumbling alliance long enough to defeat her in next month's election. The alliance cut deals with smaller parties spanning the range of the ideological spectrum, from Islamic fundamentalism to secular socialism. ``This is a fight against Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party,'' said Ijaz ul-Haq, campaign manager for the alliance and son of the late Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who ruled Pakistan for 11 years until his death in a 1988 plane crash. ``There is so much pressure on everyone that we have to fight together to get the People's Party out.'' Alliance leader Nawaz Sharif launched its campaign at an election rally at the eastern village of Gujranwala in Pakistan's populous Punjab Province. Ms. Bhutto, who won election in November 1988 and became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation, is a candidate for five seats in the 217-member National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament. The former prime minister said her party will participate in the elections even if she herself is disqualified. ``If I'm stopped from taking part, don't lose heart. Work to make the party successful,'' she told a crowd of about 4,000 supporters on Tuesday in a village on the outskirts of Karachi, her hometown. Ms. Bhutto has vehemently denied any wrongdoing and repeatedly accused the president of corruption and nepotism. The caretaker government has spent much of the past month trying to portray Ms. Bhutto's administration as the most corrupt in Pakistan's 43-year history. But many Pakistanis consider the special tribunals like the ones that will consider her case to be kangaroo courts, and say the scenario evokes memories of Ms. Bhutto's father. The late Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was overthrown in a 1977 coup, and a special tribunal ordered him hanged in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Reserves Than Expected Likely to Get Call for Active Duty
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf with 2 grafs to update with additional Army reserve callups due for Thursday
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is continuing to activate reserve forces for Operation Desert Shield, but the total call-up is likely to fall well short of the 50,000 authorized by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, military sources say. The Pentagon today said call-ups of reserves from all services have reached 21,970, an increase of 317 from its previous tally announced last week. Pete Williams, the chief Pentagon spokesman, said another 4,620 Army National Guard and Army Reserve members will be called up on Thursday, rassing the total to 26,590. Spokesman Maj. Doug Hart said the latest tally included a decline of 156 in the previously announced total for the Army. He said this was due to a counting error in the Pentagon's earlier tally. The Navy's total rose by 183, the Coast Guard added 290 and the Air Force total was unchanged. Additional callups late this week are expected to bring the service-wide total to about 26,000. President Bush authorized use of the reserves on Aug. 22. It is the first reserve call-up since the Vietnam war. Cheney told a House committee last week that he expected nearly 50,000 reserves to be on active duty by Sept. 30, but a military source said Monday the total is unlikely to exceed 40,000 and that it would take several more weeks to reach even that total. The source spoke on condition he not be identified. ``It's not going to be anywhere near'' the 50,000 figure projected by Cheney, the source said, unless war with Iraq breaks out. In the case of war the Pentagon would be expected to activate far more reserves, including combat units. It was not immediately clear whether the services had scaled back their original projections of how many reserves would be needed or whether Cheney had miscalculated. In response to a reporter's inquiry, the Pentagon issued a statement Monday evening saying Cheney's original approval of the call-up plan was ``designed to allow the services a maximum amount of flexibility'' to meet their needs. ``At present, it is not possible to forecast whether the needs of the services will come up'' to the nearly 50,000 total authorized by Cheney, the statement said. Bush's decision to mobilize the reserves marked an important political moment in the administration's campaign to try to force Iraq's army out of Kuwait. ``Weekend warriors'' from around the country have been forced to leave their jobs, families and communities to provide medical, transportation, airlift and other services in support of Operation Desert Shield in the gulf region. Those placed on active duty are obliged to serve 90-day tours, and the period can be extended another 90 days if Cheney decides the extra help is needed. When Cheney signed an order Aug. 23 approving a reserve activation plan, his spokesman, Pete Williams, said as many as 49,703 reserves could be placed on active duty by Oct. 1. He said the actual number was likely to be about 46,000 because the Marine Corps did not plan to use the 3,000 reserves it was allowed to call. Williams stressed that the services would call up ``only what we need and only when we need it,'' but the total was likely to be near the figure authorized by Cheney. Last week the Army, Navy and Air Force activated more than 7,000 reserves, and the Army announced that it had alerted 24 reserves units in 13 states and Puerto Rico to prepare for activation.

DOC.HEAD: EC Leader Seeks German Commitment to European Unity
With AM-Germany-Literati, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's chief executive Tuesday challenged German leaders to pledge that the merger of East and West would not weaken their support for European economic union. ``Are the Germans truly interested in economic and monetary union?'' asked Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission. ``We need clear, unambiguous political commitments. ... Without them, there is a risk of a weak Europe with a strong Germany in its midst.'' Delors' unusually blunt remarks, at a forum on Germany's future role in Europe, reflected apprehensions among Western European leaders about the consequences of German unification next week. Some, such as British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, fear Germany will aggressively dominate a unified Western Europe. Others fear the Germans will lose interest in EC integration as they turn their energies toward Central and Eastern Europe. French President Francois Mitterrand, another speaker at Tuesday's forum, said unification will pose a formidable challenge for businesses in neighboring countries. He accused some French executives of timidity, saying they should be pursuing markets inside Germany. ``This sort of dynamism, this audacity, I expect it from the French,'' Mitterrand said. Delors said the future of European integration was linked entirely to Germany's ability to decide on key policy issues within the next few months. ``I've felt disoriented by the contradictory declarations'' of German officials in recent weeks, he said. Karl Otto Poehl, president of the West German central bank, has rejected rapid moves toward European monetary union. Poehl and West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel maintain the 12 EC nations are not ready to create a European central bank. However, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher are pushing for rapid European monetary and political union. Genscher has backed a plan offered by the EC Commission to begin putting together a European central bank as early as 1993. Delors said the Germans were being unrealistic if they expected ``perfect economic convergence'' among all 12 EC members before monetary union occurred. He said the time had come to ``fix the dates'' for union. Mitterrand said he accepted the fact that Germany would emerge from unification with greater economic clout. ``If the development of Germany is incitement to do more, than it's a good thing,'' he said. ``This competition will enable us to show what France is capable of.'' Mitterrand said he considered unification to be a right of the German people, ``who cannot pay the price forever for a horrible war lost in 1945.'' No government official in Western Europe has been as outspoken about German unity as Britain's former trade and industry secretary, Nicholas Ridley. He resigned in July after telling an interviewer that the ``uppity'' Germans were trying to dominate Europe. The push for monetary union was ``a German racket designed to take over the whole of Europe,'' he said. Of the European Commission, he said: ``I'm not against giving up sovereignty in principle, but not to this lot. You might just as well give it to Adolf Hitler, frankly.'' Ridley's views were regarded widely as being shared privately by a large segment of Thatcher's Conservative Party. Britain and France were offered advice Monday in an op-ed article in the International Herald Tribune. Dominique Moisi, associate director of the French Institute of International Relations, and Lawrence Freedman, professor at King's College in London, said their governments should increase bilateral security cooperation. ``They both recognize a need to balance growing German power,'' the authors wrote. ``They must show the rest of Europe that they work in concert and not just in parallel.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Press Effort to Delay Spending Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Congress today took the first step to delay $85 billion in imminent spending cuts while the White House said it would rather ``negotiate into the night'' than accept a delay. Republicans were almost unanimous in opposition as the House Appropriations Committee approved, 32-20, a catchall bill that would keep government operations going for an additional 20 days - until Oct. 20 - to provide more time for negotiatiors to reach an agreement on deficit reduction. In an effort to discourage President Bush's promised veto, the committee attached to the bill an additional $2.1 billion to finance U.S. participation in Operation Desert Shield in the Persian Gulf. ``Why hold American troops in Saudi Arabia hostage?'' demanded Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla. ``This (the Desert Shield money) won't protect it. The president does intend to veto it.'' The legislation would double - to 12 months - the time for which the president may call up reserves for the Middle East operation. The committee sidestepped another major foreign policy question, Bush's proposal to forgive $6.7 billion worth of Egyptian debt in appreciation of Egypt's assistance in the Persian Gulf. Amid indications the committee would have refused to forgive the debt. Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., offered - and the panel approved - an amendment that would allow aid to Egypt to continue despite a failure to repay past assistance. Stripped from the legislation - known as a continuing resolution - was a section aimed at discouraging the National Endowment for the Arts from supporting ``any indecent, anti-religious or obscene picture, play or writing.'' Rep. Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., chairman of the committee, said failure of Congress to block arbitrary spending cuts due to take effect next week would ``bring the economy to its knees ... We can't afford the risk.'' Rep. Silvio Conte of Massachusetts, senior Republican on the panel, said one extension of the deadline would only lead to another delay. ``A full-blown crisis'' may be the only way to force a deficit reduction, he said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater repeated today that Bush would veto any legislation that would delay across-the-board spending reductions. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and other Democratic leaders are urging an extension in hopes of resolving the year-long budget stalemate. The cuts - called a ``sequester'' - will take place unless the targets of the Gramm-Rudman law are modified or delayed and will mean across-the-board reductions of up to 40 percent throughout the government. ``We want to avoid a sequester. We are willing to negotiate into the night,'' Fitzwater said. He was asked about reports that one immediate impact of the spending cuts would be the cancellation beginning Monday of all U.S. commercial flights after 6 p.m. The flights would be cancelled because of sharp cutbacks in air traffic controllers and in evening operation of U.S. weather forecasting stations. ``We're concerned about it, just like we're concerned about all the cuts,'' Fitzwater said. ``But if you think this seems draconian, you ain't seen nothing yet. You're going to see a lot more dramatic and difficult things to deal with than night flights.'' Negotiators from the two sides met in a back room of the Capitol until nearly 12:30 a.m. today, emerging to say they were still searching for a deal. ``We're making progress in cutting spending, but we're not quite there,'' White House chief of staff John Sununu told reporters. The major sticking point to a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction deal has been over whether to slash the tax rate on capital gains, the profits from the sale of investments. Bush says the reduction would boost the economy. Democrats, insisting the break would aid the wealthy, have refused to accept it without a compensating tax increase on upper-income people. The seemingly endless negotiations have left the government staring at the start of the new fiscal year next Monday with no budget, spending bills or other fiscal legislation in place. ``It's a game of chicken, that's all it is,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., who was a negotiator from May until top congressional leaders took over last week. To prevent a complete government shutdown, the Democrats who control Congress planned to begin working on a bill that would temporarily finance the government through Oct. 20. The date was chosen to give budget bargainers a chance to work out a pact and enact it into law. ``If you get into the business of suspending and suspending and suspending ... we'll be at it for 114 years,'' said budget director Richard Darman. The same legislation is expected to provide about $2 billion toward the expenses of Operation Desert Shield, the U.S. military deployment in the Middle East. Unless some combination of tax increases and spending cuts are found, the fiscal 1991 deficit is expected to exceed a record $250 billion in a budget of about $1.2 trillion.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Adviser Says Sweeping Powers Needed to Expedite Reforms
With AM-Soviet-Solzhenitsyn, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev needed sweeping new powers to quickly carry out economic reforms, not to introduce a ``state of siege,'' his economic adviser said Tuesday. Nikolai Petrakov fended off charges that Gorbachev was amassing too much power. The Supreme Soviet parliament voted overwhelmingly Monday to give Gorbachev broad authority to order the switch to a market economy without consulting legislators every step of the way. Dissenting lawmakers said the special powers would make Gorbachev a virtual monarch, despite his vow to act responsibly. The resolution permits Gorbachev to issue presidential decrees for the next 18 months on property, wages, prices, the national budget, the financial system, and law and order. ``So why does the president need these extraordinary powers? Of course not for the purpose of introducing a state of siege or ... president's rule,'' Petrakov told a news briefing. ``Some of the problems will have to be resolved in one, two or three days and those decisions should be taken instantaneously,'' he said. ``It will be difficult to convene the parliament and discuss every issue.'' The Supreme Soviet also voted in principle Monday to end seven decades of inefficient, centrally planned economics and take the leap toward a Western-style free market. Lawmakers were unable, however, to decide which of three conflicting plans they liked best. Gorbachev appointed a commission, headed by himself, to try to merge the plans by Oct. 15. Previous attempts have failed. The commission held its first meeting Tuesday. Petrakov expressed surprise at a weekend challenge of Gorbachev's request for expanded powers by leaders of the Russian Federation, the largest and wealthiest of the 15 Soviet republics. Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and other leaders of the republic's legislature read a statement on the popular ``Vremya'' television news program calling Gorbachev's request unacceptable. Yeltsin said it was an attempt to introduce presidential rule in the republics and disband their governments. ``It was a reaction based on rumor,'' Petrakov said Tuesday. Seven decades of Communist-style economics have left the Soviet people short of adequate housing, food and consumers goods. Eggs and vegetables are the latest scarcities in Moscow. The egg shortage was blamed on last year's campaign against salmonella, which has lowered egg production without eliminating the dangerous bacteria. The Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper said Moscow warehouses had only 6 percent of the potatoes they expected to store this winter, and only 13 percent of other vegetables. It said there had been many reported thefts from personal vegetable cellars. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, the author of the most conservative economic reform program, has become a lightning rod for public disenchantment, and has been fighting demands for his resignation. Petrakov, asked why Gorbachev doesn't fire the beleaguered chief minister, replied: ``The president is a very resolute and independent person and I believe that you should understand that there is a certain apprehension regarding the consequences of a government crisis.''

DOC.HEAD: `Cool' Club Admissions Policy Called Biased
DOC.TEXT: The doorman who decides whether you look cool enough to get into a hot nightclub may be about to get his own comeuppance under California civil rights law. The state Alcoholic Beverage Control Department and a private lawyer, in separate actions, have accused two fashionable Los Angeles night spots of arbitrary discrimination based on appearance. The state's Unruct prohibits any arbitrary discrimination by businesses. ``It's a subjective policy,'' Carl Falletta, the ABC's deputy division chief in Los Angeles, said Monday. ``It depends on who the doorman wants to let in.'' He said a nigh Civil Rights Ahtclub open to the public can legally enforce a neutral dress code or a ban on disruptive customers, but can't rely on a subjective, eye-of-the-beholder standard like ``no nerds allowed.'' The ABC is seeking a 30-day liquor license suspension of a downtown club called Vertigo, where undercover officers allegedly were excluded because of their appearance. Lawyer Kenneth Lipton, excluded from the nearby Mayan, has sued that nightclub in small claims court seeking the $250 damage award provided by state law. He said other spurned customers should besiege the clubs with similar lawsuits and force a change in policy. ``The people have the power to do this if they would stop allowing themselves to be treated conomy was headed toward a recession before Iraq, and Iraq was just the nail in the coffin,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co. A recession ``seems inescapable,'' he said. Surveys following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait - and the subsequent oil-price spiral - showed many top economists forecasting an imminent recession. The National Association of Business Economists reported Tuesday that more than half of the 71 professional forecasters responding to its survey in late August and early September said a recession already has begun or will begin in the fourth quarter of 1990 or the first quarter of 1991. And half of the top economists surveyed each month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators now believe the economy will enter a recession this year. ``In a sharp revision of earlier views, 50 percent of the 50 panel members replying ... now think the long-delayed recession will start this year,'' wrote R.J. Eggert, the newsletter's editor. ``Of those expecting the recession to begin this year, three believe it actually began in the second quarter, six expect the downturn to begin in the current quarter and 16 have pegged the fourth quarter of this year as the starting date.'' Sinai pointed to negative economic data already available for July and August and said, ``It looks like the recession started in the third quarter.'' ``The economy ground to a halt in the second quarter and is in the process of contracting right now,'' added Richard W. Rahn, chief economist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. A price index tied to the GNP was unchanged at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the second quarter. But with the surge in oil prices, inflation as measured in the Consumer Price Index jumped 0.8 percent in August alone. The higher prices will be reflected in the third-quarter GNP report. The price of oil before the Iraqi invasion was less than $20 a barrel. It reached a record $38 a barrel on Monday. Since oil is used in producing so many consumer goods as well as for heating and transportation, any price increase not only slashes available funds needed to feed economic growth but also feeds inflation. The department originally had estimated the economy grew at a 1.2 percent rate from April through June, after advances of 1.7 percent in the first quarter and 2.5 percent in 1989 and 4.5 percent in 1988. But it said Tuesday that more complete data showed weaker net exports and lower inventory accumulation than first thought. The new data showed net exports declining by $9.2 billion rather than $4.5 billion, and inventories totaling $19.8 billion rather than $22.4 billion. ``But there really were no areas of strength,'' Sinai said. Consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, rose just 0.2 percent, down from 1.1 percent in the first quarter. Business investment fell 4.7 percent after a 5 percent gain from January through March. Housing construction plunged 11.2 percent after advancing 15.1 percent in the first quarter. Government spending rose 6.2 percent but most of that was by the federal government. State and local spending was down 0.6 percent. If the economy were in a recession - generally described as two consecutive quarters of negative growth - it would end the nearly eight years of expansion that began after the 1981-82 downturn. The Commerce Department also reported today that after-tax corporate profits fell a revised 0.6 percent, worse than the 0.2 percent drop first reported and their poorest showing since a 5.9 percent decline in the third quarter of 1989. They had risen 0.5 percent in the first quarter and 1.7 percent in the final quarter of 1989. The various changes left the GNP growing by $4.5 billion in the second quarter. After removing the effects of inflation, the GNP totaled an annual rate of $4.16 trillion.

DOC.HEAD: German Kremlin Flier Charged with Attempted Murder
DOC.TEXT: Matthias Rust, the young West German pilot who stunned the world by landing a small plane on Moscow's Red Square, has been charged with attempted murder, authorities said Tuesday. Rust, 22, was charged in the November 1989 stabbing of a nurse in a Hamburg hospital, said an official of the Hamburg prosecutor's office. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Rust was charged at the beginning of the month. Rust allegedly stabbed the nurse after she fended off his attempts to kiss her. He was held briefly in custody, then released on bail. Rust flew a single-engine Cessna plane undetected across a vast space of Soviet territory and landed at Red Square in May 1987. The landing triggered a shake-up in the Soviet military - the retirement of defense minister Gen. Sergei Sokolov and the dismissal of air defense chief Gen. Alexander Koldunov. Rust was held in a Soviet prison for 14 months before he was released in August 1988.

DOC.HEAD: ``Mommy, I Love You,'' Are the Dying Words of a Little Girl With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Twelve-year-old Lissette Rodriguez insisted she had to go to church in the middle of the night. At 2 a.m. Tuesday, her nurse, Holly Popovich, dressed her and drove her to the St. Elizabeth's Hospital chapel in Elizabeth, N.J. Lissette prayed for her life for 20 minutes. ``God, please help me, please help me,'' she implored. ``I don't want to be like this. I'm scared. I don't want to die. I want to live.'' Sandy, as she is nicknamed, saw her nurse crying at her side. In tears herself, she told Ms. Popovich not to cry. She carried with her from the church a book, ``Christ The King,'' and a cup of holy water. After church, there was one more stop, an all-night supermarket. Sandy bought some gum, candy and a Mickey Mouse book. Back at her home in Elizabeth, she gave the religious book to the woman she called her mother, Carmen Candelaria, who is really her aunt. Sandy blessed her with the holy water. ``Mommy, I love you,'' she said. She ought sleep because it represented a death that stalked her until she finally slipped away shortly after 9 a.m. Barely 12 years old, she was another victim of AIDS, one of the more than 1,300 children who have died in the United States. Sandy was born four weeks prematurely in New York City. Mrs. Candelaria took Sandy from her own sister when she was born because the sister was unable to care for her. Sandy contracted AIDS through a blood transfusion needed because of her early birth, Mrs. Candelaria said. The girl's mother died two years ago, at age 41, after mixing Valium and alcohol at a party, Mrs. Candelaria said. She said she knows nothing about Sandy's father. Her own husband, the man Sandy knew as her father, was killed when she was 7 in a holdup in the video store he owned in Puerto Rico, where the family lived for five years. Sandy died without fulfilling a few simple dreams: to walk again, to go to school, to see her classmates and New Kids on the Block, to have another party, to fly to Puerto Rico to visit her grandmother, to see the clouds from the plane. For Sandy, death was represented by the concept of heaven, where everything is beautiful and she could walk again. ``You close your eyes and your body is not working,'' she said in a interview. ``Then you go to God, go to Jesus in a big place where he lives. My father is in there. Everyone who dies goes there.'' Those around Sandy say they think she had a premonition she would die Tuesday morning. ``It's not uncommon for people who are dying to have a premonition that they're going to die,'' said Ms. Popovich. ``She was cold to the touch all night.'' ``She kind of knew what was going on yesterday,'' said her chief nurse, Doreen Small. ``She was bleeding through her nose and her ear.'' An earlier news story about Sandy brought letters and cards to her and the gift of an airplane ticket to Puerto Rico. Now she will fly back in death to be buried in her family's native land.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Envoy Delivers Saddam Tape to State Department
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led with screening for reporters at 3:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The United States received a 76-minute videotaped message from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Tuesday, the State Department said. The tape was delivered to the department by Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat. Officials were making a copy of the tape before handing it to the news media later in the day. Saddam taped his address in response to an eight-minute message delivered on Iraqi television by President Bush 10 days ago. Despite U.S. urging that Iraq hand the tape directly to the media, Iraq insisted on delivering it to the State Department. All media in Iraq are state-run. In his message, which was aired in its entirety, Bush said that Saddam had brought his people to the brink of war. Most U.S. television networks have said they are unlikely to broadcast the entire tape. Bush, when told last week that Saddam's message might run 90 minutes, said the tape would put Americans to sleep.

DOC.HEAD: Mickey Rourke, Carre Otis Reach Agreement Over Nude Photos
DOC.TEXT: Mickey Rourke and Carre Otis, co-stars of the steamy movie ``Wild Orchid,'' have reached a settlement with the movie's producers over the selling of nude photos to two magazines, Rourke's lawyer said. The attorney, Ralph Loeb, declined to reveal details of the agreement, only saying Monday that it had been reached within the past 45 days. The actors filed suit in May, accusing Vision of the unauthorized release of movie photographs, which were printed in Playboy in June and the German magazine Kino in April. Miss Otis and Rourke filed separate lawsuits seeking general and punitive damages. Rourke's suit charged that the producers ``had no intention of obtaining Rourke's approval prior to their dissemination of explicit photographs of Rourke to various magazines for use in tawdry sex pictorials. ... '' Miss Otis claimed she had signed a contract with Kruger-Bent Group, a subsidiary of Vision Entertainment, that guaranteed her control over the use of nude photos from the movie. She also charged that her reputation had been harmed. Miss Otis' attorney, Peter Laird, declined comment Tuesday, as did Scott Cooper, an attorney for Vision Entertainment.

DOC.HEAD: Women Marines Say They're Ready For Any Challenge in Desert
LaserPhoto DHA7
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Pentagon rules on coverage of operations in Saudi Arabia prohibit disclosing the precise location of U.S. military installations. ---

When Marine Cpl. Janice Brautigam joined up, she didn't even know where Saudi Arabia was. Now she lives in a tent on the edge of its vast desert, as close to the front line as women are allowed to be. ``I never knew it existed, to tell the tuth,'' Brautigam, 22, of Clearwater, Fla., said of the desert kingdom by the Persian Gulf she is helping to defend. She and fellow female Marines are among the tens of thousands of U.S. troops deployed in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. Those interviewed at their base were uniformly proud of tasks they perform. Although the U.S. military restricts the combat roles of the women, they still come in for their share of difficult and even dangerous work. Lance Cpl. Melanie Roberts, 20, of Richmond, Va., a crew member on a crash rescue truck, was on duty Sept. 12 when a big CH-53 Sea Stallion helicopter crashed on takeoff. She helped to pull out the five injured crew members and control the fire. After a month in Saudi Arabia, she says she prefers it to boot camp at Parris Island, S.C. ``No sand fleas here,'' she said. Brautigam, who weighs in at 105 pounds, is a truck driver. ``Eighteen wheelers, you name it,'' she said. ``I can haul anything from tanks to supplies to buses.'' She said she joined the Marines ``because they ask the most. You have to to work harder physically and mentally.'' Sgt. Susan Ritter, 26, of Weiner, Ark., agreed. ``You might as well go for the gusto,'' she said. Lance Cpl. Stephanie Bowlin, 20, of Modesto, Calif., a military policewoman assigned to base security, said she joined the Marines ``for the challenge.'' She was in a patrol vehicle perhaps 50 yards from the Sea Stallion helicopter when it crashed. She was among the first to reach the blazing wreck and helped one of the burned crewmen to safety. Nothing quite that dramatic has happened to Brautigam or Cpl. Coe Hart, 26, of Binghamton, N.Y., but they say they're ready for whatever comes up. Both Brautigam and Hart have Marine husbands, who are also in Saudi Arabia and stationed several miles from their base. Brautigam and her husband, Lance Cpl. Thomas J. Buday, were married seven months ago. Now they meet for a few minutes whenever possible. Hart and her husband, Staff Sgt. Doug Willey, a combat engineer, were scheduled to be married in Hawaii on Sept. 1, but had to move up the date after both got orders to ship out for the Persian Gulf. ``We'll have our honeymoon here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller Says Health Insurance Overhaul Inevitable
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a national bipartisan commission said Tuesday that its $70 billion plan to guarantee universal access to health care is ``absolutely inevitable'' because of growing public anger over the current health system. ``People who predict we can't do this are going to be wrong, because the American people are going to make us do it,'' said Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va. The panel, headed by Rockefeller and known as the Pepper Commission - after its former chairman - released the final report of its two-year study. While the basic elements of its proposal, for overhauling Medicaid and the health insurance system, were decided last spring, the panel provided supporting details and cited potential tax increases to pay its $70 billion price tag. The recommendations drew criticism from opposite sides, with some saying it was unrealistic and too expensive, and others saying it fell short of a national health insurance solution. ``The Pepper Commission report is a start but needs to be taken with a grain of salt,'' said a Republican member, Sen. David Durenberger of Minnesota. ``We didn't finish the job of building political consensus behind a solution. But we did help define the problems and narrow the options. And that sets the stage for the president to make his contribution.'' The commission's recommendations were opposed by the Bush administration, which lobbied the commission members to oppose them, Rockefeller said. The U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care was established out of concern that more than 30 million Americans have no health insurance and millions more face impoverishment by long-term care. Its first chairman was the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla., the long-time champion of America's senior citizens. The commission plan calls for requiring all businesses with more than 100 employers to provide private health insurance or contribute to a new public plan for all employees and their dependents. Smaller employers would be given financial incentives to provide their employees coverage. If, after five years, such coverage is not widespread, those employers would be required to provide private insurance or participate in a new federal public health insurance plan. The commission also would improve Medicare coverage for the elderly and would establish a program to cover long-term care services, including provisions for care within the home. All would be guaranteed coverage for the first three months of a nursing home stay, with extended benefits based on financial need. People needing long-term care would not be required to spend themselves into poverty before receiving federal coverage, as Medicaid requires. Cost of the package was estimated at $24 billion for recommendations involving people under age 65, $3 billion for elderly health care and $43 billion for long-term care, when fully implemented after five years. The commission said the $70 billion total amounts to $8.25 a week for every non-poor adult in the country. The plans face an uphill struggle in Congress, and bills to fully implement them won't even be ready until next year. Rockefeller is sponsoring with Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, a bill that would make a first step by extending Medicaid to cover all low-income children and pregnant women. But with the administration and congressional leaders still debating ways to lower the budget deficit, prospects for any action on expanding health care coverage are considered dim. Still, Rockefeller said the commission's plan or something like it will be enacted eventually. ``It is absolutely inevitable,'' Rockefeller said. ``Before the end of this century, well before, the Pepper Commission or a plan similar to that will be the health care system of this country.'' The commission's initial recommendations drew fire for failing to include recommendations for how to pay for it. The commission made no financing recommendations, but its final report includes six potential finance packages as possibilities. Key elements of include an increase in the top income tax rates, a surcharge on all federal income taxes, imposing a new value-added tax and increasing Social Security taxes. The report includes dissenting views from members, including Rep. Pete Stark, chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health. He said a job-based plan will not provide coverage to all Americans, and that the Pepper Commission failed to include realistic health cost containment proposals. ``A single national plan is the only realistic way to make health insurance affordable to small employers,'' said Stark, D-Calif., who has sponsored his own universal health care bill. Rep. Bill Gradison, R-Ohio, also on the commission, pronounced the recommendations ``so costly that they are unrealistic.''

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Jolts Quake-Prone Iranian Town
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian town where 40,000 people died in an earthquake in June was rocked by a strong quake Tuesday, but no injuries or damage were reported, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The temblor that struck Rudbar in western Iran on Tuesday measured 5.5 on the Richter scale, said the IRNA dispatch, monitored in Nicosia. The quake struck in the afternoon. The devastating June 21 earthquake in Rudbar, 125 miles northwest of Tehran, injured 60,000 residents and left half a million homeless. The Richter scale is a guage of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake registering 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage, especially in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises Increased Trade with Turkey
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 14-16, At the Pentagon, with further on Iraqi troops.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, vowing anew that Iraq's conquest of Kuwait ``will not stand,'' today promised increased trade with Turkey to help it economically weather the international embargo against Iraq. Meanwhile, a Pentagon spokesman said Iraq has increased the number of troops and tanks in Kuwait and southern Iraq over the past week. About 430,000 Iraqi soldiers are now in southern Iraq and occupied Kuwait, said spokesman Pete Williams, an increase from the 360,000 total reported last week. Bush met at the White House with Turkish President Turgot Ozal and, separately, with Portugese Prime Minister Cavaco Silva. Both leaders voiced strong support for the U.S.-led effort to isolate Saddam Hussein. The president praised ``staunch allies like Turkey'' for joining in telling ``the world we will not tolerate this invasion, it will not stand.'' In a brief White House ceremony after his meeting with Ozal, Bush said the United States would seek a new agreement to increase textile imports from Turkey. He also pledged to work closely with Congress to ``make sure that Turkey gets its fair share'' of military aid in the coming year. ``We will also work to help modernize the Turkish armed forces by the future sales of F16s and provision of other military equipment,'' Bush said. ``We stand by those who stand up for civilized values around the world,'' Bush said. For his part, Ozal praised Bush for ``his firm stand against aggression.'' Turkey was one of the first nations to help the United States after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait by closing a major pipeline carrying Iraqi oil. Portugal is allowing U.S. airlift flights to Saudi Arabia to use an airbase in the Azores for refueling. Silva, speaking with reporters after his meeting with the president, said the ``international community must stick together and be very firm'' in enforcing the United Nations' sanctions against Iraq. ``Nobody can accept that such a brutal aggression will pay off,'' he said. Ozal, who had lunch with Bush, told reporters at a picture-taking session in the Oval Office that ``we're going to talk now'' about prospects for more aid to his battered economy. Asked how long Turkey could hold out without trade with Iraq or with oil-related revenues, Ozal said, ``as much as it requires.'' At the Pentagon, Williams said the Iraqi deployments still appear to be ``essentially a defensive force,'' but are capable of readily converting to an offensive strike force. He said the reported increases in Iraqi troops and tank deployments are due in part to the Pentagon including a larger geographic area in its count. Williams said he could not estimate how much of the increase was due to this factor. He said some of the extra soldiers had been moved from the Iranian border area. The number of tanks in the Kuwait theater has jumped by 700 from last week, to 3,500 tanks, Williams said. He said the number of armored personnel carriers has risen to 2,500, an increase of 700. Artillery pieces now total about 1,700, up by 250. U.S. officials said in advance of today's meeting that the administration was not prepared to provide any additional direct assistance to Turkey or other troubled economies in the Middle East. The Turkish government put its economic cost at $4 billion or more annually, including millions of dollars in construction contracts. About 6,000 Turkish workers have lost jobs as a result of the pipeline closure, the government says. Bush was prepared to tell the 152-member International Monetary Fund later today and its sister lending organization, the World Bank, that the two organizations should take a more active role in the Middle East crisis, administration aides said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would ask the international agencies to match political leadership shown by the United Nations with economic leadership in helping ease the shock to poor nations of the Iraqi embargo. World Bank President Barber Conable outlined today emergency plans to help resettle hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. On Monday, Bush told a group of Arab-American business leaders at the White House there will be ``no, no, no negotiation'' with Iraq until it fully withdraws from Kuwait. He encountered some sharp questioning after he finished prepared remarks to about 150 representatives of Arab-American groups - including one from a participant who told him that ``as Moslems, we object to Saudi Arabia inviting the foreign troops to our land.'' ``The objective is to see that naked aggression does not pay off, sir,'' Bush replied. Asked by another participant why he would not talk directly with Saddam, the president said the United States would not negotiate until Iraq pulled out of Kuwait, the former Kuwaiti leadership was restored and the safety of Americans was assured. ``We're not going to yield one inch on those provisions,'' he said. Bush also said ``I am not going to be distracted'' by Saddam's suggestions that the atmosphere for a settlement would be improved if Israel withdrew from occupied territories. ``We are going to resist his attempts to justify what he did based on other regional concerns. So I think these are merely, on his part, an effort to create additional pretexts so that he can stay in Kuwait,'' Bush said. Asked why the United States was depriving the children of Iraq of food in the international trade embargo, the president said the Iraqi government would not permit relief organizations to send in supervised food shipments. ``I am much less interested in feeding Saddam Hussein's army at this point,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Oct. 6 as Discovery Launch Date
DOC.TEXT: NASA said Tuesday it will try to launch the shuttle Discovery with a sun-probing satellite on Oct. 6, while the search goes on for mysterious hydrogen leaks that have grounded Columbia. Discovery is scheduled to lift off at 7:35 a.m. with five astronauts who will send the European satellite on a five-year journey to study the sun's polar regions. It would be the first spacecraft to orbit the solar poles. ``This date is a little success-oriented and is dependent on not encountering any unusual problems,'' said shuttle director Robert Crippen. ``But I think the shuttle team has a good chance of making the 6th.'' NASA's last shuttle flight was in April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Soon afterward, the rest of the fleet, Columbia and Atlantis, were crippled by hydrogen leaks. Columbia is not expected to fly until late this year or early next year. NASA's fourth attempt in as many months to send Columbia on an astronomy mission failed last week. Atlantis has been in the hangar since early August, undergoing repairs for leaks in hydrogen lines between the orbiter and its external tank. Its classified Pentagon mission, originally scheduled for July, is now set for early November. NASA officials repeatedly have said they are confident Discovery's fuel lines are leak-free because of the shuttle's flight performance in April and the minimal amount of work performed since then in its engine compartment. NASA faces an Oct. 23 launch deadline for Discovery and the plutonium-powered sun probe, named for the legendary Greek adventurer Ulysses. If Discovery does not lift off by then, the mission will have to wait until the planets are properly aligned again in late 1991. To enter an orbit passing over the sun's poles, Ulysses must travel to Jupiter, a 16-month trip, and use that planet's gravity to throw it back toward the sun. Ulysses is expected to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole the following year. The White House on Monday approved Discovery's launch with Ulysses. Such approval is necessary when radioisotope thermoelectric generators, or RTGs, are used. Ulysses' one RTG will convert heat from 24{ pounds of decaying plutonium into electricity. Anti-nuclear activists and environmentalists oppose the generator's use, saying a Challenger-like accident would spread the deadly plutonium over Florida. But officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration contend the health risk would be small, even in the worst circumstance. The $750 million mission initially was scheduled for May 1986 but was delayed by the Challenger explosion earlier that year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Senate to Quickly Approve German Unification Treaty
With AM-German-Literati, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush urged the Senate Tuesday to swiftly approve a historic treaty to end the division of Germany, 45 years after the defeat of the Nazis. At a ceremony in the Rose Garden, Bush called the agreement ``the culmination of more than four decades of Western resolve and determination, from the darkest hours of the Cold War to the bright new horizons that stretch before us.'' The accord formally relinquishes all rights and responsibilities over Germany by the four victorious allies in World War II. It was signed in Moscow on Sept. 12 by officials from the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. The treaty must be ratified by the four allied powers before their rights in Germany are formally terminated. However, the four countries have agreed to ``suspend'' their rights on Oct. 1, two days before the merger of East and West Germany. In the transmittal letter to the Senate, Bush said, ``It is wholly fitting that Germany formally and irrevocably achieve its unified status at the earliest possible moment, unfettered by four-power rights, shared by the Soviet Union, which are now outmoded and unnecessary.'' He said the treaty ``represents a major achievement for our German allies, who have not forgotten the past or the role Germany once played in the horrors of 1933-45, but who have demonstrated over four decades of steadfast support for democracy and the Western alliance what the world can expect from the united Germany.'' After the defeat of the Nazis, the four allies divided Germany and its capital into four occupation zones, which became East and West Germany and East and West Berlin. Aside from ending the division of the country, the treaty calls on the Soviet Union to complete the withdrawal of its estimated 370,000 troops from what is now East Germany by 1994. U.S., British and French troops will remain in Berlin during the interim. In his remarks, Bush said the treaty ``will end the artificial division of Germany and Berlin and it will restore to Germany sovereignty over all its territory and end all remaining four-power rights and responsibilities. ``This agreement clears the way to achievement of the goal we Americans have long shared with the German people, a united, democratic and sovereign Germany,'' the president said. He congratulated West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the German people ``for keeping their dream of national self-determination ever alive.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Says Sanctions Slowed Reform in South Africa
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs de Klerk remarks; picks up 4th graf pvs, The 24-member...
DOC.TEXT: South African President F. W. de Klerk said today he believes the economic sanctions imposed by the United States against his country slowed down the reform process that he has instituted. De Klerk, speaking to a press luncheon as he neared the end of his official visit here, said his government nonetheless plans to carry out all of the reforms the sanctions were designed to promote. Asked about the impact of the sanctions legislation, de Klerk said, ``To a great extent it was counterproductive. ``People under threat tend to react negatively. We don't like as a country to be prescribed to by other countries. And there's an emotional reaction which is brought about by that.'' Among other measures, the sanctions, approved in 1986 over President Reagan's veto, forbid new U.S. investment in South Africa and deny South African air carriers landing rights in the United States. De Klerk spoke to reporters at a National Press Club luncheon after conferring with Senate leaders. Since his arrival here Sunday, de Klerk has sought to convince Americans that he is serious about his commitment to establish a non-racial system in his country. But some black activists remain skeptical. The 24-member Congressional Black Caucus canceled a meeting it had scheduled with de Klerk because it feared the session could be misinterpreted. After de Klerk's meeting Monday with President Bush, Randall Robinson, head of the TransAfrica anti-apartheid group, said the two leaders' meeting sent a ``false and dangerous message'' that South Africa is on its way to change. De Klerk, meanwhile, assured Bush that the process of democratic reform cannot be reversed. ``We will not turn back,'' he said, promising a new system in which all South Africans will have a ``vote of equal value.'' Bush, in turn, hailed the ``dramatic progress'' away from apartheid rule in South Africa. ``Clearly, the time has come to encourage and assist the emerging new South Africa,'' Bush said after his 2{ hour session with de Klerk. Behind the leaders, a black Marine held the flag of South Africa and a white Marine held the American flag. It was just a year ago that de Klerk assumed the South African presidency, a time when U.S.-South African relations were still frosty because of the negligible progress toward ending white rule. Bush remarked on how far South Africa has come under de Klerk's tutelage. ``Who among us, only a year ago, would have anticipated these remarkable developments,'' Bush said. De Klerk has overseen the lifting of bans on democratic political parties and the release of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, among other prisoners. Still, South Africa has not met the requirements for lifting U.S. economic sanctions, which were imposed by Congress four years ago over President Reagan's veto. U.S. officials said South Africa still must lift emergency rule in Natal Province and release the remaining political prisoners before the sanctions may be suspended. Later, Foreign Minister Pik Botha said Bush's characterization of the dismantling of apartheid as irreversible should help persuade European governments to lift sanctions. He said he understood the difficulty in changing U.S. sanctions written into law by Congress. ``We are aware of the sensitivities constraining the U.S. administration and we are not here to ask the U.S. to do anything about it at this stage,'' Botha said. The Congressional Black Caucus remains skeptical about de Klerk's promises. Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., caucus chairman, explained the decision not to meet with de Klerk, saying, ``To meet with the caucus separate and apart bestows a level of credibility that at this point we are not prepared to deal with.'' But Dellums and other black members of the House were to be among the lawmakers meeting with de Klerk this afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Illusionists' 10,000th Performance Raises $150,000 for Eye Research
DOC.TEXT: Illusionists Siegfried & Roy, who dreamed 20 years ago of someday playing Las Vegas, have raised $150,000 for eye research with their 10,000th performance here. The veterans of the Las Vegas Strip used the milestone show at the Mirage Hotel on Monday night to stage a $300-per-ticket gala to raise money for the Baltimore-based Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation. After the show, Siegfried, whose last name is Fischbacher, said he and partner Roy Uwe Ludwig Horn, came to the United States from West Germany two decades ago with the dream of playing Las Vegas. ``We are living proof that you should never give up your dreams,'' he said. Roy told of being approached 16 years ago with the idea of bringing blind children to the estate where the two keep a menagerie of tigers and other exotic animals. He said his fondest memory of the day was of a blind girl approaching him and asking to ``feel'' what a tiger looked like. ``She asked me to put her hands on the tiger, to run her fingers along his stripes.'' Mirage Chairman Steve Wynn sat with Retinitis Pigmentosa President Gordon Gund, who is blind, and described the show to him. ``I have a vested interest in this subject,'' Wynn said of the Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation. The gaming executive suffers from partial sight impairment.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Move to Market Accompanied by Rise in Economic Crime
With AM-Soviet-Solzhenitsyn, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets' stumbling transition to a free economy is unleashing a wave of economic crime, and the black market is thriving on the sale of scarce goods, senior police officials said Tuesday. Investigators have found corruption at half of the 160,000 businesses they have inspected so far this year, and cases of serious embezzlement are running at twice last year's rate, Col. Vyacheslav I. Runyshkov of the Ministry of Internal Affairs told a news conference. The release of such alarming statistics on black marketeering indicated that law enforcement officials are concerned about social and economic problems stemming from the zigzag path to reform. For a year, the Soviet government and legislature have been on the verge of moving from a planned to a market economy but have balked repeatedly, throwing the system into chaos. Severe shortages of consumer goods, such as bread and tobacco, not only have caused widespread dissatisfaction, but have fueled the already extensive black market. The disappearance of goods between factories and state-owned retail outlets means the system will be able to provide only 32 percent of the national requirements for medicine, but purchases abroad could raise that figure to 68 percent, said Runyshkov, who is in charge of the nation's chief anti-corruption unit. He cited similar shortages of vegetables, potatoes, grain and other staples. Runyshkov strongly denied the shortages were caused either by a conspiracy among hard-line Communist Party opponents of reform, or by an organized crime network. ``It is often said that this is a result of the actions of some destructive forces or the mafia,'' he said. ``I declare that neither the Ministry of Internal Affairs nor the KGB have established this.'' ``What is at hand is just negligence,'' he said, describing case after case in which workers diverted goods from state enterprises and sold them illegally. Asked to provide more specific reasons for the disappearance of bread or vegetables, Runyshkov and five other police officials laughed nervously and replied: ``We don't understand it.'' The phenomenon they described was one of many small- and medium-sized thefts in which the goods turn up for sale in private shops, called cooperatives, or on the black market. The chaos that has surrounded economic reform led the national legislature on Monday to grant President Mikhail S. Gorbachev broad powers to steer the country from a planned to a market system without consulting lawmakers every step of the way. The resolution allows Gorbachev to issue presidential decrees for the next 18 months on property, wages, prices, the national budget, the financial system, and law and order. The surge in economic crime indicates that the state distribution system appears to be disintegrating. Black market prices run two to three times those in state stores for most goods, and three to five times for automobiles, Runyshkov said. On Sept. 20, he said, 650 state-owned butcher shops did not have meat, 799 did not have sausage, 1,069 dairy shops had no eggs and 1,803 grocery stores had no sugar. He did not cite the number of stores overall for comparison. Runyshkov said the number of people tried on major embezzlement charges doubled from last year to this year, but he did not say specifically how many people were involved. The number of people tried for economic crimes of all types was 188,000 in the first eight months of this year, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Reports Shift in Soviet Defense Spending, Arms Output
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military spending fell last year for the first time since President Mikahil Gorbachev came to power in 1985, reflecting the impact of a domestic economic crisis and ``new thinking'' in the Kremlin, the Pentagon said Tuesday. The Defense Department also said in its annual assessment of Soviet military strength that Moscow slowed the pace of arms production last year, particularly of tanks, artillery pieces and other equipment for its ground forces. The report, the ninth in a series started by then-Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, departed from previous editions by striking an encouraging tone in describing the security threat to the West posed by the Soviet military. ``The likelihood of a conflict stemming from U.S.-Soviet confrontation is lower than it has ever been in the post-war era,'' the report said, noting the historic changes of the last year, including the breakup of the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe. ``Prior to the advent of `new thinking,' Soviet military policies sought to build and maintain forces capable of defeating the combined forces of all potential adversaries,'' it said. ``... the Soviets now set less ambitious goals.'' In an introductory essay, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he was encouraged by signs of Soviet eagerness to cooperate with the West, but he added that domestic political and economic turmoil made it difficult to be sure of Soviet intentions. ``In such an atmosphere, it is difficult to predict what will happen next month, let alone next year,'' Cheney wrote, adding a note of caution: ``The Soviet Union remains an enormous military superpower. The intentions of that regime are changing. But intentions are not enough to support dramatic changes in our level of preparedness.'' The report said Soviet defense spending last year fell by 4 percent to 5 percent from the 1988 level. Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, said that in the period from 1985, when Gorbachev assumed power as General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, to 1988, Soviet military spending rose by an annual average of 3 percent. U.S. defense spending since 1985 has declined by an annual average of about 2 percent and is headed for a bigger drop as a resulf of current negotiations between the White House and Congress over the 1991 budget year, which starts Monday. Gorbachev announced in January 1989 that he intended to cut defense spending by 14.2 percent by 1991. The Pentagon report said the most pronounced reductions in Soviet arms production in 1989 came in ground forces materiel. Moscow built about 1,700 tanks last year, half the previous year's total. Production of artillery pieces fell by nearly 20 percent and multiple-rocket launchers dropped to 300 from 480. Cheney stressed that while Gorbachev was reducing arms production in most areas he was maintaining Soviet strength in strategic, or long-range, nuclear forces. The Soviets, for example, are modernizing their arsenal of intercontinental ballistic missiles, including continued deployment of the SS-24, a multiple-warhead missile, the mobile SS-25 and a new version of the SS-18, which carries 10 warheads. The Pentagon report said that domestic crises, including nationalist movements and economic turmoil, pose grave dangers to the stability of the Soviet Union - and thus made it impossible to be sure if military reforms will be lasting. ``Domestic crises ... are bringing the Soviet Union to the brink of economic breakdown and potential internal chaos,'' the report said. ``As a result, the Soviets are developing a policy and strategy that is oriented toward defense of the USSR and away from external adventurism.'' In a departure from past practice, Cheney did not personally present the Pentagon report at a news conference. His spokesman, Pete Williams, said Cheney's decision reflected in part U.S. appreciation of Soviet cooperation in the multinational effort to force Iraq, a former Soviet arms customer, out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Two Students Killed In Clashes With Police
DOC.TEXT: Police shot and killed two students and wounded seven others Tuesday in street battles with upper-caste Hindus protesting a quota policy that reserves many government jobs for lower castes, police said. In Haryana state, north of New Delhi, one student committed suicide by consuming insecticide and two more tried to burn themselves to death Tuesday, Press Trust of India reported. The trouble in the capital started after hospital authorities announced the death of Surinder Singh Chauhan, a 24-year-old student who had set himself ablaze Monday to dramatize the protest. Students rampaged for more than six hours, burning government and police vehicles and clashing with policemen. About 400 people were detained, a senior police official said, but said they were expected to be released Wednesday without charges. ``The situation is tense. The (police) action had to take place, but I don't think the situation is beyond control,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The protests were the most violent in eight weeks of demonstrations against the new quotas. Under them, 27 percent of government jobs are reserved for people from low castes in an effort to make up for centuries of oppression imposed by India's rigid caste system. An additional 22.5 percent of the jobs already were kept aside for what were designated as the most backward castes and native tribes. Five percent to 10 percent of jobs are to be reserved for the poor, irrespective of caste. Upper-caste students say the policy will deprive them of jobs which will go to less qualified applicants. Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi demanded Prime Minister V.P. Singh's resignation, saying it would pave the way for reconciliation. The Bharatiya Janata, or Indian People's Party, which supports Singh's minority government, called for a general strike in New Delhi on Wednesday to protest the police action. In the anti-quota protests, at least 27 people have died in battles with police in northern states. At least 27 other protesters have attempted suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Strike in Disputed Territory in Soviet Caucasus
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people went on a 24-hour strike Tuesday in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh in the southern Soviet Union, demanding the restoration of rule by its Armenian majority, the Tass news agency reported. The protest was peaceful, and Soviet Interior Ministry troops did not interfere, Tass said. The troops are enforcing the state of emergency in the enclave, located inside the republic of Azerbaijan in the Caucasus mountains. In the past two years, more than 200 people have been killed in a dispute between Azerbaijan and neighboring Armenia over who should govern Nagorno-Karabakh. Soviet authorities gave the mountainous territory to Azerbaijan, which is predominantly Shiite Moslem, in 1923. Like Nagorno-Karabakh's population, Armenia is predominantly Christian. Tuesday's demonstrators expressed support for Soviet parliament deputies from Nagorno-Karabakh who are on a hunger strike to protest the dissolution of regional councils and the regional Communist Party committee by the Soviets, Tass and the independent Interfax news agency reported. Neither agency said when the legislators began their hunger strikes. Armenians are upset over what they perceive as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's failure to respond to their complaints that Azerbaijani authorities violated a Soviet parliament decree in November 1989. That action abolished a Soviet government committee that had controlled Nagorno-Karabakh for the previous 10{ months, and returned it to Azerbaijani rule. Armenians complain that Azerbaijani authorities have been altering the administrative boundaries in Nagorno-Karabakh and resettling Azerbaijani refugees there. Protesters sent a telegram to Gorbachev on Tuesday that said concentrations of Azerbaijani militants were growing in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Homosexuals Taking Precautions Following Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Male homosexuals have started carrying guns when they go to bars since they heard rumors that a murderer may be stalking them. ``At least six of my friends are carrying guns now, too,'' Richard Todd said recently in Our Place, a gay bar. In the past decade, the bodies of 11 slain young men in their teens and 20s have been found dumped in remote areas of central Indiana and western Ohio. All were nude or partially clothed; seven were strangled and the causes of death of four were not determined. The first 10 had ties to the Indianapolis homosexual community, investigators say. It is not known if the latest victim, found Sept. 12 in Darke County, Ohio, had ties to that community, said Larry Swihart, a Preble County, Ohio, sheriff's investigator. Authorities believe the slayings may be the work of one person, although they stop short of calling the deaths serial killings.
