David Morse, manager of Our Place, said he and others believe the killer is a gay man who believes he is heterosexual. ``He experiences sexual urges and acts impulsively upon them, then feels guilty and afraid because of it,'' Morse said. ``It's very hard to come to terms with homosexuality because there is so much discrimination against it.'' Morse added: ``Whoever is killing these people has a good knowledge of the gay community. He knows where to go to find his victims.'' Todd says he and other gay men have changed their lifestyles since the slayings were linked. ``You can't have one-night stands. If it is a one-night stand, then you are chancing dying,'' he said. But Morse said the community is not afraid, just more cautious. He has asked employees to keep an eye out for strangers and plans to post newspaper articles about the slayings. ``We're encouraging them to read the articles and to know the people they meet,'' he said. ``I know people pick up the paper and say, `This won't happen to me,' '' said David Roettger, whose son was one of the victims. ``Well, not everything happens to somebody else.'' Investigators say they are no closer to finding a suspect. ``We have no answers,'' said Darke County, Ohio, Sheriff Robert Sullenbarger. ``We don't even know where the homicides occurred. Now we pray for a little luck.''

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Issues Rules for Catholic Universities
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II issued rules for the world's Catholic universities Tuesday, a compromise document that instructed schools to uphold official doctrine but dropped proposals to give bishops wide powers. The long-awaited document pleased many U.S. Catholic educators, who had protested earlier drafts that would have given bishops a say in hiring and firing of theology teachers. The final document assigns bishops a watchdog role in protecting the universities' Catholic identity. American officials were surprised, however, by the pope's stipulation that a majority of a university's teachers be Catholic - a decree Vatican officials acknowledged will be difficult to carry out in certain countries. Archbishop Pio Laghi, head of the Vatican's Congregation for Catholic Education, said finding a Catholic-majority faculty in nations like Japan and Indonesia might be impossible. ``This should be considered a principle, something that should be put into effect as much as we can,'' he said. The 49-page document, drawn up over 10 years and issued in the form of a constitution, upheld the right ff academic freedom and independence. But it also stressed that students and teachers, particularly theologians, must not stray from official church teaching. ``All Catholic teachers are to be faithful to, and all other teachers are to respect, Catholic doctrine and morals in their research and teaching,'' it said. American Catholic educators had complained that earlier drafts threatened to undermine academic freedom and give the church hierarchy too much control. The United States, with 235 Catholic institutes of higher learning, has the world's largest Catholic university system. Sister Alice Gallin of Washington, D.C., executive director of the Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities, said she did not believe the U.S. system would have to make major changes to comply with the church's new policy. The document says the constitution will go into effect at the start of the 1991 academic year and applies to all 935 Catholic universities and institutes throughout the world. Four years ago, the presidents of 110 U.S. Catholic institutions said imposition of the Vatican's original proposals could force some of the nation's schools to close, drive theologians away and cost the colleges federal and state student aid. The final document says the local bishop ``has a responsibility to promote the welfare of the Catholic universities in his diocese and has the right and duty to watch over the preservation and strengthening of their Catholic character.'' The document said relations between universities and bishops should be marked by ``mutual trust, close and consistent cooperation and continuing dialogue.'' ``That statement in itself would not disturb anybody here,'' said the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, president of Fordham University in New York and part of a U.S. delegation that conferred with Vatican officials in April 1989. The church recognizes freedom of research and teaching in each discipline, it says, but stresses that this must be ``in accordance with its own principles and proper methods.'' The document singled out the role of theologians, saying they must ``respect the authority of the bishops and assent to Catholic doctrine.'' During John Paul's papacy, several theologians have been punished for straying from church teaching on sexual and other issues. They include the Rev. Charles E. Curran, barred from teaching at Catholic University of America in Washington in 1987. Three months ago, the Vatican issued a document ruling out public dissent by theologians, telling them to uphold church doctrine or keep quiet.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois City's Plan to Tax College Students' Tuition Fails
DOC.TEXT: The City Council, unable to override a mayoral veto of its proposed tax on college students' tuition, has decided to look at other ways of increasing revenue from Northwestern University. Council members voted 10-8 Monday in favor of overriding Mayor Joan Barr's veto. Twelve votes were needed. But the council did establish a three-member committee to look for other ways to increase the revenue Northwestern brings into the city. Officials said that if approved the tuition tax would have been the first in the nation. Supporters of the tax said it would have offset revenue lost because Northwestern's 242 acres are not subject to property taxes. School officials complained the tax would hurt students. The measure called for most students at Northwestern and three other colleges in the Chicago suburb of 73,000 to pay about $45 annually. Alderman Jack Korshak said the measure would have generated more than $500,000 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Stuntman Dies While Practicing Jump off Cliff
DOC.TEXT: A movie stuntman died after miscalculating his landing on a practice jump off a seaside cliff, officials said. Jay Currin, 34, was attempting a 60-foot fall Monday from a cliff at Point Dume State Beach when he landed on the edge of an air bag and was thrown onto the rocks along the beach, Sgt. Eugene Cox said. ``He just miscalculated his leap,'' Cox said. Paramedics airlifted the stuntman to Westlake Medical Center, where he underwent surgery for internal injuries. He died Monday evening, said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Rafael Estrada. The state Division of Occupational Safety and Health and the district attorney's office will investigate the death, officials said. Currin, described as a veteran stuntman employed by B.I. Productions, was part of a crew filming a movie, but authorities refused to disclose the film's title or any of its stars.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Dead Reported in Sandinista-Contra Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista peasants and demobilized Contra rebels fought over land in remote northern Nicaragua, and seven people were killed, a newspaper reported Tuesday. It was the latest in a series of violent incidents in the hinterland involving land-hungry peasants from the two sides, and comes amid increasing tensions elsewhere in the country. Striking workers at the main government bus depot in Managua burned tires Tuesday and said they would not allow the vehicles to leave the yard. The strikers, who oppose privatizing public transport and are demanding higher pay, took over the facility Sept. 17 and since then have been ousted twice by police. On Tuesday morning, they remained outside the locked gates of the yard, and citizens were forced to use private buses and pickup trucks to get to work. The leftist Sandinista Front and its powerful labor unions announced a march by teachers Wednesday to kick off a civic protest that is to culminate next Monday with a nationwide strike. On Wednesday President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is scheduled to leave for New York, where she is to speak at the United Nations. Barricada, official newspaper of the Sandinista Front, said in a front-page story that seven people were killed and four were wounded when a group of demobilized rebels tried to take over a Sandinista cooperative farm called La Dalia. The farm is near San Juan de Rio Coco, a village 150 miles northeast of Managua, in the mountains near the Honduran border. Official confirmation of the incident, which Barricada said occurred Monday afternoon, was not immediately available. Spokesmen for the Interior Ministry, in charge of rural police, and the Sandinista People's Army were in a meeting and not immediately available for comment, their offices said. According to Barricada, the former Contra rebels are in control of the narrow dirt roads leading into the zone and have erected roadblocks where passing vehicles are checked. Agrarian Reform Minister Gustavo Tablada's deputy, Nemesio Porras, said Tablada was out of the country, but did not say where. Tablada's ministry is in charge of more than 3,000 agriculture cooperatives established during the 10 years of Sandinista rule and of distributing land to nearly 20,000 rebels who laid down their weapons earlier this year and returned to civilian life. Most of the former Contras are peasants and many had their lands confiscated by the Sandinistas when they took up arms against the leftist regime, who lost Feb. 25 elections to Mrs. Chamorro. Government officials say they have distributed as much land as they can to the former guerrillas, who say they want more land because much of what has been given them is unusable. Mrs. Chamorro's government has met with strong Sandinista opposition in its attempts to rescue Nicaragua's economy. Among measures announced by the government is the planned firing of 25,000 civil servants starting Oct. 1 and the privatization of hundreds of enterprises confiscated by the Sandinistas. The Sandinistas have vowed not to allow that to happen and plan staggered strikes nationwide, beginning with teachers on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Burglary Victim Turns Sleuth
DOC.TEXT: A bit of high-tech sleuthing enabled burglary victim Marvin Valento to get back most of his stolen goods, and enabled police to round up a group of teen-agers on charges in three robberies. ``He's unique. What he did opened up a Pandora's box,'' said Sgt. John Ballis of the St. Paul burglary unit. Valento, 30, reported that his house was broken into Aug. 28 and a shotgun, audio gear and two telephones were missing. He had modified the cordless phone's base to pick up sounds whether the phone was in use. ``I told my wife, `I bet those guys are going to use that phone,' '' Valento said. ``I punched in the phone's frequency on my police scanner and, sure enough, I got a signal. I said, `I want to bust these guys.' '' Shortly before midnight, Valento discovered the signal in a nearby house with the aid of the scanner, a directional antenna and 200 feet of extension cord. Then he heard a voice describing the burglary. He got a cassette tape from an all-night convenience store and started recording. The next day Valento presented his findings and cassette tape to detectives. The detectives were skeptical, but Ballis said he had heard enough to apply for a search warrant, which Ramsey County District Judge David Marsden approved. The detectives burst into the house late Aug. 29 and found everything taken from Valento's house but the shotgun. The cordless phone was on the second floor, where Valento had said it would be. Ballis started asking the youths in the house about other recent burglaries in Valento's neighborhood. Some of them confessed, and started naming others. By the time investigators closed the books on the case, three burglaries had been solved and seven teen-agers were facing charges. ``I outsmarted the criminals. That's the philosophy I'm taking on it,'' Valento, a computer manufacturing entrepreneur and electronics hobbyist, said Monday. So far, two 14-year-olds and a 16-year-old have been sent to juvenile institutions, a 17-year-old has been charged with transporting stolen property, and three 18-year-olds were charged with burglary. ``It just snowballed,'' Ballis said. ``We even got an auto thief out of the deal. We wouldn't have gotten any of them without Mr. Valento.''

DOC.HEAD: Don't Tell Bluto: College Dorm Promotes Healthy Lifestyle
DOC.TEXT: Please don't confuse Anibal house with ``Animal House,'' the 1977 movie about a rowdy, beered-up fraternity. Bluto, the dissolute character played by John Belushi in the movie, would have kicked himself out of Anibal Hall, a dormitory at Oakland University in suburban Detroit. The 46 women and 22 men in the dormitory agreed before moving in that they would not use or possess alcohol or tobacco on the premises. That's only one aspect of what school officials call the first Michigan college dormitory devoted to a wellness program. Anibal Hall also has weight-training and aerobics rooms. Residents are encouraged to attend lectures on subjects such as stress management, weight control, cardiopulmonary resuscitation and sports nutrition. ``It removes some of the craziness, probably,'' said Fritz Barnes, an 18-year-old freshman engineering student. ``There's still craziness, but it's good craziness. It's nothing that's going to hurt anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Attacks Solzhenitsyn Article About Russia's Future
LaserPhoto MOSB6
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Solzhenitsyn's proposal to replace the Soviet Union with an all-Slavic state is destructive and disrespectful to the country's other ethnic groups, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Tuesday. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prize-winning author who was expelled from the Soviet Union for treason in 1974, made his proposal in an article published a week ago by two Soviet newspapers. In his first public comment on the article, Gorbachev told the national legislature that Solzhenitsyn was an ``undoubtedly great man,'' but ``his views on the future of our multinational state are unacceptable.'' Gorbachev cast himself as a politician dedicated to preserving the Soviet Union as a multiethnic country. Several lawmakers also attacked Solzhenitsyn, and none supported him or came to his defense. Solzhenitsyn believes Russia has a unique heritage and destiny, and he condemns Soviet efforts to bind dozens of disparate cultures into a single nation. Solzhenitsyn, 71, wrote his rambling, philosophical article, titled ``How We Can Make Russia Comfortable,'' at his home in Cavendish, Vt. It was published Sept. 18 by the reformist newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda and a day later by the literary weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta. The newspapers have a combined circulation of 26.5 million, and the article was an immediate sensation throughout the country - discussed on Moscow streets, read by lawmakers and mentioned on the nightly TV news. But until Gorbachev was asked by a lawmaker to comment on the article Tuesday, there was no public reaction from a top government official. The article, which took up the equivalent of four full newspaper pages, said communism had taken a flourishing country and turned it back into a ``half-savage state.'' But it also expressed disdain for Western ``pop-mass culture'' and urged Russia not to follow the West blindly. Solzhenitsyn urged a populist revival ``from below,'' saying that Russia's villages and rural areas should be the starting point for the creation of democracy and a healthy economy. He also advocated the breakup of collective farms, called for free enterprise and warned against a political system in which parties compete for power. ``Every party tries to do its best not for the whole nation but for itself and its own members,'' he wrote. Gorbachev focused on just one of Solzhenitsyn's many suggestions: that Russia, Byelorussia, the Ukraine and much of Kazakhstan, which are inhabited primarily by people of Slavic extraction, should form a single nation and let the other 11 Soviet republics secede. ``The article and the author's personality demand a very srious analysis,'' Gorbachev said. ``I am seized by very contradictory feelings. ... As a Russian, I fully share concern for the destiny of the Russian people and Russia. ``But at the same time, as a Russian, I definitely cannot agree with Solzhenitsyn's attitude toward other ethnic groups. Even by the most generous appraisal, it is a disrespectful stand. I cannot agree with it.'' Gorbachev added that Solzhenitsyn was ``living entirely in the past, the past Russia, the czarist monarchy.'' The writer's views ``are far from reality and ... have a destructive character,'' he said. Gorbachev's remarks came as the national legislature began debate on how to negotiate a new union treaty with the 15 Soviet republics. Gorbachev said he wants a ``union of sovereign states'' in which every ethnic group ``feels good and realizes its potential.'' Among the lawmakers who criticized Solzhenitsyn was Boris Oleinik, deputy chairman of the legislature's Council of Nationalities, who said the writer's views ``belittle the national dignity'' of many ethnic groups and ``could lead to separatism.'' Yurii Shcherbak, a lawmaker from the Ukraine, said Solzhenitsyn's proposals were underlined by ``messianic, neo-monarchist ideas of great power chauvinism.'' The lawmaker who asked for Gorbachev's comments was Erkegali Rakhmadiev of Kazakhstan, who objected to Solzhenitsyn's appeal for Russians to take control of some Kazakh lands. He said in an interview later that the writer's proposal was a ``Hitlerite, fascistic approach.'' Even delegates from republics that are seeking independence from the Soviet Union - such as Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Georgia - did not try to defend Solzhenitsyn. One bit of support for Solzhenitsyn came Tuesday from Ryazan, the city 100 miles southeast of Moscow where Solzhenitsyn wrote his books ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich'' and ``The Cancer Ward.'' The city council officially gave him ``the freedom of Ryazan,'' an honor much like receiving the key to a city. Solzhenitsyn's works describe life in Soviet labor camps and were banned in the Soviet Union from the mid-1960s until after Gorbachev came to power in 1985. His books, including ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' are now being published but are still not widely available. Gorbachev restored the writer's citizenship last month but Solzhenitsyn has expressed reluctance about returning.

DOC.HEAD: Conan Doyle's Robe Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: A bathrobe worn by Sherlock Holmes' creator, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, was sold for more than $2,000 on Tuesday. The century-old, calf-length garment of thick tweed in a light brown check pattern was offered for sale by a collector and bought by an anonymous telephone bidder, said Vennett-Smith Auctions of Goatham near Nottingham. The dressing gown was described in a short story, ``The Man with the Twisted Lip,'' said auctioneer Trevor Vennett-Smith. He said Conan Doyle often wore it when writing, and it later belonged to Sidney Paget, who used it as a model in six of his illustrations for stories about the fictional detective. ``We sell only postcards, cigarette cards and autographs, but we were offered the dressing gown by a good client and we know that anything with a Sherlock Holmes connection always sells,'' the auctioneer said. The sale price was 1,100 pounds, or $2,068.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Fails To Secure Iranian Pledge On Sanctions
LaserPhoto TOK7
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Syrian President Hafez Assad left Tehran on Tuesday after a four-day visit, and sources said he failed to win a pledge from his Iranian allies not to send food and other essentials to Iraq. Sources close to the Syrian delegation quoted Assad as saying Tehran did promise not to buy embargoed Iraqi oil, or to help Baghdad export its crude through Iranian pipelines. Iran has said it will enforce sanctions on neighboring Iraq imposed by the United Nations after Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The United States has formed a new alliance with Syria since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Assad, who met earlier this month in Damascus with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, is believed to have gone to Tehran at Washington's behest to gauge the seriousness of Iran's suggestions it would send essentials to Iraq. But the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington's main concern was whether the Iranians intended to help Iraq export oil, its main source of revenue, through their pipelines. In his meetings with Assad, Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani insisted that food supplies to Iraq - Iran's foe in the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war - did not violate those sanctions because ``humanitarian shipments'' are permitted, the sources said. Assad has sent 4,000 commandos to join the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia and has pledged to send an armored division as well. Saddam, internationally isolated and squeezed by the embargo, suddenly made peace with Iran last month, ending two years of deadlocked peace talks. The Islamic Republic News Agency reported Sunday that Iranian authorities had arrested 29 smugglers trying to move foodstuffs across the border into Iraq - the first report of Iran taking steps to enforce the sanctions. The sources said Assad carried a message to Rafsanjani from Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, calling for an improvement in the strained relations between the Moslem rivals if Tehran blocked supplies to Iraq and sent troops to join the multinational force confronting Saddam. Iran rejected the Saudi conditions, the sources said. The Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, flew to Damascus shortly before Assad to get a first-hand account of the talks in Tehran, Arab diplomats said. Rafsanjani, leader of the country's so-called pragmatists, is eager to rebuild bridges with the West and is believed to favor abiding by the sanctions. But he is under pressure from his powerful, vehemently anti-American radical rivals who want Iran to help Iraq confront ``The Great Satan.'' The Iranians have condemned the Iraqi invasion. But they have also criticized Fahd for allowing non-Moseem Western forces into Saudi Arabia, where Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina are located. Riyadh severed ties with Tehran in 1987, citing subversion and terrorism. The sources reported that Assad had some differences with Iranian leaders. But they said these were not so great as to drive a wedge between Tehran and its Arab ally. Before leaving Tehran, Assad told a news conference that he and Rafsanjani were in ``complete agreement'' on issues concerning the gulf, Tehran Radio reported. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Rafsanjani as confirming that ``on the gulf crisis our stance was completely in line with Syria's.'' Assad was originally due to leave Tehran on Sunday, but he extended his stay an extra day. The sources said another item discussed in the meetings was the fate of 13 Western hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon, where Syria is the main power broker. No results of the meetings were announced. Iranian diplomats said last week when Assad's visit was announced that some hostages could soon be freed. Most of the captives - six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian - are held by Shiite Moslem factions linked to the fundamentalist Hezbollah, Tehran's main ally in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops May Get R-And-R In Romania
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is considering a Romanian offer to put up thousands of U.S. troops on their way to and from the Arabian peninsula in luxury resorts free of charge, officials said Tuesday. The offer would apply through the winter and would be extended to British and Canadian troops as well, Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu said. If the offer is accepted, Romania would become the first member of the crumbling Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to permit U.S and other NATO troops on its territory. The Romanian proposal was revealed two days before the departure of President Ion Iliescu for the United States. Iliescu, a former Communist who took power during the December revolution that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu and won popular elections in May, is seeking to repair his image in the United States. An official at the U.S. Embassy described the Romanian offer as ``a gesture of support for the West in the gulf crisis.'' The official, speaking on condition on anonymity, said Romanian officials contacted the embassy last week and offered ``R-and-R facilities for American troops both in the mountains and on the Black Sea coast, on favorable terms.''

DOC.HEAD: City Considers Turning State Penitentiary Into Mall
DOC.TEXT: Prisoners have been fighting to get outside the thick stone walls for more than a century, but in the future shoppers might be fighting to get inside for bargains. City and Marshall County officials are considering converting the 124-year-old West Virginia Penitentiary into a outlet shopping mall. The state's maximum-security prison is scheduled to be closed in 1992 and replaced with a new prison in Fayette County. The city paid PRP Consultants $13,000 to do a feasibility study, which will take about two months, of what can be done with the six-acre site.

DOC.HEAD: New Bolivian Law Returns Rain Forests to Indians
DOC.TEXT: Bolivia on Tuesday gave its Indians control of vast tracts of troical rain forest and moved to limit exploitation by logging companies. ``I have the feeling we are writing one of the most beautiful and clean pages in the contemporary history of Bolivia,'' President Jaime Paz Zamora said Monday night during a meeting with leaders of Bolivia's lowland Indian community. The measures were enacted after 800 Indians from the lowland rain forests made a 35-day march across the Andes to the capital, La Paz, to bring attention to the destruction of their environment. The destruction of South America's tropical rain forests has become a major international concern, because of the loss of irreplaceable species of plants and animals and because it may contribute to global warming. Under the new law, 1.9 million acres of land in the Beni tropical lowlands will be under the control of Chimane Indians. Two logging companies with operations in the area will be able to take wood from the forests only until Dec. 31. After that, they will be allowed to bid for logging in new areas, under government-established ecological guidelines. Four other logging companies that have contracts for another year will be able to continue with operations, the government says. But once the contracts expire, new concessions will not be granted on the lands whose control was ceded over the Indians. Bolivia's lumber companies and some other business leaders warned that limiting logging concessions would hurt foreign investment in the country. Logging companies mainly harvest mahogony trees, most of the wood bound for the lucrative export market. Bolivia exported $40 million worth of fine woods in 1989, the government says. ``We are returning to our homes with dignity and with the knowledge that we have recovered our territories,'' said Indian leader Ernesto Noe. ``We have managed to have doors opened to us and that our proposals be heard.'' The group of Indians, including women and children, marched 470 miles from the city of Trinidad to La Paz, which is 13,000 feet above sea level. At least 150,000 Indians live in the tropical rain forests northeast of La Paz. Two-thirds of Bolivia is made up of tropical lowlands. The Indians are mainly nomadic hunters, fishermen or work as hired hands at cattle ranches.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Democrats Press Effort to Delay Spending Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with Bush comment
DOC.TEXT: Congress today took the first step to delay $85 billion in imminent spending cuts and President Bush vowed to veto such a measure. ``So if there is no budget agreement with real spending reductions and real process reform by the end of the week, I will have to veto it,'' Bush angrily told reporters he summoned outside the Oval Office. ``I do not want to see further delay in kicking this problem on down the road.'' The president said he would veto any congressional resolution that postpones the deadline for the administration and Congress to agree on deficit reductions. He made the comments after a key House panel voted to do just that. THe president commended Republicans who opposed the action and accused Democrats of trying to avoid their fiscal responsibility. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. D-Wash., and other Democratic leaders have said they will press for an extension if a budget deal has been nailed down or seems near
DOC.HEAD: Republicans were, 2nd graf
Eliminate 11th graf: ``White House,'' now redundant
Surgeon General Offers Same Word to Smokers: Quit
DOC.TEXT: Smokers who quit can attain within 10 to 15 years nearly the same chance for a long life as those who never smoked at all, according to Surgeon General Antonia C. Novello. Her first report on smoking - the 21st by a surgeon general since 1964 - said 50 million Americans continue the tobacco habit, though nearly half of all living adults who ever tried it have quit. It said 390,000 die each year from diseases attributed to smoking. ``The earlier one quits, the greater the benefits,'' Novello said. But ``even people who quit smoking at older ages can expect to enjoy a longer and healthier life compared with those who continue to smoke.'' Her report echoed many of the findings of her predecessors, but it was the first to stress the benefits of quitting, rather than the risks posed to those who ignore the medical warnings about tobacco. For example, it emphasized that people who quit before age 50 have half the risk of dying in the next 16.5 years compared with continuing smokers. And for all age groups, it said, 10 to 15 years of abstinence can improve an ex-smoker's outlook for life to nearly the level of those who never smoked. Novello's report is based largely on previously unpublished data from an American Cancer Society study. Because the health benefits of quitting are so great, health insurance plans routinely should cover smoking cessation programs, said Dr. William Roper, director of the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. States also should add that benefit to their Medicaid programs, he said. Federal officials are considering whether to add the coverage to Medicare, which provides health care for the elderly and disabled, but congressional action would probably also be necessary to accomplish that, he said. Officials did not have cost estimates for adding coverage of smoking cessation to health plans. However, they said 90 percent of people who quit smoking do so on their own without the aid of a program. Among other findings of the Novello report: -Men with a pack-a-day habit are 27 times more likely than nonsmokers to die of lung cancer, the nation's leading cause of cancer death. Women who smoke at this rate have 16 times the risk of nonsmokers. -Quitting smoking steadily reduces the lung cancer risk. After a decade of abstinence, ex-smokers have 30 percent to 50 percent the risk of dying of lung cancer as continuing smokers. The risk continues to decline as the period of abstinence lengthens. -Quitting also reduces the risk of cancers of the larynx, mouth, esophagus, pancreas and bladder. -Smoking during pregnancy doubles the risk of having a low-birthweight baby. About 25 percent of pregnant women smoke. Those who quit after three to four months of pregnancy can reduce the risk to the child, but simply cutting back without quitting appears to have little or no benefit. -Smokers are twice as likely to die of heart disease, the leading cause of death, as nonsmokers. They can cut the excess risk in half after only a year of not smoking, the report said. The risk keeps declining with future years of abstinence. -Quitting also reduces risk of dying from stroke, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, influenza, pneumonia, peripheral artery occlusive disease and aortic aneurysm. Additionally, quitting smoking lowers the risk of developing gastric or duodenal ulcers, the report said. The average weight gain by smokers when they quit is five pounds, but this poses very little health risk, the report said. Less than 4 percent who quit gain more than 20 pounds, it said. The extent to which quitting the habit will improve health and reverse the health damages caused by smoking depends on how long and how much someone has smoked, the report noted. But even smokers who have already have developed smoking-related disease or symptoms can benefit from quitting, it said. Studies have found that cancer patients who quit smoking lower their risk of getting a second primary cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Former Governor's Aide Sentenced to 46 Months in Money-Laundering Case
DOC.TEXT: The onetime chief of staff to former Gov. Jerry Brown has been sentenced to 46 months in prison for conspiring to launder $300,000 that an undercover FBI agent told him was Colombian drug money. U.S. District Judge J. Lawrence Irving on Monday also fined Richard Silberman $5,500 and said he would decide by next week whether to raise that to the maximum $75,000. Silberman was arrested at a San Diego hotel in April 1989. Prosecutors said he was attempting to negotiate a $1.1 million money laundering deal with FBI agent Peter Ahearn, whom Silberman thought was an associate of Colombian cocaine traffickers. Silberman apologized before his sentencing ``for the hurt and the pain'' he caused his wife, San Diego County Supervisor Susan Golding, and other family members. ``I accept full responsibility for what I did and it won't happen again,'' he told Irving. Silberman, 61, was Brown's chief of staff in the 1970s and an influential Democratic party fund-raiser for years. The former financier also served on several state commissions and donated money to many non-profit groups in San Diego. ``It is clear to me that you have achieved more than most men could ever dream of. Your contributions to this community have been significant,'' Irving told him during sentencing. ``What boggles my mind is that you chose to become ... part of the chain that brought poison into the community that you had supported for years.'' Silberman was accused of masterminding the laundering of $300,000 in purported drug profits during the FBI scam. A jury convicted him in June of structuring a financial transaction to avoid federal currency laws, but deadlocked on six other counts, including conspiracy. He pleaded guilty Aug. 24 to the single conspiracy count in exchange for the dropping of the other charges. Authorities say Chris Petti, a reputed mobster, introduced Silberman to Ahearn through Robert Benjamin, a longtime acquaintance of Petti's who was working secretly as a government informant. Petti faces trial Oct. 3. In his plea bargain, Silberman admitted exchanging $100,000 for shares of Yuba American Gold Ltd. stock for Ahearn in November 1988. The company was a financially strapped Northern California gold-mining venture Silberman headed at the time. Ahearn and Silberman conducted a $200,000 transaction three months later. Silberman testified during his trial that it was the agent's idea to buy U.S. Treasury bonds that time instead of more Yuba American Gold stock. He also testified he didn't want to complete the second deal, but Benjamin threatened to harm him and his family if he didn't. Golding appeared dejected as she sat behind her husband with her teen-age daughter and other family members at Monday's sentencing. ``I love you,'' she called out as he was led off to jail. ``The only thing I can say is that when someone you love is in trouble, you do the best to stand by them,'' she said outside court.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Clears Most Foods On Pesticide Threat
DOC.TEXT: Nearly all U.S.-produced foods and 96 percent of imported foods tested last year met government standards for pesticide residues, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday. In its annual study of pesticide residues, the FDA said most of the violations found during the regular testing involved pesticides being used on types of produce for which use of the chemicals is not allowed. The violation rate in regular testing was about the same as for the three previous years for both domestic and imported foods, the FDA said. However, the violation rate in targeted testing of U.S.-produced food where residue problems were known or suspected jumped from 25 percent in 1988 to 33 percent last year. Still, FDA Acting Commissioner James Benson said the report ``again demonstrates that the American food supply is the safest in the world - and far freer from pesticide residues than many Americans imagine.'' But the U.S. Public Interest Research Group called the FDA's assessment ``an outrageous distortion.'' Rick Hind, environmental program director for the group, said some of the sample sizes were too small to be meaningful. For example, he said, the FDA tested only 18 cranberries. Pesticide residues were found in 16 of them, though the level in each was under the tolerance limit set by the Environmental Protection Agency. Such a finding should have prompted more testing of that food type, he said. The report also shows that of the domestic samples, 63 percent of apples, 86 percent of grapefruit and 75 percent of celery had residues, though within tolerance limits, he said. ``The federal government is presenting these numbers to prove the long-held political opinion that pesticide residues are not a problem,'' he said. Hind's group also takes issue with the tolerance levels set by EPA. The FDA tested 7,394 samples of commonly consumed domestic foods and 10,719 imports during regular surveillance monitoring in fiscal 1989. Of these, 1 percent of the domestic samples and 4 percent of imports violated pesticide residue limits, the report said. The agency also analyzed 304 domestic and 381 imported samples in compliance testing last year. Of these, 33 percent of domestic and 16 percent of imports were in violation. The agency tested for 270 pesticides and found 108. The report said this is about the same as found in previous years. Imported foods had higher levels of pesticide residues across most of the food groups, according to the repor. Milk, eggs and other dairy products were most often found to be free of residue. The FDA was unable to detect any residues in 90 percent of the imports and 87 percent of the domestic samples in this category. Also none of the samples in this group was in violation of the tolerance limits. Fruits were more likely to contain residues. The report said 56 percent of the domestic samples and 60 percent of imports had no trace of pesticides, while 43 percent of domestic and 38 percent of imported fruit samples had residues within the tolerance levels.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Sends Along Measure to Rescind China's Favored Trade Status
DOC.TEXT: Plans were laid Tuesday for a showdown in the House on whether to allow China to export billions of dollars in toys and clothing to the United States under low tariffs despite Beijing's alleged human rights abuses. The House Ways and Means Committee, on a voice vote without dissent but contrary to the views of most of its members, sent to the full House a measure that would undo President Bush's decision to continue China's ``most favored nation'' trade status. The vote effectively allows the measure to be paired against a bill the committee endorsed in July that would maintain low tariffs on Chinese imports another year but condition them after that to ``significant progress'' by Beijing on human rights issues. ``While I disapprove this resolution, I don't want to play games with it,'' said Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla., chairman of the panel's trade subcommittee and a leading proponent of untying trade to human rights and diplomatic issues. The Bush administration vigorously opposes suspending China's 10-year-old status as a most-favored-nation trading partner, which effectively reduces the tariffs on Chinese imports by 90 percent. A Chinese-made sweater with an import price of $20 now carries a tariff of $1.20 cents. Without most-favored status, it would cost $32 to import the sweater. The United States imported about $12 billion in Chinese goods last year and sent to China some $5.8 billion in U.S. exports. Amnesty International and a coalition of other human rights, labor and Chinese student groups want normal trade status suspended because of Beijing's forced suppression of Tiananmen Square demonstrators in June 1989. ``So what if the president vetoes this resolution and Congress fails to override him,'' said Rep. Richard Schulze, R-Pa. ``At least the Chinese government will understand that the ground it stands on in the eyes of Americans is, at best, extremely shaky. A conditionality bill ... just won't get this message across.'' Similar measures disapproving Bush's continuation of most-favored-trade status for China have been introduced in the Senate by Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sens. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., and Alan Dixon, D-Ill. However, none of them have the support of Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which has postponed action until after the full House acts. In a related action, the Ways and Means panel on Tuesday also approved granting lower most-favored-nation tariffs to Czechoslovakia under a trade agreement signed between the two countries last April.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Low Ratings For Kentucky's First Family
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky First Lady Martha Wilkinson, who hopes to succeed her husband in office, has some work to do on her image before next year's elections, according to poll results released Tuesday. Bluegrass State Poll results published in The Courier-Journal, showed just 22 percent of the state's registered Democrats had a favorable opinion of Mrs. Wilkinson. Forty-four percent held an unfavorable view. When asked about the survey's findings, Ed Lynch, Mrs. Wilkinson's press secretary, said, ``We can't be too discouraged this far away'' from the election. The poll also found that Gov. Wallace Wilkinson's job-performance rating has dropped significantly from five months ago. In the latest poll, 49 percent of Kentucky adults approved of the job Wilkinson is doing as governor, while 41 percent disapproved and the rest had no opinion. In April, 57 percent approved of Wilkinson's work as governor. Since then, the tax increases the governor supported in the 1990 General Assembly have taken effect, and his wife has begun campaigning to succeed him. The survey also asked respondents to rate three other major candidates running in next year's Democratic gubernatorial primary. Lt. Gov. Brereton Jones had the best overall standing among registered Democrats, with a favorable-unfavorable ratio of slightly more than 3 to 1. Lexington Mayor Scotty Baesler's ratio was a little better than 2{ to 1, while Dr. Floyd Poore's was about even. Although Mrs. Wilkinson had twice as many viewing her unfavorably as favorably, she is by far the best-known candidate. Most Democrats had an opinion of her. Sixty-eight percent said they were undecided or hadn't heard enough about Jones to have an opinion, as did 73 percent for Baesler and 84 percent for Poore. The poll was conducted from Sept. 13-19. The margin of error for the governor's job rating was plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. The margin for the favorable-unfavorable ratings was plus or minus 5 points.
DOC.HEAD: Cuomo: A Candidate for Governor in 1994?
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, widely viewed as a potential 1992 presidential candidate, raised the prospect Tuesday that he might run for a fourth term as New York's governor in 1994. Democrat Cuomo is running for re-election to a third term this year and already has reported raising about $8 million for his campaign. His comments about his political future came as the governor defended his contribution of just $55,000 from his campaign war chest to crucial state Senate races. ``You have to be very judicious about how you spend the money,'' the governor said. ``How much do I need here? Will I run a fourth time if I win now? Where will I get the money for it?'' In contrast to Cuomo, Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret has reported raising less than $1 million and has said his campaign is broke. Cuomo has said that having Democrats take control of the Senate this year is one of his priorities. Cuomo noted that he has conducted fundraisers to benefit Senate Democrats that had raised at least $300,000 for them.
DOC.HEAD: Preston Calls Off Recount in New Hampshire Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Robert Preston has called off the recount he requested of last week's New Hampshire gubernatorial primary results, acknowledging his rival, Joe Grandmaison, as the Democratic nominee. The recount was little more than half finished when Preston called it off on Monday, saying it appeared there would be no further significant changes in the vote totals. Grandmaison came out of the primary 1,134 votes ahead, but, before the recount began, revisions cut his lead to 593. Other minor adjustments during the rcount cut the lead to ``about 550 votes,'' according to Preston. Preston, the state Senate Minority Leader, wished Grandmaison well in his campaign against Republican Gov. Judd Gregg and thanked his supporters.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos, Granted Immunity, Testifies Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos testified with immunity Tuesday before a federal grand jury investigating allegations that Westinghouse Electric Corp. bribed her late husband to secure a nuclear power plant contract. The former first lady of the Philippines, who was greeted by cheering supporters as she entered and left the courthouse, testified for more than two hours in the morning and returned in the afternoon. The questioning was led by Theodore Greenberg, deputy chief of the U.S. Justice Department's fraud division. Mrs. Marcos' attorney, James P. Linn, said she was questioned more ``about the jewelry on her hands'' than her knowledge of any illegal payoffs to her husband, Ferdinand, the former Philippine president. ``That's not the purpose of the United States government,'' Linn told reporters before climbing into a limousine with Mrs. Marcos and some of her entourage. The grand jury subpoenaed Mrs. Marcos in connection with allegations that Pittsburgh-based Westinghouse paid $17.3 million in bribes to associates of Marcos and to the former president, who held office from 1965 until he was deposed in 1986. Officials haven't named the targets of the criminal probe. The bribery allegations were made in a civil lawsuit Philippine government filed in 1988 against Westinghouse. Linn said Mrs. Marcos knows nothing about any payments. ``Ferdinand Marcos was not the kind of man who sat down every night and discussed business with his wife,'' he said. Many in the crowd of about 100 Filipino-Americans said they thought Mrs. Marcos is being made a scapegoat by the U.S. government at the request of Philippine President Corazon Aquino. Signs they carried read, ``U.S. Stop Harassing Imelda,'' ``Imelda Not Guilty, Send Her Home,'' and ``Enough is Enough, Free Imelda Now.'' In addition to the bribery allegations, the Philippine government also charges that the never-used nuclear plant, located on the Bataan Peninsula about 60 miles west of Manila, was flawed and its construction was substandard. Westinghouse, in a statement issued Tuesday, said the Philippine government has refused to operate the plant for political reasons. The company said it never has been charged with wrongdoing in connection with the plant, despite more than a dozen years of investigations. ``The allegations of improper conduct are stale, unfounded and should be finally put to rest,'' Westinghouse said. ``Mrs. Marcos has no connection with Westinghouse, and she will have nothing to add to this drawn-out investigation,'' the company said. ``We do not understand why she has been subpoenaed to testify. Apparently, neither does she.'' The company said in another statement, issued last week, that it paid $17 million over 10 years to sales representatives who helped secure the contract for the $2.3 billion plant. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted in July of unrelated federal fraud charges after a 10-week trial in New York. Prosecutors in that case alleged she helped her husband loot their country's treasury of more than $220 million, using the money to buy New York real estate, art and jewelry. She still faces several federal lawsuits, Linn said. He dismissed suggestions that his client needed immunity to testify. ``The government requested it and we had no objection,'' he said. ``No lawyer in his right mind would decline immunity.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Plans `Private' Visit to United States
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki will make a quick visit to the United States to meet with President Bush, the government said Tuesday. Mazowiecki, who is expected to announce his decision soon to run for president against Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, was to arrive Friday in the United States and see Bush on Saturday. He also planned to take part in the UNICEF-sponsored Convention on the Rights of the Child in New York, said government spokesman Krzysztof Bakalarski. Walesa picked Mazowiecki to be prime minister after Solidarity triumphed in June 1989 elections over the Communists. But recently Solidarity has split into two camps. Walesa claims the government is going too slow in transforming the country from Communism. Polish officials are worried the political split in Solidarity could erode U.S. sympathy for Poland. They would like the feud to be viewed in the West as part of the normal process of democracy. The Polish elections are to be held by the end of December to replace President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader who has agreed to curtail his six-year term by 4{ years. Mazowiecki is on a four-day visit to Spain, where he is meeting with King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. On Monday, Mazowiecki committed a Polish field hospital and medical ship to the gulf region in support of the U.S.-led economic blockade of Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Beauty Is Skin Deep For Tattoo Lovers
DOC.TEXT: NEW ORLEANS (AP - Call it body art. Robert Fleisher, who calls himself an art collector, scrutinized the field at the Tattoo Expo '90 and then stripped to the waist, leaving his body in the hands of Ronald Bonkerk of Amsterdam, a man Fleisher refers to as a ``Dutch master.'' ``I have well over 100 tattoos. I'll keep going until I run out of places to put them,'' said Fleisher, a 53-year-old retired automobile salesman from Philadelphia. ``The human body is just a canvas for these artists.'' Fleisher was just one of hundreds at the Clarion hotel during the four-day Tattoo Expo '90 that ended Sunday. Needles buzzed constantly at the booths. Women in bikinis and bare-chested men showed off their tattoos or added new ones. Others were more circumspect. ``All of my tattoos are covered,'' said Janet Rivard, a 34-year-old registered nurse from Sacramento, Calif. ``I don't mind showing them, but I like it to be my choice.'' Rivard started with a small flower design on her right breast, then added a full color lynx that covers her entire left buttock, before having a lion's head done on her stomach to cover an appendectomy scar. ``Our shop is near a college, and we have a lot of college girls come in,'' said Susan Agan of Susan and Critter Tattooing in Troy, N.Y. ``They don't want their tattoos seen. They want them to be something they can share in intimate situations. Something only seen when they're undressed.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Cite Pilot Error, Poor Management In Hawaii Air Crash
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators said Tuesday that one of the worst commuter air crashes in U.S. aviation history occurred last year when the pilot flew into a bank of clouds at a dangerously low altitude and slammed into a mountain ridge on Hawaii's Molokai Island. All 20 people aboard the Aloha IslandAir plane were killed in the Oct. 28, 1989 accident, including eight members of the Molokai High School volleyball team. The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that the probable cause of the accident was the decision of the pilot, Captain Bruce Pollard, 30, to continue the flight into clouds that obscured the rising mountainous terrain. But it also blamed the management of the commuter airline, Aloha IslandAir, for inadequate supervision of its personnel and for inadequate training and operations. And it said the Federal Aviation Administration had failed to provide adequate supervision of Aloha IslandAir operations, particularly at a time when it was rapidly expanding its operations. ``When you're operating, carrying passengers, there is an enormous responsibility there to the public,'' said Susan Coughlin, the safety board's vice chairman, after the board's morning-long examination of the accident. ``They were not taking the care that was necessary to assure safe flight, and that is the responsibility of an air carrier,'' she told reporters. Safety board members said that any one of a dozen factors could have resulted in preventing the Aloha IslandAir accident, plus two earlier ones in Hawaii. And they said it could have been avoided altogether had the plane been equipped with a ground proximity warning device. The safety board said radar data revealed that the aircraft had descended from its intended cruising altitude of 1,000 feet to 500 feet when the crash occurred. Safety board staff members said flying at such a low altitude is prohibited by FAA regulations and is ``basically illegal.'' Ms. Coughlin noted that investigators had discovered that Aloha IslandAir had cut back required pilot training from the 44 hours ordered by the FAA to 24 hours. ``I would consider that a pretty important factor in this accident,'' she said. The board said Pollard had a record of ``performance difficulties'' before joining AlohaAir, including a 180-day suspension. And it faulted airline management for not adequately checking Pollard's background before hiring him. It also said that the first officer on the flight had not received FAA-approved ground training and was therefore disqualified to serve in that capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Welcomed to Meeting of World Bank, International Monetary Fund
DOC.TEXT: The head of the International Monetary Fund welcomed Soviet officials to its annual meeting for the first time Tuesday and told them that a study underway could help them get aid from the West. The Soviet delegation was led by Viktor Geraschenko, head of the USSR State Bank, and included Soviet Finance MinisterValentin Pavlov. IMF managing director Michael Camdessus welcomed the Soviet ``invitees.'' ``The Soviet Union is not a member,'' Camdessus said. ``Yet we are all watching with interest, and sympathy, the efforts of the Soviet Union to move toward a market-oriented and more efficient economy.'' He noted the United States and other major governments have asked the fund and three more international organizations to study the Soviet economy. The study, due by the end of the year, would ``make recommendations for its reform and ... establish the criteria under which Western economic assistance could effectively support these reforms,'' he said. The Soviets sat toward the back of the vast hotel ballroom used for the speech-making plenary session. There are 152 governments in the fund and its sister organization, the World Bank, including China and some Eastern European nations. Barber B. Conable, president of the World Bank, also welcomed the Soviets. ``The welcome presence here of guests from the Soviet Union is a symbol of the mutual willingness to explore the great issues of reform,'' he said in his opening speech. Conable is American, Camdessus is French. Soviet leaders have said they want to join all international organizations, including the bank, the fund and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). The Bush administration have opposed their membership. An international monetary official, who asked that his name not be used, said a major reason for delay at this point is the political turmoil inside the Soviet Union. Several of the Soviet republics have sought independence from Moscow.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix agate coding
Eds: This introductory take is in BODY; subsequent 17 takes of tabular matter are in AGATE. A story to accompany the tables will move spot.
DOC.TEXT: Here are the Environmental Protection Agency's fuel economy ratings for 1991 model cars, vans and light trucks. The first column gives the manufacturer and the model. A ``d'' after the name indicates the vehicle has a diesel engine; a ``g'' indicates the car is subject to the gas guzzler tax; and a ``p'' indicates the car uses premium gasoline. The second column shows miles per gallon in city driving; the third column miles per gallon in highway driving; and the fourth column miles per gallon combining both city and highway driving. The fifth column indicates engine displacement in cubic inches and the number of cylinders. The last column indicates the type of transmission and the number of gears. An ``A'' designation indicates automatic transmission. An ``L'' designation indicates automatic transmission with a fuel-saving device that eliminates slippage. An ``M'' designation indicates manuel transmission. For example, an ``A4'' means a four-speed automatic transmission; an ``M5'' means a five-speed manuel transmission; and an ``L3'' means a three-speed automatic transmission with a fuel-saving anti-slippage device. In some cases identical car listings with the same engine displacement, cylinders and transmission may show slightly different mileage because of equipment or other differences not shown in the table. The mileage figures reflect test conditions. For some years the EPA has adjusted the test results through the use of a weighting formula so the mileage more closely reflects actual driving conditions. The combined mileage is calculated on an assumption that 55 percent of the miles driven are driven under city conditions. The mileage tests are conducted by the manufacturer with about 30 percent confirmed in separate tests by the EPA. Some manufacturers may not have completed tests in time and their cars are not listed.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: AMA Complains to Bush About Medicare Investigator
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association asked President Bush on Tuesday to fire a government official who physicians say has been reckless and unfair in his investigation of Medicare and Medicaid fraud. The AMA, in a letter to the president, said that in carrying out his oversight duties at the Department of Health and Human Services, Inspector General Richard Kusserow has discredited the administration. ``Competent and honest physicians have been damaged and many more have been unnecessarily harassed,'' the AMA letter said. Kusserow was out of town Tuesday and could not be reached for comment. His spokeswoman, Judy Holtz, said the office was surprised by the AMA's action. She said she ould not comment, except to say: ``The inspector general's record speaks for itself.'' Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif., chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health, quickly came to Kusserow's defense, putting out a statement shortly after the AMA released its letter to reporters. ``Criticism from the AMA is a red badge of courage to Mr. Kusserow,'' said Stark, whose proposals often are opposed by physicians. ``Anyone who resists giving the AMA completely free access to the Treasury and the taxpayer's wallet is immediately branded by the AMA as anti-doctor,'' he said. ``Dick Kusserow should get a medal for saving the taxpayer fortunes. That he is being criticized today is a sure sign he is doing his job.'' Dr. Robert McAfee, vice chairman of the AMA Board of Trustees, said frustration over Kusserow's actions has built up over the last five years to the point that ``physicians don't trust him any more.'' McAfee said the AMA wants incompetent and dishonest physicians out of the Medicaid and Medicare programs and out of the medical profession as much as Kusserow. But, McAffee said, the AMA has had to go to court to win fundamental protections for physicians accused of misconduct and to dismantle a reward system for enforcers working for Kusserow. The AMA was particularly upset by Kusserow's statements last week on ABC's ``Prime Time Live,'' in which he said a physician who had been kicked out of the Medicare program and later killed himself had been a drug abuser. Later in the segment, Kusserow was reported to have retracted his comment a week after the interview was taped, saying drug use was not an issue in the case.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
House Committee Votes Extra $2 Billion For Persian Gulf Operations
DOC.TEXT: The House Appropriations Committee voted an extra $2 billion Tuesday to pay for U.S. military operations in the Persian Gulf and proposed that the president be allowed to activate reservists for up to 12 months. Present law limits such callups without congressional approval to a total of six months. The votes came as the committee approved legislation designed to keep the government operating until Oct. 20. The stopgap measure is necessary because Congress has not enacted any of the 13 annual appropriations bills for the budget year, which begins Oct. 1. There was no debate on the additional money for Persian Gulf operations or on giving the president authority to call up reservists for longer periods. A related provision, appropriating $20 million in ``imminent-danger'' pay for U.S. forces in the gulf region, also was approved without controversy. But President Bush's recommendation that $6.7 billion in Egyptian debt be forgiven in recognition of Egypt's support in the gulf was put aside for fear it would fail if brought to a vote. Instead, the committee accepted a plan by Reps. David Obey, D-Wis., and Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., to make Egypt eligible for additional aid. Under the law, aid may not be extended to a nation that is a year or more in arrears in repaying earlier assistance. Egypt will be a year behind in payments starting Oct. 4. Several members of the panel praised Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's courage in sending thousands of troops to Saudi Arabia to help U.S. forces defend against a possible attack by Iraq. ``His life is really on the line,'' said Rep. Bob Livingston, R-La. The debt is bound to be forgiven sooner or later, said Rep. C.W. Bill Young, R-Fla. ``Why do we hang President Mubarak out to dry while we play with smoke and mirrors? Why give radical Arabs in Egypt a reason to go against President Mubarak?'' Rep. Robert Mrazek, D-N.Y., said forgiving the debt might send a signal that the United States was trying to buy Egypt's support. ``We are rapidly approaching a crisis in our country. What is the message to the American people on forgiving a $7 billion debt'' at a time when many Americans fear loss of jobs because of a slumping economy, he asked. The bill could be considered by the House on Thursday, giving mebers their first opportunity to cast a meaningful vote on the gulf operations.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves $7 Billion Increase for Agriculture
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Tuesday to spend $52.3 billion on agriculture and rural development programs in fiscal 1991, an increase of about $7 billion over the current year. The 79-19 vote sends the bill to a conference committee with the House, whose version is about $1.9 billion less costly. Unlike the House, the Senate supplied $325.8 million in its bill to continue federal crop insurance, a subsidized program through which private insurance companies protect farmers from the potential financial ruin of weather disasters. The House, favoring direct aid for weather disasters, voted to spend $101.5 million on a phase-out program for crop insurance. Agriculture interests in the House counted on the Senate to save the program and planned to fight for it in conference committee. All but about $10.17 billion of the total appropriations bill is earmarked for entitlement programs, such as food stamps, which are protected from deficit reduction cuts. Many of these programs require increased spending because of increased participation. Food stamp participation, for example, was up to 20 million people by the end of the fiscal year, the highest since 1985. The Senate voted to spend $19 billion on food stamps next year, about $12 million more than the House approved. The bill also provides $2.35 billion for the popular WIC feeding program for poor pregnant women, nursing mothers and their infants. It funds the special milk program in schools, subsidizes school lunches and breakfasts and supplies money for several other nutrition programs. Other agriculture programs supported by money in the bill include administrative operations, rural development and international programs. The bill also funds the Food and Drug Administration and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The money that goes for subsidies on certain commodities is subject to deficit reduction cuts and could be adjusted after a budget agreement is reached.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank, IMF Meetings Focus On Gulf, But Poverty Still Major Problem
DOC.TEXT: Reducing world poverty remains the major challenge of the World Bank, despite new efforts to deal with the Gulf crisis and emerging democracies, the bank president said Tuesday. ``As the 1990s unfold, success in reducing poverty should be the measure of global economic progress,'' bank President Barber Conable told the opening session of the bank and International Monetary Fund's annual meetings. ``We meet in the shadow of the Gulf crisis,'' Conable said. ``We meet as Eastern European nations are attempting to transform themselves into pluralistic, market-oriented societies. We meet when a billion of our fellow human beings continue to live in abject poverty.'' This triple challenge occupied the opening session, where President Bush announced creation of a multi-nation clearing house to coordinate financial help for countries suffering from the results of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. The world has experienced unprecedented development in the last two decades, Conable said, citing what he called ``impressive advances against poverty,'' including per capita annual consumption in developing countries, up from $590 dollars to $985, life expectancy up from 51 to 62 years, and primary education enrollment up from 73 to 84 percent. But one billion people still live on less than $1 a day, he said. Living standards in Latin America have fallen below those of the 1970s, while parts of Sub-Saharan Africa have suffered ``a veritable collapse of living standards, institutions and infrastructure,'' he said. Bank projects stress the productive growth and efficient use of labor, he said, while protecting against environmental damage. Conable said the number of poor people in developing countries can be reduced by at least 300 million by the end of the decade, reducing child mortality and making primary education ``almost universal.''

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Studies Immigration Penalties
DOC.TEXT: Harsher penalties should be levied against employers who discriminate against foreign-looking workers to avoid hiring illegal aliens, an administration task force said Tuesday The 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act ``was not intended to be a barrier for persons who are eligible to work, but the evidence shows that many employers are discriminating by adopting exclusionary hiring practices,'' the task force said in its report to Congress. Those practices include hiring only applicants who prove they were born on U.S. soil and rejecting legal immigrants who present work-authorization documents issued by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the study said. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh endorsed the work of the task force. ``Our nation's continuing commitment to fighting discrimination in all its guises requires that there be sufficient penalties to deter discrimination and adequate enforcement of prohibitions against discrimination,'' Thornburgh said. ``The task force's recommendations will further these goals.'' The task force said fines for discriminating against foreign-looking workers should be commensurate with the penalties for employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens. That would increase the maximum fine for repeated discrimination from $2,000 to $10,000, it said. The Justice Department's Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices should open three regional offices to investigate complaints and conduct programs to educate employers about their legal obligations, the report said. The special counsel now has one office in Washington. The task force also recommended streamlining the procedures for employers to check documents that applicants present to prove citizenship or legal status. The interagency panel, consisting of representatives of the Justice Department, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Civil Rights Commission, adopted many of the findings of an earlier study by the General Accounting Office. The 1986 immigration reform law provided amnesty for hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens living in the country when it was enacted.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Solicits Squirt Guns, Comics, Crafts for Soldiers in Saudi
DOC.TEXT: After weeks of shipping tanks and other tools of war to the Persian Gulf area, the Pentagon is now looking for a few lighter items to supply the troops. Things like squirt guns, nerf balls, macrame and kite-making kits. The Pentagon on Tuesday invited the public to donate a variety of recreational items to the troops in the desert and in the Persian Gulf. It also cautioned that reading materials should not include pictures of scantily clad women. Among other desired items: electronic and board games such as Nintendo and Trivial Pursuit; music and video tapes as well as Arab language tapes; comics and editions of USA Today; fitness equipment such as jump ropes and stair-climbing machines, and sports equipment such as portable basketball goals, soccer balls, rubber footballs, volleyball nets and horseshoes. Also suggested: writing materials, including Christmas cards, and personal items such as sun visors, insect repellant and sun block. People planning to send items should check first with a Defense Logistics Agency hot line at 703-274-3561.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Launches Campaign on S&L Bailout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs `The news ...' to UPDATE with S&L demonstration in Washington. Picks up 8th graf `Kennedy, a ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Neil Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Politicians, consumer activists and labor representatives said Tuesday they will lobby Congress to remove the burden of the savings and loan bailout from average taxpayers. ``Today we say that enough is enough,'' Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy II said at a news conference organized by the Financial Democracy Campaign. ``The Bush (S&L) bailout has already cost working families close to $150 billion,'' he said. ``Now the administration is telling us that hundreds of billions more are needed to pay off the depositors of failed thrifts.'' The Financial Democracy Campaign is a coalition of consumer, labor and religious groups. Others speaking at the news conference included Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn; Ed Garvey, a former president of the National Football League Players Union; Michael Waldman, director of Public Citizen; and Maude Hurd, president of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now. Jesse Jackson and consumer activist Ralph Nader had been scheduled to appear, but did not attend. The news conference was held on the first day of a public hearing in Denver on conflict-of-interest charges against President Bush's son Neil, who was a director of a failed Colorado savings and loan. Another group, the September 25th Coalition, demonstrated Tuesday at the Washington headquarters of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions, the industry's main lobbying group. About 20 people protested what they called ``S&L robbery.'' Some played cymbals, drums and tambourines as they carried signs that read: ``Hey, hey we won't pay. Throw them all in jail today.'' Kennedy, a member of the House Banking Committee, has introduced legislation that would create a special surtax on affluent individuals and corporations to pay for the S&L bailout. He said the measure would raise $21.2 billion a year; the S&L bailout will cost taxpayers an estimated $500 billion, or $2,000 per person. The measure would create a 7.5 percent surtax on the unearned income of individuals who earn more than $100,000, excluding the first $7,500 of such income. Unearned income includes interest, dividends and capital gains. The bill also would impose a 5 percent surtax on the income of corporations earning more than $75,000 a year. ``Working people received nothing from the deregulation of our nation's thrifts except higher rates on their mortgages and small business loans,'' Kennedy said. ``The people who went to the deregulatory party - the wealthiest Americans ... - should be the ones to pay for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Maintained Among Warring Liberian Factions
DOC.TEXT: A cease-fire among warring factions held for the fourth day Tuesday, but two rival rebel groups disagreed on how to form a new government and one of the groups was building up its troops, officials said. The spokesman for a five-nation West African army sent to halt Liberia's tribal war, Maj. Chris Otulana, said no violations had been reported in the truce since it began Saturday. But Otulana said rebel leader Charles Taylor, who initiated the cease-fire in the 9-month-old war, had started building up forces in areas under his control. Taylor has reportedly threatened to suspend the truce if the West African force sends in more troops. Nigerian warships bringing reinforcements and a new field commander for the force were expected to arrive in Monrovia on Wednesday or Thursday. Otulana said the additional troops would help the force set up checkpoints to keep the rebel factions apart. He said rebel leader Prince Johnson and Brig. Gen. David Nimley, commander of remnants of the army loyal to slain President Samuel Doe, were cooperating with the West African force. According to news reports on Monday, Taylor was supposed to meet with the commander of Doe's mansion guard on Tuesday. It was not known if the meeting was held. Johnson, in a radio telephone call to the British Broadcasting Corp., rejected Taylor's plan to hold elections on Oct. 10. Johnson said Taylor had no right to call elections and that the proposal was unrealistic because of the collapse of the country's infrastructure. More than half a million Liberians have fled to neighboring countries, and another million of the 2.3 million population have been displaced within the country. Johnson also said he would accept an invitation by the West African group to meet Taylor Friday in Freetown, Sierra Leone. Taylor opposes a plan proposed by the Economic Community of West African States for an interim government to run the country until elections can be held next year. The community, which sent the five-nation task force, said the temporary government could make sure none of the warring groups manipulates the voting. Taylor, who accused Doe of corruption and nepotism, started the civil war on Dec. 24 when his forces invaded from Ivory Coast. Johnson later split with Taylor and formed his own rebel faction. More than 5,000 civilians have been killed in the fighting. Doe was captured earlier this month by Johnson's forces and tortured to death. The capital has been cut off from the outside world for three months and people are dying of starvation because food supplies are gone. Substantial relief supplies, including 50,000 tons of rice from the U.S. government, have been waiting in neighboring Ivory Coast and Sierra Leone for a stable cease-fire. ``Once ships can begin to call in the port of Monrovia, which has been essentially closed to traffic since the end of June ... these supplies will be brought in,'' a U.S. government official said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Jetliner Hijack Attempt Foiled by KGB Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with further details of hijack attempt. SUPERSEDES AM brief. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A special KGB team foiled an attempt to hijack a Soviet jetliner on Tuesday by a man who said he had a bomb hidden in his briefcase, the state news agency Tass reported. The man threatened to blow up the plane while at the same time wishing the crew ``a pleasant flight,'' Tass said. It was the latest in a rash of Soviet hijackings and hijack attempts, most involving diversion of flights to Nordic countries. The would-be hijacker, Grigory Polyakov, 53, boarded the flight from Leningrad to the White Sea port of Arkhangelsk on Monday night and tried to divert it to Stockholm, Sweden, the report said. A note he handed to the flight crew said, according to Tass: ``We propose to you that the plane be directed to Sweden and head toward Stockholm. If you do not do it, the plane will be blown up. We will control the course. Do not approach me and do not ask questions. We wish you a pleasant flight. Let us be mutually polite and avoid crime in the name of the passengers' health and welfare.'' The crew persuaded Polyakov the plane had to land at Arkhangelsk for fuel. Once on the ground there, authorities negotiated the release of the 66 passengers, Tass said. A trained unit of KGB security police then captured Polyakov, the report said, but gave no details, including any further information about whether there actually was a bomb. It said Polyakov had three previous convictions, including one in 1988 for ``attempting to leave the Soviet Union illegally.'' Tass said Polyakov earlier was diagnosed as suffering from chronic paranoia.

DOC.HEAD: Police Groups Criticize Foley on Handgun Controls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to move higher brief debate of bill in House. Picks up 6th graf pvs `The anti-crime ...' SUBS penultimate graf pvs `Foley spokesman ...' to DELETE now-redundant first reference to Biggs.
DOC.TEXT: Police groups Tuesday accused House Speaker Thomas Foley of handing law enforcement a setback by barring consideration of handgun controls as part of a major anti-crime package. The law enforcement leaders launched their criticism of Foley as the House first started debate on the anti-crime package and then shelved it as rebellion broke out among conservatives over its death penalty provisions. Foley spokesman Jeff Biggs, responding to the criticism of the speaker, said the House could still consider the handgun plan before Congress adjourns in a few weeks. But he said there was no guarantee. Police groups told a news conference that stringent controls on semiautomatic assault weapons and handguns are needed if police are to be effective in fighting crime. ``Should we wait until the blood of law enforcement officers an peaceful citizens is running in the halls of Congress before we pass sensible gun legislation?'' asked Fraternal Order of Police leader Dewey Stokes.
