The anti-crime bill calls for the death penalty for 10 offenses ranging from presidential assassination to treason and espionage. It is designed to curb delays of a decade or more in carrying out executions. Under the bill, courts would be able to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants if police carried out their searches ``in good faith.'' President Bush has been urging approval of an anti-crime package but said recently that the one before the House would hamper police. He urged approval of warrantless searches if police acted in good faith and called for more stringent provisions to prevent unwarranted delays in death penalty cases. Leaders of police organizations criticized a Rules Committee decision on Monday barring consideration of an amendment that would require a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases. The seven-day waiting provision has been dubbed the Brady Bill by its sponsors, in honor of former presidential Press Secretary Jim Brady, severely wounded by John Hinckley in his attempted assassination of President Reagan. The aim of the measure is to give police time to check the backgrounds of would-be handgun purchasers. Police officials blamed Foley for the Rules Committee's decision to keep the measure separate from the anti-crime package. ``Right now, Speaker Foley is not permitting the Brady bill to come to a vote on the floor of the House, so who else can we blame?'' Stokes said. Biggs noted the House Judiciary Committee had approved the anti-crime package and the handgun bill as separate measures and noted that Foley often goes along with the wishes of committee chairmen. He also said that Foley had not ruled out consideration of the plan as a separate item. ``Can we guarantee it? The answer is no,'' he added. He said the crime bill itself as well as the budget dispute and major farm legislation are guaranteed to absorb a large chunk of the House's time in the weeks ahead.

DOC.HEAD: South African Police Put Curfew on Restive Black Towns
DOC.TEXT: Police imposed a 9 p.m.-to-4 a.m. curfew Tuesday on some black townships wracked by chronic faction fighting. The curfew, announced last week, was included in police measures designed to halt fighting that has killed about 800 people since Aug. 12 in townships around Johannesburg. Black organizations asked supporters to defy the curfew, but several areas appeared calm after it started. Reporters said streets were empty in parts of Soweto included in the curfew area. Police checked vehicles at a roadblock. Two armored police vehicles were seen patrolling. ``We are quite prepared for dealing with some resistance,'' police Brig. Gen. Leon Mellett said Tuesday. ``We certainly will meet some resistance.'' Much of the fighting has pitted Xhosas and other blacks linked to the African National Congress against Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement. The ANC, the largest black opposition group, said the curfew would leave township residents unprotected while permitting Inkatha vigilantes and other ``agents of darkness'' to launch attacks. It has accused police of aiding Inkatha in the fighting, and also alleged that right-wing extremists have taken part in attacks. The government says individual police may have acted improperly, but the force as a whole has been impartial. ``These non-aggressive measures are aimed at protecting defenseless, law-abiding residents and to ensure they sleep in peace,'' police Maj. Gen. Herman Stadler said in a statement. He said the curfew would check ``the movement of criminal elements and radical thugs.'' Township fighting has eased following periods in which dozens of blacks died daily. The fighting spread from eastern Natal Province, where five years of political and tribal warfare have killed 5,000 blacks. Police said Monday the curfew would be enforced in Tokoza, Vosloorus, Katlehong and several areas of Soweto. Violators could get up to six months in jail or a $400 fine. Township residents who work at night must provide a letter of proof to be exempt, police said. Soweto police also would accept ticket stubs to concerts, movies and soccer matches for exemption. Other measures included weapons searches, roadblocks, police and military reinforcements, and isolating flash points such as worker hostels and squatter camps. Police in Durban, the largest Natal city, said Tuesday they had seized 785 illegal firearms. They also said they increased the rewards for people aiding the discovery of some weapons, such as missiles, rocket launchers and machine guns.

DOC.SECOND: Wounded Knee Survivors Appeal For Apology, Compensation, Monument
DOC.TEXT: Descendants of Indians who were killed or wounded 100 years ago at Wounded Knee appealed Tuesday for an apology, reparations and a national monument to atone for their ``blackest day.'' ``History has to be rewritten to show the Indians' side,'' Claudia Iron Hawk Sully told the Senate Indian Affairs Committee. ``Apologies and memorials have to be made to the victims' descendants.'' Sully's grandmother was among the victims of the battle - or massacre, depending on the view - that marked the end of the Indian wars Dec. 29, 1890, at Wounded Knee, S.D. The remote site on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation was made a national historic landmark 25 years ago, but the victims' descendants hope to use the 100th anniversary to win the compensation and official apology they have long sought. The government should ``stand tall, admit it was wrong and atone for that massacre,'' said Mario Gonzalez, an attorney for the Wounded Knee Survivors' Association. The group wants Congress to declare the site a national monument, which would make it a part of the National Park Service, and compensate the survivors for the estimated $20,000 in property taken from the victims, plus interest. The compensation could be made in the form of benefits to Indian tribes. Their chances of getting any of that in the waning days of the 101st Congress are slim. The Wounded Knee descendants insisted that event was a massacre and that many more Indians were killed than was officially acknowledged. ``We hurt and cry deep in our souls as we remember the stories told to us by our families,'' said Sully. ``Each of us here knows more about the truth of the blackest day, than any historian or Indian expert or classroom book will every know.'' Sully said 426 Lakota Sioux Indians, including warriors, women, elderly people and children were killed when they were attacked while in the custody of drunken members of the U.S. 7th Cavalry. Her grandmother, then 16, was wounded in the arm and suffered psychologically for the rest of her life, Sully said. The Department of the Interior, however, puts the death toll lower and gives a differing account of the event that is more charitable to the troops. About 153 Indians were killed of the 400 present and 44 were wounded, said Knute Knudson, deputy assistant interior secretary. The firing began when an Indian fired his gun as soldiers were trying to disarm him, Knudson said.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Bailout Costs Mounting, Latest Figures Show
DOC.TEXT: Failed savings and loans managed by the government added $1.02 billion to the cost of the thrift bailout in the April-June qurter, regulators said Tuesday. The Resolution Trust Corp. said operating losses at the 247 S&Ls in its control at the end of June rose 22 percent from the previous quarter, when they totaled $840 million at the same institutions. However, they were down 1 percent from the second quarter of 1989 when they totaled $1.04 billion. Operating losses represent the cost of keeping the institutions open until regulators can sell or close them. Analysts said the increase in operating losses underscores the urgency of handling failed thrifts as soon as possible. However, the trust corporation will hit a cash crunch after this month unless congressional and administration negotiators at the budget summit agree to provide more money. Total losses at the government-run thrifts were $2.62 billion in the second quarter, a deterioration from $2.22 billion in the first quarter and from $2.45 billion a year ago. Total losses include recognition of bad loans and other assets that went sour before the government seized the thrifts. The report on government-controlled S&Ls came one day after the Office of Thrift Supervision disclosed losses for the 2,452 privately-run thrifts. Combining the two reports, the entire industry lost $6.3 billion in the first half of the year, nearly as much as the $7.7 billion in the first half of 1989 and $7.1 billion in the first half of 1988. Nevertheless, trust corporation officials said their analysis of the most recent data shows that the government cleanup is reducing losses. At the end of the first quarter 350 S&Ls operated under government control and lost $3.5 billion. ``By eliminating a large number of institutions that were generating losses, RTC resolution activity has had the effect of reducing the costs of operating the conservatorship program,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the agency. As of Monday 220 institutions were run by the government. The agency said that if it had managed to reduce its inventory of failed thrifts to those institutions six months earlier, then losses in the second quarter would have been $1.94 billion instead of $2.62 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Council Calls for Air Embargo Against Iraq, Halt Shipping
With AM-Gulf-Air Embargo
DOC.TEXT: Following is the official English-language version of the air embargo Resolution 670, adopted 14-1 Tuesday by the U.N. Security Council: The Security Council: Reaffirming its resolutions 660, 661, 662, 664, 665, 666 and 667, condemning the continued Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, its failure to rescind its actions and end its purported annexation and its holding of third State nationals against their will, in flagrant violation of resolutions 660, 662, 664 and 667 and of international humanitarian law; Condemning further the treatment by Iraqi forces of Kuwaiti nationals, including measures to force them to leave their own land and mistreatment by Iraqi forces of persons and property in Kuwait in violation of international law; Noting with grave concern the persistent attempts to evade the measures laid down in Resolution 661; Further noting that a number of states have limited the number of Iraqi diplomatic and consular officials in their countries and that others are proposing to do so; Determined to ensure by all necessary means the strict and complete application of the measures laid down in Resolution 661; Determined to ensure respect for its decisions and the provisions of Articles 25 and 48 of the Charter of the United Nations; Affirming that any acts of the Government of Iraq which are contrary to the above-mentioned resolutions or to Articles 25 or 48 or the Charter of the United Nations, such as Decree No. 377 of the Revolution Command Council of Iraq of 16 September 1990, are null and void; Reaffirming its determination to ensure compliance with Security Council resolutions by maximum use of political and diplomatic means; Welcoming the secretary-general's use of his good offices to advance a peaceful solution based on the relevant Security Council resolutions and noting with appreciation his efforts to this end; Underlining to the Government of Iraq that its continued failure to comply with the terms of resolutions 660, 661, 662, 664, 666 and 667 could lead to further action by the Council under the Charter of the United Nations, including under Chapter VII, with potentially severe consequences; Recalling the provisions of Article 103 of the Charter of the Uited Naitons; Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations: 1. Calls upon all States to carry out their obligations to ensure strict and complete compliance with Resolution 661 and in particular paragrpahs 3,4 and 5 thereof; 2. Confirms that Resolution 661 applies to all means of transport, including aircraft; 3. Decides that all States, notwithstanding the existence of any rights or obligations conferred or imposed by any international agrement of any contract entered into or any license or permit granted before the date of the present resolution, shall deny permission to any aircraft to take off from their territory if the aircraft would carry any cargo to or from Iraq or Kuwait other than food in humanitarian circumstances, subject to authorization by the Council or the Committee established by Resolution 661 and in accordance with Resolution 666, or supplies intended strictly for medical purposes or solely for UNIIMOG (the Iran-Iraq peacekeeping group); 4. Decides further that all States shall deny permission to any aircraft destined to land in Iraq or Kuwait, whatever its state of registration, to overfly its territory unless: a. the aircraft lands at an airfield designated by that State outside Iraq or Kuwait in order to permit its inspection to ensure that there is no cargo on board in violation of Resolution 661 or the present resolution, and for this purpose the aircraft may be detained for as long as necessary; or b. the particular flight has been approved by the Committee established by Resolution 661; or c. the flight is certified by the United Nations as solely for the purposes of UNIIMOG; 5. Decides that each State shall take all necessary measures to ensure that any aircraft registered in its territory or operated by an operator who has his principal place of business or permanent residence in its territory complies with the provisions of Resolution 661 and the present resolution; 6. Decides further that all States shall notify in a timely fashion the (sanctions) Committee established by Resolution 661 of any flight between its territory and Iraq or Kuwait to which the requirement to land in paragraph 4 above does not apply, and the purpose for such a flight; 7. Calls upon all States to cooperate in taking such measures as may be necessary, consistent with international law, including the Chicago Convention, to ensure the effective implementation of the provisions of Resolution 661 or the present resolution; 8. Calls upon all States to detain any ships of Iraqi registry which enter their ports and which are being or have been used in violation of Resolution 661, or to deny such ships entrance to their ports except in circumstances recognized under international law as necessary to safeguard human life; 9. Reminds all States of their obligations under Resolution 661 with regard to the freezing of Iraqi assets, and the protection of the assets of the legitimate Government of Kuwait and its agencies, located within their territory and to report to the committee establihsed under Resolution 661 regarding those assets; 10. Calls upon all States to provide the Committee established by Resolution 661 information regarding the action taken by them to implement the provisions laid down in the present resolution; 11. Affirms that the United Nations Organization, the Specialized Agencies and other international organizations in the United Nations system are required to take such measures as may be necessary to give effect to the terms of Resolution 661 and this resolution; 12. Decides to consider, in the event of evasion of the provisions of Resolution 661 or of the present resoution by a State or its nationals or through its territory, measures directed at the State in question to prevent such evasion; 13. Reaffirms that the Fourth Geneva Convention applies to Kuwait and that as a High Contracting Party to the Convention Iraq is bound to comply fully with all its terms and in particular is liable under the Convention in respect of the grave breaches committed by it, as are individuals who commit or order the commission of grave breaches.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Consultants Worked for Government and Developers
DOC.TEXT: Consultants assisting the government on the MX nuclear missile and a fiber-optic guided missile also worked for defense contractors on the same weapons, congressional investigators said Tuesday. The General Accounting Office said it found no basis to conclude that any of the three cases they examined resulted in a conflict of interest, but one lawmaker expressed reservations. ``Taken separately, each of the GAO findings in this report is cause for concern,'' said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark. ``Taken together, they paint a very grim picture indeed of the system by which the Pentagon procures hardware for the national defense.'' The watchdog agency of Congress found that consultants were trusted to certify that they had no associations that represented a conflict of interest. Pryor said such a system would not work ``because dishonest consultants will not volunteer their guilt.'' The Defense Department estimates it spends about $1.6 billion a year on defense consulting. The GAO said the department did not accurately identify or report its use of consulting services because of problems interpreting the definitions of these services or other internal control weaknesses. ``Without improvement in these areas, the Defense Department and the Congress will continue to lack accurate information on how much the Defense Department is relying on consulting services to develop its weapon systems,'' the GAO said. In addition to examining the consulting work on the missiles, the GAO also found that Bell Helicopter Textron hired a former Navy admiral to confer with U.S. government officials on the V-22 Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft. The Defense Department, in comments included in the GAO report, said it agreed with the findings and recommendations and was taking steps to strengthen its management and reporting system. Pryor and Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, requested the report.

DOC.HEAD: Jury: Cigarettes Killed Smoker, But No Damage Award
DOC.TEXT: Smoking two packs of cigarettes a day for 35 years killed a man who sued a cigarette maker, but he shares responsibility for his death and his family doesn't deserve money as compensation, a jury decided. The family of Nathan Henry Horton, who died of lung cancer in 1987 at age 50, sought $17 million in the suit against the maker and a regional distributor of Pall Mall cigarettes. Jurors, half of whom smoke, agreed 9-3 Monday that American Tobacco Co. and Greenwood distributor New Deal Tobacco and Candy Co. were partly to blame for Horton's death. Horton's decision to continue smoking despite the risk kept them from awarding the family a penny. ``It is possible we could have let down both sides, but the alternatives were this or a hung jury,'' jury foreman David Roach of Oxford said in a telephone interview. ``This was the only agreement we could come up with. Whether or not that is better than a hung jury is for other people to decide,'' he said. The suit sought $2 million in actual damages and $15 million in punitive damages. The trial, the second in the case, was moved to Lafayette County from Holmes County. The first ended in January 1988 when the jury deadlocked. Attorney Don Barrett, who represents Horton's relatives, said he has filed motions asking Holmes County Circuit Court Judge Eugene Bogen to award oome money for actual damages. He also asked for a new trial on the issue of punitive damages. ``They set out to see justice done, and they are determined to see it through,'' Barrett said by telephone. Horton, a Durant homebuilder, began the suit and his family pursued it after his death. His widow, Ella Mae Horton, declined to comment on the case Tuesday. Roger Baker, director of communications for Connecticut-based American Brands Inc., of which American Tobacco Co. is a subsidiary, said Tuesday that the company planned further motions in the case, but refused to say what they were. Baker said since the matter is pending in court, the company wouldn't comment further. In a similar case, a New Jersey jury awarded a widower $400,000 in 1988 after deciding a cigarette company was partly responsible for his wife's lung cancer death. An appeals court this year overturned the award and ordered a new trial. Defense lawyers argued during the latest trial that Horton knew the risks of smoking, but chose to continue. Barrett claimed Pall Mall cigarettes are defective and dangerous. ``We decided both parties were at fault,'' Roach said Monday, adding that he and eight other jurors ``thought the American Tobacco Co. acted in an irresponsible way. It was a very close decision. We were fairly near a hung jury, frankly.'' Mary Aronson, a Washington analyst who was at the three-week trial on behalf of tobacco investment clients, said Monday: ``As long as damages are not awarded, I believe Wall Street will view this as a win for the industry. This was considered the best case (against tobacco companies), yet no award was made.'' Barrett said that the jury verdict should have led to a damage award. ``We proved overwhelmingly that he suffered horrible damages, but the jury punted on that,'' Barrett said.

DOC.HEAD: Dominican Republic Government Controlling Gasoline Sales
DOC.TEXT: The government, which already has more than doubled gasoline prices in the last seven weeks, on Tuesday began rationing gas because of shortages brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis. Drivers will be allowed to buy gasoline every other day, depending on whether their license plates end in even or odd numbers. Gas station hours were curtailed. Gas will be sold from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and only until noon Sundays and holidays. Since Aug. 7, the price of gas here has soared from 55 cents a gallon to $1.42, with long lines at stations. The government has cut back fuel imports by 30 to 40 percent since crude oil prices began their climb after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. This Caribbean country, with a population exceeding 6.7 million, has no oil production of its own. The government effectively controls oil imports, refining and pricing through the Dominican Petroleum Refinery, which is 51 percent state-owned and 49 percent owned by Shell Oil. Gas stations are privately owned. Chaotic scenes occurred at some gas stations Tuesday as the plan went into effect before many drivers knew about it. Soldiers were posted at several stations, but there was no violence. The Dominican Republican has been operating under an austerity program - recommended by the International Monetary Fund - which has brought steep increases in the price of basic consumer goods.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces Plan to Tackle Pollution
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday issued a policy paper on tackling pollution, improving the environment and changing Britain's image as ``dirty man of Europe.'' Environment Secretary Chris Patten called the 300-page policy document ``the first really comprehensive statement of government policy on the environment, ranging from the street corner to the stratosphere.'' But environmental agencies said the plan, entitled ``This Common Inheritance,'' contains few new initiatives and is simply a listof good intentions. ``It is a woolly wish-list of what the government might like to see happening towards the end of the century, without making any commitment to action now,'' said a statement from Greenpeace. ``Britain remains the dirty man of Europe.'' The European Commission has attacked Britain for its plan to continue dumping more than 200,000 tons of industrial waste in the North Sea annually until 1992, despite an agreement among European nations that was to have stopped industrial dumping by last January. Britain also is one of eight European nations dumping mercury, lead, cadmium and dioxins into the North Sea. Patten said several of the major efforts listed in the document are already under way. These include a $52.6 billion program to improve water quality and a $11.28 billion industry initiative to fight acid rain. The government's Environmental Protection Bill, introduced in December and to be debated by Parliament later this year, includes measures such as fines for unlicensed waste dumping at sea, new restraints on radioactive substances and tougher standards of waste disposal. Patten said the government also would work toward increasing regenerating capacity from renewable resources such as wind and sea power to 1,000 megawatts by the year 2000, a tenfold increase on current capacity. He also promised efforts against carbon dioxide release. The Greenpeace statement said the government had failed to act on radioactive pollution, marine and river pollution, toxic waste imports, global warming, energy policy, transport policy, acid rain and ozone layer protection. Britain is a ``radioactive dustbin,'' it said, importing thousands of tons of nuclear waste from all over the world. Toxic waste from Europe, especially Italy and Germany, is being processed at British plants. A spokesman for Friends of the Earth, who spoke on condition he not be named, said the document was ``a program for discussion rather than a program for action. We are disappointed.''

DOC.HEAD: Retransmits a0701 to fix category code
$40 Oil Would Hit Consumers at Pumps, on Planes, in Pocketbooks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Other, including...,' to UPDATE with prices declining Tuesday. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Oil prices have...' Also moved on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: As crude oil approaches $40 per barrel, some analysts say consumers should enjoy $1.35 a gallon gasoline while they can. Gas prices are likely to go up, perhaps even beyond $2 per gallon, if a shooting war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, experts said Tuesday. And if oil should stay high for a sustained period, the fallout will be widespread, running up the cost of practically everything while slowing economic growth. ``This is not good news for the consumer,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. ``The problem with energy is it permeates the economy like a ripple in a pond. It's not just the price of heating oil and the price of gasoline.'' Not all analysts believe oil will stay as high as it is. They say that too much war hysteria may have been built into the market, that Iraq's ability to take out Saudi Arabian oil facilities may be overestimated, and that replacing a bombed oil well is much simpler than replacing a bombed factory. Others, including Beutel, say $40 barrels of oil seem inevitable in the near future. Some estimates have put oil at $60 to $65 during a war. On Tuesday, oil prices dipped as traders took profits from a surge a day earlier and awaited developments in the Persian Gulf. The benchmark grade light sweet crude fell 72 cents to $37.53 per barrel for November contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Some analysts suggested prices would resume their climb Wednesday because of the U.N. Security Council vote - taken after markets closed - to extend the embargo on Iraq and Kuwait by authorizing an air blockade. Oil prices have climbed steadily since Iraq invaded Kuwait last month. Saddam Hussein's saber-rattling this week put them less than $1 away from the ominous $40 figure. Crude last reached that plateau a decade ago, in the last oil crisis. ``What it means, I'm afraid, in solid terms, is the consumer is probably going to be lucky to find $1.35 gasoline, and probably a lot more of us are going to find $1.60 to $1.85 gasoline,'' Beutel said. ``We're probably going to see the average consumer pay 50 percent more for heating oil than he did last year.'' Stanley Feldman, a finance professor at Bentley College in Boston, does not predict sustained oil prices at $40. But consumers would be hit hard if it happens. ``At $40-a-barrel oil, you're probably looking at somewhere close to $1.90 for regular gasoline, maybe $2,'' Feldman said. Oil at $60 could push gasoline over $2 at the pump, the experts said. Gasoline and heating oil are commonly watched when crude starts getting more expensive. But America is so dependent on oil that the price of many other items would also be affected. Air fares, for instance, have increased to accommodate higher jet fuel, while drugs and foods would also be affected. They depend on oil for their production, transportation and refrigeration. ``Oil is the basis of plastics, and we still have a lot of oil-fired electrical generating plants,'' said David Farnsworth, a political science professor at Wichita State University. ``There are many ways that it's used. It has its impact on asphalt in the highways and how much street repair you can do.'' Feldman estimates $40 oil could push up consumer prices from 5 percent to 8 percent once all the economic ripples set in. ``That assumes the oil price stays at $40 for a sustained period of time, namely a year,'' he said. Buetel said each $10 increase in oil adds about 1 percent to the inflation rate. In addition, oil at $40 per barrel could cut about 1 percent out of the nation's economic growth, said Feldman, who termed such a scenario ``significant when the economy's already in the midst of a recession.'' Farnsworth puts gasoline at only about $1.50 per gallon if oil stays around $40. He thinks much of the increase consumers have already felt was based on panic. But higher oil could have broader implications, Farnsworth said, because oil prices are set in dollars, and the dollar has been weaker in Europe. If high oil prices persist until 1992, when European nations hope to integrate their economies, the United States could find itself at a disadvantage in trade talks, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Expel 12 Jordanian Embassy Workers, Amman Recalls Envoy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD background. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia expelled 12 more diplomatic staff from Jordan's consulate and embassy Tuesday, and Jordan recalled its ambassador in protest, the Foreign Ministry said. The Saudi government's order left a skeleton staff of four employees each in the Jordanian embassy in Riyadh and its consulate in Jiddah, according to the announcement read on state Jordan Radio. No comment was available immediately from Saudi authorities. Naser Batayneh, Jordan's ambassador to Saudi Arabia, was recalled to protest the ``inexcusable'' Saudi action, the Jordanian announcement said. Last week, Saudi Arabia expelled 20 Jordanian embassy and consulate employees for activities ``incompatible with their status'' - a diplomatic euphemism for espionage. Saudi officials said the diplomats were spying on military installations in collaboration with Iraq. The Saudis expelled 46 of the 50 Yemenis at the embassy in Saudi Arabia for the same reason. Jordanian Foreign Minister Marwan Kassem denied the spying report, but several Jordanian officials, including a Cabinet minister, privately confirmed it. The expulsions showed Saudi irritation with Jordan's pro-Iraqi stance following the invasion and annexation of Kuwait last month. The Saudi government also was unhappy about a conference of radical Palestinians in Amman last week at which calls were heard for suicide attacks against the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia last week cut off oil supplies to Jordan, claiming $46 million in unpaid bills. Saudi grants to Jordan also were likely to be cut, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: No Operator Assistance Please: Students Take Exams by Phone
DOC.TEXT: Dial ``D'' for diploma. University students can now take exams from the comfort of their own homes using a telephone message system called Telequiz. ``I love it but I don't know why,'' said student Jean Pajak. ``Maybe it's the spontaneity of it.'' In what is believed to be first student testing via touch-tone telephone, students at suburban Governors State University called in the answers to their Psychology 519 quiz over the weekend. They answered by punching in numbers that were registered with computerized voice-mail equipment. ``Seeing things in print in front of you gives you more time to go back and change the answers,'' said Pajak, 35, who returned to school seeing a master's degree. ``With this you really have to concentrate.'' Pajak and classmates took a 10-question multiple choice quiz, punching the numbers 1 through 4 on the phone to register their answers with a school computer. Students taking Management 421 will try the program this week, taking an exam of 15 true-false questions by pressing 1 for true or 2 for false. ``It's a replacement for the old-fashioned No. 2 lead pencil,'' said Donald Fricker, a professor of management information systems who developed the idea. Fricker said Telequiz saves time and money. ``I can administer any quiz in just two or three days as opposed to where the secretary has to type it, I have to copy it, the class has to meet, and I still have to grade it,'' he said. The system also eliminates the need to travel to the college in suburban University Park. The 5,000-student school has no dormitories and many students have outside job and family responsibilities. The system lets instructors record up to 30 questions. It can handle just one student at a time. Quiz takers have six or seven seconds to think of an answer before the next question is asked - too short a time for a student to cheat by looking up the answer in a book, Fricker said. Telequiz will be demonstrated in November to representatives of 600 schools at the annual Computers on Campus conference in Myrtle Beach, S.C. Teresa Barker took the test Sunday night, sitting at the kitchen table after she had cleared the dinner dishes. ``Being at home, it was different than being somewhere where there's a lot of pressure,'' said Barker, 52, a child-welfare worker pursuing an undergraduate degree. Some students called as early as 8 a.m. Saturday and Sunday. The last student to call Saturday phoned in at at 10:38 p.m. The system ``gives a student tremendous flexibility,'' Fricker said. ``The student can be at his most relaxed. He can call in at 4 a.m. if that's when he's achieved nirvana and feels he knows the material.''

DOC.HEAD: Chilly In Southeast, Summer On Northern Plains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Thursday's low...' to CORRECT day to Tuesday sted Thursday.
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures tumbled to record lows across the Southeast for a second day Tuesday, but record highs in the 80s and 90s were posted across the Plains as far north as North Dakota. At 2 p.m. EDT, North Dakota was warmer than Alabama, and Minnesota temperatures were about the same as those across Georgia. The low of 42 at Montgomery, Ala., toppled a record of 45 that had been on the books since 1887. Other record lows were 53 at Apalachicola, Fla.; 44 at Athens, Ga.; 42 at Augusta, Ga.; 50 at Beaufort, S.C.; 47 at Cape Hatteras, N.C.; 42 at Greenville, S.C.; 44 at Huntsville, Ala.; 51 at Jacksonville, Fla.; 50 at Mobile, Ala.; 45 at Tallahassee, Fla., and 65 at Tampa, Fla. Records were tied at 36, at Asheville, N.C.; 46 at Auburn, Ala.; 43 at Birmingham, Ala.; 51 at Charleston, S.C.; 43 at Columbia, S.C.; 45 at Meridian, Miss.; 56 at New Orleans; 50 at Savannah, Ga. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 at Lewisburg, W.Va. But while the South chilled, afternoon temperatures climbed into the 70s and 80s over the Mississippi Valley and Plains. A record high was set at 91 at Norfolk, Neb., and tied at 93 at Concordia, Kan.; 88 at Sheridan, Wyo., and 86 at Williston, N.D. Most of the nation was dry Tuesday. Afternoon showers and occasional thunderstorms reached from southwestern Oregon across northern California, from central Louisiana into west-central Mississippi, along the southwestern and east-central coasts of Florida, over western New York state and over east-central Lower Michigan. There were no reports of significant rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 53 at Truckee, Calif., to 95 at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Press Delay Plan Despite Bush Veto Threat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS gf 7: ``None of,'' with three grafs bgng: ``House Republican,'' to note Michel concession
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget-Workers' Woes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on the House Appropriations Committee shouted down President Bush's veto threat Tuesday and voted to delay for 20 days deep spending cuts that will be triggered unless Congress and the White House agree on a deficit-reduction plan. If the $85 billion in arbitrary spending reductions are allowed to take effect as scheduled Oct. 1, Chairman Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., told the committee, ``it threatens to bring the economy to its knees. We can't afford the risk.'' ``A full-blown crisis'' may be required to force negotiators into solving the deficit, said Rep. Silvio Conte of Massachusetts, the senior Republican on the committee. At the White House, an angry Bush told reporters: ``If there is no budget agreement with real spending reductions and real process reform by the end of the week, I will have to veto it. I do not want to see further delay in kicking this problem on down the road.'' The House is likely to consider the bill later this week. No deficit agreement was in sight, although top leaders of Congress and the administration claimed some progress. The goal is a combination of targeted spending reductions and tax increases that would cut the deficit by $50 billion during the 12 months beginning Monday and an additional $450 billion in the following four years. House Republican Leader Bob Michel of Illinois told reporters he is ready to drop Bush's coveted capital-gains tax cut, which has been the thorniest issue in the negotiations. ``In my opinion the doggone price is too steep,'' he said. Michel said the administration is considering other options for stimulating the economy - options that might be more acceptable to Democratic leaders, who consider a capital-gains cut nothing but a windfall for the rich. Democrats are insisting that any capital-gains reduction be offset by raising other taxes on the wealthy. The stopgap spending legislation approved by the House panel is necessary because none of the 13 annual appropriation bills has been enacted - and a new budget year begins in less than a week. For the first time in several years, federal workers are taking the threat of furloughs seriously. ``People are literally losing sleep over this,'' said Tom Doherty, an Occupational Safety and Health Administration inspector from Allentown, Pa. ``They have kids to feed and house payments to make, and now they're having the rug swept out from under them by the system they work for,'' With the Monday deadline in mind, the House panel agreed by a nearly party-line 32-20 vote to continue spending basically at present levels through Oct. 20 and to block any threatened across-the-board spending cuts - including those that could bring mass furloughs of federal workers - before that date. In an effort to discourage a veto, the Democratic-controlled committee attached to the measure $2 billion of money to support the large-scale deployment of U.S. military forces in the Persian Gulf. ``This won't protect it,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla. ``The president does intend to veto it.'' ``His (Bush's) political advisers are not crazy enough to tell him to veto this,'' said Rep. Neal Smith, D-Iowa. Whitten said he had talked to Bush earlier in the day and ``he didn't tell me he was going to veto it.'' For anyone ``to let the whole country go to pot - it's a question of whether he's patriotic or his judgment has gone sour,'' Whitten said. Despite the looming financial breakdown in the government, the committee spent more of its session talking of the other major crisis: the Persian Gulf. The panel: -Voted to double to 12 months the maximum time for which military reservists may be activated for Operation Desert Shield. -Approved an extra $20 million to provide ``imminent danger'' pay to troops in the gulf. -Sidestepped Bush's request to forgive $6.7 billion in Egyptian debt in appreciation of that nation's contributions to protecting Saudi Arabia from Iraqi attack. Both sides agreed that domestic political pressures - the unpopularity of foreign aid - would have defeated the proposition if it had been brought to a vote. Instead, the committee agreed by voice vote to waive a law that would have barred Egypt from further U.S. aid because of failure to repay past debts. -Made clear that other countries' contributions to the costs of Operation Desert Shield must be channeled through the regular congressional appropriations process. The administration had proposed to let the Pentagon handle such funds without intervention by Congress. The committee stripped from the bill a section aimed at prohibiting the National Endowment for the Arts from supporting ``any indecent, anti-religious or obscene picture, play or writing.'' The panel's explanation of the stopgap spending resolution mentions what could happen if the spending cuts - called a sequester - mandated by the Gramm-Rudman law are allowed to take effect. ``The effect ... would be disastrous not only to the nation's economy, but ... would have a dangerous impact on a weak economy,'' the report states. Among the possibilities: ``the air traffic control system would turn into chaos''; a major influx of illegal aliens; a shortage of money to pay jurors; compromised safety for nuclear facilities; 1 million children would miss shots; Social Security checks for new applicants could be threatened; Internal Revenue Service enforcement could suffer by $8 billion; the Space Shuttle would be grounded until 1993, and farm loans would be slashed. Top representatives of Congress and the administration began negotiating a deficit reduction more than four months ago. By most accounts, the major obstacle has been Bush's insistence that the tax on capital gains be reduced to increase incentives for investment. Democrats have resisted cutting that tax, which applies to profits on the sale of investments, because 80 percent of the direct benefits would go to those with incomes of $100,000 a year or more. They have insisted any such cut be accompanied by a tax increase of some other kind on upper-income people, but the two parties have been unable to agree on the type of tax increase.

DOC.HEAD: William Hurt Stars in Chekhov's `Ivanov' at Yale Rep
DOC.TEXT: Oleg Yefremov's adaptation at the Yale Repertory Theater of ``Ivanov,'' starring William Hurt in the title role, begins and ends with a gunshot. But what happens in between is what really counts in this dark, moody and unrealized production of one of Anton Chekhov's early and lesser-known plays. ``Ivanov'' has attracted attention not only because of Hurt, one of the few film stars willingly to put himself on stage with any degree of regularity, but also because of Yefremov, artistic director of the Moscow Art Theater. The revival certainly looks authentic. The design by David Borovsky, head artist of the Moscow Taganka Theater, is a marvel of the power of suggestion. The decrepit facade of a country mansion, its columns covered with gnarled, leafless vines, fills the wide playing area at the University Theater. With a few chairs strategically placed on stage in front of this haunted house the director conjures up the deadening bourgeois activity of two different families in vastly different financial situations. Yefremov is not afraid to tamper with the text. For example, he reshuffles scenes, opening the play with a second-act party that has the guests commenting on Ivanov's tribulations before the audience has seen him. And the title character has enough troubles for several dramas. Ivanov is a man in despair. ``I don't believe anymore,'' he says. He doesn't believe in his marriage to Sarah, his rich Jewish wife whose parents cut off love and money to her after she married. And he spends more time worrying about his debts than trying to earn money to pay them off. But an articulation of his anxiety is hard to find in Hurt's muffled portrait of Ivanov. The blond, bearded Hurt can be a galvanizing actor on stage, as audiences who saw his jumpstart performance off and on Broadway in David Rabe's ``Hurlyburly'' know. Here his acting is muted, his voice rarely rising above a drone. Whatever magic Yefremov has worked on the play's atmosphere has not filtered down to his star. Other members of the large, underrehearsed cast seem to be left to their own resources, losing both the comedy and the tragedy of the piece. Some fare better than others. Frances Conroy, as the dying Sarah conveys the evening's only real sense of sadness. Zeljko Ivanek has mastered the outrage of a young doctor amazed at Ivanov's treatment of his critically ill wife. And Lee Richardson has the right amount of charm as Ivanov's reprobate uncle. But Austin Pendleton and Susan Kellermann flounder as Ivanov's prosperous neighbors and Leo Burmester is more All-American farmhand than savvy country bumpkin. The result is an incomplete production, tantalizing for the atmosphere Yefremov is able to coax from a production team that also includes costume designer Jess Goldstein and lighting designer Geoff Korf. This ``Ivanov,'' which runs in New Haven through Oct. 13, is an inviting shell of a play, but not a world inhabited by real people.

DOC.HEAD: Another Congressional Fight Over Aid
DOC.TEXT: Supported by a lobbying blitz by the President of El Salvador, the Bush administration has revived efforts to head off deep cuts in next year's military aid to the Central American country. Administration officials said Tuesday they were preparing to fight the issue when the 1991 foreign aid bill comes to the Senate floor in the next few weeks, and were lining up support for a cut that would be less than the 50 percent slash already called for by the House. Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani, in Washington for four days of meetings with administration and congressional officials, continued his sales pitches Tuesday in separate meetings with lawmakers and reporters. Cristiani promised to speed the investigation into the murders last November of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter, and proposed to bring three American judges to his country to study how the case is being handled. ``The case is testing the administratio of justice in El Salvador,'' Cristiani told reporters at a luncheon. It also has been the primary impetus behind congressional efforts to cut the country's $85 million in military aid. Cristiani also said he would accept a 50 percent cut in military aid, but only if Congress made it contingent upon agreement of both sides in the decade-old conflict to a cease-fire. Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass., who heads a House Democratic task force on El Salvador that has been critical of the Salvadoran government, said he was not persuaded by the president's proposals. Reform of the Salvadoran military must come before an effective cease-fire can be reached, Moakley said. That is the issue which has stymied United Nations-sponsored peace talks between the two warring sides. But Moakley, who last month accused the military of a coverup in the case, said he was encouraged that senior military officers were now agreeing to testify personally before the investigating judge. Eight officers have been arrested in the case, but none has been brought to trial. Moakley's task force found that some key evidence has been destroyed and that testimony has been withheld. The State Department apparently is pinning its hopes for continued military aid on the Senate. Administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they would seek to draft a milder version of the aid cut that could be offered as an alternative to the 50 percent cut being pushed by Sens. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., and Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. The State Department has largely ignored the issue for the last two months, but has taken a renewed interest as the end of the fiscal year on Sunday forces action on appropriations bills. Cristiani said he still hoped that the military aid could be rescued, but added that if it were cut it would not jeopardize his government. ``It would be creating more economic problems for the country,'' he said. But he added: ``We do not feel the government is going to topple because of this.''

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Furious Over Fictitious Army Enlistments
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders on both left and right raged Tuesday against a rare common enemy: a scheme that allows middle-aged ultra-Orthodox Jews to get veteran's benefits without ever serving in the army. Public disclosure of the arrangement renewed the simmering resentment many non-observant Israeli citizens feel for ultra-Orthodox Jews and their demands to change Israeli society to fit their religious beliefs. Shulamit Aloni, head of the left-wing Citizens' Rights Movement, suggested the doling out of military benefits to men who never serve was a way to reward ultra-Orthodox political parties. ``This is part of an agreement to take advantage of the defense minister's authority to give money to this public who eats but never pays,'' Aloni said. Parliament member Ran Cohen, who uncovered the scheme, said the ultra-Orthodox were insulting the average Israeli man who is drafted into the army for three years and serves in the reserves until age 54. ``They play act as if they want to go into the army, but they don't want to contribute to the army. They want the money,'' Cohen said. He said hundreds and perhaps thousands of religious Jews 35 to 50 years old were receiving benefits without ever serving in the army. As Cohen explained the arrangement, ultra-Orthodox Jews enlist in the army after getting exemptions for the draft for years of study of the Torah. Typically, the men are in their late 30s or 40s when they enlist, and they are never called up to actually serve because of their age and because they often are fathers of large families, Cohen said. But, he added, they are still eligible for higher benefits as ``veterans.'' The benefits are especially important to big Orthodox families because every Israeli with three or more children gets a government stipend. For example, an Israeli family of seven receives $213 monthly, but the same size family headed by a veteran is eligible for $408. The difference rises with the number of children. Israel television said a senior military forum headed by Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron debated the issue Tuesday. The military command also issued a statement insisting it was not responsible for the government stipends, which are handled by the Labor and Social Affairs Ministry. It said religious Jews drafted into the army ``serve in active reserve duty in accordance with the needs.'' The army said it saw as its duty to draft religious men who have completed their studies at religious seminaries. Their number the last five years has totalled 4,000, it said. Of these, 24 percent were found unfit for service, more than 50 percent were drafted into regular and 24 percent into reserve units, the military said. ``It should be stressed that there was no major increase in the last year in the number of seminary students drafted into the army, and those mobilized cannot know beforehand what they would do during reserve service,'' the statement said. Lawmaker Uriel Lin of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's ruling right-wing Likud bloc reacted to Cohen's charges by calling for an army investigation. ``The law cannot be made into a joke and the people of Israel cannot be turned into a joke,'' he said. Cohen's complaints, printed on front pages of Israeli newspapers Tuesday, also brought angry phone calls to radio talks shows. Israelis, most of whom are non-observant Jews, regularly complain about military exemptions for the ultra-Orthodox.

DOC.HEAD: End of the Road Seen For San Francisco's `Berlin Wall'
DOC.TEXT: It looks like the end of the road for the earthquake-damaged Embarcadero Freeway, a double-decker span likened to the Berlin Wall for the way it separates San Francisco's downtown and waterfront. The Board of Supervisors voted Monday to tear down the mile-long stretch of the road that's been closed since the 7.1-magnitude quake did widespread damage in October 1989. The freeway's concrete support columns were damaged. ``The Embarcadero Freeway has been San Francisco's environmental Berlin Wall,'' Supervisor Bill Maher said. ``It has been a blight on our city and our waterfront ever since it was built.'' At the time of the quake, the Embarcadero carried 60,000 cars a day along the waterfront to Chinatown, the North Beach restaurant district and Fisherman's Wharf, the city's prime tourist attraction. Chinatown merchants oppose its destruction because the highway made it easy for tourists and other customers to get there. Technically, the board's 6-5 vote was strictly advisory, but federal and state officials have made it clear they will go along with the city's decision. No formal demolition request has been filed by the city. Mayor Art Agnos said he is waiting while he tries to secure funds for an underground replacement highway. The California Department of Transportation has said it would cost $54.6 million to repair the freeway. Agnos believes he can get more federal quake-related emergency transportation relief funds after completion of new soil studies, which could raise the estimate. ``I intend to make sure that we get every single dollar that we're eligible for,'' Agnos said. Agnos declined to put a timetable on its demolition, but he said the board's vote goes a long way toward helping him get the $135 million he needs to replace the freeway. State transportation spokesman Breg Bayol said Tuesday that tearing down the 30-year-old freeway would take at least six months. ``There's more to it than just tearing it down,'' Bayol said. ``There's the engineering and traffic control studies to do before we put it out to bid. Some portions could be troublesome because they're so close to buildings.'' Chinatown merchants led the battle against demolishing the structure, pushing for a quick reopening to get traffic flowing into their area again. They even closed their shops for one day in April and converged on City Hall to protest the mayor's plan. ``There's still some opposition, but most of it's political,'' said Rose Pak, spokeswoman for the Chinatown Chamber of Commerce. ``The real turning point came when we realized the cost and time to repair the Embarcadero. This way, the mayor's plan didn't look so bad.'' The freeway was controversial even before it was built in 1959. Pulitzer Prize-winning architecture critic Allan Temko has called the Embarcadero ``one of the chief horrors of the 1950s, when technocrats started ramming freeways through cities.'' He said tearing down the freeway will give San Francisco a chance to once again be the ``ideal of a civilized American metropolis, as it was before the freeway transformed one of the loveliest waterfronts in the world into one of the most obscene.''

DOC.HEAD: No Home for Bust of Former Soviet Leader Chernenko
DOC.TEXT: Officials in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk want a bust of former Soviet leader Konstantin U. Chernenko removed from a city square, but they can find no takers, a newspaper reported Tuesday. The likeness of the predecessor to Mikhail S. Gorbachev was erected in the city about 1,950 miles east of Moscow after Chernenko was awarded his third ``Hero of Socialist Labor'' title, the Trud newspaper reported. But the Krasnoyarsk City Council decided to dismantle the bronze bust, saying ``established procedure'' calls for such monuments to be erected in the recipient's birthplace, Trud said. That would be quite impossible in Chernenko's case, Trud noted, since the village of Bolshaya Tes, where he was born, is now underwater because of a dam built for the Krasnoyarsk hydroelectric power plant. The residents of Sharypovo, a town 130 miles west of Krasnoyarsk, don't want the bust either, Trud said. Until recently, Sharypovo was named for Chernenko, but it has since been given its old name back. Krasnoyarsk's City Council decided to put the bust in a cultural museum, but can't move it there until Kremlin authorities rescind the decision that placed it in the square in the first place. Chernenko, a crony of the late Leonid I. Brezhnev, led the Soviet Union from Feb. 13, 1984, until he died on March 10, 1985. Under Gorbachev, memorials to Brezhnev and his proteges have been removed and their leadership has been denounced.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Executed for Robberies in Canton
DOC.TEXT: Nine people were executed in the south Chinese city of Canton and four others were sentenced to life for robbing passengers on long-distance buses, an official newspaper reported. The executions were the latest of a yearlong anti-crime campaign that Amnesty International says has seen at least 500 people executed. Two county courts on Monday sentenced the 13-member gang for 37 robberies in a 10-month period, the Canton-based Yangcheng Daily reported. The highway bandits robbed 98 passengers of $36,544. Thirteen people were stabbed during the robberies, said the paper, seen Tuesday in Beijing. Ringleader Gao Shiming was responsible for 26 robberies, during which he injured three people, the paper said. Gao, Lin Jinquan, Lin Guanghong, Fan Tiansheng and five others were sentenced to death and executed. Four other gang members were given life sentences, the paper said. Executions in China are usually carried out with a bullet to the head. Monday's executions came less than a week after 65 people were executed in one day in Canton, which has one of China's worst crime problems.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rejects Keating's Bid to Cut $5 Million Bail
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court refused Tuesday to reduce the $5 million bail for Charles H. Keating, the savings and loan executive accused of fraud in selling American Continental Corp. junk bonds. The 2nd District Court of Appeal said in a one-paragraph ruling that it considered an appeal filed Monday by Keating's lawyers and had examined transcripts of bail proceedings before Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner. ``The petition is denied,'' the three-judge panel wrote. The court apparently rejected arguments by Keating that he is being made a scapegoat in a criminal fraud case involving sales of the now-worthless bonds through branches of Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln Savings & Loan. Lincoln, an American Continental subsidiary, has been seized by federal regulators. District Attorney Ira Reiner said he was pleased the court had upheld $5 million bail, but said he expected further efforts by the Keating defense to win reduction of the bail by a higher court. Reiner acknowledged that $5 million is a high price for freedom. ``It is an exceptionally high bail and Mr. Keating is an exceptional defendant,'' Reiner said. ``The principal factor involved is risk of flight. You can't consider Mr. Keating without thinking of Robert Vesco.'' Vesco, a fugitive financier, fled the United States while being investigated by authorities. Keating, who has been held at the downtown Men's Central Jail for a week, contends he can't adequately defend himself if he remains in custody. Stephen C. Neal, Keating's main attorney, said Monday night that he would pursue every avenue to get Keating out of jail. The next appeal would be to the California Supreme Court, and after that, to a federal court. Keating and three co-defendants surrendered to face a 42-count state grand jury indictment on Sept. 18. Klausner set Keating's bail at $5 million and held the other defendants on $1 million bail. After a hearing last week, the judge reduced the co-defendants' bail to $100,000 or $200,000. Klausner refused to lower Keating's bail, saying the possibility of 10 years in prison made him a flight risk. Keating's attorneys argued that he had not fled any of the numerous legal problems that have arisen since federal regulators seized Lincoln and American Continental went to bankruptcy court. They also said he is about $5 million in debt and, with the help of his children, could only post bail of $500,000. The co-defendants, officers of American Continental or Lincoln, posted bail last week and are free. All four are due back in court Oct. 5 to enter a plea to the charges of misleading investors about the safety of the risky junk bonds sold at Lincoln branches. Keating and the others are charged with ordering employees to steer Lincoln depositors away from insured certificates of deposit and into the bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Amendment Permitting Abortion Counseling
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Thursday to reverse Bush administration regulations that prohibit federally supported family planning clinics from offering information on abortion. The regulations, which are the subject of a case before the Supreme Court, were imposed in 1988 by the Reagan administratin and continued after President Bush took office. They have become the focus of debate between both sides of the abortion issue. The Senate voted 63-35 to approve an amendment offered by Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., saying the clinics must provide ``information and counseling concerning all legal and medical options'' to pregnant women who ask for it, including ``pregnancy termination.'' The clinics provide helth care and family planning services for the poor. The amendment was added to a Senate bill that extends the life of the family planning program, established 20 years ago by Title X of the Public Health Service Act. The Senate continued to debate other amendments to the reauthorization bill into the evening, and a vote to limit debate was tentatively scheduled for Wednesday. Opponents of abortion opposed the amendment, arguing that the federal government should not encourage abortions or make them more available. ``Most Americans do not want their tax dollars used in any way to facilitate abortions,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Advocates of abortion rights argued that the regulatory ban discriminated against poor women, preventing them from having the same information that women who could afford their own doctor would receive. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, called them a ``gag rule.'' ``This program isn't about abortion. It's about options,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md. ``Whether it's abstinence, adoption or abortion, I believe young people have a right to know.'' Since enactment in 1970, Title X has prohibited aid from going to ``programs where abortion is a method of family planning.'' But until 1988 that was interpreted as barring the use of federal money to pay for abortions. The Reagan administration's Department of Health and Human Services in 1988 adopted a broader interpretation that said federal money couldn't go to family planning programs that provide counseling and referral for abortion. The action touched off a series of lawsuits, and federal appeals courts have delivered conflicting rulings. One of the cases is scheduled for argument before the Supreme Court in its October term. ``Why not let the court make this decision, because it's probably going to have to in the end anyway,'' Hatch said.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff's Deputies Rescue Hostages At McDonald's, Nab Alleged Gunman
LaserPhotos LA3-4-5
DOC.TEXT: A young man who helped authorities capture a gunman who held 20 people hostage inside a McDonald's restaurant said Tuesday he was a reluctant hero. ``All I knew was to take care of my people, my crew,'' said the restaurant's assistant manager, Ramiro Gironas. ``I'm glad I'm safe and that all my people are safe. I'm not a hero. I just did what I had to.'' Police said Gironas, 21, hid in the kitchen during the seven-hour standoff Monday night and Tuesday morning and kept them informed by phone of the gunman's movements. Officers were eventually able to distract the man with explosive charges and overpower him shortly after midnight. None of the hostages was hurt. Douglas Girard, 32, of San Jacinto, was arrested for investigation of armed robbery and false imprisonment, authorities said. He was treated for minor facial injuries suffered during his arrest and jailed in lieu of $500,000 bail. A second man, Frank M. Teresi, 38, of Anaheim, surrendered to police shortly after the standoff began about 5:30 p.m. Monday in this suburb 35 miles northeast of Los Angeles, said police Lt. Ron Ingels. Teresi, on parole for robbery and being under the influence of a narcotic, was jailed on a no-bail parole hold, said police Sgt. John Ortega. Police said the standoff began after Girard allegedly robbed a nearby Kids Mart clothing store of $200, while warning he had an armed partner outside. Authorities said Girard and Teresi ran from the store to the McDonald's. Eleven employees and one customer hid in the basement when they noticed a .38 caliber revolver in Girard's back pocket. Authorities said he forced the remaining eight people to lie on the floor. An 18-member Los Angeles County sheriff's SWAT team, along with dozens of Pomona and La Verne police officers, surrounded the restaurant and negotiators tried unsuccessfully to talk with the gunman. Officers finally lobbed ``flash-bang'' percussion grenades into the restaurant as a distraction. ``They were able to get inside without being detected,'' said Deputy Bill Wehner, a sheriffs' spokesman. ``A deputy leaped over the counter and took the suspect into custody.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Blame Vendetta by 14-Year-Old Girl for Picnic Poisoning
DOC.TEXT: A 14-year-old girl took a page from the script of the movie ``Heathers'' in plotting revenge against two 11-year-old playmates she allegedly fed poisoned picnic fare, police said Tuesday. Other girls invited to the picnic and croquet party were aware that a peanut butter sandwich had been laced with rat poison and some grape drink mixed with a household cleanser, police spokesman Tony Burtt said. They stood by while the victims tasted the poisoned food and drink Sept. 16, and didn't report the plot until afterward, police said. Then the children told their parents. One 11-year-old girl vomited after tasting the grape-flavored drink and the other girl suffered stomach pains after taking several bites of the tainted sandwich, police said. Neither had any serious aftereffects. None of the children was identified. The mother of the 14-year-old denied that her daughter planned the poisoning. In an interview for Wednesday's editions of the Valley Daily News, she blamed two other 11-year-old playmates at the picnic. The paper withheld the mother's name to avoid identifying the children. ``At the very least, they were more than just witnesses,'' she said. Burtt agreed the 11-year-olds may have been involved, but said investigators believe the teen-ager staged the picnic to get revenge. A dispute over possession of a ``Heathers'' videotape and clothing and jewelry allegedly taken by one of the victims prompted the poisoning, he said. Friends told police the teen-age girl said she got the idea from the plot of ``Heathers,'' an R-rated dark comedy featuring teen-age murder and a tight clique of popular girls. In the film, the leader of the in-crowd is killed with household poisons. The movie opens and closes with characters playing croquet. Two girls told investigators they were at the 14-year-old's home the day she came up with the plan for the picnic, Burtt said. The teen-ager allegedly made peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and put them in plastic bags. Rat poison was hidden in one sandwich, which was cut and wrapped differently so it could be picked from the others. The girl told her friends she expected the food to make the girls sick but not to seriously harm them, other children later told police. No charges have been filed pending completion of the police investigation, said Dan Donohoe of the King County prosecutor's office. It was being investigated as a possible criminal assault, police said. The food was seized as evidence. ``It's scary because the girl that's supposed to have done all this was a friend of my daughter's,'' the mother of the girl who got the grape drink told the newspaper. ``They've been good friends for a year, and they used to spend the night at each other's houses.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Army Tears Down More Palestinian Buildings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with military report on demolition. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The army demolished or sealed 37 Palestinian shops and houses on Monday night and Tuesday in the Gaza Strip's Bureij refugee camp, where a soldier was killed last week, the military command said. It said 26 shops and seven houses were demolished and four additional houses were sealed ``to allow safer transportation in the area.'' The camp remained under curfew imposed soon after reserve Sgt. Amnon Pomeranz, 46, was stoned to death. Searches continued for accomplices in the death, the military said. Bulldozers leveled 15 buildings in Bureij on Monday night before a temporary restraining order halted razing. The Supreme Court canceled the order Tuesday and demolition resumed. Palestinian journalists said about seven bulldozers, backed up by 25 army trucks, destroyed buildings on the main road at the camp's entrance after dark Tuesday. The army said the road had to be widened to improve security and that the demolitions were not punitive. Pomeranz was killed after his car hit a donkey cart, injuring two Palestinian teen-agers. A Palestinian mob set his car and body afire. He was the 12th soldier to die since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in December 1987. The restraining order was obtained Monday by the Association for Civil Rights in Israel, which said Palestinians should be given a chance to appeal the deolition order. A three-judge Supreme Court panel canceled the order Tuesday, but did not make its findings public. Maj. Gen. Matan Vilnai, chief of the Southern Command, told the judges the demolitions were required to meet ``an immediate and urgent military need.'' He said Palestinians not involved in the killing would be compensated with ``alternate shops and houses.'' Shmuel Ovenboy, spokesman for the military government, which is responsible for administration in Gaza, said: ``I don't know a thing about this.'' The army has demolished more than 300 homes as punishment for Arab suspects since the uprising began 34 months ago. Human rights groups and the U.S. State Department have condemned the demolition as collective punishment. Israeli newspapers say the government also is considering deporting Palestinians suspected in the sergeant's death. Journalists have been barred from entering Bureij, home to 20,000 Palestinians. Nearby Nusseirat camp and Jabaliya camp to the north were put under curfew Tuesday to prevent violence, the army said. Pomeranz was the 48th Israeli to die in the uprising. Israelis have killed 730 Palestinians. At least 265 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration. Masked Palestinian gunmen killed Ibrahim Abu Obeid, 35, on Tuesday in the Gaza town of Rafah as a suspected collaborator, Arab reporters said. The army said it was checking the report.

DOC.HEAD: President Gaviria Presents New Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: President Cesar Gaviria, confronted with a resurgence of guerrilla attacks, agreed Tuesday to rebel demands for international supervision of any possible cease-fire. Gaviria made the announcement at a news conference in Bogota shortly before leaving for the United Nations. He said international supervision of a cease-fire is possible ``any time the guerrillas halt their kidnappings, taking of hostages, terrorist attacks and their recruiting of children 15 and younger.'' ``We are thereby removing any obstacle that might keep rebelious groups from adhering to the government's position of peace,'' Gaviria said. There was no immediate response from the two main rebel groups that Gaviria's statment was aimed at: the National Liberation Army and the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces. The groups have been fighting in the mountains and jungles of Colombia for more than 20 years. Their attacks contribute to a climate of violence that includes murders and kidnappings by right-wing death squads and drug smugglers. The cease-fire would be the first step toward convincing the guerrillas to disband and form civilian groups to participate in the country's politics. A constituent assembly will meet next February to consider proposals to change the country's constitution, including a wider distribution of power now held mostly by the country's traditional parties, the Liberals and Conservatives. The government has said that if guerrillas want to participate in the assembly, they must sign a peace agreement and take steps toward disbanding. The guerrillas have been ambushing army patrols and attacking towns in the last few weeks. On Sept. 5 they blew up the main oil pipeline in the country. A third major guerrilla group, the April 19 Movement, disbanded last February in exchange for amnesty and the right to form a political party. Antonio Navarro, one of the movement's leaders, is serving as health minister for Gaviria.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Help for Nations Rocked by Gulf Crisis; Iraqi Buildup Seen
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS graf 8: ``Ozal himself,'' with Ozal quote on Iraq's military shortcomings; INSERTS grafs 20-21: ``Japanese Finance,'' Japan's assessment of new aid group
DOC.TEXT: President Bush appealed Tuesday for a ``generous response from the world community'' for countries rocked by the Persian Gulf crisis as the Pentagon reported new buildups of Iraqi troops and armor in Southern Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Bush, speaking to the annual meeting of the 152-member International Monetary Fnd, announced he was forming an international clearing house to coordinate financial help for the most seriously affected countries. ``We are determined not to allow the brutal behavior of one aggressor to undermine the historic process of democratic change or to derail the movement towards market-oriented economic systems,'' Bush told the gathering of world financial leaders. Meanwhile, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said about 430,000 Iraqi soldiers are now in southern Iraq and Kuwait, within striking distance of Saudi Arabia. Last week, the total was put at 360,000. Williams said the Iraqi deployments still appeared to be ``essentially a defensive force,'' but were capable of readily converting to an offensive unit. But Bush was told earlier by Turkish President Turgot Ozal that western estimates of Saddam Hussein's military capability may be overstated, a State Department official said. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State James Dobbins, briefing reporters on the Bush-Ozal meeting, said that Ozal and his aides told Bush that ``there is an inordinate concern with Iraqi capabilities. It is an exaggerated concern.'' Ozal himself, answering questions at a National Press Club luncheon, said Saddam in his war with Iran ``was supported heavily by Russia, by France, by many Western nations, and also heavily supported by his neighbors, Arab neighbors, including Kuwait, Saudi Arabia - maybe more than $200 billion. And on the other hand, Iranians were not supported by the West, there was even an effective embargo on them for arms sales. The war took eight years. How you can say this is a strong army?'' In his speech to the IMF and the World Bank, Bush said he was creating a Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group to help ``transform commitments into concrete contributions.'' And, while the group will first meet under the auspices of the U.S. Treasury, Bush made it clear he would welcome an increased role by the IMF in the panel's deliberations. ``The political leadership of the U.N. must be matched by the economic leadership of the of the IMF and the World Bank,'' he said. Earlier in the day, World Bank President Barber Conable outlined emergency plans to help resettle hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. Bush noted the refugee crisis, as well as unemployment problems and serious disruptions in the price and flow of oil. ``This staggering burden, which is pressing upon those most seriously affected countries, calls for a generous response from the world community,'' Bush said. He noted that the United States had already begun mobilizing financial help for front-line states such as Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. The United States has extracted pledges of $20 billion in military and financial aid from allies. Bush said that the new group, expected to hold its first meeting on Wednesday, would be chaired by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Its members will also include Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Germany, Britain, Italy, France, Canada, South Korea and the European Community. An administration official said Wednesday's meeting of the new group was an organizing session among donor countries to discuss a wide variety of issues - including how much needs to be raised. He would not predict whether the group, an informal clearing house to coordinate the flow of money, would be able to reach a consensus on the funding amount. A West German official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said that the United States was seeking approximately $4.5 billion in assistance for Egypt, Turkey and Jordan for this year and an additional $10 billion in 1991. The German official said some countries may balk at the size of the contribution being sought by the United States. He suggested that the U.S. fund-raising drive should be expanded to include Switzerland and Sweden. Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, whose country has pledged $4 billion so far in the campaign against Saddam Hussein, said the Japanese are willing to participate in Bush's crisis coordinating group but he indicated numerous details on the proposal remained to be negotiated between the large donor countries. ``President Bush gave one idea. Whether it will go ahead will depend on the response of the countries involved,'' Hashimoto told reporters. Earlier Tuesday, Bush met with Ozal and, separately, with Portuguese Prime Minister Cavaco Silva. Both leaders voiced strong support for the U.S.-led effort to isolate Saddam Hussein. In a brief ceremony after Bush's meeting with Ozal, Bush praised ``staunch allies like Turkey'' for solidarity with the United Nations and the United States in telling ``the world we will not tolerate this invasion.'' ``It will not stand,'' Bush added. Bush said the United States would seek a new agreement to increase textile imports from Turkey. And he said he promised Ozal the administration would continue to support Turkey's bid to become the 13th member of the European Community. Bush also pledge to work closely with Congress to make sure Turkey gets ``its fair share'' of military aid in the coming year. ``We will also work to help modernize the Turkish armed forces by the future sales of F-16s and provision of other military equipment,'' Bush said. Asked by reporters at a picture-taking session in the Oval Office how long Turkey could endure hardships caused by the embargo, Ozal said, ``as much as it requires.'' Turkey was one of the first nations to help the United States after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait by closing a major pipeline carrying Iraqi oil. Portugal is allowing U.S. airlift flights to Saudi Arabia to use an air base in the Azores for refueling. The Portuguese leader said after his meeting with Bush that the ``international community must stick together and be very firm...Nobody can accept that such a brutal aggression will pay off.'' The Pentagon said call-ups of reserves from all services have reached 21,970, an increase of 317 from its previous tally announced last week. Maj.
