Doug Hart, a Pentagon spokesman, said a larger increase is likely to be announced late this week. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said up to 50,000 reserves may be on active duty by Sept. 30. In all, there are over 150,000 U.S. troops in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Addresses U.N., Warns of Further Action Against Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts of Secretary of State James A. Baker III's speech Tuesday to the U.N. Security Council, which voted 14-1 to adopt an air embargo against Iraq:

``Our meeting here today is extraordinary. This marks only the third time in the 45-year history of this organization that all of the Permanent Five Foreign Ministers of the Security Council are meeting. Rarely has the U.N. been confronted by so blatant an act of aggresison as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Rarely has the international community been so united and determined that aggression should not succeed.''

``Acts have consequences. The stakes are clear. For international society to permit Iraq to overwhelm a small neighbor and to erase it from the map would send a disastrous message. The hopes of the world for a new, more peaceful post-Cold War era would be dimmed.''
``We cannot allow our hopes and aspirations to be trampled by a dictator's ambitions or his threats.''

``These penalties (sanctions) are beginning to take effect, and bellicose language from Baghdad cannot compensate for the perils of isolation. ... Iraq has been quarantined because its brutal actions have separated it from the community of nations. There can be no business as usual. In fact, there can be no economic exchanges with Iraq at all.''

``We agree to consider measures against any government that might attempt to evade the international quarantine. No temptation of minor gain should lead any government to complicity with Iraq's assault on international legality and decency.''

``The Council puts the government of Iraq on notice that its continued failure to comply could lead to further action, including action under Chapter 7 (which provides for U.N. military operations). The international community has made clear its desire to exhaust every peaceful possibility for resolving this matter in accordance with the principles of the U.N. Charter. ``But we are well aware that the Charter envisages the possibility of further individual and collective measures to defend against aggression and flagrant violations of international humanitarian law.''

DOC.HEAD: Financial Institutions Charged with Abusing Student Loans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 2nd graf by inserting dropped word `more' in `granting more loans...' Picks up 3rd graf prv `Our investigation...'
DOC.TEXT: Taxpayers have been cheated out of hundreds of millions of dollars in student-loan money by financial middlemen, a Senate panel was told Tuesday. Chief Investigator David Buckley told the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that some lenders, guarantee agencies, loan servicers, and the student loan secondary markets have abused the system by pocketing processing fees due the government and by granting more loans than the law allows. ``Our investigation, 3rd graf prv.

DOC.HEAD: Strike in Disputed Territory in Soviet Caucasus
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people went on a 24-hour strike Tuesday in the disputed Caucasus mountain region of Nagorno-Karabakh, demanding the restoration of rule by its Armenian majority, according to Soviet news reports. The protest was peaceful, Tass reported, with no interference by Soviet Interior Ministry troops that are enforcing the state of emergency in the enclave, which is inside the republic of Azerbaijan. In the past two years, more than 200 people have died in the dispute between the predominantly Christian republic of Armenia and neighboring Azerbaijan, which is predominantly Shiite Moslem, over control of Nagorno-Karabakh. The protesters expressed support for parliament deputies from Nagorno-Karabakh who are on a hunger strike to protest the dissolution of regional councils by the Soviets, according to Tass and the independent Interfax news agency. Interfax said thousands of people participated in unspecified acts of civil disobedience in Stepanakert, the enclave's administrative center, and other areas of Nagorno-Karabakh. Armenians claim President Mikhail Gorbachev has done little to protect them since the Soviet government's Special Administration Committee, which controlled Nagorno-Karabakh for 10 months, returned it to Azerbaijani rule in November. Azerbaijani authorities have been altering administrative boundaries in Nagorno-Karabakh and resettling Azerbaijani refugees there, the protesters claim. Protesters sent a telegram to Gorbachev on Tuesday that said concentrations of Azerbaijani militants were growing in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Throws Out Campaign Law
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday threw out campaign contribution limits imposed by California voters in 1988, saying they give an unfair advantage to incumbents. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton knocked out the limits created by Proposition 73 and also tossed out the proposition's ban on transfers of funds between candidates. The ruling sent a shock wave through California's political establishment, although it was uncertain what effect the ruling would have on the gubernatorial race between Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Pete Wilson. Both national political parties, concerned over the outcome of the governor's race because of reapportionment stemming from the 1990 census, have targeted the California governor's race as a top priority. If allowed to stand, the decision means candidates for governor, other statewide posts and, in some cases, local offices will have no contribution limits during the remaining six weeks of the election campaign, a spokeswoman for the Fair Political Practices Commission said. But FPPC chairman John Larson warned candidates not to start a ``fund-raising frenzy,'' saying the commission would ask Karlton to stay his rling. Proposition sponsors also said they would appeal the decision. Larson said that if the decision remains in place, the FPPC will enforce similar contribution limits in Proposition 68, but that measure applies only to legislative candidates. Voters approved both Propositions 68 and 73 in June 1988, but 73 took effect because it got more votes. However, a few minor provisions of 68 also became law. Proposition 73's limits, which, among other things, allow individuals to give no more than $1,000 to a particular candidate per fiscal year, apply to state and local candidates. The measure also allows political action committees to give up to $2,500 or $5,000 per candidate per fiscal year, depending on the size of the committee. Assembly Minority Leader Ross Johnson and state Sen. Quentin Kopp, I-San Francisco, two of the co-authors of Proposition 73, said they planned to ask the 9th Circuit Court of Appeal on Wednesday to overturn Karlton's ruling. ``The timing of this decision is most unfortunate,'' Johnson said. ``Closing arguments were heard April 19 and we finally get a ruling just six weeks before Election Day. There will be enormous confusion now as hundreds of candidates at all levels of government try to figure out what the new rules are.'' Proposition 73 was sponsored as an alternative to the reform-group-supported Proposition 68 and bases its contribution limits on fiscal years that start on July 1. Since state election campaigns typically span two calendar years, the measure creates three contribution periods: the first six months of the non-election year, the last six months of the non-election year and the first half of the election year, and the last half of the election year. That means that an individual contributor can give a candidate $3,000 over two calendar years. Critics say the fiscal-year format helps incumbents because they usually start raising funds earlier than challengers. Karlton agreed. Karlton issued the decision in response to a lawsuit filed by the state Democratic Party and labor unions, which said Proposition 73 unfairly limited constitutional rights to free speech and association.

DOC.HEAD: New York Merchants Help Beaten Canadian Tourists
DOC.TEXT: Two Canadians tourists beaten by a gang that mistook their help for an elderly woman as a mugging got some help from neighborhood merchants - including $100 in cash, auto repairs and a free lunch. Merchants in Bensonhurst, the predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood where black teen-ager Yusef Hawkins was killed by a mob in August 1989, took up a collection for the tourists Tuesday. ``With all the bad, with the Hawkins killing last year, I'm glad something good came out of the neighborhood, instead of something negative,'' said Vinny Pinello, owner of Reliable Auto Repair. Eric Plourde, 19, and Patrick Chartrand, 20, both of Quebec, were beaten with baseball bats and pipes Monday afternoon while assising an elderly woman who fell, police Detective Joseph McConville said. ``Apparently these kids thought these two guys were mugging the old lady,'' McConville said. The group numbered between 10 and 12 members, he said. The Canadian men were treated at Coney Island Hospital for bruises after the beating, and released, spokesman Daniel Armstrong said. Gang members also smashed their car's windshield and two other windows, police said. Pinello said he began organizing assistance after officers asked him for some plastic to cover the shattered windows. No arrests were made in the case, and authorities were searching for the youths and the woman, who left the scene before police arrived. Tourists have suffered notable crimes in New York this summer, with a Utah tourist stabbed to death while protecting his mother during a Manhattan subway mugging and a Soviet visitor slain by thieves who snatched his wife's purse. After learning that Plourde and Chartrand only had $25 between them, merchants ``got up $100 in maybe 90 seconds,'' Pinello said. ``I'm sorry we didn't give them more.'' While the money was being collected, a customer at the auto store bought the young men sandwiches. By late Tuesday, the car's smashed windows were fixed at no charge. ``They were so appreciative, when we handed them the money, they looked like they were going to cry,'' said Fred Alvaro, owner of Fre-Val Home Improvement, who added that he helped ``so that they don't get the impression that all New Yorkers are bad.'' ``These kids are like a pack of wild dogs, they follow the leader,'' Alvaro said of the gang that attacked the tourists, whom he described as ``nice kids who weren't looking to hurt a fly.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Throws Out Law Limiting Campaign Contributions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8 pvs, `Spokespersons for...upheld,' to CLARIFY that Wilson isn't committing himself to abide by invalidated limits if opponent doesn't. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Feinstein spokeswoman...' Corrects category code to `p' sted `a.' Stands also for AM-California-Campaign Funds, which moved as a0812.
DOC.TEXT: In a decision that could have a profound impact on the November governor's election, a federal judge Tuesday threw out campaign contribution limits imposed by California voters in 1988. The decision, if allowed to stand, means candidates for governor, other statewide posts and, in some cases, local offices will have no contribution limits during the remaining six weeks of the campaign, said a spokeswoman for the state Fair Political Practices Commission. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton said the limits give an unfair advantage to incumbents. Karlton also tossed out the a ban on transfers of funds between candidates that was imposed by the same ballot initiative. The ruling invalidated Proposition 73, which, among other things, limits individuals to a maximum of $1,000 in contributions to a particular candidate per fiscal year. The measure also limits political action committees donations of $2,500 or $5,000 per candidate per fiscal year, depending on the size of the committee. The ruling sent a shock wave through California's political establishment, although it was uncertain what effect the ruling would have on the gubernatorial race between Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Pete Wilson. Wilson, who had only token opposition in the June primary, raised $12.5 million through June and had $3.9 million in the bank as of July 1. Feinstein raised $8.1 million through June but had only $645,344 left over from her primary campaign against state Attorney General John Van de Kamp. Aides to both candidates claimed not to know how much they have raised since June. Wilson challenged Feinstein to join him in abiding by Proposition 73 if Karlton's ruling is upheld. But spokesman Bill Livingstone would not commit the candidate to following the measure if Feinstein doesn't follow suit. Feinstein spokeswoman DeeDee Myers said Feinstein hadn't decided what to do. She said that removal of the limits ``gives us a chance to close the gap a little,'' but she predicted Wilson would still raise more money. But John Larson, chairman of the Fair Politicial Practices Commissio, warned candidates against a ``fund-raising frenzy,'' saying the commission would ask Karlton to stay his ruling. The proposition sponsors also said they would appeal the decision. The decision was in a lawsuit filed by the state Democratic Party and labor unions, which said Proposition 73 unfairly limited constitutional rights to free speech and association. Proposition 73, which was sponsored by three legislators as an alternative to the reform-group-supported Proposition 68, bases its contribution limits on fiscal years that start on July 1. Since state election campaigns typically span two calendar years, the measure creates three contribution periods. That means that means an individual contributor can give a candidate $3,000 over two calendar years. In this election, for example, a candidate who began fund-raising early could collect up to the limit from a particular contributor for the period from January through June of 1989. Then the same person could again donate the limit for the fiscal year that ran from July 1989 through June 1990. And he could give again before the election, in the fiscal year that began July 1. Critics say the fiscal-year format helps incumbents because they usually start raising funds earlier than challengers. Karlton agreed. Voters approved both Propositions 68 and 73 in June 1988, but 73 took effect because it got more votes. However, a few minor provisions of 68 also became law, where they didn't conflict with Prop 73. Some provisions of the competing measure, Proposition 68, also took effect, including one that limits contributions in races for the state Legislature. If the court decision isn't suspended or reversed the political commission will enforce those limits, Larson said. Assembly Minority Leader Ross Johnson, R-Fullerton, and state Sen. Quentin Kopp, I-San Francisco, two of the co-authors of Proposition 73, said they planned to ask the 9th Circuit Court of Appeal on Wednesday to overturn Karlton's ruling. ``The timing of this decision is most unfortunate,'' Johnson said. ``There will be enormous confusion now as hundreds of candidates at all levels of government try to figure out what the new rules are.'' Former Gov. Jerry Brown, the chairman of the state Democratic Party, which was one of the plaintiffs in the case, said the decision ``strikes down one of the most pernicious campaign laws ever enacted and puts an end to the pervasive state censorship of grassroots activism imposed by Proposition 73.''

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Power Company Agrees to One-Year Franchise Extension
DOC.TEXT: Commonwealth Edison Co. agreed to a one-year extension of its contract Tuesday while the city investigates a recent series of power failures. The old contract expires Dec. 31, but city officials month halted negotiations for a new deal, saying it wanted to extend the existing apct while it examines whether Edison is dependable. ``While we had hoped to reach agreement on a new franchise before Dec. 31, an extension will preserve what we believe is already the best set of benefits held by any major city in the country,'' Edison Chairman James J. O'Connor said Tuesday in a news release. The extension of the 42-year-old contract calls for continued payment of Edison's municipal franchise fee, which is 4 percent of the company's gross revenues. The 1990 payment is estimated at $66 million, O'Connor said. Chicago Mayor Richard Daley was welcomed the extension agreement reached while the Illinois Commerce Commission and the city investigate recent power failures, Daley spokeswoman Carolyn Grisko said. Edison is trying to salvage its image after blackouts including one in late July that left 40,000 West Side customers without electricity for three days. Some small stores were looted during the outage. About a week later, another outage cut power to 25,000 customers. Four less severe power failures have hit the city and suburbs in recent days, affecting thousands of customers.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Orders Air Embargo on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new quotes, details of air embargo, Argentine warships leave for gulf. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,4, BEI2
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council ordered an air embargo of Iraq on Tuesday and warned of worse to come unless Iraq quits Kuwait. The vote was 14-1, with only Cuba opposed, and extended the powers of an earlier U.N. trade embargo. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III cautioned, ``Acts have consequences. . . . For international society to permit Iraq to overwhelm a small neighbor and to erase it from the map would send a disastrous message.'' Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Al-Anbari, who had been attending as an interested party, stalked out after the vote, saying ``boycotting a country by enforcing a naval embargo as well as an air embargo is an act of aggression, an act of war.'' He said Iraq has ``been practicing self-restraint because we know that if war were to break out, it would destroy everything in the region.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, who presided at the special council meeting, said war was an option, if not a desirable one, but ``I hope that peaceful ways will be found to find a way out.'' Earlier, Shevardnadze joined a world chorus of rage and indignation against Iraq, calling the lightning takeover of Kuwait an ``act of terrorism'' and warning of possible U.N. military action. Echoing a growing pessimism over the possibility of a diplomatic solution soon, Shevardnadze warned: ``A great war may break out in the gulf region any day, any moment.'' The painful economic impact of the invasion, which left Saddam Hussein's Iraq in control of 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, grew more apparent. Crude oil prices approached $40 a barrel, nearly double the price before the Aug. 2 blitzkrieg. Some U.S. analysts said Tuesday in New York that gas prices may exceed $2 a gallon if a shooting war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. They said the fallout will be widespread if oil prices should stay high for long, running up the cost of practically everything while slowing economic growth. The New York Stock Exchange has sunk to a 14-month low and gold has passed $400 an ounce. President Bush appealed on Tuesday for a ``generous response from the world community'' for countries hardest hit by the crisis. He spoke at the annual meeting in Washington of the International Monetary Fund. World Bank President Barber Conable on Tuesday outlined emergency plans to help resettle hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. The U.S. Defense Department meanwhile reported new buildups of Iraqi troops and armor in southern Iraq and Kuwait, within striking distance of Saudi Arabia and its vast oil fields. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said about 430,000 Iraqi soldiers now are in the area, up from 360,000 last week. He said Iraqi deployments still seemed to be ``essentially a defensive force,'' but could readily convert to offense. Saddam showed no sign of yielding. He said in a message to Americans broadcast Tuesday that Bush was sending Americans to a war more terrible than Vietnam. In a rambling, 75-minute address taped last week, Saddam warned that if Bush were to launch war against Iraq, ``It would not be up to him to end it.'' He repeatedly accused Bush and Kuwait's rulers of plotting to impoverish Iraq and steal its oil. ``Bush, ladies and gentlemen, is sending your sons to war for no purpose save fatal arrogance,'' the Iraqi president said. He spoke in Arabic, with English subtitles supplied by Iraqi authorities. Security Council Resolution 670 sks all states to prevent use of airspace by any passenger or cargo flight to or from Iraq or occupied Kuwait, except for approved mercy missions. It bans use of force, but calls for searches and detention of aircraft. It calls for halting Iraqi shipping and freezing Iraqi assets overseas. The air embargo was one more step to completely isolate Iraq. A naval force is currently enforcing the trade embargo. The council said it would consider ``serious action'' if Iraq continued to defy the will of the international community, hinting at a U.N. military operation. It said countries that evade the U.N. embargo against Iraq may themselves face secondary sanctions. The resolution was the ninth passed by the Security Council condemning Iraq over Kuwait. The session was unprecedented, with 13 foreign ministers attending from among the council's 15 member states. Syrian President Hafez Assad meanwhile ended his four-day visit to the Iranian capital, Tehran, having failed to persuade Iranian leaders not to send food and other essentials to Iraq. Sources close to the Syrian delegation said Tehran insisted that the embargo allows ``humanitarian shipments'' of food. Saddam has said he would rather go to war than let the U.N.-ordered embargo ``strangle'' his country. On Tuesday, Baghdad announced it would put Bush ``on trial'' for ``crimes against the peoples of the world,'' and it set a date - Oct. 15. Shevardnadze suggested the same should be done to Saddam. He told the General Assembly that people who take hostages, use torture, threaten nations with destruction and are ``guilty of particular ruthlessness in the use of force'' should be tried by an international tribunal for their ``crime against humanity.'' Saddam has threatened to destroy Israel, and has detained thousands of Westerners, moving some to strategic sites to serve as shields against potential Western attack. The Soviet foreign minister noted that the United Nations has the power to suppress acts of aggression. ``There is ample evidence that this right can be exercised,'' he said, adding that such a step should come only after peaceful, non-military options have been exhausted. Although the Soviets have not joined the U.S.-led multinational force amassing in the gulf, they have said they might be willing to participate in a U.N. military effort - provided they share command. In other developments Tuesday: -Saudi Arabia expelled 12 more diplomatic staff from Jordan's consulate and embassy Tuesday, and Jordan recalled its ambassador in protest, Jordan said. It said that left eight Jordanian diplomatic employees in Riyadh and Jiddah. Last week, the Saudis expelled 20 Jordanian diplomatic employees for activities ``incompatible with their status'' - a diplomatic euphemism for espionage. -Two Argentine warships left for the gulf on Tuesday to become the first Latin nation to help enforce the U.N. trade embargo on Iraq. Legislators complained that President Carlos Menem acted unconstitutionally in not getting Congress' consent. -The French Foreign Ministry said Iraqi soldiers have taken two new French nationals hostage in Kuwait and transported them to an unknown destination. The news came a day after French President Francois Mitterrand, opening the General Assembly, called Iraq a warlike state and expressed outrage over Iraqi raids on European embassy compounds in Kuwait. -U.S. military sources said the Pentagon was continuing to activate reserve forces for Operation Desert Shield, but that the total call-up was likely to fall well short of the 50,000 authorized by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. The Pentagon said call-ups of reserves from all services had reached 21,970.

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine Cartel Chief Charged in Presidential Candidate's Assassination
DOC.TEXT: A judge operating in secrecy has charged Pablo Escobar, leader of the Medellin drug cartel, with last year's assassination of a presidential candidate during a campaign rally, the court said Tuesday. Colombia's new president, Cesar Gaviria, has said Escobar would be extradited to the United States if captured. Escobar was charged with planning and ordering the murder of Luis Carlos Galan, cut down by automatic weapons fire as he prepared to deliver a speech in a poor Bogota neighborhood on Aug. 18, 1989. The killing provoked then-President Virgilio Barco to begin a crackdown on drug traffickers that developed into a bloody war with the cartel. The name of the judge ordering Escobar's arrest was kept secret lest he be murdered, according to a communique from Colombia's federal court system. In the last nine years, 228 judges and other court employees have been slain, mostly by drug traffickers who could not bribe or threaten them into silence. Escobar also has been charged in the March 1989 killing of leftist presidential candidate Bernardo Jaramillo and in the December 1987 slaying of Guillermo Cano, owner of the Bogota daily El Espectador. He also is wantedfor planning a car bomb explosion which killed 63 people last December in front of the secret police headquarters of Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez. Gaviria has said fewer extraditions will take place under his government, but prominent cartel leaders still would be charged in the United States. Colombia has major problems in prosecuting the powerful drug lords, who can easily pay off or threaten police, judges and jailers. Last week, Eduardo Rueda, an alleged triggerman in Galan's shooting, escaped from La Picota Prison in Bogota. The daily El Tiempo quoted investigators as saying Rueda paid more than $250,000 in bribes to walk out. In a speech Tuesday, Gaviria attacked the latest round of intimidation by drug traffickers - the kidnapping of seven Colombian journalists. ``Millions of Colombians are closing ranks to demand the safe return of these people,'' he told reporters and others who began a drive to free the reporters. Six of the journalists, including Diana Turbay de Uribe, daughter of former President Julio Cesar Turbay, disappeared on Aug. 30. Francisco Santos, 28, news editor of El Tiempo, was kidnapped last Wednesday. El Tiempo said it later received an anonymous phone call from a man claiming to speak for the Medellin cartel, who said its members want the government to grant them full pardons, as it has done with leftist guerrillas who surrender weapons. Gaviria has said there will be no negotiations with drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Issues Two Recalls Affecting 32,500 Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Tuesday recalled about 14,500 Aerostar minivans and about 18,000 L-Series heavy trucks for possible safety problems. The company said latches on optional second-row, right-hand captain's seats on 1989-90 Aerostars could fail, allowing the seat to tilt forward unexpectedly. Ford said it was unaware of accidents involving the latches. The company also said a valve in the air-brake systems of the heavy trucks could malfunction causing a loss of pressure in front-wheel brake assemblies. Should such a pressure loss occur, the company said, there should be warnings and automatic application of emergency brakes. There were no reports of brake failures stemming from the valve problem, Ford said. Owners will be notified by mail and repairs in both recalls would be performed free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti Sets Elections for Mid-December
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - After scrapping together funds and convincing politicians it is safe to campaign, Haiti's Electoral Council set Dec. 16 as the date for presidential and municipal elections, an official said Tuesday. The elections have been postponed several times. They were last set for Nov. 4, but the Electoral Council had to drop that date because the impoverished government couldn't provide the money to organize the voting. Last week, the Haitian government came up with $4 million. The government will get an additional $1.5 million through the U.N. Development Program and the U.S. government. West Germany and France have made pledges as well. Jean Casimir, who heads the Electoral Council, said the Canadian government confirmed paper to be used for ballots would arrive in Haiti the first week of November. Without Canada's contribution of the costly, imported paper, the election date could not be set, he said. Many leading politicians had refused until recent days to participate in any elections organized by interim President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, who was appointed in March. They claimed she was unable to control the corrupt and violence-prone military. But several prominent parties announced Monday they had decided to participate. Because of Haiti's weak democratic tradition, there did not appear to be a front-runner in the election. The president-elect will be sworn in Feb. 7, 1991, the fifth anniversary of the fall of the dictator, Jean Claude Duvalier. The Duvalier family ruled Haiti for almost three decades. In 1987, the last attempt at free elections collapsed when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters. Since its independence from France in 1804, Haiti has been ruled mainly by dictators.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Ground Some AV-8B Vertical Takeoff Jets
DOC.NOTE: EDs; SUBS 4th graf: ``The grounded,'' with three grafs bgng: ``Wagner said,'' to CORRECT that jets NOT based in Hawaii; subs headline to conform
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps has grounded four Harrier jet fighter-bombers similar to those sent to the Persian Gulf because of faulty sensors that stabilize the aircraft, the service said Tuesday. The vertical takeoff AV-8B planes were found to have defective ``rate sensor assemblies,'' a system which includes three gyroscopes and provides direction information for the jet, said Col. Stuart Wagner. ``It's not critical to flying the aircraft safely, but it's something we want to fix,'' Wagner said of the assemblies, similar to the power steering on a car. The rate sensor assemblies are wearing out faster than expected, he said. Wagner said the grounded Harriers were based at Kaneohe Bay Marine Corps Air Station in Hawaii. But Tuesday night, the Defense Department said no Harriers were based there. The Defense Department spokesman, Army Maj. Mike Dibble, said he was unable to determine immediately where the grounded planes were. The action has no effect on the Harriers deployed in Saudi Arabia as part of the U.S. military buildup against Iraq, Wagner said. The announcement on the grounding came as the House Government Operations subcommittee on legislation and national security again examined procurement and testing irregularities by Northrop Corp. involving the Harrier jet and advanced cruise missile. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 fraud charges and agreed to pay $17 million in fines, which according to the Justice Department is the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. The charges stemmed from Northrop's work on the Harrier and the nuclear-armed air-launched cruise missile. The Navy, which handles procurement for the Marine Corps, suspended Northrup from further contracts and recommended a suspension from all defense work. The Air Force, however, is buying B-2 stealth bombers made by Northrup. Testimony before the House panel Tuesday detailing the procurement and testing irregularities was similar to what the Justice Department told a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee in July. Witnesses Tuesday described how Northrop never performed life expectancy tests on the rate sensor assemblies. The assemblies were supposed to have undergone a vibration test at 32 times the acceleration imparted by gravity, but instead were tested at half that acceleration. They also were to have been operated continuously for 4,000 hours to determine life expectancy. ``We decided that it would cost too much to perform this test at an outside lab,'' Howard Hyde, a former chief engineer with Northrop who is serving a one-year sentence for falsifying tests on the Harrier jet, said of the vibration tests. No spare sensor assemblies are available, forcing the Marines to park the $22 million planes as problems arise. No other company produces the assemblies. The Marine Corps officer for the Harrier program told the panel that it has waived the suspension against Northrop to buy a package of spare rate sensor assemblies for $300,000. Col. James Hart said the service is working out a contract with another manufacturer that will likely cost $1 million. ``Who will supply the new rate sensor assembly components to the the Harriers back off the ground? The corporation that bilked us to begin with,'' complained Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the Government Operations subcommittee. ``It looks like business as usual for Northrop. It has a corner on the market and national security needs override all other considerations.'' The Marine Corps has nearly 200 Harriers, made by McDonnell-Douglas Corp. under license from a British manufacturer. The Harriers, needing no runway to take off, can be based in forest clearings and other unorthodox places to provide close support and air cover for Marine units. Their swiveling jet exhaust nozzles give them outsanding maneuverability in the air that enabled British pilots to dominate their Argentine opponents in the 1982 Falklands War.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers Get Surgery For Ear Complaints After Plane Loses Cabin Pressure
DOC.TEXT: Several dozen passengers were treated at hospitals for ear problems Tuesday after a jetliner lost cabin pressure over the Atlantic and had to return to Bangor International Airport, officials said. About 20 passengers underwent minor surgery to relieve pressure in their ears, said airport marketing director Bob Ziegelaar. Seventy-two of the 206 people aboard the Air Europe Boeing 757 received hospital treatment, he said. The flight, which originated in Orlando, Fla., and was bound for Newcastle, England, landed about 2:30 a.m. It had left Bangor around midnight Monday and lost cabin pressure about an hour later, Ziegelaar said. An emergency landing was not necessary and the passengers were never in serious danger, he said. The cause of the pressure loss was undetermined. All 206 passengers boarded an alternate flight Tuesday evening, said Dave Bellomy, an airport dispatcher.

DOC.HEAD: Indicted Lawmaker Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Indicted state Rep. Robert Kohn, who prosecutors said had worked undercover for the FBI in its investigation of vote-buying in the South Carolina Statehouse, resigned Tuesday. Kohn, 45, a Republican, is among ten state lawmakers indicted by a federal grand jury looking into Statehouse corruption. A representative since 1975, Kohn was suspended from his seat following his Aug. 24 indictment. His resignation takes effect at noon Wednesday. Two hours later, he is to appear before U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins in Charleston for a plea hearing. Kohn is charged with one count of conspiring to violate the federal Hobbs Act, which among other things outlaws bribery of officials. He faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted. Nine South Carolina lawmakers were indicted in an investigation of vote-selling related to a bill to let voters consider pari-mutuel betting. A tenth lawmaker and a registered lobbyist were indicted on drug charges unrelated to the vote-buying probe dubbed ``Operation Lost Trust.'' Three lawmakers have pleaded guilty and await sentencing. The grand jury charged that Kohn and another lawmaker met with lobbyist Ron Cobb and agreed to accept money for supporting the pari-mutuel bill and to get other lawmakers to support it too. Cobb was working undercover at the time. Prosecutors said Kohn also worked secretly for the FBI, in its case against former GOP Rep. Daniel Winstead. When Winstead pleaded guilty earlier this month, prosecutors showed a grainy videotape of Kohn giving him an envelope at a restaurant. Prosecutors said the envelope contained $1,000 given to Kohn by the FBI. Prosecutors also presented transcripts of a conversation between Kohn and Winstead that Kohn secretly recorded. In it, the lawmakers discuss the investigation and Winstead tells Kohn, ``Let it roll, and deny everything.''

DOC.HEAD: First Day in Miami, Woman Robbed of $275,000 in Cash, Jewels
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli woman's dream of resettling in Florida was snatched away by a robber who grabbed her purse with more than $275,000 in cash and jewels inside, officials said. Marie T. Spector, 58, of Tel Aviv was robbed Sunday morning and lost family heirlooms including diamond earrings, an opal necklace, pearls and a gold necklace, police said. ``She was screaming, she was crying, she was hysterical, she was sick, she needed Valium,'' said Mara Meir, who was with her friend when she was robbed. Mrs. Spector had planned to open a bank safe deposit box on Monday. The $273,700 in jewels and $1,300 in cash she was carrying weren't insured. Ms. Meir and Mrs. Spector were going to her hotel to meet her husband when the two heard footsteps from behind. Ms. Meir told police she threw her purse at a young man who charged her. Mrs. Spector tried to fend off the other mugger and was dragged along the sidewalk until he ripped her bag out of her grasp. The Spectors, who left Israel Saturday, hired Miami attorney Norman Funt to see how they might recover the loss. Funt said the couple had left Miami. ``Mrs. Spector was a little disenchanted with the welcome she received,'' Funt said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Votes Air Embargo against Iraq, Occupied Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Iraqi statement, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council voted 14-1 Tuesday to impose an air embargo against Iraq in an effort to force Iraqi occupying forces to quit Kuwait. Iraq's envoy called it ``an act of war.'' The council warned Baghdad it may take further punitive action and hinted at sanctions against nations that fail to observe U.N. measures against Iraq. Cuba cast the only vote opposing Resolution 670, which directs all states to bar use of airspace by any passenger or cargo flight to or from Iraq or occupied Kuwait, except for approved mercy missions. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Al-Anbari, who attended as an interested party, stalked out after the vote, saying, ``You know, boycotting a country by enforcing a naval embargo as well as an air embargo is an act of aggression, an act of war. ``But up to now we have been practicing self-restraint because we know that if war were to break out, it would destroy everything in the region.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, who presided, said in response that ``even if this resolution is not observed, there are certain other things that can be done short of war, because this is not yet a full blockade of Iraq.'' Shevardnadze said war ``is not a desirable option, but it is one of the options contained in the U.N. Charter. Anyway, I hope that peaceful ways will be found to find a way out.'' He spoke in Russian through a translator. Tuesday marked the ninth time the Security Council has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and demanded immediate withdrawal. The resolution prohibits use of force, but calls for searches and detention of aircraft; for halting Iraqi shipping, and freezing Iraqi assets overseas. The council warned it would consider ``serious action'' if Iraq continued to flout international will, hinting at a U.N. military operation. It said countries that evade the U.N. embargo against Iraq may themselves face secondary sanctions. At a breakfast meeting with journalists Tuesday, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd remarked, ``I don't see much in the way of next steps except against sanctions-busters.'' The presence of 13 foreign ministers among the council's 15 member states underscored the determination of the international community to compel Iraq to quit Kuwait. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said it was the first time in the United Nations' 45-year history so many foreign ministers attended a meeting to vote on a substantive issue. On only three previous occasions have the foreign ministers of all five permanent members - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, China and France - attended a Security Council meeting. ``Rarely has the international community been so united and determined that aggression should not succeed,'' U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told the council. ``Iraq has been quarantined because its brutal actions have separated it from the community of nations. There can be no business as usual. In fact, there can be no economic exchanges with Iraq at all.'' The Security Council earlier adopted a trade embargo against Iraq that includes a ban on air traffic. The new resolution makes the air embargo explicit and gives states the power to enforce it. Cuba has said it is against any sanctions on Iraq. Earlier resolutions authorized ships to implement a maritime embargo and to stop and search vessels that may be violating trade sanctions. Other resolutions repudiated the annexation of Kuwait, demanded the release of hostages and condemned Iraqi raids on foreign missions in Kuwait. Baker warned, ``Each day that Iraqi officials flout norms of elementary decency makes it that much more difficult for Iraq to resume its place in the international community.'' The resolution did not spell out the mechanics of implementation. Diplomats said lawyers would be studying the text. Baker said the council puts Iraq on notice that continued failure to obey the international community could lead to further action under Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which provides for U.N. military intervention. Shevardnadze said earlier: ``This (Iraqi invasion) is a major affront to mankind. . . . The United Nations has the power to suppress acts of aggression. There is ample evidence that this right can be exercised. It will be, if the illegal occupation of Kuwait continues.'' The foreign ministers of all but Cuba and the Ivory Coast attended. Beside the five permanent members with veto power, the council includes Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Chancellor to Propose Condom Distribution in High Schools
DOC.TEXT: The schools chancellor is preparing a plan to distribute condoms to students through health clinics in 20 junior high and high schools, a city official said Tuesday. ``We see this as an effective preventive measure for pregnancy and in slowing the spread of AIDS,'' said Carmen Rivera, director of the mayor's office of health policy. ``We see both these things as in crisis proportions in certain communities.'' A spokesman for Chancellor Joseph Fernandez said the plan was still being formed. But Ms. Rivera said the condoms would be distributed through the 20 clinics, which also offer examinations and other services to tens of thousands of students. The school system briefly distributed condoms through the clinics in 1986, but stopped the program because of opposition from several Board of Education members. The school clinics referred students seeking contraceptives to private physicians and other clinics. Ms. Rivera said most of the seven school board members now support the plan. James Vlasto, the chancellor's spokesman, said Fernandez had asked the city health commissioner, Dr. Woodrow Myers, to speak to the board Wednesday on health issues of young people. ``The proposal has to come from the chancellor, but it has to be a cooperative effort,'' Vlasto said.

DOC.HEAD: National Guardsman Father To Join Soldier Son In Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: National Guardsman Felipe Cardenas II soon will arrive in the Saudi Arabian desert, and one of his first orders of businesss will be to find a familiar face - his son. Felipe's 19-year-old son, Phillip Cardenas III, has been stationed in the desert for three weeks with the Army's 101st Airborne Division. Cardenas, 41, a National Guardman for 17 years and a Vietnam War veteran, said he learned this week that volunteers from his unit will soon be leaving for the Middle East. The elder Cardenas went to Vietnam at age 18. He now serves as a staff sergeant in the Longmont tank unit of the Army National Guard. His son, an infantryman, has been in the Army a little more than a year. Like his father, he shipped out to face possible combat while still a teen-ager. ``Of course I worry about him, but I know that the Army prepares people, just like theydid me,'' Cardenas said. He hopes he can find his son in Saudi Arabia, although there are thousands of other U.S. service men and women stationed there in reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in early August. ``I know if we go to battle, I'll probably be in front of him,'' he said. ``The tanks will cross the front line ahead of the infantry.''

DOC.HEAD: One Man's Trash ...
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Cantara's trash could be a treasure to anyone who finds the $17,000 Tiffany lampshade he accidentally threw away. The 41-year-old antique dealer lost the amber, green and white glass shade on Sept. 16 after a street fair in the Manhasset railroad station on Long Island. Nassau County police Detective Arthur Meininger said Cantara put a box he thought was filled with paper next to a trash bin as he was cleaning up. Only after he had gone home to the New York City borough of Queens did he realize the lampshade was in the box. He reported the lampshade missing Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Claims Brutality by Los Angeles Sheriff's Department
DOC.TEXT: A civil rights lawsuit was filed Tuesday against the Sheriff's Department on behalf of 75 people who allegedly were victims of brutality or racial harassment by deputies at one sheriff's station. The suit claims more than 40 incidents, including two killings, as well as beatings, chokings and use of racial epithets, said Patrick Patterson of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, a nonprofit civil rights law firm. All but one incident occurred within a three-month period this year and all but two involved either a black or Hispanic person, Patterson said. The Sheriff's Information Bureau declined to respond on behalf of Sheriff Sherman Block. The U.S. District Court suit named the Sheriff's Department, Block, Los Angeles County, the city of Lynwood, where the station is located, sheriff's Capt. Bert Cueva, the commander of the Lynwood station, state Attorney General John Van de Kamp and District Attorney Ira Reiner. The suit seeks damages for the plaintiffs but doesn't state a sum. ``The point of this lawsuit is to recompense the individual plaintiffs for their injuries and damages, but each of them is aware the point is also to change a very bad situation,'' said George V. Denny III, the lead attorney. The NAACP Legal Defense Fund is unaffiliated with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. It retains the initials because of an affiliation that ended in the 1950s. The Lynwood station is one of 17 stations which serve unincorporated areas of Los Angeles County or cities which contract with the Sheriff's Department for police services. The lawsuit seeks a permanent injunction against the defendants to stop the alleged abuses, and appointment of a receiver or special master for the Lynwood station. The city of Lynwood, 10 miles south of Los Angeles, has about 54,000 citizens. The city is about 43 percent Hispanic, 34 percent black and 19 percent white. One allegation of the lawsuit was that a motorist, William Leonard, was ordered out of his car on Feb. 10 by deputies who thought he was armed and then shot more than 30 times by 12 or more deputies standing in a half-circle around him as he tried to kneel down with his hands behind his head. Another incident included in the lawsuit occurred the next day, Feb. 11. Lloyd Polk purportedly fled from two deputies because of outstanding warrants for minor infractions. When he was caught, deputies allegedly beat him with batons, kicked him for 10 minutes and broke both his arms. He was then arrested for assaulting a deputy with a board.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: restores embargoed slug to fuel economy story
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk's official visit to Washington is stirring protests from anti-apartheid activists, but some black members of Congress are joining colleagues to meet with him today. ``Our view is that (de Klerk) has not earned a trip to the Oval Office,'' Randall Robinson, head of the TransAfrica group that has led U.S. protests against apartheid, said Monday. ``President Bush has made a large mistake and has offended freedom-loving people around the world and in the United States by becoming the first president since apartheid was codified in 1948 to invite into the Oval Office the head of a country that practices repression in an unprecedented way,'' Robinson said. Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, said the 24-member group canceled its plans to meet with de Klerk out of concern the session would be misinterpreted and could lend symbolic support to the apartheid regime. Dellums joined Robinson and other activists outside the White House gates to protest Bush's meeting with de Klerk on Monday. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush says he's ``not going to yield one inch'' to Saddam Hussein and won't be distracted by the Iraqi leader's efforts to link the Persian Gulf crisis with the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Bush said he appreciates concerns of U.S. partners in the region over economic hardships, food shortages and the continuing Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But he told a group of Arab-American business leaders at the White House on Monday there will be ``no, no, no negotiation'' with Iraq until it fully withdraws from Kuwait. Bush encountered some sharp questioning on Monday after he finished prepared remarks to about 150 representatives of Arab-American groups - including one from a participant who told him that ``as Moslems, we object to Saudi Arabia inviting the foreign troops to our land.'' ---=
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EMBARGOED for release noon EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Automakers are showing little or no gain in fuel economy for the fifth straight year, with 1991 model cars having on average as much thirst at the gas pumps as they did in 1987, the government reported today. The Environmental Protection Agency released the new fuel economy figures as the Senate considered legislation that would require sharp improvements in automobile fuel efficiency over the next decade. According to the EPA's annual fuel economy statistics covering about 1,000 cars, the 1991 models - both domestics and imports - show an overall average of 28.1 miles per gallon, slightly better than last year and identical to the fleet average in 1987. While the most miserly cars such as the minicompact Geo Metro attain more than 50 mpg, more than half of the cars on the list achieved no better than 22 mpg. The increasingly popular passenger vans and specialty vehicles could on average do no better than the high teens. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Champions of a source of clean and abundant energy blew into town today, arguing that America could live contentedly without any country's oil if it only would harness the wind. The American Wind Energy Association brought together 300 engineers, consultants, manufacturers, scientists - and visionaries - to discuss the possibilities of using wind power to produce a substantial percentage of the nation's electricity. Today the wind generates only a trifling fraction of the nation's power. More than 15,000 wind turbines are in commercial use in California, the world's pioneer in wind-generated electricity. ---= BALTIMORE (AP) - Using newly released Soviet documents on 400,000 of Hitler's victims, a new Red Cross clearinghouse is offering to help people track the fates of loved ones sent to labor or death camps by the Nazis. The center opened here Monday to process a flood of expected requests for access to the records in West Germany that the Soviets began releasing last year. Soviet soldiers recovered the documents when the camps were liberated at the close of World War II. Emmy Hubert Mogilensky, the daughter of Holocaust victims, said at the opening of the Holocaust and War Victims Tracing and Information Center that she sympathizes with relatives who still don't know the fate of loved ones. The 67-year-old woman said she grieved with her brother when the Red Cross sent them a message in 1946 saying their parents died in a Nazi concentration camp. As time passed, she said the letter became a ``comfort, a closure.''

DOC.HEAD: Uprising Through a Soldier's Binoculars
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli soldier stares through binoculars to penetrate the privacy of a Palestinian home. He sees laundry billowing in the breeze, falls secretly in love with a young Palestinian woman and witnesses a tragic explosion. In the scenes from the new movie ``Lookout,'' the soldier is largely passive. Director Dina Zvi Riklis says her intent was to shake Israelis out of their complacency about the 31-month Palestinian uprising. The film, the latest in a series of Israeli movies on the Palestinian conflict, won the Golden Dove Award as the best short film at this summer's Jerusalem film festival. It starts with an anonymous soldier in a lookout post above a neighborhood in the occupied Gaza Strip. He twists a radio's dial to the station whose Hebrew news and chatter, along with American and Israeli rock music, will be almost the only sound for the film's 28 minutes. Riklis' camera shows the life of a Palestinian family through the eyes of the brown-haired reservist in his late 20s. He sees a Palestinian father builds a pigeon coop atop his roof, and his son sets free the birds. On the street, two soldiers confiscate a soccer ball from Palestinian boys. As the soldier looks down on the dusty streets in Gaza, the radio deejay brightly announces, ``A day on the Mediterranean. We love the weather here.'' The soldier's glance is drawn across the street to an old Arab house built of stones with arched windows. A 7-year-old boy lives there and his teen-age sister, innocent and stunningly beautiful. The girl knows she is being watched and seductively lingers near her window. In his only descent from the lookout post, the soldier walks by the house and encounters the girl. They stare into each other's eyes but do not speak. When the girl marries a Palestinian activist, she changes. Her dark, lush hair is covered by a scarf in Moslem fashion. The husband closes the bedroom window shutters, blocking the soldier's view. In the living room, the family watches a television news report showing troops savagely beating Arabs. A youth unfurls a Palestinian flag. The soldiers sees the family's life, but his only line in the movie, ``I didn't see anything,'' comes as troops raid the house and arrest the woman's father. In the gripping climax, the woman's husband sends her brother to deliver a package to the father as he returns from a military lockup. An army patrol appears, and the boy hurriedly tosses aside the package. It explodes. The boy dies before his father's eyes. Now the lookout's passivity ends. He stares at the boy's limp body, raises his rifle and kills the young husband. In an eerie epilogue, the Palestinian woman paces her porch months later singing to her newborn child, still watched by a lookout. But the reservist is gone. A different, wide-eyed soldier gazes on. For Israelis, Riklis' film presents the unfamiliar world of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip juxtaposed with the familiar chatter of an Israeli radio show. ``Radio is almost the second voice of the nation. It is still not a medium of entertainment here, but taken very seriously,'' said deejay Dori Ben-Zeev, whose show was on the soundtrack. ``What the soldier sees is a story,'' Riklis said. ``What he hears on the radio is reality. I wanted to take a difficult situation and hit the audience with our indifference. The events (in the territories) are the same, only we get used to hearing them and they don't phase us anymore.'' The film is more a mix of documentary with drama than two recent Israeli films that focus on relations with Palestinians. ``Green Fields,'' winner of the feature-film award at the 1989 Jerusalem festival, follows an Israeli family on a destructive journey in the West Bank. ``One of Ours,'' Israel's entry in this year's Academy Awards, is about the slaying of a Palestinian prisoner. The stars of ``Lookout'' are both young Israelis, Uri Ram-Klausner plays the soldier and Esti Yerushalmi is the Palestinian girl. The supporting cast is made up of Israeli Arabs from Jaffa, where the film was shot. Riklis got the idea for the film more than two years ago when the Palestinian uprising was just starting, but it took time to raise the money for the film. ``Unfortunately,'' she said, ``the issue has remained relevant.''

DOC.HEAD: Steve Allen Brings the Golden Age of TV to HA! The TV Comedy Channel
DOC.TEXT: Thanks to Steve Allen, an entire generation soon will learn that the idea of hot, young comedians doing live, hip, sketch comedy on a TV variety show is older than NBC's ``Saturday Night Live.'' At last, another generation can wonder whether there's a fern in its creel. On Oct. 1, Ha! The TV Comedy Network, debuts the first of 100 half-hours from ``The Steve Allen Show,'' a live, weekly variety show that ran head-to-head against ``The Ed Sullivan Show'' on Sunday nights from 1956 to 1959. Elvis Presley made his TV debut on the Allen show, but the program was known more for its daft, inspired comedy by a troupe of brilliant comics that included Don Knotts, Louis Nye, Tom Poston, Pat Harrington and Allen himself. ``We all had a kind of vibration of mutual craziness and creativity that first of all made our work pleasurable and, secondly, very effective,'' Allen said. The show was a jumping-off point for pop culture. Allen's wordplay with the band (``Smock! Smock! Smock!'') and the cast's doubletalk (``How's your fern?'') on Sunday night would echo in schools and businesses on Monday. For the record, Allen said, he does not have a fern in his creel. ``Well, I had it removed several years ago,'' Allen said, ``but it didn't hurt much.'' Barump-bump! ``When the Sunday show started, there were just three of us writing it: Stan Burns, Herb Sargent and myself,'' Allen said. ``Today, a show like that would have literally 22 or 23 writers. ``In four or five days, we were putting together each week something that was literally on the level of a Broadway musical comedy revue,'' he said. ``And yet we were so young and energetic and having such great fun, we never even thought to complain about it. ``Believe it or not, we were having such fun with it, we never looked upon it as a burden. It was hard work, oh yeah, but we loved it.'' Allen, 67, is the author of 35 books - three of them coming out this year - and he's still one of America's most prolific popular music composers. The Ha! shows came from his own collection. ``I was saving them for my great-grandchildren, should they ever be curious as to what I did,'' he said, ``but a combination of economic and cultural factors has created a vacuum, a market, for the good comedy of that 1950 period.'' The underlying sociological fact, Allen said, is that today's generation is the first in human history to have been exposed to comedy since birth. Children are ``literally hearing group laughter and the verbal cues that occasion it as part of their early exposure to human language of any sort,'' he said. ``I think this must have something to do with the fact that when they get to be 5 and 6 and a little more discriminating, they all expect comedy.'' In an essay Allen wrote back in the '50s for The Atlantic Monthly, he remembers observing that there were only 50 comedians in show business. ``Just think: The whole funny business . . . was being taken care of by a little group that you could have fit on a school bus,'' he said. ``Now we have over 2,000. That's an explosive, mushrooming growth. ``Many of today's comedy performers are funnier than the old-timers - no names of the old-timers - but that is not the problem. What is highly objectionable now . . . is the degree to which wit, which was once characteristic of American comedy, is being replaced by shock vulgarity.'' Vulgarity is creeping into TV comedy as well, Allen said. Viewers, he said, should try to induce a sense of guilt or shame in television executives who either are permitting or demanding shock-vulgar TV shows. ``Even if it turned out that those who say `Hey, don't knock it, it's the way to get ratings' were right, they still should be discouraged,'' Allen said. ``Somebody should still say to them, `Does the condition of the national consciousness mean nothing to you? Is it all dollars and cents?' '' --- Elsewhere in television ... PBS ON HOME VIDEO DEPT.: There's a new label showing up in your local video store Wednesday. Major retailers will be offering the PBS Home Video label, featuring programs from ``Nature,'' ``This Old House,'' ``A Walk Through the 20th Century with Bill Moyers,'' ``The Frugal Gourmet'' and other shows from public TV. A ``starter kit'' of 12 titles is due for release Wednesday, and a second series of programs will be available in December, priced at $19.95 each. The PBS Home Video label is a joint venture with Pacific Arts Video, founded by producer-musician Mike Nesmith in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: A Woman's Perspective: Reporting in Male-Dominated Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Women reporters covering the U.S. military buildup in male-dominated Saudi Arabia exulted when the invitation came to join female soldiers in their exercise classes. Exclusive! We gloated. But the chance to swim and sweat with the U.S. women in uniform nearly backfired when the three reporters - myself included - walked through the front door of the $80 million gymnasium at a Saudi air base. Several Saudi custodians, all men, leapt up and followed us to the registration desk, complaining loudly that we had violated custom by using the front entrance. Women, they said, must enter through the rear door. Our timing, it appeared, couldn't have been worse: we had committed this faux pas on a Friday - Islam's holy day - during Moslem prayer time. The Saudis were not the only ones who were annoyed. `You nearly ruined it for all of us,'' one angry Air Force nurse told the sheepish reporters. ``They almost kicked us out.'' The military women had fought hard for the privilege of using the gym three times a week, and they dreaded the idea of losing it. The culture clash was an example of the hidden challenges that American women encountered in Saudi Arabia, a country where females don't vote, don't drive, don't go out in public without covering their faces and heads with veils, don't socialize in meeting places and rarely hold jobs that bring them in contact with the general public. Most Saudi women seem to accept the social structure that is based on the laws of Islam. They say they are put on a pedestal in their homes and treated generously by their men. The female reporters - writers, television and radio correspondents, photographers and television camera crews - have been treated fairly by both Saudi and American officials in terms of access to events and opportunities to cover the U.S.-led military deployment. We have slept on cots in the desert with the 82nd Airborne out of Fort Bragg, N.C. We have visited Egyptian paratroopers near the Saudi-Kuwaiti border; interviewed the powerful Saudi petroleum minister; and toured the strategic petroleum refinery at Ras Tanura. In deference to Saudi custom, we cover our arms, wear longer skirts and keep bare skin to a minimum. But none of us wear the black cloaks known as abayas or head coverings. The heat argues against wearing stockings. We act generally as we do in the United States: eating in restaurants, sipping coffee in the hotel lobbies. But we remain oddities on the social scene, the only women attending an Arabian nights dinner under a big tent hosted by Saudi prince, for example. We were warned about the muttawa, the so-called religious police who enforce the Islamic dress code and insist conservative standards are upheld. But an informal survey indicated none of the reporters has been accosted by the muttawa, who have the power to make arrests. On the streets or in the souks (markets), our small cadre of female reporters has grown accustomed to sares from curious Saudis, but the incredulous looks did not interfere with work. The major complaint - and the biggest frustration - is the ban on driving. We must hire taxis, drivers or rely on male colleagues to ferry us around, an expensive inconvenience in a country with a modern system of interstate highways. The U.S. Embassy also advised women not to sit next to a man to whom she was not married. In one case, I drove to a remote post on the Saudi-Kuwaiti border with a male colleague, 300 miles from the coastal city of Dhahran, to meet with the governor of the province. The trip would have been impossible without a male escort. Air travel was potentially a problem because Saudi custom dictates women must be accompanied by a male relative. Expatriate women have to obtain a letter approving their travel from their sponsoring company. Airports have check-in lines designated for ``males'' and ``families.'' Saudi officials seemed to ignore the rules for the foreign reporters. I was never asked about my marital status, for instance, when I flew to Riyadh, the Saudi capital, in the company of an American male reporter. Female reporters benefit from the famed Saudi hospitality and generosity. When one reporter mentioned she had lost a contact lens, her host insisted on having his driver take her the next day to the clinic for a replacement. At Prince Mohammed Bin Fahd's daily Majlis - a combination of a town meeting and a magistrate's court - Saudi citizens ask the governor of the Eastern Province to resolve problems ranging from land disputes to homelessness. After meeting the prince, I jokingly told himII had some problems he could solve. Pressed on what theywere, I assured him I was only kidding. That night, I received a call from the prince's worried press officer. ``You mentioned you had some problems and the prince wanted to know if there was anything he could do,'' the press officer said. ``A car to take you shopping? Some interviews? Anything?'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Joan Mower, a Washington reporter for The Associated Press, reported from Saudi Arabia for four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Islamics in Algeria Dominate Arab Country's Rush to Democracy
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: This capital now boils with political activity as Algeria undertakes an Arab-style transition toward democracy. One question dominates: will free elections in this North African country replace a Marxist-style dictatorship with an Islamic one? The potent brew of politics and religion bubbles to life each evening in the Casbah, where bearded young men sip mint tea and dissect democracy and the Koran in a capital long derided as ``Moscow on the Med.'' ``Vive FIS'' (``Long Live The Islamic Salvation Front'') reads the graffiti on the Ketchaoua mosque, a bastion of Algeria's most potent political movement. ``This is a Moslem country,'' said Ali Hamidouche, 32. ``It's only natural that people would want a Moslem government.'' The 28 political parties and lively free press born since constitutional rforms in 1989 contrast sharply with an Arab world ruled by monarchs, dictators and one-party states. But vows by Islamic councils elected last June to impose Koranic law fuel fears that the democratic experiment may be short. ``If the FIS wins, we're dead,'' a leading women's rights activist said. The Islamic Salvation Front took control of more than half the country's municipal and regional councils June 12 in Algeria's first free elections since independence from France in 1962. The verdict repudiated the ruling National Liberation Front (FLN) and its 28-year monopoly on power. But local councils hold little power. The fundamentalists cannot effect changes while the FLN holds all seats in the National Assembly. Their complaints forced President Chadli Bendjedid to move legislative elections ahead a year to next spring. ``No matter who wins, the first success of these elections will be stability and legitimacy for the National Assembly,'' FIS leader Abassi Madani said in a recent newspaper interview. The 59-year-old philosophy professor presents the moderate face of a movement encompassing classical scholars and pro-Iranian radicals. His alter ego is Ali Belhadj, 31, whose fiery speeches attract thousands. He blames ``infidels'' - France chief among them - for Algeria's woes. For the young men outside the Ketchaoua mosque, the FIS heralds an end to the Soviet-inspired system the National Liberation Front imposed on Algeria, one of the continent's largest countries and situated on the Mediterranean. The fundamentalists' message is clear: the old regime was corrupt. It brought poverty and unemployment. An Islamic regime will stop corruption and, thereby, social problems. The FIS vows to end to secular practices that let men and women mingle at school and work. ``For us, secularism means liberty from God,'' Hamidouche said with a grimace. Ranged against the fundamentalists are dozens of political groupings, but only a handful with significant support. The FLN remains the best organized. Thousands of its adherents run the public sector to which most Algerians owe their livelihood. But the FLN managed only to win a quarter of the June vote. ``They'll be lucky to keep 25 percent next time,'' a Western diplomat said. ``People are fed up, and they've thrown up no young, charismatic leader.'' The oppostion includes the liberal Rally for Culture and Democracy, the centrist Front for Socialist Forces and the populist Movement for Democracy in Algeria. The Rally received a boost when the other two parties boycotted the June voting, claiming the FLN would rig the results. Their leaders are heroes of the war for independence - Berber chief Hocine Ait Ahmed and Algeria's first president, Ahmed Ben Bella. Ben Bella, 73, is the man Algerians are watching. He hopes to weld a ``democratic consensus'' to lead the country out of its economic ills. Ben Bella's stature is unrivaled by any living Algerian. He planned the 1954 uprising against France and ruled three years after independence until toppled in a military coup. Half his life has been spent in exile or prison. He currently lives in Geneva though a return to Algiers is considered imminent. ``They never broke him,'' said Hocine Guermouche, spokesman for the Movement for Democracy in Algeria. ``You've seen Mandela. He spent 27 years in prison and never lost his spirit. Ben Bella has done more ... he won the war.'' But he also gave Algeria ills it is only now shaking off: secret police, a single-party system, a Marxist economy. Whoever wins next year's elections will struggle to revive the sagging economy. In October 1988, thousands of Algerians rioted over living standards that plummeted along with prices for the country's chief export, oil. Scores of people, including many fundamentalists, died when the army crushed the uprising. The deaths robbed the FLN of popular legitimacy. Bendjedid, whose term expires in 1993, distanced the government from the FLN and drafted last year's constitutional reforms. He appointed technocrats to impose market economics. No party seems likely to meddle with the privatization program. But the pace of economic change remains slow. Unemployment officially stands at 25 percent. Families of 12 often live in two-room apartments. The government estimates 800,000 new dwellings are needed. Long lines form at shops often empty of basic foodstuffs. Jobless young men survive by hawking black-market cigarettes. Strikes proliferate. As the meuzzin at Ketchaoua mosque called the faithful to prayer, one young man said lots of political parties are fine, as long as they adhere to Islam. ``If the people vote for the FIS, fine. If they vote for ... some other party and they win, that's good, too,'' said Boumari Nacer Edde, a Casbah candy seller. ``The important thing is that there's democracy. We want democracy.''
