DOC.TEXT: With the dangers and failures of urban public schools chronicled almost daily in the news, why would someone choose to teach? This fourth part of the series, ``City Faces, City Fears,'' follows one teacher through her tumultous day for the answer. ---

It was 11:30 a.m. when rude laughter and the whoosh of rushingwater sundered Deborah Terrell's algebra lesson. The odds against the lesson already were high enough for Ms. Terrell and her 19 eighth-graders at Burnet Street Elementary School, a magnet school where 200 of 500 children are homeless. This day, like most Ms. Terrell has spent here for the last decade, would be a melange of frustration, fatigue, self-doubt and, perhaps, a small victory or two. But as she spoke of equations, a former student in a prankish mood gleefully sprayed the glass in her classroom door with jets from the hallway fire extinguishers. ``See that?'' she said, pointing angrily to the truant. ``This is fun? What kind of life is that?'' Later that day, as if sent to restore her faith, a second visitor dropped in: Tawana Woolridge, a prim, polite 12th-grader at Newark's tough Central High whom Ms. Terrell had taught five years earlier. ``She was my favorite teacher,'' Tawana said. ``She wasn't too strict, but she didn't let you get away with anything, either.'' ``When one kid like that comes back and is making it, that's what makes it all worthwhile,'' said the teacher. --- 3 p.m. at last. Most of the students leaving Room 303 headed for Baxter Terrace or other downtown Newark housing projects. Three caught buses for homeless shelters at the Lincoln or Carlton Hotels. Ms. Terrell slumped back in her chair, exhausted. She hadn't always wanted to be a teacher. She studied psychology at Rutgers University but quickly lost her taste for it after an internship at a mental health center: ``Too depressing.'' ``When I went to school, everyone wanted to be a teacher. I came here to Burnet to do my student teaching. The seventh-grade teacher left one day, and the principal just gave me her class. The rest is history.'' At age 36, her chosen career now earns her about $33,000 a year. ``I don't see myself here for another 10 years. But I guess I wonder: if I leave, who's going to be here for these kids?'' Later, back home in her neat, wood-frame house on a tough-looking downtown Newark street, she'd make sure her sons Malcolm, 8, and Toussaint, 9, buckled down to homework, as her own mother once had for her. But now, as the last pupil straggled out, she needed to decompress. ``I have to wind down before I can see my kids,'' she said. ``If I don't take half an hour to wind down, I might take things out on them.'' After dinner, homework awaited - grading neatly bound projects her students had prepared on the evils of drugs to mark National Drug Awareness Month. Then she planned to phone parents to exhort them to attend open school night. She wondered aloud: ``Am I just speaking to the air? Did anyone learn anything today?'' She thought. ``Well, I know Murad learned something.'' Murad, a bright, cocky, reed-thin boy, is quick with excuses and short on study habits. Ms. Terrell had forced him to sit in a desk alongside hers, a spot known in her class as ``Out of Society.'' But today Murad actually had taken notes in class and used them to solve a math problem. A small victory. And Ronald. A big day for him, too. Quiet, withdrawn, homeless for the last year, Ronald had stood up for the first time and given an oral presentation. The class had applauded. Ronald had smiled shyly. Another victory. Victories come hard at Burnet Street, designated four years ago a magnet school for homeless children in kindergarten through eighth-grade. Only last year did the board of education add staff and resources to help the school accommodate this most troubled population. Teachers say they have yet to get any formal training on how to deal with them. ``Kids wre sleeping on desks, had to meet bus schedules, had to make stops at the grocery stores,'' Ms. Terrell said. Average daily attendance at Burnet Street is just 87.6 percent; the national average is more than 92 percent. Twenty percent at Burnet need special help with basic skills, and 15 percent have been held back a grade or more. Only 5 percent of parents participate in school activities, according to New Jersey state statistics. For Ms. Terrell, teaching is a daily gantlet of delays, interruptions, excuses. The PA system squawks messages. The bell rings every 45 minutes. In the space of a morning, the attendance teacher knocks on the door to take roll. Four Hispanic students get pulled out of class for special English classes. Eight others are summoned for remedial classes to boost low English and math test scores. Still another group goes for computer instruction. In the afternoon, Ms. Terrell's homeless students are called away early to catch buses to shelters. And then there are the excuses. A kid tells her she didn't do her homework because ``I left the book in school, OK?'' At that, Ms. Terrell's mouth twists upward in a streetwise curl that says without words: You think I haven't heard that nonsense a thousand times before? You think you're kidding me? I was raised in the same streets you were. ``No,'' she finally says. ``That's not OK. You know how I feel about excuses and that's not even a good one. And get rid of the gum!'' She has a way of mixing humor, affection and discipline. On her desk is a small sign: ``U toucha My Desk, I breaka U face!'' Sometimes she'll say with a hint of a smile: ``You know how un-rational I am.'' How do the kids feel about her? Defiant. Yet dependent. She sometimes invites her students to write what they think, without signing their papers. They write her things they wouldn't tell their parents: about drugs, AIDS, their neighborhoods, being homeless. --- Her kids say Ms. Terrell sometimes gets teary during her ``life lectures,'' when she speaks about what she wants for them, why she's there. One such talk comes minutes after the class's standardized state test scores arrive. The 7th grade scores, the ones her kids took the spring before, show only 28 percent testing above average in math - the lowest passing rate in the school by far. ``Oh brother,'' she says. ``We're the lowest on the list. ``Everyone has so much time to talk and play, talk and play. What bothers me is I know you can do better. These scores are garbage. That's a reflection on me. Whatever I have to do to get this up, I will do. ``You always should expect to do the best for yourself. There's too much potential in this room. I'm just here to help you. But you have to help me help you. You already have the strikes against you. You're minorities, blacks, Puerto Ricans. So people look at these scores and say, `What did you expect?' ``I know where you belong, and I want to take you. I certainly don't want any of you in here next year shooting fire extinguishers at the window.''

DOC.HEAD: Facts, Figures on Urban Schools
With BC-City Faces-Teacher
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 40 percent of the nation's minority students and about 30 percent of its poor children are educated in large, urban school districts, according to data collected by the Council of Great City Schools. About 11 percent, or 4.5 million U.S. schoolchildren, attend school in the nation's 37 largest urban districts, according to the council. Urban districts with the biggest enrollments are New York, 940,000; Los Angeles, 592,000; Chicago, 394,000; Miami-Dade County, Fla., 268,000; Philadelphia, 191,000; Houston, 190,000; Detroit, 174,000; Dallas, 131,000; San Diego, 117,000; Baltimore, 107,000, and Memphis, Tenn., 106,000. The families of nearly 1.5 million urban schoolchildren are below the poverty line; 408,000 are enrolled in classes for the handicapped; 293,000 have limited English proficiency. Forty-five percent are black, 26 percent white, 23 percent Hispanic, and 5 percent Asian. Daily attendance averages 94 percent in urban elementary schools, 91 percent in middle schools and 87.6 percent in high schools. The national average for all schools is 92 percent. Excluding federal funds and capital spending, Pittsburgh spent the most per pupil among the 50 largest school districts: $7,163, according to 1988-89 data from the American Federation of Teachers, the latest comparable statistics available. Memphis, Tenn., at $2,521, spent the least. The 50-district average was $4,365. Average class size in the the 50 largest U.S. districts is about 17 students, compared with the 17.4 average for the entire nation, according to AFT statistics. Newark, N.J., had the best pupil-teacher ratio, 11.5, followed by St. Louis, 12.4, Boston, 12.6, Baltimore County, 13.5, Pittsburgh, 14.0, Orange County (Orlando) Fla., 14.5, Denver, 14.5, and Columbus, Ohio, 14.5. Los Angeles had the most crowded classes among the 50 largest districts, with a student-teacher ratio of 24. Some 203,000 teachers work in inner-city schools. Among urban districts with settled contracts in 1990-91, Philadelphia teachers earn from $24,000 to $49,600; Newark teachers, $23,867 to $50,757; Minneapolis teachers, $22,192 to $47,273; Cincinnati teachers, $21,679 to $44,847; Baltimore teachers, $22,162 to $43,002; and Dade County, Fla., teachers, $26,500 to $49,400.

DOC.HEAD: 450 Years Later, El Greco's Hometown Celebrates the Artist
DOC.TEXT: El Greco's hometown is holding its first major exhibit of paintings by its most famous son, celebrating his 450th birthday a year early. Domenicos Theotocopoulos, as the artist was born and as he signed his work, is represented by 30 paintings, five early Byzantine icons and by a wealth of documents and books illuminating his life. He died in Toledo, Spain, in 1614. It was there that the visionary artist became known as El Greco - the Greek - and created his mannerist masterpieces. His flamelike lines, brightly lighted figures and elongated, distorted forms depicting religious ecstasy and ascetic nobility have been brought to his hometown on Crete for the first time ever. They are on display at the Basilica of St. Mark. Although it is believed that Theotocopoulos was born in 1541, Iraklion held his 450th anniversary a year early. ``We guessed that next year major museums will be holding their own exhibitions and we wouldn't be able to get any paintings. We wanted to get in first,'' said Nicos Hadjinicolaou, professor of art history at the University of Crete, who spent two years organizing the exhibition. For Cretans, the exhibition of El Greco's work and life has become a source of pride, with over 2,500 people flocking to it each day since it opened Sept. 1. It runs until Oct. 10. A five-day international congress on his life and work pointed out the Greek and Byzantine influences in El Greco's work and illuminated aspects of his life in Crete. Iraklion was a busy port called Candia controlled by the Venetian republic when Theotocopoulos left in about 1570 to study under Titian in Italy. The town does not own a single painting by its most famous son. But it certainly remembers him. Overlooking the basilica square in which a large crowd gathered for the exhibition's inauguration is the huge neon sign of the El Greco Hotel. Further away is the Theotocopoulos Hotel. ``The atmosphere at the exhibition is very interesting. We see people here who have never been to an exhibition,'' said Hadjinicolaou in an interview. ``It is a symbolic honor by us to a young artist who lived and worked here ... before making a great career abroad. We owe it to honor someone who honors us,'' he said. The costs were borne by private donors and the municipality in this town of about 100,000 people. Hadjinicolaou would not specify what they were. When the carefully wrapped paintings began arriving from museums in Washington and Leningrad, crowds gathered and applauded every time a crate was lowered from a truck. Irene Florou, a historian at the Athens School of Fine Arts, believes that the exhibition could inspire Cretans and remind them of the flowering of art and literature the island experienced in the 16th and 17th centuries. At that time, painters such as Theotocopoulos and Mihalis Damaskinos picked up the Byzantine tradition. Writers such as Vincenzios Kornaros and Giorgos Hortatzis wrote Venetian-inspired epics that are sung to this day in the distinctive Cretan dialect in remote villages. ``This exhibition creates a counterbalance to the general climate of the time,'' Florou said in an interview. ``People will be reminded that there is more to life than buying cars and building hotels. They will remember the arts that they carry about inside them.'' Crete is currently enjoying an unprecedented economic boom, with high European Community subsidies for agriculture and construction of hotels touting the Mediterranean island's beauty. Hadjinicolaou says that the town hopes to find a way to gather 850,000 pounds ($1.6 million) to buy El Greco's ``View of Mount Sinai and the Monastery of St. Catherine,'' currently in a private collection in Vienna. ``Fortunately, both candidates for mayor in the (October) municipal elections support our effort,'' he said. The first major congress on El Greco was held in Toledo in 1982. No Greeks were invited to it and there was no mention of the Greek side of his life and work. The second such gathering was held at Iraklion's harbor fortress last month. ``This was a small reply to their `El Greco of Toledo.' Our catalog is called `El Greco of Crete.' A quarter of the speeches concerned El Greco's Cretan period,'' Hadjinicolaou said. Most of El Greco's work in Crete was on icons. One of the major results of the congress was that participants appeared to have accepted the authenticity of an icon found on the Aegean island of Syros bearing Domenicos Theotocopoulos' signature. It was discovered in 1983 and would have been painted when the artist was in his early 20s.

DOC.HEAD: Judas Priest Says They Were Scapegoats in Unnecessary Trial
DOC.TEXT: Members of the heavy metal band Judas Priest would like to put the recent past behind them, but they're not about to change their tune. The band is recovering from a recent Nevada court battle, which questioned whether subliminal messages exist on their 1978 album, ``Stained Class,'' and ultimately prompted two young men to enter a suicide pact. Lead singer Rob Halford and guitarist Glenn Tipton said their court victory, clearing them of deliberately placing the subliminal messages on the album, was bittersweet. But they're not about to quit making the music they've been driven to make for the past 16 years. ``We won't back down to that kind of legal terrorism,'' said Tipton. The Priest's new hard-driving album, ``Painkiller,'' and upcoming tour demonstrate their tenacity. The band was cleared on Aug. 24 by Washoe County District Court Judge Jerry Carr, who ruled the plaintiffs' alleged subliminal message ``do it'' on the song ``Better by You, Better Than Me,'' was an unintentional exhalation of breath and a drum beat. ``We were fighting a case on an issue based on something that doesn't exist. We had to sit in court while they were discussing Freudian theories on subconscious levels and whether the subconscious mind could pick up sub-audible signals and act upon it,'' said Tipton. ``We had to sit through that when all the time we wanted to just stand up and say, `But there are no messages!' '' Raymond Belknap, 18, died from a self-inflicted shotgun blast to the face on Dec. 23, 1985. James Vance, then 20, shot himself also. He lived but suffered horrible facial disfigurement, and died in 1988 of complications from his injuries and a reaction to medications. Both had listened to ``Stained Class'' before making the suicide pact. Their families sued Judas Priest and CBS Records for $6.2 million in damages, claiming the subliminal messages were on the album and influenced their sons' actions. Defense lawyers, however, countered that the youths came from troubled homes and had been drinking and smoking marijuana that day. The judge did order CBS Records to pay the plaintiffs $40,000 for refusing to comply with discovery orders involving the original master tape of the album. Both Halford and Tipton, recently in New York before three weeks of rest in England and Spain, said they were sorry the young men died, but the band was the unnecessary scapegoat for the tragedy. ``People try and shoulder the burden of guilt on any one else's shoulders. They should look a little closer to home for the real issues and the real reasons that cause incidents like this,'' Tipton said. Halford added that it was ridiculous to place the blame on the band or the music. He said at times during the court battle he felt it was heavy metal on trial, not just Judas Priest. ``There's absolutely never been, and never will ever be, any scientific proof evidential that heavy metal music, or any kind of music, can physically make somebody to do something, or change, or be someone else.'' So-called ``backward-masking,'' or conveying a subliminal message by recording it backward, also became a well-publicized issue in the trial. Halford testified on the stand he had put a backward message on one Judas Priest song, but it was not on the album or song cited by the plaintiffs. And he disagreed that backward messages are ``masked'' to influence behavior. ``No, it's not backward-masking. And that's the confusing issue about that. When I made that statement in court, the prosecution was jumping up and down in glee, because they thought they won the trial,'' Halford said. ``The fact is, it's just a sound effect. It's been going on since Jimi Hendrix and before him. It's a simple operation of recording an instrument - a cymbal, a guitar, a voice - backwards to create a sound effect. It's been going on for 30 or 40 years,'' he added. Tipton agreed, saying it was impossible to prove whether backward messages are effective. ``In the whole history of there world there is not one instance that's been proven that anybody can interpret anything backwards, particularly something below audible level,'' he said. Halford, 39, wearing a T-shirt imprinted with the words ``Free Speech'' formed from the American flag, is the group's primary lyricist. He said that although Judas Priest is known for ``no-holds-barred'' heavy metal, he's never written lyrics that are obscene, or advocate satanism or violence. ``That's what's so ludicrous about the whole controversy supposedly surrounding this band,'' Halford said. Tipton agreed: ``We've never condoned the use of drugs or alcohol or doing bad things.'' Although the band does use words such as ``hell'' and ``damn'' on the new-release ``Painkiller,'' the words are not used in a violent manner. ``It depends on how these words are used. We don't say `Take these babies down into hell and kill them.' It's like `Hell's a hot place.' The word hell is used, but its not used in what I would consider a bad or influential way,'' Tipton said. Judas Priest, which includes Halford, Tipton, K.K. Downing, Ian Hill and Scott Travis, will go on the road in October with their new album. The worldwide tour starts in Canada, moves into the United States in November, and ends up in Europe next year. Judas Priest is one of the founding fathers of modern-day heavy metal. Known for cultivating the leather, studs and motorcycle look in heavy metal, the band has cut 14 albums. Although Judas Priest has been around longer than many in its genre, Halford says competition with younger groups is no longer an issue with the band. ``What I've noticed in the past few years, particularly in heavy metal, is that the substance is the most important issue now. It's not how much hair you've got and how pretty you look. It's the validity of your work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: For Salvadoran Chopper Pilots, a Perilous Job Becomes Moreso ^Laserphotos planned
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Enrique Torruella swooped the UH-1H ``Huey'' helicopter below 1,000 feet into the range of guerrilla rifle fire. He banked the craft steeply in a tightening gyre, then abruptly landed in the combat zone. The copter's deafening rotor flattened the waist-high grass. Pvt. Manuel Zepeda, squinting through swollen eyes, his face bloodied by shrapnel from a grenade, ran to the waiting ship. So did another soldier carrying on his back Pvt. Santos Alfaro, badly wounded in the head and arm by the same explosion. The aircraft was on the ground less than a minute. Torruella revved the turbo-jet engine and raced off. Before the aircraft reached safety beyond the range of enemy fire, medic Cpl. Tomas Vasquez had a needle in Alfaro's arm and plasma dripping into his veins. The Grupo de Helicopteros at Ilopango air base five miles east of San Salvador embodies the single most significant tactical advantage government forces have over the FMLN leftist rebel army. Military analysts consider the infusion of helicopters and pilot training provided by Washington from 1982-85 crucial in preventing the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front from winning the civil war. The fleet provides transport of troops and supplies, rocket and machine-gun support for ground troops and evacuation of nearly all the wounded government soldiers. According to casualty statistics, no job in the military is as dangerous as that of the squadron's 60 pilots. During the past 18 months it has become more so. The guerrillas since early 1989 have worked diligently on anti-aircraft tactics. Virtually all the approximately 65 aging Hueys and the few, newer Hughes 500s making up the squad have been hit by ground fire. Several, perhaps a dozen, have been shot out of the sky. The precise number is classified. Thirty pilots have been killed in action since the group was formed in 1982. Most of the survivors have been wounded. Part of Torruella's right foot was shot off in August 1989 when rifle fire pierced the floor. Charcoal portraits of 26 of those killed adorn a wall of the lobby of the group's headquarters. Once the four pending portraits are added, there will be space for only two more before room will have to made on another wall. The air force jealously guards information on rebel effectiveness against its planes and helicopters. But, by way of indication, on both days an AP correspondent and photographer accompanied crews on ``medivac'' missions, at least one ship was struck by gunfire. Most of the time, damage is limited to perforations of the fuselage. But if 7.62mm fire from guerrilla AK-47s strikes the engine, the tail rotor or hydraulic hoses, the helicopter may crash or be forced to land off base. ``Rene,'' a guerrilla squad leader based on the slopes of Guazapa Mountain 20 miles north of San Salvador, sat in the shade one recent afternoon and described ``triangulation.'' The tactic concentrates fire of up to 15 AKs on helicopters descending to either pick up wounded or deliver supplies. The circling and dipping practiced by the pilots are intended to minimize guerrilla efficiency. ``If you approach in a straight line, they get a bead on you,'' said Torruella, a smooth-faced 24-year-old. Like several of the squad's members, he looks out of uniform more like an adolescent than a combat chopper-jockey. All the pilots except one - a recent graduate of the local aviation school - were trained at the U.S. Army's Fort Rucker in Alabama. ``They have the same training as U.S. pilots. That instruction combined with constant combat has made them among the best in the world. Practice makes perfect,'' said Lt. Col. Arch Kielly, U.S. Air Force attache in El Salvador. Military analysts say the air force, especially the helicopter squadron, was essential to beating back November's large-scale guerrilla offensive. The FMLN accused the government of indiscriminate rocket fire and strafing of densely populated urban neighborhoods where guerrillas had dug in. Air force authorities and U.S. advisors dispute the allegation, saying dozens of requests from ground troops for air support were denied for fear of inflicting unacceptable civilian casualties. Judging from what reporters saw during the offensive and from inspections of battle-scarred neighborhoods afterward, the truth is somewhere between the government and guerrilla claims. Aerial machine-gun fire perforated roofs in several areas and rockets were launched into a few residential districts. But intense use of air power appeared to have begun on the offensive's fourth day, when most civilians had evacuated the battle zones. With the insurgents talking of a new offensive in coming weeks, the pilots face a new peril. The rebels' reported acquisition of scores of shoulder-fired surface-to-air missiles could prove to be a strategic watershed in the nearly 11-year-old war. Employment of similar weapons in the 1980s by U.S.-backed Afghan guerrillas was one of the keys to the success of their campaign against Soviet forces.

DOC.HEAD: Money, Indifference Block Path to Islamic Morality
With AM-Algeria-Fundamentalists
DOC.TEXT: The burst of repression expected to follow this summer's election victory by Islamic fundamentalists hasn't materialized. Take the case of Tipasa. This Mediterranean resort welcomes tens of thousands of European and Algerian tourists a year to pristine beaches and extensive Roman ruins. Not long after the 15,000 residents elected a council dominated by the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS), posters went up announcing a ban against shorts. The news quickly reaching Europe was portrayed as evidence the fundamentalists knew no limits in imposing strict morality. How could shorts be banned in a beach town? The impression of fire-breathing fundamentalists imposing a draconian crackdown killed the season. ``June and July were just dead - there were almost no Europeans,'' Ahmed Mansour remarked on the empty terrace of his restaurant. But town administrator Mohammed Essamelli says the reality of the ban was more complicated. ``First, this law's been here since 1965,'' said Essamelli. ``All the new council did was say they intended to enforce it.'' Second, the law does not affect Tipasa's beaches, where men and women in Western swimwear outnumber those in long robes 20 to one. It covers only the town center and was modeled on similar rules on the French Riviera 25 years ago, Essamelli said. The law permits shorts in town if they reach the top of the knee for men or the bottom of the knee for women. Essamelli finds this reasonable. Mansour notes that no police officer has bothered to enforce the ordinance and says the fundamentalists don't want to bite the economic hand that feeds the electorate. ``Nobody has come here asking us to stop selling alcohol,'' he said. ``They may be for Islam, but they know this country needs other things, too.'' The Tipasa case finds echoes elsewhere. Stories proliferate of official crackdowns on ice cream and alcohol. Most turn out to be exaggerated. Many of the reports originate with the official APS news agency, an organ of the ruling National Liberation Front. The fundamentalists thrashed the party in the elections. The fundamentalists certainly hope to change Algerian society. Councils have moved to segregate boys and girls at school. The movement debates whether women should work. But in the absence of holding national power - legislative elections are planned next spring - the changes are mostly limited to cosmetics. In Oran, Algeria's second city, humor made a difference. Fundamentalist councilors there denounced a festival of the popular rai music, which celebrates youthful revolt. They said one devoted to Islamic music would be better. A rai singer responded with a number featuring a compromise refrain: ``I voted for the FIS, I voted for the FIS.''

DOC.HEAD: Families of Americans Hel

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices approached $40 per barrel on the futures market, about double the price before Iraq invaded Kuwait and close to the level of cash prices paid 10 years ago during the Iranian revolution. Wholesale unleaded gasoline and home heating oil shot over $1 per gallon Monday as the market responded to amplified fears about the Persian Gulf crisis. After peaking at $39.20 per barrel in the afternoon, light sweet crude for November delivery settled up $2.82 at $38.25 per barrel - a new record on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where oil futures have been traded since 1983. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The federal budget deficit jumped $52.8 billion to a record $241.7 billion in August, but could be reduced before the fiscal year ends Sept. 30, the Treasury Department reported. The 67 percent surge over the comparable 11 months of 1989 boosted the spending imbalance well over the record of $221.1 billion posted in fiscal 1986, the department said Monday. The August total, however, fell short of the one-month record of $53.3 billion set last March. ``We used to have years that were that bad,'' economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said of the August deficit. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A federal judge ordered the release of pre-sentencing documents about convicted financier Michael Milken, ruling the public had a right to the information before she pronounces his punishment. But Judge Kimba Wood said the released documents would be edited to delete possibly incriminating information about others, and she left unclear whether Milken's sentencing would proceed as scheduled next Monday. Her ruling was part of last-minute legal maneuvers surrounding the sentencing of Milken, the biggest and richest figure to fall in a federal crusade against securities fraud crimes that began in the late 1980s. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Losses at the nation's privately-run savings and loans stabilized in the April-June quarter, the government said, but analysts warned that deteriorating real estate markets threaten the industry. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said Monday that 2,437 S&Ls operating outside of government control lost $196 million in the second quarter of 1990. That was a modest improvement over the $219 million loss in the first three months of the year, a dramatic gain over the $720 million loss in the last three months of 1989 but a substantial deterioration from the $308 million profit earned by the same institutions a year earlier. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Chase Manhattan Corp.'s announcement that it will slash its dividend and eliminate 5,000 jobs could signal impending cutbacks by other major banks, analysts said. The nation's second-largest bank plans to halve its dividend this quarter because it planned to set aside more than $650 million by Sept. 30 to bolster reserves for loans that may go bad. Most of the loans financed commercial real estate. But analysts said Monday that real estate is just one trouble spot for major banks as the economy deteriorates. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The city is threatening to pull the plug on Commonwealth Edison Co., which is reeling from recent power losses that blacked out thousands of residents and raised doubts about the utility's dependability. Edison's problems come just as it's trying to negotiate its first new franchise with Chicago in 42 years. The contract expires Dec. 31, but the city this month halted negotiations, saying it wanted to extend the current deal another year while it figures out whether Edison is dependable. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The United Airlines pilots' union, contending management is trying to discredit an employee buyout effort, has urged its members to voice support for the proposal in a letter-writing campaign to UAL directors. The Air Line Pilots Association said in a letter to members that if the effort toward employee ownership falls through, it is ready to ``confront senior management ... up to and including a strike.'' Union spokesman James Hanson said Monday that the letter merely spells out the ultimate option and is not a strike threat. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Many Americans are dumb consumers. Some don't know much about buying a house, about compound interest, about unit pricing at the grocery store or what a used-car disclosure must contain. The Consumer Federation of America said Monday that it tested 1,139 people in shopping centers in seven states and found only 54 percent of its questions were answered correctly. ``Many consumers are not equipped to function competently in the market place,'' said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the federation. ---

The stock market fell sharply to a 14-month low Monday, battered by the one-two punch of rising oil prices and trouble in the banking industry. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 59.41 to 2,452.97, its lowest close since it stood at 2,452.77 on July 3, 1989. The dollar sank against all major currencies. Prices of gold jumped. Coffee prices sagged. Grains and soybeans were mostly higher. Cattle futures fell. Pork futures were mixed. Bond prices fell, with the bellwether 30-year bond falling 19-32 point, or $5.94 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, had climbed to 9.17 percent from 9.11 percent late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck's Asil Nadir Fights For His Business Reputation
Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Asil Nadir, a Turkish-Cypriot who built up his Polly Peck conglomerate over more than two decades, is fighting a battle on two fronts as he tries to impede the erosion of the company's stock market value and his own business reputation. The company's board of directors and the Turkish government have rallied around the chairman and chief executive officer of Polly Peck, a firm whose interests are as diverse as Del Monte pineapples and Sansui stereos. The company's shares dove 55 percent last Thursday on rumors of a possible Serious Fraud Office investigation into the company. Later that day, Nadir was interviewed by the office, which investigates and prosecutes cases of serious fraud. British newspaper reports in recent weeks have alleged the company's share price may have been supported illegally, as was the case in the headline-making Guinness scandal, which resulted in a five-year prison term for the brewer's former chairman. The Department of Trade and Industry is considering a request made Sunday by Polly Peck's board for an independent inquiry into the conglomerate's dealings, a department spokeswoman said Monday. She was not identified, in accordance with British practice. Trading in Polly Peck's shares, a high-flying stock of the 1980s, remained suspended Monday. London's Stock Exchange agreed to the company's request to halt trading Thursday after the shares slumped by 135 pence ($2.50) to 108 pence ($2). The exchange says it allows trading in a company's shares to be suspended pending an announcement by the company. It says it does not impose a deadline for such an announcement, but presses for one as quickly as possible. Nadir said in a letter to the trade department requesting the independent inquiry: ``So intense and severe is the attack on myself that we, on our own, are unlikely to be able to find a fair hearing.'' Nadir also issued a statement Sunday saying he would start legal proceedings for alleged defamation against Times Newspapers Ltd. and The Observer Ltd. The newspapers reported Sunday that a former Polly Peck executive has given information about Polly Peck activities to the Serious Fraud Office. After a board meeting Friday, Polly Peck's directors said it ``deplores the recent attacks on the chairman'' and that there would be a ``more detailed statement next week.'' The Turkish government has accused Greek Cypriots of a smear campaign against Nadir. A Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman recently said ``this ugly campaign begun at the instigation of Greek Cypriots was aimed at bringing the Turkish Cypriot republic's economy to its knees.'' Nadir, an ally of Turkish President Turgut Ozal, has extensive publishing and electronics interests in Turkey and is the largest private employer in the Turkish-controlled part of Cyprus. Polly Peck's shares crashed once before, in the early 1980s, after Greek Cypriots claimed the company was exploiting land seized from Greek Cypriots after Turkey's 1974 invasion divided the island in two. The shares also were hurt because the company's earnings weren't matching analysts' forecasts. The company's stock has fallen sharply since August, when Nadir, who owns 28 percent of the company's shares, said he wanted to take the company private and then withdrew the plan after five days. The Stock Exchange criticized him for his hasty actions. William de Winton, an analyst with the London investment firm Hoare Govett Ltd. said the company has been doing well. ``The business is not in an untenable position. As far as I can see they are going to have a relatively successful year,'' he said. Polly Peck's after-tax profit rose 16 percent last year. Nadir, the son of a wealthy Cypriot, came to England in the 1960s and set up his own clothing company in east London. He then branched out into fruit distribution, electronics and tourism. In 1980, he took control of the ailing British textile company Polly Peck and used the firm as his stock market vehicle for expansion. Polly Peck bought the Del Monte fresh fruit operations last year and control of Sansui Electric Co. in December. In the process of building his company, Nadir became one of Britain's richest persons last year with a personal fortune valued at 213 million pounds ($396 million). That fortune is worth considerably less at today's market price.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Edited Versions of Sentencing Documents Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ordered the release of pre-sentencing documents about Michael Milken, which could provide revealing information about the convicted financier before his punishment is officially announced. But the ruling Monday by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood said the released documents would be edited to delete possibly incriminating information about others. She also left unclear whether Milken's sentencing would proceed as scheduled Oct. 1, less than a week away. Her ruling was part of last-minute legal maneuvers surrounding the sentencing of Milken, the biggest and richest figure to fall in a federal crusade against securities fraud crimes that began in the late 1980s. Milken reversed claims of innocence in April, pleaded guilty to six felonies and paid a record $600 million in fines and penalties to settle the biggest securities fraud case ever against a single person. In the past few weeks, prosecutors and defense attorneys have given Wood exhaustive documents to guide her in determining a sentence for Milken, who faces a possible 28 years in prison. News organizations sought copies of the documents before the sentencing date, but Milken's lawyers opposed an early release on grounds it could unfairly prejudice the sentencing. ``I reject that contention. There's no jury here,'' Wood told a hearing at Manhatttan federal court. Delaying the release of the information, she said, ``may prejudice the ability of the press to understand it.'' She ordered prosecutors to release edited versions of their sentencing memos that avoid references to other individuals or pending criminal investigations. They were expected to be available later today. Defense lawyers declined to comment on Wood's ruling but said they would release similarly edited versions of their sentencing memos at about the same time. Although the documents are edited, people familiar with the case said Monday they could provide revealing insights into the scope of government's enormous case against Milken, as well as the depth of his defense. Milken is widely perceived as one of the most influential financiers in the 1980s, who made a fortune by parlaying high-risk securities known as junk bonds into a $200 billion market. Although Milken pleaded guilty to only six crimes related to securites and tax crimes, prosecutors have been seeking to persuade the judge to consider a list of other illegal acts they say Milken committed. They have asked for an extraordinary hearing on this question, which could delay Milken's sentencing. Wood did not say whether she would grant such a hearing but asked Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll to provide examples of other cases in which similar hearings were requested. The case against Milken is by far the most important result of an intensive federal crackdown on securities fraud that surfaced nearly four years ago when stock speculator Ivan Boesky paid the government $100 million to settle charges of trading on inside information. Boesky's revelations led to numerous prosecutions and played a role in the downfall of Milken's former employer Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the once-feared Wall Street powerhouse that is now out of business. Milken pioneered Drexel's use of junk-bond financing for takeover deals, and he had extensive and close links with a number of leading American investors and speculators.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Blackouts: City Threatens To Pull Plug on Power Company
Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The city is threatening to pull the plug on Commonwealth Edison Co., which is reeling from recent power losses that blacked out thousands of residents and raised doubts about the utility's dependability. Edison's problems come just as it's trying to negotiate its first new franchise with Chicago in 42 years. The contract expires Dec. 31, but the city this month halted negotiations, saying it wanted to extend the current deal another year while it figures out whether Edison is dependable. ``We can't bargain in the dark,'' Mayor Richard M. Daley said recently. Edison hasn't said yet whether it will agree to the extension. Utility spokesman John Hogan said Comm Ed would like to see the deal completed this year and that, in any case, its reliability is unimpeachable. Even if eependability weren't an issue, the city holds a wild card: the option under the current franchise of buying Comm Ed's facilities in the city. Other major U.S. cities, including Los Angeles, have public utilities, and some smaller cities have recently used franchise buyout clauses to purchase private utilities, said Deborah Nuttall, a spokeswoman for the Washington, D.C.-based American Public Power Association. But no large cities have made such a buyout in recent years, she said. Edison is trying to salvage its image after a series of crippling blackouts, including one in late July in which 40,000 West Side customers were without electricity for three days. Some small stores were looted during the outage. About a week later, an outage cut off 25,000 customers, infuriating many people. Four less severe power failures have hit the city and suburbs in the past three days, including two Monday that briefly knocked out power to more than 2,000 customers. On Saturday, 15,000 West Side customers were without power for up to seven hours, and on Sunday a brief blackout hit about 2,500 South Side customers. Other unrelated failures cut off power to the downtown area of the city of Streeterville and the Chicago Board of Trade, where trading was suspended for about an hour last Tuesday. Hogan said that because of the two major summer blackouts, the media is reporting minor problems that previously would have been ignored. Edison has blamed the West Side blackouts on a problem at a generating plant, and other failures on damaged cables and animals chewing power lines. Still, Hogan said Edison maintains ``a 99.98 percent reliability factor.'' ``We don't have any reason to believe the total infrastructure is in jeopardy,'' Hogan said. Even so, the Daley administration insists a buyout is a real alternative. ``This is not a bargaining chip,'' Daley spokeswoman Carolyn Grisko said Friday. ``This is a possibility.'' The current agreement gives the city the right to purchase Comm Ed's system within the city's limits - an option first given serious consideration in 1985 under the late Mayor Harold Washington's administration. The utility serves 3.2 million customers in 25 counties of northern Illinois. Other issues besides the buyout are on the table, including how much money the utility pays the city for the right to operate here. Currently, the utility pays Chicago 4 percent of its gross receipts - which last year was in excess of $72 million, Hogan said. Consumer groups, such as Citizens Utility Board, are asking the city to consider a new franchise that would require Commonwealth Edison to work harder to cut customer costs. Residential Commonwealth Edison customers paid 10.7 cents per kilowatt hour for electricity in 1988, compared with a national average of 7.5 cents, according to the power association. Edison financial analysts say the utility also has a lot to lose in the talks. Chicago represents ``a large portion of the company's sales,'' said Linda Byus, a utility analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Its image also is linked closely to the city, which may help forge an amicable agreement between the two, she said.

DOC.HEAD: United Pilots Union Urges Letter-Writing Campaign to Support Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Still struggling to obtain financing for an employee buyout of UAL Inc., union pilots of United Airlines now are trying to beat back emerging opposition within the company. Officials of the Air Line Pilots Association sent letters over the weekend asking members to let the company directors know they support employee ownership. The union, in a letter to its members, said a broad showing of support is needed to counteract efforts by UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf to undermine the buyout. The union also said there has been an anonymously sponsored anti-employee ownership letter-writing campaign within the company. UAL spokeswoman Sara Dornaker said Monday she did not know the origin of the letter-writing campaign. But she said ``several hundred'' employees have written to Wolf expressing concern about an employee buyout would burden the company with too much debt. ``There is a growing concern in the industry and among employees about being a highly leveraged carrier in these highly uncertain times,'' she said. Doug Wellman, vice president of the Association of Flight Attendants' United local, said his union will join the pilots in urging its members to write to UAL directors. He denied the union letters have anything to do with the struggle to obtain financing for the buyout. ``It has to do with the ill-conceived, (anti-buyout) propaganda'' surfacing within the company, he said. Wellman said several hundred letters opposing employee ownership are inconsequential considering the number of company employees - more than 71,000. It was not known whether the third union in the buyout attempt, the Machinists, also would write the directors. Spokesmen were not in their offices late Monday and could not be reached for comment by telephone. The pilots union said in its letter that if the effort toward employee ownership falls through, it is ready to ``confront senior management ... up to and including a strike.'' Union spokesman James Hanson said the letter merely spells out the ultimate option and is not a strike threat. The pilots, flight attendants and machinists unions have offered $201 a share, or $4.38 billion, for UAL, the parent of United Airlines. The company's directors accepted the offer, but the employee group has had trouble coming up with the financing. Union officials said it was within days of arranging financing with some lenders - and within hours with others - when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The effect on oil prices, the cost of running an airline and the uncertainty introduced into the economy ``may continue to cause difficulty'' with financing, the union said. A $300-a-share offer collapsed for lack of financing last October. The UAL board meets Thursday, but the union has until Oct. 9 to arrange financing. The employee group failed t meet a deadline in August and was given a two-month extension by the directors. The board said then that if the financing was not in place by Oct. 9, the deal would be off.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release noon EDT; time set by source
Little Gain in Fuel Economy Reported in 1991 Models
DOC.NOTE: EDS: With PM-Auto Mileage-Best & Worst and PM-Fuel Economy. EPA mileage list of all cars moved in advance Sept. 21 as b0245-b0262. Also moved on the general news wire. ^By H. JOSEF HEBERT
DOC.TEXT: Automakers are showing little or no gain in fuel economy for the fifth straight year, with 1991 model cars having on average as much thirst at the gas pumps as they did in 1987, the government reported today. The Environmental Protection Agency released the new fuel economy figures as the Senate considered legislation that would require sharp improvements in automobile fuel efficiency over the next decade. According to the EPA's annual fuel economy statistics covering about 1,000 cars, the 1991 models - both domestics and imports - show an overall average of 28.1 miles per gallon, slightly better than last year and identical to the fleet average in 1987. While the most miserly cars such as the minicompact Geo Metro attain more than 50 mpg, more than half of the cars on the list achieved no better than 22 mpg. The increasingly popular passenger vans and specialty vehicles could on average do no better than the high teens. The manufacturers want to ``sell bigger engines, more muscle and acceleration which they call performance,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, a Washington-based consumer organization, and a frequent critic of the automakers. Auto industry executives have pointed to the significant improvements in fuel economy of cars since the 1970s, when the fleet average was only about 14 mpg, and attribute the more recent figures to consumer demand for larger and peppier cars. Similar views are found in automobile showrooms. ``It's not the industry pushing performance. It's the consumer that's been demanding it in the last few years,'' said Ray Turk, a salesman at a Nissan dealership in suburban Maryland. Janice Walsh was one of those consumers the other day as she prepared to take a sporty Nissan 300ZX for a test spin, taking little notice of its skimpy 18 mpg mileage rating for city driving. ``I like a car that's fun,'' she said. Down the road at another dealership, retiree John Webb and his wife said the 17 mpg city driving estimate on a Mercury Marquis didn't bother them. ``When we travel we want a good-sized car and lots of trunk space,'' said Webb. ``We really haven't talked about mileage.'' The EPA noted that between the mid-1970s and early 1980s significant gains were made in making automobiles more fuel-efficient. ``Since 1982, however, the overall fleet fuel economy figures have increased only slightly, partly because stable oil prices reduced the demand for fuel-efficient vehicles.'' Since 1987 the fleet-wide averages have been virtually at a standstill. They were 28.1 mpg in 1987, 28.6 mpg in 1988, 28.1 mpg in 1989 and 27.8 mpg in 1990. As in previous years, the 1991 figures showed a wide range of gas mileage, from the minicompact Geo Metro that gets 58 mpg on the highway and only a few miles less in the city to the luxurious two-seater Lamborghini Diablo that gets 9 mpg on city streets. Four of the 10 best performing cars were variations of the Geo, a Japanese-made minicompact that is sold through General Moors. The others were two versions of the Honda Civic CRX, two varieties of the Suzuki Swift, a Daihatsu Charade and a diesel-powered Volkswagen Jetta. All get at least 37 mpg in the city and 42 mpg on the highway. At the other extreme were the Lamborghini, five versions of the Rolls-Royce, two Ferraris and two BMWs - none of which attained more than 12 mpg in city driving and generally only slightly higher on the highways. Even within various size categories the fuel efficiency of different cars varied widely. As expected, small economy cars generally showed much better fuel economy than expensive and performance-leaning luxury models. The EPA listed only 35 cars subject to the so-called ``gas guzzler'' tax, which in the case of the Lamborghini Diablo amounts to $3,200. But those figures can be misleading. The guzzler tax, which kicks in if a car gets less than 22.5 mpg in combined city and highway driving, is based on raw test results, while the EPA figures are adjusted downward by a mathematical formula so the mileage figures more closely reflect actual driving conditions. Using the adjusted EPA figures, 393 of the 728 cars, specialty vehicles and passenger vans on the list attained gas mileage of less than 22.5 mpg. All but a handful of the nearly 300 trucks on the list also failed to meet the 22.5 mpg figure. Trucks, passenger vans and specialty vehicles are not covered by the tax, which is assessed only on cars based on a sliding scale depending on miles per gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Exec Favors Mid-American Site for New Toyota Plant
DOC.TEXT: A decision has yet to be made about where Toyota Motor Corp. will put its new U.S. assembly plant, but one executive favors mid-America. Bob McCurry, executive vice president of Toyota's U.S. sales and marketing arm, said Monday that the company needs the capacity of another car plant to meet its goal of selling 1.5 million cars and trucks in the United States by the mid-1990s. About 80 percent of those vehicles, or 1.3 million, will be cars, said spokesman John McCandless. If that goal is met and if current sales trends continue into the mid-1990s, Toyota could overtake Chrysler Corp. as the nation's third-largest automaker. Before that can happen, Toyota has to develop more manufacturing capacity, McCurry said. ``To do the volume we're talking about, with 50 percent (of production) in this market, we need new facilities,'' McCurry said. Toyota officials have said an announcement about the location of a new assembly plant should be made within two months. But McCurry hedged Monday, saying only that a decision would be made soon. A possible place is next to Toyota's assembly plant now operating in Georgetown, Ky. There is available land on the site and supply lines already are in place. Toyota also has the option in 1996 to buy General Motors Corp.'s share of the companies' joint New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. plant near Fremont, Calif., which builds the Toyota Corolla and GM's Geo Prizm. When asked about the possible location of a new plant, McCurry said, ``I'm one who believes your plants should be in mid-America.'' In 1989, Toyota sold 707,357 cars and Chrysler sold 1,077,651 cars. But through the first eight months of this year, Chrysler's car sales of 560,057 were down 21.6 percent from last year, while Toyota's 602,562 were up 15.7 percent. Toyota's sales in August set a company record, partly because of an aggressive sales campaign, and inflated the year-to-date figure. McCurry's comments came during the introduction of a newly designed Tercel entry-level car. He said the two- and four-door models of the car, which looks similar to a Ford Tempo, is the ``lowest-priced car in America with a trunk.'' The base price for the two-door is $6,488. McCurry said he expected the price for a typically equipped Tercel, with all dealer handling costs, taxes and fees included, would cost about $8,400. The car targets the Hyundai Excel, Nissan Sentra and Ford Escort. McCurry said he expected 1991 Tercel sales to be about 130,000 cars, up from about 100,000 of the 1990 models.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Slashes Catalog Headquarters Jobs By 20
DOC.TEXT: Sears Roebuck and Co. has trimmed 213 jobs from its unprofitable catalog division in an effort to cut costs, a company spokesman said. The cuts represent 20 percent of the company's catalog headquarters staff and are part of a plan to consolidate hundreds of corporate-level jobs. Last year, the suburban Skokie-based catalog division logged about $4 billion in sales, but the segment hasn't turned a profit since 1985. But despite these difficulties, a company spokesman said Sears Chairman Edward A. Brennan intends to remain in the catalog business. Brennan vowed ``to stay in the business and to address our problems more aggressively,'' the spokesman told the Chicago Tribune in comments published in today's editions. The newspaper did not name the spokesman. Including the latest cuts, the catalog headquarters staff has shrunk by more than half, to 821 from about 1,700 in January 1989. The cuts affect both full-time managers and hourly employees in Skokie and in support offices in Downers Grove and Northbrook, Ill. More than half work in advertising, marketing and buying, the spokesman said. In contrast to previous cuts, the catalog division employees weren't given the choice of remaining with Sears. Managers informed the employees Monday and outlined severence-pay plans based on the number of years each worker has spent with the company, the newspaper said. Sears officials said the catalog division has improved and they expect it to show a profit again by 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Approves Assignment of Stotler Commodity Funds
DOC.TEXT: McCormick Capital Inc. has received court approval to acquire seven commodity funds belonging to Stotler Group Inc., a recently collapsed futures company. The transaction, approved Monday by U.S. District Judge Milton Shadur, is subject to certain conditions, including approval by the limited partners of the funds. McCormick Capital's subsidiary, McCormick Futures Management Inc., will become general partner and commodity pool operator of the funds: Advanced Portfolio Management Limited Partnership II, Stotler Futures Fund, Stotler Heartland Futures Fund I, Thomson Commodity Partners I, Thomson Commodity Partners II, Thomson Financial Futures Partners I and Thomson McKinnon Futures Fund. The federal bankruptcy court suspended proceedings against Stotler Group to allow McCormick to assume control of the funds. McCormick said that it expects the acquisition to be completed before the end of the year and that it may begin acting as clearing broker for the funds in October. Stotler wasone of the nation's largest futures brokers and until this summer was headed by Karsten Mahlmann, who resigned under pressure as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Peabody Cuts About 275 White Collar Workers
DOC.TEXT: About 275 white collar employees are being dismissed as part of a cost-cutting move by Peabody Holding Co. Inc., the coal mine operator. Peabody said Monday it would trim 70 employees from its 250-member headquarters payroll and another 70 from its Henderson, Ky., Peabody Coal Co. subsidiary. All corporate activities at Henderson are to be reassigned to St. Louis and to operating divisions throughout the country, said Ronald Greenfield, vice president of public relations. Henderson will serve as the headquarters for Peabody's Midwest division, which includes mining operations in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky and Oklahoma. Other cuts will be made in offices in 11 states where Peabody mines coal, the company said. The dismissals represent 2.5 percent of Peabody's total workforce. The company had 11,107 salaried and hourly workers at the end of 1989, according to Peabody Holding's annual report. Greenfield blamed the layoffs on ``competitive pressures that the whole industry has been under since the mid-1980s.'' He said the payroll cuts were initiated by Hanson PLC, the British conglomerate that assumed control of Peabody earlier this year. The layoffs, which were announced Monday in a letter to employees by John H. Wimberly, acting president of Peabody, were to take place Tuesday. ``Those employees terminated or who resign with management's approval...will be eligible for a special package in lieu of notice which doubles the current severance payments and includes an extra two months of medical benefits,'' Wimberly's letter said. Dismissed workers will get five months' worth of health benefits and will be able to purchase up to 15 more months of coverage. The company also will provide placement services. According to its 1989 annual report, Peabody Holding owns or controls 8 billion tons of coal reserves, and its subsidiaries operate 43 mines. Peabody reported $136.5 million in operating profits on revenue of $1.74 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Hears Arguments in Eastern Pilots Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines has asked a federal appeals court to overturn a Florida judge's decision that the company must give former strikers some of the jobs taken by replacement pilots. Eastern hired about 900 replacement pilots during the 1989 strike by the Air Line Pilots Association. ALPA walked out with Eastern's Machinists, who remain on strike, but ended the action about nine months later. U.S. District Judge Edward Davis of Miami, where Eastern is based, ruled last month that the union is entitled to the jobs of trainees. But Eastern attorney Joseph Manson argued before the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Monday that Davis erred in ruling that replacement pilots did not have permanent employee status if they were in training when the ALPA strike ended. James Linsey, an attorney for the union, said the replacement workers cannot be given permanent protection until they are ``transformed into fully qualified employees.'' The three-judge 11th Circuit panel did not indicate when it would rule. The number of jobs at issue also must be determined by the court; Eastern puts it at about 190, while the union says it's 400.

DOC.HEAD: Kobe Steel, Alcoa to Set Up Joint Venture in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Kobe Steel Ltd. said Tuesday it has agreed with Aluminum Company of America to set up a joint venture in Japan to produce and market aluminum sheet for beverage cans. The plan would give Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, better access to the Japanese market and provide Kobe Steel with a steady source of aluminum ingot, a Kobe Steel official said. As a part of the proposal, Kobe Steel and Pittsburgh-based Alcoa will exchange technical information and the U.S. company will supply Kobe Steel with primary aluminum ingot, the official said. The official said the two companies also agreed to collaborate on developing aluminum products for the automotive industry in both Japan and the United States. The official said the venture, to be capitalized at abouyt $71 million and equally owned by Kobe Steel and Alcoa, will be established in Tokyo by the end of this year. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the venture will build a plant by early 1993 with an annual production capacity of 180,000 metric tons of aluminum sheet for manufacturing aluminum cans for the Japanese and Asian markets. He said the plant would be located in Moka city, 48 miles north of Tokyo.

The stock market struggled to rally today as prices seesawed in a narrow range and flirted with the 14-month low reached in the previous session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 2.97 points at 2,455.94 in the first hour and a half of trading. But the broader market suffered as losers outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 5 with 708 issues declining, 510 advancing and 533 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 52.43 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Stock prices inched higher on the opening as traders drew encouragement from lower oil prices. The benchmark crude contract had fallen $1.03 to $37.22 a barrel early today after record-high crude prices helped drive the Dow down by nearly 60 points on Monday. But equities' move upward was shortlived. ``It shows that any rally should be sold in this marketplace,'' said Emmanuel Geronimous, senior vice president at Lehman Brothers. ``Uneasiness continues to take hold with any rally.'' He noted, however that the market has been able to stabilize somewhat in the absence of wholesale institutional selling. Separately, the economic outlook dimmed as the government reported a downward revision in second-quarter gross national product figures. MCA led the Big Board's actives list, skyrocketing 25 to 59{. The company is discussing a possible buyout with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. at a price reported to be between $80 and $90 a share. The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 352.37 up 0.21 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed, Seeking Direction
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid a lack of news that would have a significant impact on prices. Soybean futures opened modestly higher, wheat was up slightly and corn futures were narrowly mixed following gains Monday in all those markets, largely in reaction to powerful rallies in oil and precious metal prices. The energy and metal markets provided little direction this morning, however. The Census Bureau's monthly report of an August soybean crush of 92.8 million bushels contained no surprises, analysts said. Neither did Monday's weekly crop-progress report, which showed corn and soybean maturity still lagging behind the normal pace. The next scheduled event that could affect grain prices is Thursday's quarterly Agriculture Department grain stocks report, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.75} a bushel; corn was } cent lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.28\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with December at $1.12 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 2{ cents higher with November at $6.14} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent lower to .05 cent higher with October at 79.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent lower to .25 cent higher with September at 89.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .13 cent to .40 cent higher with October at 55.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .02 cent lower to .35 cent higher with February at 56.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures prices fell on Monday; pork futures were mixed.

The stock market struggled to remain in positive territory as prices turned mixed after an opening bounce upward. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 1.73 points at 2,454.70 at midday. But the broader market suffered as losers outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 5 with 757 issues declining, 556 advancing and 521 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 73.45 million shares at noon on Wall Street, compared with 79.48 million shares at the same time Monday. Stock prices inched higher on the opening as traders drew encouragement from lower oil prices. The benchmark crude contract had fallen more than $1 a barrel early today after record-high energy prices helped drive the Dow down by nearly 60 points to a 14-month low on Monday. But equities' move upward was shortlived. ``It shows that any rally should be sold in this marketplace,'' said Emmanuel Geronimous, senior vice president at Lehman Brothers. ``Uneasiness continues to take hold with any rally.'' Separately, the economic outlook dimmed as the government reported a downward revision in second-quarter gross national product figures. But the market focused on the administration's reiteration that it sees no recession in 1991, said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. MCA led the Big Board's actives list, skyrocketing 22{ to 57. The company is discussing a possible buyout with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. at a price reported to be between $80 and $90 a share, or as $7.5 billion. Metz said the news served as ``a tonic to speculators, who had nothing to feed upon for a while.'' DOC.HEAD: Fuji To Replace Plastic Film Canisters With Paper
DOC.TEXT: The makers of Fuji film said Tuesday they will replace the plastic canisters in which their film is sold in the United States with paper ones as an environmental measure. In addition, Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. Inc. said most Fuji film boxes will be made from recycled paper. The new film canisters are made of moisture-proof paper the Japanese company said it developed with its own technology. It said the containers provide the same protection as plastic ones. Fuji Photo Film is a subsidiary of Fuji Photo Film Co. Ltd. of Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Lufthansa Subsidiary Orders 17 Boeing Aircraft Worth 1.3 Billion Dollars
DOC.TEXT: Condor, the Lufthansa airline charter subsidiary, said it has placed a $1.3 billion order with Boeing for 17 new aircraft in what the charter company said was its largest order to date. Condor Flugdienst GmBH made the announcement on Monday. The company said it will take delivery through the middle of 1995. The acquisition is in line with the Neu Isenburg-based airline's fleet expansion plans. At present Condor operates a fleet of 22 aircraft, of which three are Mcdonnell Douglas DC-10s, three are Airbuses made by Airbus Industrie, seven are Boeing 757-200s and nine are Boeing 737-300 aircraft. The spokesman said Lufthansa, a 51-percent state-owned German flag carrier, will acquire Condor's Airbus planes next year as Boeing replacements arrive. Condor said its new Boeing order consists of nine 757-200 type aircraft as well as eight long-range versions of the 767-300. Lufthansa itself has a multibillion dollar fleet overhaul program under way with a large volume of Boeing aircraft on order. The Condor Spokesman said his airline will retain the DC-10s it currently is flying.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Hit New High for Current Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The price of gasoline has reached a new high since the Persian Gulf crisis began, rising to an average of $1.31 for a gallon of self-serve unleaded regular, the American Automobile Association reported Tuesday. Average prices went up 1.8 cents in the latest week, and were up 23.5 cents from levels on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The latest price information was collected Tuesday. AAA had found its all-time average gasoline price, $1.388 per gallon, just before the 1981 Easter weekend. Prices were up in all regions but the Midwest, where the nationwide survey found a modest price decrease. The biggest price increases were in New England and the West, while prices rose more moderately in the Great Lakes region.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Announce Settlement in Price-Fixing Case
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys general in Missouri and Kansas on Tuesday announced an antitrust settlement in principle in a $1 billion natural gas price-fixing case. Bob Stephan of Kansas and William Webster of Missouri said the settlement with Amoco Production Co. and Oxy USA, a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum, in Tulsa, would benefit natural gas consumers in four states who paid excessive rates from 1979-85. The consumers were from Kansas, western Missouri, southern Nebraska and northern Oklahoma. Officials said details of the settlemene three major dt with two of thefendants could not be released until Friday, the deadline for lawyers to put the deal in writing. The attorneys general spoke at the federal courthouse in Kansas City, Kan., where a consolidated lawsuit had been scheduled to begin Tuesday against the two gas producers and Williams Natural Gas Co. Williams has not agreed to the settlement, and jury selection for the suit against Williams was scheduled for Wednesday morning. Several utility companies who distributed the gas to consumers were also involved as plaintiffs. Webster and Stephan said they believe those utilities would sign on to the settlement. ``I'm sure the terms will benefit the consumers for many years to come,'' Stephan said at the newn that gets 18 mpg in the city, John Webb and his wife looked over a Mercury Grand Marquis - a big car with a V-8 engine and a cavernous trunk. ``When we travel we want a good size car and lots of trunk space,'' said Webb, a retiree who says the Marquis fits the bill although its city mileage is a thirsty 17 mpg. ``We really haven't talked about mileage,'' Webb said. The Persian Gulf crisis has prompted renewed efforts in Congress to require automakers to improve fuel economy. A bill before the Senate would require fleet averages to reach 40 mpg by 2001, a 40 percent increase from today's averages of roughly 28 mpg. Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen and a frequent critic of the auto industry, accused automakers of pushing ``bigger engines, more muscle and acceleration which they call performance'' instead of trying to make cars more fuel efficient. ``They want to sell speed instead of fuel economy,'' said Clarence Ditlow, head of the Washington-based Center for Auto Safety. ``The performance cars are the higher priced cars and the ones with more options and more profits.'' But those in the auto business say they're only giving the customer what he or she wants. ``It's not the industry pushing performance. It's the consumer that's been demanding it in the last few years,'' argues Ray Turk, the Nissan salesman at Herb Gordon AutoWorld in suburban Maryland where Ms. Walsh was shopping. As in previous years, the 1991 models reflected a wide range of mileage from the minicompact Geo Metro that gets 58 mpg on the highway and only slightly less in city driving to the luxurious two-seater Lamborghini Diablo that guzzles at 9 mpg on city streets. In between are about 1,000 models and variations of models of cars, trucks and vans. The EPA list includes only 35 cars subject to a gasoline ``guzzler'' tax that kicks in for cars getting 22.5 mpg or less and in the case of the Lamborghini Diablo amounts to $3,200. But those numbers may be misleading. For tax purposes, only the raw fuel economy test scores are used, not the lower EPA figures that are adjusted through a mathematical formula to better reflect actual driving conditions. Increasingly popular passenger vans, speciality vehicles and trucks also are excluded. Using the adjusted EPA figures, more than half the cars listed showed a fuel economy of fewer than 22.5 mpg with the average mileage for increasingly popular passenger vans and 4-wheel drive speciality vehicles coming in at fewer than 20 mpg. Four of the 10 cars with the best fuel economy were variations of the Geo, a Japanese-built car sold through General Motors. The others were two variations of the Honda Civic, two versions of the Suzuki Swift, the Daihatsu Charade and the diesel-powered Volkswagen Jetta, all with mileage estimates of between 37 mpg and 49 mpg in the city and 43 mpg to 52 mpg on the highway. At the other extreme were the Lamborghini Diablo, five versions of the Rolls-Royce, two BMWs and a pair of Ferraris. None of the 10 vehicles achieved more than 12 mpg in city driving. According to industry figures, those worst and best performers account for only a small fraction of the vehicles likely to be on the nation's highways. The industry estimates cars that get better than 40 mpg account for less than 3 percent of sales, while the luxury cars that make up the worst mileage performers are far fewer in number. Energy conservation advocates and environmentalists said the latest figures demonstrate the failure of the auto industry to push fuel economy in marketing and research.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday, although traders said the movement did not suggest a continuing upward trend. Traders said the gains were not significant compared to recent swings in the London market. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 8.9 points, or 0.4 percent, at 1,999.2. The Financial Times 30-share index ended up 16.2 points at 1,526.6, while the Financial Times 500-share index rose 1.83 points to close at 1,072.12. Volume was 412.4 million shares, less than Monday's 500.3 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with late European quotes and prices plus New York rates in early afternoon.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar ended mixed against major currencies in European trading today. Gold prices rose again amid anxieties over the Persian Gulf crisis, increasing as much as $11 an ounce. Foreign Exchange dealers said the dollar benefitted from technical factors linked to cross trading between the Japanese yen and major European currencies. They said the dollar could be helped if oil prices lose momentum and Wall Street remains relatively steady. The dealers reported that concern about the effect of rising oil prices on the Japanese economy, which depends heavily on imported oil, was driving investors out of the yen to major European currencies, particularly the safe-haven Swiss franc. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8765 from $1.8810 late Monday. A pound fetched $1.8710 in early afternoon trading in New York. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.5630 German marks, up from 1.5565; 1.2990 Swiss francs, down from 1.2965; 5.2340 French francs, up from 5.2145; 1.7618 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7665; 1,168.25 Italian lire, up from 1,165.50; and, 1.1493 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1483. Selected dollar rates around midday in New York included: 1.5655 German marks; 1.3035 Swiss francs; 1,14975 Canadian dollars; and 1,172.50 Italian lire. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 136.70 Japanese yen from 137.33 yen at Friday's close. Japanese markets were closed Monday for a national holiday. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 136.50 yen and in the New York afternoon the dollar traded at 137.52 yen. Precious metals dealers said their markets were busy but trading was choppy as operators tried to carve out a new trading range following the surge through $400 an ounce. Dealers said if there is no improvement in the Middle East conflict they expect gold to continue firming. Gold closed in London, the major market, at a bid of $403.25 a troy ounce, up from $396.55. The late Zurich bid was $404.25, up from $392.90. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $405.85, up from Monday's late $389.75. Silver bullion closed in London at a bid of $4.87 a troy ounce, down from $4.89 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Tests: Arco's `Clean Gas' Has Higher Concentration of Suspected Carcinogen
DOC.TEXT: The environmental benefits of Atlantic Richfield Co.'s new premium unleaded gasoline outweigh any possible health risks suggested by private tests, scientists said. The tests indicate the gasoline, designed to reduce pollutants, produces a 34 percent increase in emissions of a suspected carcinogen. But scientists said the fuel's overall benefits to clean air and health are worthwhile, and the increased concentrations of 1,3-butadiene were too small to pose a health threat. ``I don't personally think the emissions are anything to worry about. I think we're buying a lot more by reducing the benzene and the carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons,'' said Rogene Henderson, an inhalation toxicologist at the Lovelace Inhalation and Toxicology Research Institute. Arco unveiled its new EC-Premium on Sept. 6, calling theffuel the ``cleanest burning'' gasoline available in Southern California. Environmentalists became concerned about the new formula after obtaining previously undisclosed results of Arco's testing. Compared to conventional unleaded premium, Arco had said the new fuel reduced emissions of cancer-causing benzene by 36 percent, carbon monoxide by 28 percent and smog-forming hydrocarbons by 21 percent. But the company made no mention of the 34 percent increase in emissions of 1,3-butadiene and a possible 9.8 percent increase in smog-forming nitrogen oxides. Arco confirmed the butadiene results Monday, the Los Angeles Times reported in its Tuesday editions. However, the company said the 9.8 percent nitrogen oxide increase was based on unreliable data.
