Butadiene, used in manufacturing some rubber, is a toxic component of tailpipe emissions that is considered less threatening to health than benzene. Emissions of 1,3-butadiene from EC-Premium were measured at 3.3 milligrams per mile, compared to 2.5 milligrams per mile for conventional unleaded premium gasoline. Scientists at the Lovelace Institute in Albuquerque, N.M., and the Health Effects Institute in Cambridge, Mass., said that even with a 34 percent increase, the 1,3-butadiene concentrations were too small to be significant. Dan Townsend, manager of Arco's clean fuels task force, said that despite the increase in butadiene, EC-Premium reduces pollutants overall. ``While the butadiene is up, all of the other toxics are down enough that the overall cancer risk is down by 28 percent,'' Townsend said.

The stock market sputtered higher today, but analysts criticized the bounce as unimpressive because it was linked to a single potential takeover. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 17.57 points at 2,470.54 at midafternoon. But the broader market suffered as losers outnumbered gainers by about 10 to 9 with 748 issues declining, 688 advancing and 489 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 110.21 million shares at 2 p.m. on Wall Street. The Dow climbed higher on the opening but then spent much of the morning struggling to remain in positive territory. Even when the Dow rose, however, the broader market eased. The market drew strength from heavy trading in MCA, whose stock erupted after it was disclosed the company is discussing a possible buyout with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. at a price reported to be between $80 and $90 a share, or as high as $7.5 billion. MCA led the Big Board's most-active list, skyrocketing 21{ to 56. Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. said the news served as ``a tonic to speculators, who had nothing to feed upon for a while.'' Echoing that sentiment, Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president at St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc., noted that for ``the past 10 years, any time merger mania came back in the market, the conclusion is that stocks are pretty cheap.'' But he termed the rally ``puny,'' especially on the heels of Monday's 60-point drop in the Dow. Today's rise is more an indication that sellers are exhausted, he said, that a signal of renewed interest in equities. Separately, the economic outlook dimmed as the government reported a downward revision in second-quarter gross national product figures. Among other actively traded issues, Paramount Communications rode MCA's coattails, rising 2] to 34; Philip Morris was up { at 44]; Chase Manhattan Bank was up | at 11}, and IBM was up ] at 105]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.83 at 168.34. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 0.54 at 312.30.

DOC.HEAD: Satellites Will Expand Communication for Airline Passengers
DOC.TEXT: Communications Satellite Corp. said Tuesday that beginning next year, it will offer telephone and data communications to airlines for use by passengers flying anywhere in the world. The company also is collaborating with Sony to develop a service to display breaking news to passengers on international flights, said Elizabeth L. Young, vice president of Comsat Aeronautical Services. It expects to offer that service by 1991. By the end of next year, Comsat also expects to offer facsimile service to air travelers. Sony Trans Com Inc. will provide the cabin display equipment and Comsat will provide the satellite service. Comsat is a user and 25 percent owner of Inmarsat, the International Maritime Satellite Organization, which operates satellites around the globe for 60 member nations. ``We will be providing a digital news feed of 70 to 75 pages with news type,'' Ms. Young said. GTE Airfone Inc., which supplies telephone services to 1,300 planes flying over the U.S. and Canada, has signed an agreement to use Comsat's ground earth stations in Southbury, Conn., and Santa Paula, Calif., for international flights. The use of satellites will allow communication over oceans. Comsat announced last week that it had signed a long-term agreement under which Aeronautical Radio Inc. will use Comsat satellite facilities for operational and passenger communications to airlines. ``United, Northwestern and American airlines signed,'' Ms. Young said. Other American, European and Asian airlines are planning to equip their planes for data and voice services, she said. Inmarsat will launch the first of four second-generation satellites in October and three more in 1991, she said. Comsat will bear 28 percent of the $650 million cost.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush Hearing Under Way; Witnesses Spar On Fifth Amendment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with second witness refusing to talk volutarily, third witness answering questions. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `The OTS...'. ADDS 4 grafs on end with detail from Murray's testimony. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A hearing on conflict-of-interest allegations against Neil Bush opened today with a judge rejecting a witness' attempt to invoke the Fifth Amendment and offering to take testimony in private. A second witness refused to talk voluntarily and faced a subpoena. The federal Office of Thrift Supervision is trying to bar the president's son from the banking and savings industry. The regulators in February accused Neil Bush of wrongdoing in his former role as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan, which failed in late 1988 at an cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. He could be banned from the banking and savings industry. The president's 35-year-old son, a Denver oil and gas developer, was not present when the hearing began today before a nearly full courtroom. Bush, who adamantly denies wrongdoing, was expected to be the final witness of 11 scheduled to testify this week. After the hearing was called to order today, former Silverado Chairman Michael Wise asserted his Fifth Amendment right to refuse to answer questions on the ground that he could incriminate himself. Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson disagreed that the right could be claimed at such a hearing, saying, ``I do have the authority to require Mr. Wise to answer despite his claim to the Fifth Amendment.'' He then adjoured the opened hearing, and the participants went into a closed session in his chambers. It was not immediately clear whether Wise agreed to testify in private or continued to take the Fifth. Wise left the closed hearing after about a half-hour and would not respond to reporters' questions. Davidson had said that Wise's testimony in his chambers would be on the record and that a transcript would be made available later, probably at the end of today's hearing. Another former Silverado director scheduled to testify, Florian Barth, today gave a letter to OTS lawyers saying he will not testify voluntarily. Davidson promptly announced he would sign a subpoena aimed at forcing Barth's testimony. The open hearing finally got under way with former Silverado executive vice president Russell M. Murray. He answered questions put by Bush's attorney, James Nesland, who attempted to show that Murray was aware that Silverado had guidelines for approving loans and lines of credit to board members. The OTS is seeking an order against Bush banning him from the industry to avoid alleged conflicts of interest. The president has said he will not interfere with the disciplinary process. Last week, Bush and other former Silverado directors were also sued for $200 million by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The lawsuit alleged that gross negligence on the part of Silverado directors contributed to the S&L's collapse. OTS contends Bush failed to disclose adequately to Silverado his business relationships with Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters, two big borrowers from Silverado who defaulted on loans totaling more than $130 million. The two Denver developers helped finance Bush's oil and gas company, JNB Exploration, at the same time Bush voted on the men's requests from Silverado for millions in loans and a line of credit, the OTS has alleged. Bush could have avoided the hearing by agreeing not to dispute the charges, as other S&L officials have done. By fighting the government, he has taken the case out of attorneys' and regulators' offices into a rare public forum. ``The swords are drawn,'' his attorney, James Nesland, said recently. The judge has until Dec. 6 to recommend a ruling to OTS Director Timothy Ryan, who has until April 8 to make a final decision on whether to impose the sanctions. Bush could appeal, most likely to a federal appeals court in Denver. In his testimony today, Murray discussed a $900,000 line of credit that Bush and Denver developer Kenneth Good obtained from the Silverado board in 1986 for an oil and gas exploration partnership in Argentina. The line of credit never was tapped, but the board's approval of the request is one of the conflict-of-interest counts leveled by the OTS against Bush, who voted as a board member on the transaction. Murray said he talked to Good, Bush and Wise about the line of credit and decided to submit the matter to the Silverado investment committee and then to the Silverado board because of Bush's involvement in the deal. ``I knew there were some limitations on loans to officers and directors,'' Murray said.

DOC.HEAD: Ailing Financier Fined in Guinness Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Multimillionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons was fined 3 million pounds, or $5.6 million, Tuesday for his part in the Guinness takeover scandal, but escaped a jail sentence because of ill health. The judge also announced that Guinness Chairman Ernest Saunders, sentenced to five years in the same case, would not have to face a second trial on related charges because the prosecution had decided it would not be in the public interest. At Southwark Crown Court, Judge Sir Denis Henry said Lyons was ``guilty of dishonesty on a major scale'' and could have expected a three-year prison sentence. But after medical testimony that Lyons, 74, had cancer, heart problems, high blood pressure and chronic bronchitis, the judge said he would not send Lyons to jail. Lyons was ordered to pay 440,000 pounds ($831,000) toward government legal costs. Lyons was convicted Aug. 27 on six counts of conspiracy to commit fraud, false accounting and theft. He and three other figures in London's City financial district were charged with organizing an illegal operation to boost the stock market price of shares in Guinness during a successful takeover battle for Distillers Co., a Scotch whisky and gin maker. The Distillers takeover involved buying large blocks of Guinness shares to make them more attractive than those of rival bidder Argyll, a supermarket operator. The prosecution claimed Guinness paid about 25 million pounds ($48 million at the time) in unlawful indemnities against losses in share dealing and in fees for a successful outcome. Lyons bought Guinness shares for himself and clients and was paid more than 3 million pounds ($5.8 million) in illegal success fees and indemnities. He later repaid nearly 2 million pounds (nearly $4 million) of the money he received. The other three tried with Lyons were sentenced earlier. Saunders, 55, chairman and chief executive of the Guinness brewing giant, received five years. Stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 45, was sentenced to 2{ years while Gerald Ronson, 50, received one year and a record fine of 5 million pounds ($9.75 million).

DOC.HEAD: Milken's Lawyers to Judge: Don't Imprison Him, Let Him Work With Kids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typo in Arthur; INSERTS new grafs 3-9 to add quotes, more details, CORRECTS Milken's age to 44; picks up 7th graf pvs, Such sentencing. . .
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's lawyer has asked the judge who will sentence him for fraud to spare the former junk-bond king from imprisonment and let him repent by helping inner-city youth, court papers released today said. ``Such a sentence would constitute a most serious punishment; but it would be purposeful punishment,'' wrote his lead attorney Arthur Liman in a sentencing proposal to U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood. He said Milken could work under the auspices of the Los Angeles Police Department, near the financier's home, and that its chief Daryl F. Gates supported the idea. It would ``not only embody the concept of social restitution, but would also hold him fully accountable and punish him for his behavior in the most appropriate way,'' Liman said. The lawyer also asserted that Milken, 44, already has been punished severely by nearly four years of intense public scrutiny, payment of a record $600 million in fines and penalties and a bleak future fighting civil lawsuits. ``We cannot adequately describe the anguish and devastation that this experience has caused Michael, an intensely private and sensitive individual,'' the memorandum said. ``Everyone who has come into contact with him speaks of his acute pain and suffering.'' Liman's sentencing proposal portrayed Milken as a brilliant, selfless family man who spurned the life of the rich and famous, despite amassing enormous wealth in the securities industry over nearly two decades. ``Michael's passion lies in his ideas. His life has been devoted to seeking value for others ... For Michael, substantial compensation was a by-product of his ideas,'' the defense said. The proposal was hundreds of pages long and was accompanied by lengthy appendices with statements of support from more than 240 people ranging from close relatives and leading business figures to Milken's family rabbi. Milken's lawyer released the sentencing proposal to Wood with less than a week to go before she is scheduled to pronounce punishment for Milken, the most influential financier of the 1980s and the biggest figure to fall in the Wall Street securities fraud scandal that broke in 1986. Such sentencing proposals are usually released on the day a defendant is sentenced. But because of the enormous interest in the Milken case, Wood ordered versions released early, edited to delete incriminating references to others. The government was working to make its version available later. Milken, former head bond trader at the once powerful Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., reversed longstanding claims of innocence and pleaded guilty to six felonies in April. Most of the charges were linked to his relationship with fallen stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky. There has been intense speculation about what sentence will be imposed by Wood, who has been swamped with letters both in support of leniency and heavy punishment. He faces a maximum of 28 years in prison. Wood has given no indication what she will do, but the government has urged her to consider a vast array of unproven crimes Milken allegedly committed. In its reply to the prosecution's sentencing memorandum, the defense argued that the judge should not consider any evidence relating to other alleged crimes. It also asked the court not to punish the financier for the collapse of Drexel or in reaction to his considerable wealth. The defense said the government's strategy of presenting additional allegations prior to sentencing violated Milken's constitutional rights. It also said that imposing a provisional sentence - subject to possible reduction based on the value of Milken's cooperation with the government's continuing investigation of insider trading - would violate both his constutional rights and his earlier plea agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Representative Complains About Northwest Loan
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, who is complaining about European subsidies to Airbus Industrie, finds the jet maker's loan to Northwest Airlines ``particularly disturbing,'' a spokeswoman said Tuesday. In a Sept. 14 letter to the European Community, Hills said she wants ``clarification and information'' about the loan as soon as possible, said spokeswoman Torie Clarke. Hills believes the $500 million loan was an unfair inducement to get Northwest to buy 75 jets built by Airbus, a four-nation European consortium. The United States has threatened to go to an international tribunal, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, with complaints about the $13 billion in government subsidies that Airbus receives. Hills believes the subsidies are unfair to American manufacturers. The loan ``is a new element of concern and the industry is quite concerned,'' Clarke said. Hills has given the EC until Sunday to respond satisfactorily to her complaint about Airbus subsidies, Clarke said. Representatives of Airbus and the EC deny the Northwest loan was unfair. ``The facts as she states in the letter cannot be substantiated,'' said Ella Krucoff, a spokeswoman for the EC delegation in Washington. Alan Boyd, chairman of Airbus' North American division, said the Northwest loan was strictly a commercial transaction financed by private banks. Boyd told the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press that the loan follows a precedent established in 1987 when Boeing Co. bought $700 million in convertible notes from Allegis, then the parent company to United Airlines, as part of a jet sale. Northwest, based in Eagan, Minn., must repay the loan within seven years, Boyd said. He said it is secured with non-Airbus aircraft and parts and the interest rate is not below 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Decides Against Cutting Off Debate on Fuel Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 9 grafs to update with vote, picking up 7th graf pvs: Aides to. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate decided against cutting off debate today on legislation requiring more fuel-efficient cars, a major setback for a bill automakers claim would require them to stop making large cars. The Senate rejected 57-42 a petition asking that the measure be brought to a vote. Sixty votes were needed to cut off debate. The bill would require cars to achieve a fleet average of 35 mpg by 1995 and 40 mpg by 2001. The bill's sponsor, Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., said that eventually would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day. Bryan had said he was optimistic about the legislation's passage and argued the higher automobile fuel efficiency requirements were needed to curb America's thirst for foreign oil. But opponents, led by Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., waged an intense campaign against the measure, maintaining that the tougher fuel economy requirements would lead to the production of smaller cars and increased traffic deaths. The automakers in recent week lobbied intensely against the legislation and auto industry unions sent thousands of telegrams to senators urging the legislation not be approved. The measure's chances all along appeared brightest in the Senate. Even some supporters expressed doubt that the bill would be approved in the House, where it is staunchly opposed by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, through which the bill normally must be channeled. Aides to President Bush have said they would recommend a veto if the bill is approved by Congress. Late Monday, the Senate rejected 49-46 an amendment by Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., that would have provided special unemployment aid for workers who lose their jobs because automakers must shift to producing more fuel-efficient vehicles. Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., a bill cosponsor, said the Simon amendment would ``doom this bill'' because of many senators' opposition to a worker assistance proposal. Meanwhile, an amendment was approved 55-40 to include new incentives for automakers to produce vehicles that can run on alternative fuels such as methanol, ethanol or compressed natural gas. The measure would let manufacturers claim more credits against fuel efficiency requirements if they produce such vehicles. The floor debate Monday centered on whether the high fuel economy requirements would force manufacturers to dramatically reduce the size of their cars and doom the future of the six-passenger family sedan. ``It means smaller cars, it means less safe cars,'' declared Riegle, whose state is home to the major U.S. automakers. Bryan disputed such claims, arguing that higher fuel efficiency can be achieved without sacrificing car size. He noted that auto executives made the same claims in the 1970s when faced with tougher fuel economy requirements. ``That just didn't happen. The six-passenger vehicle is here just as it was before,'' said Bryan.

DOC.NOTE: $adv30
For release Sunday, Sept. 30, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Embattled Trader Faces Federal Charges
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: From the boxing ring to the trading ring, Ray Pace never has been one to back down. But in a federal courtroom that is the venue for his latest confrontation, Pace fights the feeling that he is already whipped. He says it's not because he has no hope of winning his case but because the cost of his defense has nearly wiped him out. ``To see that everything you've saved is gone because of this trial, it's a hard pill to swallow,'' said Pace, an amateur boxer in the Chicago area from 1976 to 1981. Pace, 34, is one of 14 commodity traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange standing trial on charges of defrauding customers while executing their orders in the Merc's busy Japanese yen futures pit. He also is accused of racketeering conspiracy, a charge that carries a maxmimum penalty of 20 years in prison and possible confiscation by authorities of his home and personal property. Pace is not a poor man. For several years before his indictment in August 1989, he could gross more than $1,000 in commissions on a good day working as a broker in the yen pit. But neither is he one of the relatively few millionaire speculators personifying the popular perception of Chicago's commodity traders as high-rolling fat cats with expensive German cars and luxurious homes on the Lake Michigan shore. In an interview in his lawyer's office, Pace said he owns a 1988 Chevy Blazer and his wife Cleo, a real-estate broker, drives a 1988 Cadillac. He said their cars and their three-bedroom home in Westmont, a middle-class suburb not far from his blue-collar hometown of Cicero, are the only assets left to seize in the event of a racketeering conviction. Like many of the total 47 traders and a clerk who were indicted last year on commodity fraud charges in Chicago, Pace contends he is a little fish caught in an indiscriminate FBI net. ``It could have been anybody who was down there filling orders at that time,'' he said. Pace's defense is that he only did what everybody else was doing. Defense attorney Steven Rosenberg told the U.S. District Court jury in an opening statement Sept. 13 that Pace and every other Merc trader routinely violated exchange rules. He said they changed or invented the prices at which customer orders were executed to repay other traders who absorbed their trading errors. Rosenberg said such rule violations did not constitute racketeering, fraud or losses to customers. He said exchange officials tolerated such activities, although they deny it. The son of a factory worker, Pace entered the risky world of commodities trading after a dissatisfying stint as a high school football and baseball coach. During part of that time, he was in the boxing ring. ``I enjoyed it a lot but I just didn't see it financially,'' said the ruggedly handsome Pace, who remains physically fit. ``I was making $13,000 or $14,000 my first year. I didn't know if I wanted to stay in coaching for 25 years to start making some decent money.'' His wife was employed at that time by a commodities trading firm. Another trading company offered Pace a job and he took it. He began in 1982 as a runner, carrying papers between the trading pits and his company's desk on the Merc floor, for $150 a week. Late in 1984, Pace passed a series of exams and received his broker credentials. He took ajob as an assistant to a more experienced broker who belonged to a broker association. Broker associations are groups of independent traders who fill customer orders for the major brokerage houses. They pool a portion of their commissions to pay their shared expenses. Pace's job was to stand next to his employer in the Merc's Swiss franc futures pit, one of the pits that was later infiltrated by FBI agents, and deal him the customer orders. Pace's salary rose to $200, then $300 a week. Most of it went toward the exchange membership, or seat, that he leased through the broker association for about $800 a month. The seat allowed him to trade in the pit. ``I went through five to 10 grand of my own money to stay in business at that time because I wasn't making enough to pay the bills,'' he recalled. By 1988, Pace said he was making enough money from commissions and personal trades to give up his salary. He leased a more prestigious exchange seat for $3,500 a month and moved from the Swiss franc pit to the more active Japanese yen pit. FBI agent Dietrich Volk also was in the yen pit in 1988, posing as corrupt trader Peter Vogel while he secretly recorded conversations among traders inside and outside the pit. Pace was indicted in August 1989 along with 20 other traders from the yen pit, representing about one-fifth of the pit's normal trader population. Seven of them have pleaded guilty to reduced charges. Pace said his income has fallen dramatically since his indictment while legal fees have consumed his life savings. He has dropped back to the less expensive exchange membership and said his wife is seeking work with a steadier income than real estate sales. Pace said he and several other indicted yen traders have continued to fill customer orders despite the exchange's request that they refrain from doing so. But his tradingThree new names were proposed Tuesday for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, including two that do away with the word ``Soviet.'' In a parliamentary debate on the union treaty that is being drawn up between the Kremlin and the 15 Soviet republics, these names were proposed: the Union of Sovereign Socialist States; the Union of Soviet Sovereign Republics, and the Union of Euro-Asian Republics. Rafik Nishanov, chairman of one of the Supreme Soviet's two chambers and an ethnic Uzbek, revealed the names. He said the proposed name change to the Union of Sovereign Socialist States, first reported Sept. 8, came from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Union of Soviet Sovereign Republics came from a group of legislators from Kazakhstan. The Union of Euro-Asian Republics was one entry in a contest organized by radical members of the parliament. The word ``Soviet'' is disliked by nationalist movements in some republics because they consider the Soviets to be invaders who forced them to accept Communist and Russian domination. Nishanov has said a name change may be approved as part of the new union treaty, which is expected to redefine the country as somewhere between a federation and an economic alliance. Action on the treaty is expected before the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Announces Creation of Clearing House for Help to Needy Countries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing to shorten. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, decrying the ``staggering burden'' suffered by many nations because of the Persian Gulf crisis, today announced creation of an international clearing house to coordinate financial help for needy countries. Bush announced the initiative at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Today's session opened with an announcement by World Bank President Barber Conable of emergency plans to help resettle hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. ``Superpower rivalry has dissipated, but the gulf crisis poses an obvious threat to world peace,'' Conable said. In his remarks, Bush said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has had devastating reprecussions, with serious disruptions in trade and the flow of oil, as well as major problems with refugees and displaced workers. ``This staggering burden, which is pressing upon these most seriously affected countries, calls for a generous response from the world community,'' Bush said. He said the United States already has begun to mobilize financial help for front-line states, such as Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, suffering as a result of a loss of trade with Iraq because of sanctions against Baghdad. On a recent trip, Secretary of State James A. Baker III secured promises of $20 billion in military and financial aid. Bush said that ``to transform commitments into concrete contributions,'' he was establishing a Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group ``with the aim of achieving effective, timely and sustained financial support to these most seriously affected countries.'' The group will be under the chairmanship of Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Its members also will include Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Germany, Britain, Italy, France, Japan, Canada, South Korea, the European Community and possibly others. The IMF and World Bank will provide technical advice and support. ``The political leadership of the U.N. must be matched by the economic leadership of the IMF and the World Bank,'' Bush said. Top finance officials from 152 member nations and, for the first time, an invited delegation from the Soviet Union, are attending the meetings. Soviet representatives were not in earlier closed-door, policy-making sessions, but sat toward the back of the hall in the plenary session today. Soviet officials have said informally they want to join all major international lending institutions, but the United States has always opposed Soviet membership in the World Bank or the IMF. ``The bank is not a relief agency,'' Conable said in announcing an emergency assistance program, ``but it can help by financing expenditures for rehabilitation and other services which generate immediate employment and income, while building productive assets.'' ``The World Bank is already taking action,'' he said. ``We have the flexibility to respond quickly in such crises.'' Conable said the bank also is taking other steps. These include speeding up existing loan programs for countries affected by rising oil prices and other results of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. President Bush was to address the finance officials this afternoon. The president planned to call on the IMF to show economic leadership in the gulf crisis to match the political leadership already taken by the United Nations, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Michel Camdessus, IMF managing director, told the delegates they had to face critical questions in dealing with the gulf crisis. They include what policies to adopt to ward off a global recession and how to improve global trade and the international monetary system. ``The crisis in the Middle East has reminded us all that peace is fragile and that economies are always vulnerable,'' Camdessus said. In closed-door sessions of world finance ministers who oversee the institutions, both the bank and the IMF put together plans for helping nations affected by Iraq's takeover of Kuwait and the subsequent rise in oil prices. Details were being worked out, but the two institutions were expected to supply billions of additional dollars to poor countries hurt by the crisis. At a news conference Monday night, Conable declined to say how much assistance the bank or the fund would provide in response to the gulf crisis. ``You tell us how long the crisis is going to last and maybe we can help you on that,'' he said in response to a reporter's question. In the case of refugees, he said, it is difficult to predict how many there might be, with 1 million or more still in Iraq and Kuwait. The refugee workers had traveled to Iraq and Kuwait from surrounding countries and from as far away as Korea and the Philippines. Salaries sent to families at home are a significant source of hard cash for the countries to buy goods abroad. In some countries, the workers will be returning to areas where jobs and housing are scarce. Earlier Monday, the IMF's policymaking interim committee promised in a communique that it would respond on an ``expedited basis'' to the Mideast crisis. Among IMF programs that could be tapped for money is a compensatory fund used in the past to aid nations hit by earthquakes and hurricanes.

DOC.HEAD: TVX Board Backs Sweetened Paramount Bid
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Communications Inc. raised its offer Tuesday for the 17 percent of TVX Broadcast Group Inc. stock it does not own to $9.50 a share from $7.50, and the TVX board of directors recommended the offer. New York-based Paramount already owns 83 percent of TVX stock. TVX owns and operates six independent television stations. The transaction would cost about $63 million, up from $53 million under the initial offer for the roughly 7.1 million shares Paramount does not own. Completion of the transaction is subject to negotiating an acquisition agreement and to approval of TVX shareholders at a yet-to-be scheduled meeting. A special committee of independent TVX directors recommended acceptance of the latest proposal, and the board accepted that recommendation. Paramount, which has extensive holdings in movies and TV show production as well as in publishing, is getting a foothold in the broadcast television business with the TVX purchase. In September 1989, Paramount agreed to buy the 79 percent TVX stake that the investment firm Salomon Brothers held in a deal worth about $140 million. It subsequently bought another 4 percent, and offered in July to buy the remainder at $7.50 a share. TVX's special committee rejected that offer. In national over-the-counter trading Tuesday, TVX rose $1.25 a share to $8.87{. ``With the acquisition of the remaining TVX capital stock, we can now fully realize the outstanding potential of the TVX stations which together have access to nearly 10 percent of the nation's television viewers,'' Paramount said in a statement. The TVX stations are WTXF-TV, Philadelphia; WDCA-TV, Washington, D.C.; KTXA-TV, Dallas; KTXH-TV, Houston; WLFL-TV, Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; and KRRT-TV, San Antonio, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Ousted as Norton Chief Executive
DOC.TEXT: The president and chief executive officer of Norton Co. has been forced from his job less than a week after a French conglomerate completed a $1.95 billion takeover of the abrasives firm. John M. Nelson played a key role in the takeover last spring by Compagnie de Saint Gobain. But he resigned Monday at the first meeting of Norton's new board of directors, saying he did so at the request of the new owner. Michel L. Besson, a longtime Saint Gobain executive, was elected to succeed Nelson. The company said Nelson, who has been with Norton for 31 years, would remain as a consultant. Since 1980, Besson has been vice chairman, president and chief executive officer of CertainTeed Corp. of Valley Forge, Pa., a subsidiary of the Saint-Gobain Group. Norton is the world's leading manufacturer of abrasives and a producer of engineering materials, including advanced ceramics, performance plastics and chemical process products. The firm employs 16,800 people and operates 92 plants in the United States and 19 other countries. Saint Gobain ranks among the top industrial companies in the world, with annual sales of more than $14 billion. It employs 88,000 people and operates 350 plants in the United States and 20 other countries. Amory Hall, a Saint Gobain spokesman, said the French firm asked Nelson to resign because ``they thought it would be best to have one president of the American operations.'' He said he did not expect large scale layoffs at Norton.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Products Company Tightens Procedures Against Takeover Bids
DOC.TEXT: Boise Cascade Corp. said Tuesday it has tightened its procedures to head off unsolicited takeover bids. The Boise-based wood products company announced it has reduced the amount of stock a single person or group can obtain before triggering the compay's shareholder rights plan. Under the revisions, the plan will be triggered if a person or group obtains 15 percent of the company's voting securities, down from 20 percent. ``The revised plan encourages a potential acquirer to negotiate with the board of directors earlier than was likely under the previous plan,'' the company said in a statement. The new plan also lowers from 25 percent to 15 percent the amount of stock ownership that will trigger a process under which stockholders can exercise their right to acquire additional shares of stock at a market value equal to twice the exercise price of the right. Company officials said they adopted the revisions so they could better represent stockholder interests in the face of a takeover bid.

The stock market rallied today as investors focused on blue chip issues at the expense of the broader market. Analysts said the market was ripe for an advance after the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell to a 14-month low in the previous session. But today's gains were spotty, and market watchers doubted the advance would be sustained. Investors prefered blue chip issues because of their ``high visibility of earnings and growth,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst at MKI Securities Corp. But the broader market languished. While investors went bargain hunting, the market drew support from a number of factors, including the possibility that there will be a resolution this week on the budget deficit, a firming bond market the fact that stock prices remained buoyant despite Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's assessment that war could break out at ``any moment'' in the Middle East. Separately, enthusiasm for potential takeover targets was rekindled by hectic trading in MCA, whose stock skyrocketed after it was disclosed the company is discussing a possible buyout with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. at a price reported to be between $80 and $90 a share, or as high as $7.5 billion.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: The Wind Alone Could Meet America's Energy Appetite, a Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Alsomoving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: With oil approaching $40 a barrel, a group of energy visionaries said Tuesday that a study finds America windy enough to provide all the energy the country needs - if only it would harness the breezes. The American Wind Energy Association met in convention to promote wind power - already providing one-tenth of 1 percent of the nation's electricity - as one answer to energy crises like those generated by the upheaval in the Persian Gulf. Dale Osborn, president of U.S. Windpower, Inc., said wind is not only plentiful but also ``environmentally benign'' - abundant, clean, non-polluting and domestic. His California company that has sold 2 billion kilowatt hours of wind-generated electricity since 1982. The turbines wind turns emit no carbon dioxide, the villain in acid rain, and don't contribute to the greenhouse effect, the warming of the atmosphere. At a news conference, Osborn, president-elect of the association, called wind power ``a proven, functioning and ever-increasing economic success.'' The study, conducted for the Energy Department by Pacific Northwest Laboratories, a unit of Battelle Memorial Institute, establishes ``the immense potential of wind energy to meet America's energy needs,'' said Randall Swisher, the organization's executive director. The study said 1.5 percent of the area of the 48 contiguous states has usable winds averaging 16 mph or more at 50 meters above the ground, the wind speed generally needed to produce electricity competitively. That's the average speed of the winds that turn the 15,000 turbines already in commercial use in California, the world's wind energy pioneer. Swisher said North Dakota and Texas together offer enough wind to replace the energy produced by two billion barrels of oil, making each of those states a ``virtual Saudi Arabia of wind.'' If both were fully utilized, they would provide 80 percent of the nation's electricity, he said. The report said California has developed only one-fifth of its areas with 16 mph winds. They produce 2.2 billion kilowatts a year, the equivalent of 3.5 million barrels of oil, somewhat less than half of one day's imports. But California's wind potential is exceeded in 13 other states - North Dakota, Texas, Kansas, Montana, South Dakota, Nebraska, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Minnesota, Iowa, Colorado, New Mexico and Idaho - and equalled in three others, New York, Illinois and Michigan, the study said. Only four states - Alabama, Mississippi, Florida and Louisiana - were found to lack ``commercial wind potential,'' Swisher said. New technology soon will make it possible for winds that blow at an average of only 14 mph winds to produce commercial electricity, Swisher said. He said the report established that - theoretically, at least - the United States has enough harnessable wind to produce 100 billion quadrillion BTUs of energy a year. The country consumes 82 billion quadrillion BTUs. But investment costs and storage and transmission problems are barriers and esthetic concerns rule out some windy landscapes as the sites of wind turbines, Swisher said. So a realistic goal is for wind to provide 10 to 20 percent of the nation's electricity over the next 20 to 30 years, he said. The downside is that wind is ``intermittent'' - it blows on and off - so wind power ``needs to be integrated with other technologies'' to make sure electricity is on hand when it is wanted, he added. But developments in storing electric power are coming along fast enough, he said, ``to render the problem of intermittence irrelevant.'' What's more, said Carl Weinberg, research manager for Pacific Gas and Electric, ``we have learned that utilities can manage energy sources turned off by nature just as well as we manage energy sources turned off by man.'' Osborn said that potentially, at least, wind power could provide all the nation's energy, But he shies from making that claim, he said, because ``our credibility will be challenged. People would say, `There go those wild-eyed Californians again.'''

DOC.HEAD: Iberia Group Given 3-Day Deadline to Make Aerolineas Down Payment
DOC.TEXT: The Spanish airline Iberia and its Argentine partner have three days to come up with a $130 million down payment for the national carrier Aerolineas Argentinas, or lose the bid, the Public Works minister said Tuesday. Minister Jose Dromi told a congressional committee that President Carlos Menem told him to convey that message to the consortium, the private news agency Noticias Argentinas reported. Iberia and the small Argentine airline Cielos del Sur agreed to buy an 85 percent stake in the airline for $130 million in cash plus the assumption of $2 billion in face value of Argentina's foreign debt. The group presented a letter of credit, arguing it did not want to tie up the cash until the government fulfilled it obligation to obtain permission for the sale of a national asset from commercial creditors owed $46 billion. Opponents of the sale, including congressional members, claim the consortium lacks funds and is trying to buy the airline using its own assets instead of new capital. Iberia and Cielos del Sur have acknowledged they intend to sell and then lease back some of Aerolineas' planes to generate revenue.

DOC.HEAD: New-Technology Computer Storage Device Announced
DOC.TEXT: A leading maker of computer data storage systems unveiled a new device Tuesday it says represents the next generation of such technology. The system from EMC Corp. of Hopkinton, Mass., is designed to allow computers to get at information more quickly and reliably than traditional computer storage devices called hard disks. The new storage system, called redundant arrays of inexpensive disks, or RAID, takes up less space than traditional hard disks while providing faster processing speeds and better reliability, EMC said at a news conference here. The device costs $240,000 to $400,000. EMC, a major supplier of storage devices for International Business Machines Corp. computers, said it was introducing its device at least 18 months ahead of similar systems planned by other manufacturers. Traditional mainframe computer storage devices consist of a single ``hard'' disk, a 14-inch magnetic device weighing about 144 pounds. The new EMC technology combines several 5\-inch, 10-pound magnetic disks with a computerized controller that pulls data off the disks and another device that can temporarily store frequently-used data.

DOC.HEAD: Marriott Delays Construction Starts
DOC.TEXT: Marriott Corp. announced Tuesday it will delay construction starts on most of its new projects, including hotels and senior citizens housing units, following a review of its financial position. William J. Shaw, executive vice president and chief financial officer, said Marriott would reduce its capital expenditures by approximately $650 million in 1991, compared to a $1.3 billion outlay in 1990. A statement said the action was taken because a slowing economy had created a glut of hotel rooms. ``We believe this delay .. will provide us with an extra margin of flexibility in the present uncertain financial, real estate and lodging markets,'' Shaw said. The company sold approximately $900 million in assets so far this year, and Shaw said the firm expects to sell another $700 million in assets in the next few months. The company's financial situation has already forced the layoffs of 70 workers at its headquarters. Shaw also commented on a move by Standards & Poor's Corp., on Monday placing certain Marriott single A-minus-rated long term debt on CreditWatch with negative implications. ``Obviously, we're disappointed with...the action,'' Shaw said. ``We have financial flexibility as well as strong, stable cash flow.''

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont, American National Can Sign Recycling Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The Du Pont Co. and American National Can have agreed to cooperate in a recycling program for certain types of plastic. The two companies announced Tuesday they will work to develop a market for recycled syrup and ketchup bottles and other types of rigid plastic materials not now being widely recycled. American National Can will also work with the Plastic Recycling Alliance, a joint venture between Du Pont and Waste Management, Inc., to develop technology to sort various types of plastic for recycling. The efforts are expected to begin next year in Chicago, company officials said. American National Can, based in Chicago, manufactures and markets metal, glass and plastic packaging products. ``Both companies have demonstrated that plastic containers can be recycled and manufactured into new bottles and many other useful products. This alliance between the leading packaging manufacturer and one of the leading plastics producers allows us to work together to accelerate the development of economical and useful end-markets,'' said Jean-Pierre Ergas, chief executive officer of American National Can. ``This partnering effort benefits everyone, including consumers. It adds other types of post-consumer plastic to the mix of those that can be recycled,'' said Archie Dunham, Du Pont vice president for polymer products.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Ahead in U.S.; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar advanced in the United States Tuesday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen, which took center stage on world foreign exchange markets. Gold prices pulled back slightly in domestic dealing but moved sharply higher abroad. Strength in the dollar came largely as a reaction to a selloff Monday against every major currency but the yen. David Marshall, chief currency analyst at MMS International Inc., said the dollar benefited from technical factors linked to cross trading between the yen and the German mark. Comments by an unidentified West German finance ministry official, carried on news services, also sparked yen purchases. Concern about the consequences that rising oil prices could have on the Japanese economy, which depends heavily on imported oil, lately had caused dealers to dump yen mostly in favor of European currencies. In an interview with a small group of reporters, the German government official said the yen could appreciate further against the mark. He also said that he did not foresee a ``free-fall'' in the dollar, a statement that tended to boost demand for dollars. A rebound on Wall Street, combined with a steadying in oil and gold prices in New York, also renewed interest in dollars, Marshall said. The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo with a decline to 136.70 yen from 137.33 yen at Friday's close. Japanese markets were closed Monday for a national holiday. Later, the dollar was quoted at 136.50 yen in London and at 136.70 yen late in New York, down from 137.50 yen late Monday. The British pound lost ground, falling to $1.8765 late in London from late Monday's $1.8810. A pound was quoted at $1.8785 late in New York, down from $1.8805 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.5735 German marks, up from 1.5595; 1.3080 Swiss francs, up from 1.2980; 5.2665 French francs, up from 5.2210; 1.15055 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14975; and 1,177.00 Italian lire, up from 1,167.75. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.5630 German marks, up from 1.5565; 1.2990 Swiss francs, up from 1.2965; 5.2340 French francs, up from 5.2145; 1.7618 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7665; 1,168.25 Italian lire, up from 1,165.50; and, 1.1493 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1483. Precious metals dealers in Europe said their markets were busy but trading was choppy as operators tried to carve out a new trading range followin a surge through $400 an ounce. Dealers said if there is no improvement in the Middle East conflict they expect gold to continue firming. But, after a strong session Monday, gold and silver prices posted modest declines in the United States. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold settled at $402.40 a troy ounce for the September contract, off 60 cents from Monday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $401.25, $1.25 lower than Monday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold closed in London at a bid of $403.25 a troy ounce, up from $396.55. The late Zurich bid was $404.25, up from $392.90. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $405.85, up from Monday's late $389.75. Silver prices finished lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery fell to $4.834 a troy ounce from $4.915 on Monday. Silver bullion closed in London at a bid of $4.87 a troy ounce, down from $4.89 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Workers Fear That This Time, Layoffs May Be Real
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10 pvs, On Tuesday, with 3 grafs to UPDATE with House Appropriations Committee voting to extend deadline 20 days, Bush saying he'll veto any such measure. Picks up 11th graf pvs, Agencies have. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal workers who usually disregard the political rhetoric of the annual budget brouhaha fear the threat of mass furloughs and pay cuts may be real this year. ``People are literally losing sleep over this,'' said Tom Doherty, an Occupational Safety and Health Administration inspector from Allentown, Pa. ``They have kids to feed and house payments to make, and now they're having the rug swept out from under them by the system they work for,'' Doherty said. The cuts, should they occur, would mark the first government-wide furloughs since 1986. Most of the nation's 2.2 million federal employees already have been warned they may be furloughed 22 days or more in fiscal 1991 if Congress and the White House fail to agree on a deficit reduction plan before the Oct. 1 deadline. The forced, unpaid days off would be part of $85 billion in cuts to be triggered Monday by the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law. Additional cuts would follow. The Office of Management and Budget has said the cuts would mean a 32.4 percent spending reduction in non-defense areas. Among those exempt from the cuts would be all presidential appointees, active military personnel and some medical personnel at VA hospitals. ``At first, everybody was like, `Oh, boy, here we go again.' But when you hear President Bush talking about tightening your belt and pitching in, it seems a lot more serious,'' Doherty said. On Tuesday, the House Appropriations Committee ignored President Bush's veto threat voted to delay for 20 days deep spending cuts - including those that could bring the mass furloughs - that will be triggered unless Congress and the White House agree on a deficit-reduction plan. The House is expected to consider the bill later this week. At the White House, an angry Bush told reporters: ``If there is no budget agreement with real spending reductions and real process reform by the end of the week, I will have to veto it.'' Agencies have come up with different layoff plans. Some OSHA offices, for example, would have workers take two days off each week for 11 weeks to get the cuts over with as quickly as possible. Doherty said that would cost him about $568 every pay period through December. Government services, in turn, would be trimmed dramatically. A cutback in air traffic controllers would will mean canceled flights and lengthy airport delays; fewer guards would man the nation's prisons; meat and poultry inspectors would miss shifts; Medicare and Social Security checks could be delayed. ``Right now, a large percentage of federal employees don't believe that it's really going to happen, or that it would only last a day or so if it did because Congress will pass a resolution or something to take care of it,'' said Dwight Bowman, a Smithsonian photographer active in the American Federation of Government Employees. But Bowman said this year's cuts appear more likely in light of the overall state of the nation's economy, the savings and loan crisis and the American military buildup in the Middle East caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``There's just a lot of reasons to think that this is serious,'' Bowman said. Workers, many of whom already feel underpaid and unappreciated, say the possibility of cuts have hurt morale. ``We're responsible for the safety and health of workers in four counties,'' Doherty said. ``It's notsomething you do for just a paycheck, but also because you believe in it. ``When your employer kicks you in the teeth like this, it makes you kind of lose that enthusiasm for what you're doing,'' Doherty said, Rose Seaman, who processes Social Security claims in Akron, Ohio, said budget negotiators don't realize how damaging the cuts will be, especially for couples who both work for the government. Her husband is a federal meat inspector. ``The pay will stop but rent's the same, child care's the same, gas for your car is the same or going up,'' she said. ``This is not a `Poor Rose and George thing.' ... We're just working people out here in the heartland trying to do a job and get paid for it.'' Mike Grotefend, a union leader for federal prison workers based at the 800-inmate facility in Oxford, Wis., said morale there is at an all-time low and that employees ``feel like ... pawns.'' Most prison guards make between $22,000 and $24,000 a year. ``These people have car payments and house payments. The horror stories are already starting to get around,'' he said. ``We're trying to look at providing some relief within the union, but how do you administer something on such a grand scale when you have so little for so many?''

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Acknowledges Flaw In Some Engines
DOC.TEXT: Cracks inside the shafts of 12 Pratt & Whitney PW4000 jet engines have prompted a federal investigation into why the problems occurred and why the flaws were not detected immediately during inspections. Pratt, the jet-engine division of Hartford's United Technologies Corp., publicly acknowledged the potentially disastrous problem Monday after several industry sources alerted The Hartford Courant about the cracks, the newspaper reported Tuesday in a copyright article. The Federal Aviation Administration is expected to release within the next week the findings of its investigation, launched earlier this month after Pratt alerted the agency that cracks had been found. One of the engines had been in service before it was grounded. Pratt spokesman Mark Sullivan would not identify the airline that had used the defective engine. ``(We) expect to present a solution to the industry in the next four to five days,'' said Michael Ciccarelli, spokesman for the FAA's regional office in Burlington, Mass. The defective shafts had cleared inspections at Pratt and at LeFiell Manufacturing Co., the California subcontractor that forged the engine shafts for Pratt, the newspaper said. In addition to the engine that had entered service, two with cracked shafts were shipped to Boeing Co. in Seattle, and one to Airbus Industrie in Toulouse, France, for installation on their jumbo passenger jets. The other eight were in various stages of assembly at Pratt's plants in Connecticut. Most of the cracks were big enough to have been seen with the naked eye. Sullivan said his company sent a letter to all its customers advising them of the cracks. He said Pratt is completing emergency inspections on 174 engines delivered to aircraft builders and air carriers around the world. Most have been inspected, with only the 12 found defective. ``We're confident that we reacted very quickly,'' Sullivan said. ``And we see no problems to our airline customers or their passengers.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rallied Tuesday as institutional investors snapped up blue-chip issues, but analysts dismissed the advance as insignificant. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 32.67 to close at 2,485.64. The move erased roughly half the loss the key barometer registered in the previous session, when it settled at a 14-month low. Advancing issues only slightly outpaced decliners in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 770 up, 745 down and 471 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 155.94 million shares, down from 162.21 million in the previous session. ``It's not the kind (of volume) that suggests there's a stampede into stocks,'' said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at First Albany Corp. Analysts said the market was poised for a rebound given the sharp selloff in the previous session. But Johnson joined a number of other market watchers in characterizing the day's advance as ``puny'' and ``unsustainable.'' As investors focused on blue-chip issues, the broader market languished. ``Given the tentative nature of the rally, a lot more needs to happen before you can say things have turned around,'' Johnson said. A number of factors worked to support quality stocks, namely moderately higher prices in the bond market, where a downward revision in the second-quarter gross national product supported the notion that the Federal Reserve would be encouraged to lower interest rates. In addition, lower oil prices also took some pressure off both the stock and bond markets. Separately, enthusiasm for potential takeover targets was rekindled by heavy trading in MCA, whose stock skyrocketed after it was disclosed the company is discussing a possible buyout with Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. at a price reported to be between $80 and $90 a share, or as high as $7.5 billion. MCA led the Big Board's most-active list, skyrocketing 19{ to 54. The activity in MCA, which had been up as much as 25, spilled over to other entertainment issues. Paramount Communications, the third most-active issue, jumped 3\ to 34~. Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co., said MCA's news served as ``a tonic to speculators, who had nothing to feed upon for a while.'' Among other actively traded Big Board issues, Philip Morris rose 1 to 44~; Chase Manhattan Bank was up ~ at 12; General Electric gained 1[ to 55|, and IBM was up 1] at 106]. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 186.45 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $26.21 billion, or 0.91 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.69 to 169.20. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 4.44 to 363.73, and S&P's 500-stock composite index adfanced 3.67 to 308.26. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.62 to 354.78. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 313.17, up 0.33.

DOC.HEAD: Government Rejects Polly Peck Probe Call
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday turned down a request by Polly Peck International PLC for an official investigation into its share dealings. The company's board made the request in a letter Sunday to John Redwood, parliamentary under-secretary of state at the Department of Trade and Industry, following extensive articles about the company in London's Sunday newspapers. The company's shares crashed 55 percent last Thursday on rumors of a possible Serious Fraud Office investigation into the company. Later that day, company chairman Asil Nadir was interviewed by the office, which investigates and prosecutes cases of serious fraud. On Thursday, the London Stock Exchange agreed to the company's request to halt dealings in its shares, which slumped by 135 pence ($2.50) to 108 pence ($2). The stock has fallen sharply since August after Nadir attempted a buyout of the company and withdrew it after five days. British newspaper reports alleged the share price may have been supported illegally. Redwood said he was satisfied the Serious Fraud Office had the necessary powers to investigate all the allegations ``of which we are aware.''

DOC.HEAD: Reebok Expects Lower Third Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Reebok International Ltd. forecast Tuesday a third quarter drop in profits due to declining U.S. footware sales and higher advertising costs. The sneaker manufacturer said it expects third-quarter earnings to be 33 to 35 cents per share, about 25 percent lower than the 44 cents per share earned the comparable period last year. Sales were off because the company took action to stop its high-priced sneakers from ending up in discount stores, said chief executive Paul Fireman. Distribution problems with The Pump model this year hurt sales and raised expenses, said Richard Newman, executive vice president of Investor Access Corp. in New York. The sneaker allows the wearer to pump air into the shoe. Newman said company officials estimated that cutting off sales to ``diverters'' - buyers who send Reebok shoes to discount outlets - will cost the company about $20 million in the third quarter. Delays in shipping The Pump resulted in another $20 million loss in sales, he said. The company said it expects sales to rebound in the next quarter. The backlog of orders is up 15 percent over the past five months compared to the same period in 1989, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Wraps Up 100th Anniversary Convention
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Closer inspections and stiffer penalties await coal mine operators who fail to emphasize safety, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said Tuesday. Mrs. Dole issued the warning on the final day of the United Mine Workers' 100th anniversary convention. She said her agency is using a new computer program to target mines with a high risk of explosion or fire. She also said inspectors from the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration have orders to pinpoint companies that ``continue to endanger their workers despite repeated warnings.'' Mine managers who fail to maintain a safe and healthful workplace, ``believe me, will run afoul of the Department of Labor,'' Mrs. Dole said. ```MSHA, after all, was chartered to be an enforcement agency, not a guidance counselor.'' Prior to adjournment, UMW President Richard Trumka announced contract negotiations will resume Oct. 3 between the union and Decker Coal Co. in southern Montana. About 220 Decker workers have been on strike for three years. The talks will be the first in two years. Union miners praised Mrs. Dole for helping to settle the 10-month Pittston strike this year. As part of the settlement, she appointed a special commission to offer solutions to the UMW's troubled health care program for retired miners. She had little to say about the commission's findings. A final report is expected next month. The 1,000 UMW delegates have been meeting at the Fountainebleau Hotel since Sept. 17. Before heading home, miners were urged ``to get up out of the trenches and get offensive and attack and get going.'' United Steelworkers President Lynn Williams also reinterated the convention's theme: solidarity. By sticking together, organized labor can rebound from the 1980s, when Reagan administration policies sent many unions into retreat. The convention ended with a concert of mine-related songs, including ``Which Side Are You On'' and ``Solidarity Forever.''

DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales Up In August
With AM-GNP, Bjt. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes rose 2.1 percent in August, continuing an upward trend that began in June, a real estate trade group said Tuesday. The National Association of Realtors said home resales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.40 million units compared to July's revised 3.33 million rate. Sales rose 0.9 percent in June from the 1990 low of 3.30 million units in May. But mortgage rates jumped back into double digits in August. Realtors chief economist John A. Tuccillo predicted rates would continue to rise during most of the fourth quarter, having a negative impact on sales. Realtors President Norman A. Flynn attributed any strength to ``people who are buying homes in less populous areas and recreational areas.'' According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage rates rose from an average of 9.84 percent to 10.24 percent in August. They averaged 10.16 percent at the end of last week. The Realtors also said the national median existing-home price was $97,000 in August, down 1.3 percent from July but up 1.3 percent from a year earlier. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Sales rose in the South and Midwest, but fell on both coasts. They were up 6.9 percent to 1.40 million units in the South, where the median price was $86,900. They rose 2.2 percent to 950,000 units in the Midwest. The median price there was $75,000. But in the Northeast, where housing activity has been sluggish for months, sales fell 1.8 percent to 550,000 units. The median price in the Northeast was $144,900. They dropped 3.8 percent to 530,000 units in the West, where the median price was $141,600.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Curbs Corporate Securities Issues
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis put a further damper on the already depressed market for new issues of corporate securities in the third quarter, a business research firm said Tuesday. Initial public offerings of common stock fell to $1.5 billion from June through September, their lowest level in five years, according to Securities Data Corp. That brought the nine-month tally of IPOs to $8.4 billion, down 13 percent from 1989's slow pace. The volume of all common stock issues for the first three quarters totaled $16 billion, only $1 billion ahead of the slack volume of a year earlier. Securities Data did not provide figures for the third quarter alone. The New Jersey-based company attributed the slump to Middle East tensions that caused oil prices to soar and stock and bond prices to plunge and made investors wary of the financial markets. The volume of new issues of corporate debt excluding mortgage and asset-backed securities also fell, Securities Data said, attributing the slide not only to the Persian Gulf conflict but also to the growing federal deficit, increased levels of defaults on loans and higher interest rates. For the first nine months of the year, $72.1 million in debt was issued, down 28 percent from a year earlier. Securities Data did not provide figures for the third quarter alone. The analysis also ranked underwriters of corporate securities by volume. Merrill Lynch & Co. led all other investment firms during the first nine months, underwriting nearly $35.3 million in U.S. securities. Goldman Sachs & Co., with nearly $29.6 million in underwritten securities was ranked second, with First Boston Corp. third with nearly $23.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Commonwealth Edison Agrees to One-Year Franchise Extension
DOC.TEXT: Commonwellth Edison Co. agreed Tuesday to a one-year extension of its franchise to provide electricity to Chicago customers, company officials said. Edison's old contract expires Dec. 31, but a string of power failures have raised questions about the utility's reliability as it has been trying to negotiate its first new franchise with Chicago in 42 years. ``While we had hoped to reach agreement on a new franchise before Dec. 31, an extension will preserve what we believe is already the best set of benefits held by any major city in the country,'' Edison Chairman James J. O'Connor said in a prepared statement. The extension will ensure Edison's continued payment of its municipal franchise fee of 4 percent of the company's gross revenues. The 1990 payment is estimated at $66 million, O'Connor said. Chicago Mayor Richard Daley expected the move and was pleased that the utility agreed to continue dialogue while the Illinois Commerce Commission and the city investigate recent power failures, said Daley spokeswoman Carolyn Grisko.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Holds Own Despite Oil's Drop
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices held nearly steady Tuesday despite a drop in energy prices and similar reversals in other markets that usually are regarded as signposts for the precious metals. Silver and platinum futures fell sharply, though, lending support to the growing perception that gold is losing its traditional appeal as a store of value during times of rising consumer prices and international political turmoil. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures were mostly lower, and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gold futures settled 50 cents to 70 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September at $402.40 a troy ounce. Silver futures ended 8 cents to 8.8 cents lower with September at $4.834 a troy ounce. Platinum futures fell $7.70 to $8.90 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where the contract for September delivery finished at $451 a troy ounce. Analysts had no problem explaining the declines in silver and platinum as reactions to the government's report that the economy grew at a barely perceptible 0.4 percent annual rate in the second quarter. The white metals are used in a variety of manufactured products, so the report of unexpectedly slow growth led to expectations for reduced silver and platinum consumption, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Harder to assess was gold's relatively strong performance in light of sharply lower oil prices, sharply higher stock prices and a stronger dollar vs. European currencies - all reversals of the factors that were viewed as contributing to gold's strong advance Monday. John Jonat, a precious metal trader with the New York-based metal and currency dealer Deak International Inc., said gold's stubbornness was further evidence of a change in investor attitudes toward the metal. But he and others were at a loss to define what Jonat called ``a new school'' of thought about gold. Some believe investors are turning to other markets as safe havens against inflation. Some concede they just don't know. ``It's a real confusing market to call,'' Jonat said. ``Something's changing here - it's not the same old rules.'' Prices for near-term deliveries of crude oil and petroleum products fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange as the likelihood of war in the Middle East seemed to fade. After the close, the American Petroleum Institute released a weekly report that confirmed perceptions of a decline last week in U.S. supplies of crude oil and an increase in heating oil stocks. Gasoline stock rose by more than 5 mllion barrels, which exceeded expectations. Light sweet crude oil settled 72 cents lower to 1.25 cents higher with the November contract down 72 cents at $37.53 a barrel; heating oil was 2.72 cents lower to 3.11 cents higher with October down 2.72 cents at $1.012 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.18 cents lower to .76 cent higher with October down 2.18 cents at $1.0205 a gallon. Cattle futures extended Monday's losses on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid ideas that demand for beef will slow if the economy weakens further. Hog futures also fell, largely reflecting profit-taking after last week's strong gains. Live cattle were .02 cent to .70 cent lower with October at 78.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .23 cent to .55 cent lower with September at 89.02 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .45 cent lower with October at 54.80 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 56.52 cents a pound. Soybean futures rose but most corn and wheat futures fell in a lackluster session on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat settled 1} cents lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.74} a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.27} a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2\ cents higher with December at $1.14{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 6 cents higher with November at $6.17{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: New CNN President To Join Turner Board
DOC.TEXT: Tom Johnson, the new president of Cable News Network, has been nominated to join the board of CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting System, TBS board chairman Ted Turner said Tuesday. Johnson's election to the board was expected Wednesday, Turner said in a statement. Johnson succeeded Burt Reinhardt as president of Atlanta-based CNN on Aug. 1. He is a former publisher of the Los Angeles Times.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Steel Maker Cited For Contempt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. magistrate fined Nippon Steel Corp. $10,000 for failing to disclose information in Allegheny Ludlum Corp.'s patent lawsuit against the Japanese steel maker, Allegheny Ludlum said Tuesday. Allegheny Ludlum has accused Nippon Steel of infringing on Allegheny Ludlum's patent for melting and heating a high-grade, magnetic steel used in electricity transformers and generators. The civil trial is scheduled to begin in November in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia. U.S. Magistrate Edwin Naythons ruled Nippon was in contempt of court for violating an order requiring Nippon to produce information related to the case, Allegheny Ludlum said. Nippon has until Oct. 5 to pay the fine. ``A contempt finding is rare, particularly against a foreign corporation,'' said Allegheny Ludlum attorney John Williams. The high-grade steel patent Allegheny Ludlum is seeking to protect in the lawsuit accounted for $200 million of the company's $1.2 billion in 1989 sales, said company spokesman Bert Delano.

DOC.HEAD: Many Buyers Ignoring Fuel Economy for `Fun' Cars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, The Persian, with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Senate blocking legislation to increase gas mileage. Picks up 9th graf pvs, Joan Claybrook. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Auto Mileage-Best & Worst; BC-EPA Mileage List, moved in advance on Sept. 21 as b0245-b0262.
DOC.TEXT: Janice Walsh was eager to take the Nissan 300ZX for a test drive. Like many potential buyers, she wants ``a car that's fun,'' regardless of its gas mileage. Automakers are giving her what she wants. Mileage statistics for 1991 model cars released Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Agency show virtually no gains in average fuel efficiency since 1987 with more than half the cars getting fewer than 23 miles per gallon. While midsize and many of the ``performance'' cars such as the Nissan 300ZX are getting much better mileage today than a decade ago, the EPA said ``overall fleet fuel economy figures have increased only slightly'' since 1982. Over the last five model years, the average fleet figures have been stuck at about 28 mpg. The EPA said the 1991 models about to be introduced average 28.1 mpg, a shade higher than last year, but no better than figures for 1987. Down the road from where Ms. Walsh and her young son eyed the Nissan that gets 18 mpg in the city, John Webb and his wife looked over a Mercury Grand Marquis - a big car with a V-8 engine and a cavernous trunk. ``When we travel we want a good size car and lots of trunk space,'' said Webb, a retiree who says the Marquis fits the bill although its city mileage is a thirsty 17 mpg. ``We really haven't talked about mileage,'' Webb said. The Persian Gulf crisis has prompted renewed efforts in Congress to require automakers to improve fuel economy. But Tuesday, the Senate voted 57-42 to block legislation that would require automakers to dramatically increase the average mileage of their fleets to 40 mpg by 2001, a 40 percent increase from today's average of about 28 mpg. The vote ended any chance the bill will pass this year. President Bush had threatened to veto the bill if it had cleared Congress and there was formidable opposition in the House as well. Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen and a frequent critic of the auto industry, accused automakers of pushing ``bigger engines, more muscle and acceleration which they call performance'' instead of trying to make cars more fuel efficient. ``They want to sell speed instead of fuel economy,'' said Clarence Ditlow, head of the Washington-based Center for Auto Safety. ``The performance cars are the higher priced cars and the ones with more options and more profits.'' But those in the auto business say they're only giving the customer what he or she wants. ``It's not the industry pushing performance. It's the consumer that's been demanding it in the last few years,'' argues Ray Turk, the Nissan salesman at Herb Gordon AutoWorld in suburban Maryland where Ms. Walsh was shopping. As in previous years, the 1991 models reflected a wide range of mileage from the minicompact Geo Metro that gets 58 mpg on the highway and only slightly less in city driving to the luxurious two-seater Lamborghini Diablo that guzzles at 9 mpg on city streets. In between are about 1,000 models and variations of models of cars, trucks and vans. The EPA list includes only 35 cars subject to a gasoline ``guzzler'' tax that kicks in for cars getting 22.5 mpg or less and in the case of the Lamborghini Diablo amounts to $3,200. But those numbers may be misleading. For tax purposes, only the raw fuel economy test scores are used, not the lower EPA figures that are adjusted through a mathematical formula to better reflect actual driving conditions. Increasingly popular passenger vans, speciality vehicles and trucks also are excluded. Using the adjusted EPA figures, more than half the cars listed showed a fuel economy of fewer than 22.5 mpg with the average mileage for increasingly popular passenger vans and 4-wheel drive speciality vehicles coming in at fewer than 20 mpg. Four of the 10 cars with the best fuel economy were variations of the Geo, a Japanese-built car sold through General Motors.
