The others were two variations of the Honda Civic, two versions of the Suzuki Swift, the Daihatsu Charade and the diesel-powered Volkswagen Jetta, all with mileage estimates of between 37 mpg and 49 mpg in the city and 43 mpg to 52 mpg on the highway. At the other extreme were the Lamborghini Diablo, five versions of the Rolls-Royce, two BMWs and a pair of Ferraris. None of the 10 vehicles achieved more than 12 mpg in city driving. According to industry figures, those worst and best performers account for only a small fraction of the vehicles likely to be on the nation's highways. The industry estimates cars that get better than 40 mpg account for less than 3 percent of sales, while the luxury cars that make up the worst mileage performers are far fewer in number. Energy conservation advocates and environmentalists said the latest figures demonstrate the failure of the auto industry to push fuel economy in marketing and research.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Matsushita In $7 Billion Buyout Talks with Entertainment Giant MCA
With AM-MCA-Profile and BC-MCA-Glance
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: A huge Japanese electronics concern said Tuesday it is negotiating to buy entertainment giant MCA Inc. in a deal valued at $7 billion, the latest move in Hollywood globalization. The proposal by Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. also demonstrates anew the foreign craving for American trophy holdings. The merger, if completed, would mirror the 1989 acquisition of Columbia Pictures Entertainment by Japan's Sony Corp. for $5 billion, which includes the assumption of debt. One of the world's largest electronics manufacturers, Matsushita makes video equipment and audio and visual components under the brand names Panasonic, Technics and Quasar. MCA owns Universal Pictures (``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial''), a record and book publishing division (Guns N' Roses, ``Clear and Present Danger''), theme parks, real estate and a robust television division (``Quantum Leap,'' ``Major Dad''). In Japan, a Matsushita official who spoke on condition of anonymity said MCA was one of the companies with which Matsushita is involved in talks, but said nothing had been decided. He said he could not comment further. Later, MCA issued a statement in which it confirmed it is ``in discussions with a major international company regarding a possible negotiated acquisition of MCA. ``The discussions are continuing on a friendly basis. No agreement has been reached. There is no assurance that an agreement will be reached,'' the statement said. Two MCA board members said in interviews that they could neither confirm nor deny that a deal with Matsushita was being discussed. MCA President Sidney Sheinberg did not return telephone messages. In Tuesday's edition, the Wall Street Journal said Matsushita was offering between $70 and $80 a share for MCA stock, or a range of about $6.7 billion to $7.5 billion for the conglomerate. Stock in MCA Inc., which struck a 52-week low of $34.12{ in trading Monday, surged $19.25 Tuesday, or more than 57 percent, to $53.75. Other entertainment stocks also advanced in trading, with Paramount Communications up $3.12{ to $34.75 a share. The new enterprise would merge Matsushita's prominent entertainment hardware division with MCA's profitable movie and television divisions. ``The long-term advantages are that when you make hardware you can benefit from the software producer's success,'' said Jeffrey Logsdon, an entertainment analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities. ``There's an insatiable consumer demand for entertainment software.'' Logsdon speculated that other suitors might follow Matsushita's bid. U.S. entertainment companies offer wise investments for all purchasers, especially foreign investors with surplus cash. Entertainment is the United States' second leading export behind aerospace, accounting for a net positive trade balance of more than $5 billion a year. More than a quarter of Matsushita's revenues are generated by sales of video equipment. Audio and electronic components combine for another 22 percent of revenues. The company had revenues of about $44.4 billion in the year ended March 31. If completed, the MCA buyout would surely renew criticism of Japanese control of American assets that surfaced last year in the deals for New York's Rockefeller Center and Columbia Pictures Entertainment. The Japanese had been keeping a low profile in such transactions until a Tokyo golf tycoon purchased the Pebble Beach golf resorts in California for about $950 million. The merger also might face regulatory barriers. MCA owns independent television station WWOR in Secaucus, N.J., which a foreign company would be prevented from owning. Michael Ovitz, the head of the talent agency Creative Artists Agency Inc., has represented Matsushita in its attempts to find a software counterpart. A CAA spokesman said Tuesday it was premature to speculate if Ovitz would have any role in the new enterprise. Ovitz served as an adviser to Sony in its purchase of Columbia, and Columbia discussed with him the possibility of running the studio. Since its purchase, Columbia has floundered and has yet to release any box-office blockbusters. The new studio managers, Jon Peters and Peter Guber, inherited a production wing with few projects in the works. The two immediate beneficiaries of the sale would be MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman, who owns about 7 percent of MCA's shares and, with other officers, has control of about 11.6 percent of its stock, and record producer David Geffen, who sold his record label to MCA in May for $550 million. Geffen collected 1 million shares of preferred stock, convertible to 10 million shares of MCA common stock, or 12 percent of the company, in the transaction. The Journal said Matsushita wants to keep MCA management in place. MCA earned $191.77 million on revenue of $3.38 billion last year, a 16 percent increase over earnings of $164.91 million and $2.9 billion in revenue during 1988. In its most recent quarterly earnings, the entertainment giant earned $44.8 million, up 7 percent from $41.9 million during the same period in 1989. At the end of last year, MCA had approximately 17,000 employees. Universal Pictures, the company's motion picture subsidiary, is known as one of Hollywood's more daring studios. Its films include the X-rated ``Henry and June,'' Spike Lee's films, the boycotted ``Last Temptation of Christ'' and a variety of stylish horror titles. While the studio has not produced and released many recent blockbusters, its film library is loaded. The titles include ``E.T. the Extraterrestrial,'' the all-time box office champ with a domestic gate of $400 million and the best-selling video ever with more than 15 million cassettes sold. Other hits in the MCA vault include ``Jaws,'' ``Back to the Future'' and its two sequels, ``The Sting,'' ``Twins,'' ``National Lampoon's Animal House'' and ``American Graffiti.'' These films continue to generate revenues in ancillary markets such as television and home video. MCA-Universal Home Video has 500 titles in its library, including some pre-1948 Paramount titles. Universal Television produces the shows ``Murder, She Wrote,'' ``Quantum Leap,'' several ``Columbo'' movies, the comedies ``Coach,'' ``Major Dad'' and ``Uncle Buck'' and the dramas ``Over My Dead Body'' and ``Law & Order.'' Universal Studios Hollywood was the nation's third most popular theme park in 1989, drawing 5.1 million visitors. The company's theme parks have received some bad publicity recently. MCA's $650 million, 3-month-old amusement park in Orlando, Fla., has been bothered by an array of mechanical problems with some of its rides, and the company has sued the designer of the park's ``Jaws'' and ``Earthquake'' attractions.

DOC.HEAD: H. Laurance Fuller Named Amoco Chairman; Mobil Vice Chairman Retires
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Corp. President H. Laurance Fuller will succeed Richard M. Morrow as chairman and chief executive officer of the oil, chemical and natural-gas company at the end of February, Amoco announced Tuesday. Meanwhile, Mobil Corp. said Vice Chairman Richard F. Tucker, who is also president of Mobil Oil Corp., will retire May 1, 1991. Morrow, Amoco's chairman and CEO since 1983, will retire upon reaching age 65 as previously announced, the company said in a statement. Fuller, 51, will retain the title of president, a position he has held since 1983. Fuller, a native of Moline, Ill., joined Amoco in 1961 after graduating with a degree in chemical engineering from Cornell University. He also has a law degree from DePaul University. He worked in Amoco's engineering, law, refining, marketing and supply operations and became president of Amoco Oil Co., the company's petroleum refining, marketing and transportation subsidiary, in 1978. Fuller serves on the boards of directors of Chase Manhattan Corp., Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., Abbott Laboratories and the American Petroleum Institute. Morrow, a West Virginia native, joined Amoco through the company's Amoco Production Co. subsidiary in 1948. He was elected president of Amoco Corp. in 1978. Morrow is a director of First Chicago Corp., First National Bank of Chicago, Westinghouse Electric Corp., R.R. Donnelley and Sons Co., Potlatch Corp. and the American Petroleum Institute. Amoco was the nation's seventh-largest producer of crude oil last year, the second-largest producer of natural gas and the largest owner of natural gas reserves in North America. Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., said Tucker would retire at the end of his three-year term as a director. Allen E. Murray, chairman and chief executive officer of Mobil, also said Tucker will conduct a review of the oil giant's business environment. The review, beginning Oct. 1, will include ``major changes that will influence Mobil's future direction,'' Murray said, citing turbulence and uncertainty facing the industry due to a range of issues, from the Middle East crisis to environmental concerns. Tucker ``will consult widely with government and industry leaders throughout our areas of operations to assure that we have the broadest possible access to informed views on the outlook for Mobil's core businesses,'' Murray said.

DOC.HEAD: Kerr-McGee to Sell 95 Retail Properties in Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Kerr-McGee Refining Corp. will sell 95 company-operated retail properties in the Southeast in order to concentrate marketing efforts in the Midwest, the company said Tuesday. ``We want to focus future retail growth where we have brand recognition,'' said Myron Cunningham, a spokesman for the energy and chemical company. The properties to be sold include 52 operating stations, 31 closed stations and 12 undeveloped sites in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee. Cunningham said money from the sales will be used to build and acquire additional retail units in the company's primary branded marketing area, where the company continues to emphasize both branded wholesale and retail operations. That includes the Midwest and certain Texas markets. He said Kerr-McGee and its Triangle Division would continue to expand unbranded wholesale operations in the Southeast and other states where the company markets wholesale petroleum products.

DOC.HEAD: USX Names New Steel Division Chief
DOC.TEXT: Thomas J. Usher on Tuesday was appointed president of USX Corp.'s U.S. Steel division. Usher succeeds Thomas C. Graham. The company's board voted Tuesday to name Graham to the new post of vice chairman of the company's Steel & Diversified Group. USX spokesman William Keslar said the change was ``simply a matter of transition'' because Graham, who joined USX in 1983, will retire in about a year. ``You want to season a new guy into the new job,'' Keslar said. Usher, a native of Reading, was named executive vice president of heavy products in 1986. Also Tuesday, Charles C. Gedeon was appointed president of the USX's U.S. Diversified Group and senior vice president of raw materials for U.S. Steel.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades Chase Manhattan Debt
DOC.TEXT: Moody's Investors Service on Tuesday downgraded the credit rating of Chase Manhattan Corp., citing concern about the deterioration of the bank's real estate loan portfolio. Moody's, one of the two major credit rating agencies, said Chase's announcement Friday that it would halve its dividend this quarter and boost its bad-loan reserves were positive steps for the nation's second-largest bank. However, Moody's said it was concerned by ``the continuing growth in Chase's non-performing real estate assets.'' Moody's also said it was troubled by the deteriorating Northeast economy and the bank's exposure to commercial real estate loans, Third World debt and loans that went to high-debt corporate buyouts. Moody's added that the bank's basic financial structure remained sound. ``We are disappointed in the downgrade,'' said Chase spokesman Fraser Seitel. ``We don't think it's justified. ``The actions we took on Friday were designed to strengthen the institution, and even after those actions our capital today exceeds $11 billion and our capital ratios exceed the federal guidelines that take effect in 1992,'' he said. Moody's downgraded by one notch the long-term debt rating and commercial paper rating of Chase and several of its subsidiaries. About $8.4 billion in long-term debt was affected, Moody's said.

DOC.HEAD: Appointments At Shearson
DOC.TEXT: J. Tomilson Hill was named vice chairman and co-chief executive officer of Lehman Brothers, one of several executive appointments Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. announced Tuesday. Hill, 42, and Richard S. Fuld Jr., president and co-chief executive officer of Lehman Brothers, will oversee investment and merchant banking, capital market sales and trading and international activities. Lehman Brothers was formed in August as the investment banking arm of Shearson Lehman Brothers. The reorganization was directed by American Express Co., which owns Shearson. Hill succeeds Sherman R. Lewis Jr., who served as Lehman Brothers' co-chief executive officer. Lewis will become vice chairman of Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., the investment firm's parent company. Hill, Lewis and Fuld were elected to the board of directors of Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings. Also named to the board were Jonathan S. Linen, president and chief executive officer of the Shearson Lehman Brothers division, the firm's retail investment operation; and Ronald J. Yoo, vice chairman of Shearson Lehman Brothers. The company also announced Fredrick Frank was appointed chairman of investment banking group's executive committee. Frank was senior managing director.

Percentage changes in sales are based on average daily sales during each period rather than comparisons of straight totals. There were nine selling days in the period this year and nine selling days last year, and 222 selling days so far this year, compared with 221 selling days in the corresponding period a year earlier. Cars and trucks made in the United States by Honda, Nissan, Toyota, Mazda, Subaru, Isuzu and Mitsubishi are counted as domestic and appear in this table separately and combined as transplant cars. Cars and trucks imported for sale under the GM, Ford and Chrysler names are counted as foreign. Sales of imported cars and trucks are reported at the end of each month.

DOC.HEAD: Roadway Services Reports Nearly $11 Million Rise in Net Income
DOC.TEXT: Roadway Services, Inc., on Tuesday reported a 46 percent increase in net income in the third quarter as customers fearful of a strike at rival UPS boosted revenues. Roadway reported net income of $34.5 million, or 88 cents per share, on revenues of 703.5 million in the quarter that ended Sept. 8. In the same period last year, the company reported net income of $23.4 million, or 60 cents per share, on revenues of $623.3 million. The quarter's results reflected a surge in demand during late July and early August because of shippers' concern over the potential for a work stoppage at United Parcel Service, the company said. ``While felt to some degree at our LTL carriers, the impact was most significant at Roadway Package System, our small package specialist,'' said Joseph M. Clapp, Roadway chairman and president.

DOC.BYLINE: Shearson Lehman Settles Futures Rules Violation Charges ^By JOHN M. DOYLE
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street giant Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. settled administrative charges with federal futures regulators Tuesday and agreed to pay $220,000 in fines for allegedly letting a customer break the rules. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Shearson and two employees agreed to settle an administrative action by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission charging numerous alleged rules violations. In another CFTC administrative action, three floor brokers at the Commodity Exchange in New York were accused of defrauding customers in silver futures trading. The defendants have not settled in that case. In the Shearson case, the CFTC accused the securities firm - which is also a registered futures commission firm - of aiding or allowing a customer to violate exchange limits on how many open contracts in orange juice futures could be traded by one person who is speculating rather than hedging. A speculator trades commodity futures to profit from anticipating price movements while a hedger tries to minimize risk by taking offsetting positions in both the cash and futures markets. The CFTC charged that Shearson and Charles M. Barley, an account executive at Shearson's Winter Park, Fla. office, allowed or assisted a Brazilian trader violate speculative position limits for frozen concentrated orange juice futures on the orange juice section of the New York Cotton Exchange. The trader, Horst J. Happel, of Sao Paulo, general manager of Citrosuco Paulista S.A., a Brazilian frozen orange juice processor, also was charged in the CFTC administrative action. He has not settled with the agency. Shearson and the manager of the Winter Park office, Gerald W. Helmich, were accused of improper supervision. Barley, of Windermere, Fla., agreed to pay a $35,000 fine and a 30-day suspension of his registration. Helmich, of Longwood, Fla., agreed to a two-week ban from supervisory work. In addition to the $220,000 civil penalty, Shearson agreed to improve its record-keeping procedures. In the other action, the CFTC accused Craig H. Bell, of Muttontown, N.Y.; Mark B. Dickstein and George J. Fox Jr., both of New York of engaging in 19 non-competitive trading in silver futures between march and October 1987. They were among the latest individuals named in administrative actions stemming from a federal investigation last year into potential trading abuses at some of the commodity futures exchanges in New York's World Trade Center. ``It is not the first one and we do not expect it to be the last,'' said Dennis Klejna, chief of the CFTC's Enforcement Division.

DOC.HEAD: Portions of Milken Sentencing Documents Released By Defense
With AM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from a sentencing memorandum by Michael Milken's defense lawyers to U.S. District Judge Kimba M. Wood, released Tuesday in advance of his scheduled sentencing on Oct. 1. The memorandum outlines Milken's personal background, business activities at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the nature of his offenses, a proposal to sentence him and a rebuttal to government charges to which he hasn't pleaded guilty.
DOC.HEAD: PERSONAL BACKGROUND
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's unusual talents and compassion became obvious at an early age. By the first grade, Michael could perform complicated multiplications in his head, and he received the highest grades in his classes. . . . Michael's work ethic also became evident at an early age. Beginnning at the age of 10, Michael helped in his father's accounting office - at first, sorting checks and performing ministerial functions; later, reconciling checkbooks and assisting in the preparation of tax returns. . . . By the time Michael was 30, he had earned vast sums of money. But as everyone who knows him confirms, the accumulation of money and material goods has never motivated Michael. . . . Until the publicity surrounding this investigation began, not even his closest friends and colleagues had any idea of the extent of his wealth or, for that matter, the vast sums of money Michael gave away to charities. In stark contrast to the ``rich and famous'' lifestyles led by other financiers, Michael eschewed conspicuous consumption. He lives in a comfortable but not extravagant home in Encino . . . His children receive a weekly allowance. He prefers to spend his evenings with his family. . . . Michael is actively involved in all aspects of his children's life. He helps his children with their homework. He rarely misses a school function or a doctor's appointment. Michael has even coached his boys' basketball teams. . . . As the court can well imagine, Michael's greatest punishment is his knowledge that, by virtue of his offenses, his children have suffered greatly and are living with the nightmare that they may become separated from their father who has been a continual presence throughout their lives and upon whom they are deeply dependent. . . . Michael Milken will live for the rest of his life with the knowledge that he has inflicted enormous emotional and physical pain upon his wife and his children whom he loves more than anything else in the world. For him, this punishment is more severe than any this court could possibly impose. . . . Michael has immersed himself in philanthropy, having volunteered thousands of hours to assist charities and community organizations around the world. . . . Michael Milken's lifetime of charitable work cannot negate his criminal conduct. But it can serve to underscore that his offenses stand in sharp contrast to the philanthropic values he has displayed throughout his life.
DOC.HEAD: HIS HARD WORK
DOC.TEXT: Michael strove, through the use of innovative capital structures, to provide financing to companies previously denied access to capital. The sincerity of Michael's business beliefs and the goals he set for himself are central to an understanding of both the offender and the context in which the offenses occurred. . . . By 1985, Michael's business day was devoted both to supervising the numerous researchers, traders and salespersons in the multibillion-dollar high-yield department and to talking on the phone and meeting with scores of customers and other Drexel employees regarding the underwriting of millions of dollars of new securities. His day began at approximately 4:30 a.m. and ended at approximately 7 p.m. . . . Some have suggested that Michael Milken should be punished less for his offenses than for his role in pioneering high-yield finance. Such suggestions are not only improper, they are misguided as well. People are perfectly entitled to call high-yield securities ``junk bonds'' just as they are free to call shareholder rights plans ``poison pills'' but that does not make either illegal. . . . Michael Milken's high-yield business prospered long before Drexel ever financed a single hostile takeover. Michael was not in Drexel's mergers and acquisitions department, and did not suggest targets for unsolicited takeovers. In fact, he often recommended against such maneuvers.
DOC.HEAD: NATURE OF HIS OFFENSES
DOC.TEXT: Michael should be sentenced based on the offenses to which he pleaded guilty. He should not be sentenced for crimes that he did not commit. He should not be sentenced on charges for which the government expressly has foregone prosecution in return for his guilty plea. . . . Although inexcusable, Michael's offenses (deletion) were neither venal nor motivated by greed. He did not personally profit by them. They did not involve trading securities on the basis of inside information. Nor did these offenses infect the core of his business. . . . Moreover, the majority of offenses to which Michael pleaded guilty had rarely, if ever, been subject to criminal prosecution at the time of Michael's acts. . . . While Michael aided and abetted in deferring payment of taxes, Michael himself has never improperly deferred or evaded any taxes that he owed. To the contrary, from 1984 through 1988, Michael paid approximately $750 million federal and state income taxes. . . . Michael today recognizes the gravity of his actions. He understands that no one - especiallt someone in a position of leadership and trust - can ever decide that it is permissible to commit acts, no matter what one's motivation may be, that violate the law. Michael Milken is a changed person. He will be tormented for the remainder of his life by the realization that his family was devastated, his reputation destroyed and his life's work tainted by virtue of his having committed these acts.
DOC.HEAD: SENTENCING PROPOSAL
DOC.TEXT: If this court concludes that incarceration is required, we urge that any period of confinement be brief - consistent with the precedents in this district - and that it be served in a halfway house or local facility (deletion). . . . Based on the sentencing principles developed in this district, we propose that Michael Milken be sentenced to work full-time with, and under the direct supervision and control of, the Los Angeles Police Department to develop and participate in specific educational and vocational programs designed to combat the problems of drugs, crime, unemployment and illiteracy threatening to destroy the lives of inner-city youth in Los Angeles. . . . The proposed sentence fully satisfies the goals of punishment and general deterrence. Although the sentence imposed by this court must serve to punish Michael for the crimes to which he has pleaded guilty and must strive to deter others similarly situated from committing these and similar crimes, the goals of sentencing need not always be achieved through incarceration. . . . The retributive purpose of punishment has also been served in this case by Michael's agreement to pay a $200 million criminal fine and establish a $400 million civil settlement fund. Moreover, these unprecedented amounts are not the limit of Michael's economic exposure. His remaining assets are vulnerable to the more than 50 civil lawsuits that already have been commenced against him and others, seeking billions of dollars in damages. Michael may well spend the remainder of this century defending these and future lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: ConAgra Reports Record First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra Inc. reported Tuesday a 16.7 percent increase in earnings in the quarter that ended Aug. 26, boosted by a strong performance from its prepared foods segment. Contributing for the first time to ConAgra's performance were the Beatrice Cos. businesses - Hunt-Wesson, Swift-Eckrich and Beatrice Cheese. ConAgra acquired Beatrice Aug. 14. ConAgra reported net income for the first quarter of fiscal 1991 of $57.17 million, or 45 cents per share, on sales of $4.5 billion. That compared with net income of $48.97 million, or 40 cents per share, on sales of $4 billion for the same period last year. The company realized a $2.1 million gain on nonrecurring items last fiscal year. ConAgra officials said that virtually every one of its operations showed good earnings. Prepared foods, the Omaha-based company's largest segment, had a substantial operating profit. Beef, pork, chicken and turkey products also had profit growth. While unit sales in the consumer frozen food business were up, operating profit was down because of heavier spending on marketing, company officials said. Operating profits in the agri-products segment declined because heavy rains reduced plantings in some areas, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Health Care Corporation To Buy Up to $1 Billion of Its Common Stock
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of Schering-Plough Corp. Tuesday authorized a buyout of up to $1 billion of the company's common stock. Market conditions have made stock in the pharmaceutical and health care company an exceptionally good value, said Robert P. Luciano, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a news release. The company expects to buy the shares on the open market, according to the release. Last year, Schering-Plough completed the sale of its European cosmetic businesses and divested a majority interest in its Brazilian affiliate. Schering stock closed up $3.25 at $44 Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. Its 52-week low was 35|.

DOC.HEAD: DeSoto Plans $35 Dividend, Pension Plan Termination
DOC.TEXT: DeSoto Inc., is asking shareholders to approve a plan to sell off most of the manufacturer's assets and terminate its pension plans in return for a one-time dividend of $35.50 per share. In documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and disclosed Tuesday, DeSoto outlined its list of issues for shareholders to vote on at the company's annual meeting Oct. 24 in Chicago. Among them, Des Plaines, Ill.-based DeSoto wants shareholder approval of a restructuring ``under which the company would sell substantialy all of its businesses'' including its domestic consumer paint business, which has supplied Sears, Roebuck and Co. for 80 years. The company's detergent business would be the only operation retained by DeSoto, which has been battling a hostile takeover by a New York investment group, Sutton Holding Corp. DeSoto estimated that the partial liquidation and restructuring would raise about $222 million before taxes with $85 million earmarked to retire corporate debt. The remainder would go toward paying a special cash dividend of $35.50 per share but DeSoto conceded that there was ``no assurance'' it would be able to pay the cash dividend. It noted that its plan to terminate pension plans and recover some $28 million in excess assets is subject to approval by the Internal Revenue Service and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. the federal agency that guarantees workers pensions much like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. guarantees bank deposits.

DOC.HEAD: One Witness Testifies in Secret, Another Balks at Neil Bush Hearing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 19th graf pvs, `He indicated...,' to UPDATE with Murry's testimony that he would have sought legal advice on loan if he had known details of business relationship between Bush and Good. Pick up 20th graf pvs, `Later...; also moving general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DX1
DOC.TEXT: One witness invoked the Fifth Amendment 14 times and another refused to appear voluntarily as a hearing began Tuesday on conflict-of-interest allegations against Neil Bush, the president's son. Outside, the federal courthouse was surrounded by news media, security officers and protesters. The only thing missing in the savings and loan case was the center of all the attention. Neil Bush, 35, did not show up for the first day of what is anticipated to be a four-day proceeding before Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson. ``He has the option of being here. He only has to be here the day he testifies,'' said Office of Thrift Supervision spokesman Tom Mason. Bush is the last witness, and is expected to testify at the end of the week. The federal Office of Thrift Supervision is trying to bar Bush from the banking and savings industry for his alleged actions as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan, which failed in late 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. At Tuesday's hearing, Michael Wise, Silverado's former board chairman and chief executive officer, invoked his Fifth Amendment right to refuse to answer questions on the grounds that he could incriminate himself. Davidson then allowed him the opportunity to testify in his chambers in order that Wise be ``spared the ordeal of going through a futile gesture of taking the Fifth.'' But a transcript released later in the day showed Wise still refused to answer any of the 14 questions he was asked. Those questions ranged from whether he could identify exhibits to his knowledge of Bush's business ties to two Denver developers who eventually defaulted on Silverado loans exceeding $130 million. Wise also declined to speak with reporters as he left the judge's chambers. Meanwhile, Florian Barth, a former Silverado board member and a Denver car dealer, announced Tuesday he refused to testify voluntarily. The judge said he would sign a subpoena to bring Barth to court if either side requested one. At the end of the day, OTS officials said they hadn't yet requested one. Federal regulators accused Bush last February of violating his duty as a Silverado director from August 1985 to August 1988. The OTS claims Bush may have improperly voted on loans and lines of credit for developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, both of whom contributed to Bush's JNB Exploration oil company. The two defaulted on Silverado loans totaling more than $130 million. Last week, Bush and other former Silverado directors also were sued for $200 million by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The lawsuit alleged that gross negligence on the part of Silverado directors contributed to the S&L's collapse. Bush could have avoided this week's hearing by agreeing not to dispute the charges, as other S&L officials have done. By fighting the government, he has taken the case into a rare public forum. Russell Murray, former Silverado executive vice president, was the first scheduled witness to actually testify Tuesday. He reviewed a 1986 proposal for a $900,000 line of credit for Good International Inc., which wanted to search for oil in Argentina with Bush's JNB as a partner. Murray said he did not recall anyone questioning the no-collateral line of credit even though Good and Bush had a business relationship. He indicated the line of credit was for show only, to impress Argentine officials. Murray said he knew Bush and Good had a business relationship. He said he discussed the request for a line of credit with Bush, Good and Wise, and then wrote a memo to the directors about the relationship before the line of credit was approved. He said he did not have all the details of the relationship and that he would have asked for an opinion from counel if he had had all the facts. Later, J. Donald Wright, chairman of the board of Lakewood Bank and Trust of Dallas, was called by the government as an expert witness to give his opinion of Bush's role in approving $100 million in loans to Walters. Walters had invested $150,000 in Bush's company and his bank gave Bush's company a $1.75 million line of credit. ``Mr. Bush should have disclosed his relationship with Mr. Walters'' when the Silverado board voted on the loans, said Wright. ``He was obligated to Mr. Walters. It would have been difficult to move to defeat Mr. Walters' loan,'' he said. ``Mr. Bush is responsible for that judgment.'' The judge has until Dec. 6 to recommend a ruling to OTS Director Timothy Ryan, who has until April 8 to decide whether to impose the sanctions. Bush could appeal.
